I do recommend this game to a point. Just be prepared for the bullet sponges. It is Far Cry but they hired someone from the Division Team i think to work on this game. You can shoot shit in the face and it take 150 rounds from a M60 to kill it. The head shot boxes on animals do not exist, and on actual enemies apparently a pair of BMX goggles can stop sniper rounds to the head. If it is wearing a Motor cycle helmet holy shit that is better then any bullet proof armour i have ever seen. This is supposed to be a post apocalyptic world with stuff nowhere near as good in the old world and these idiots can take 150 rounds to the face. It is lazy programming to say the least. Now granted i am playing on higher difficulty level so i understand the make it harder by buffing health but it is the realm of stupidity in this game. Just be prepared for the frustration of getting owned because you simply do not have enough ammo to kill everything you need to. Oh and they can see you from across the map behind a mountain as well so be ready to be seen by everyone while you cannot target a enemy unless you are up their assess. They also have enemy levels now as well and you cannot perform take downs on said enemies if you do not have the perk for that unlocked. I made that mistake and got killed for it. Whoever thought that 1 up needs a kick to the balls imo. Other then that its a good story that leads on from Far Cry 5 that was well done i havn't finished it yet but it id good so far. The whole bullet sponge thing and no head shots on animals pissed me off so much i had to write it down to calm me down. :)

Far Cry New Dawn : By Triple F 

"Far Cry New Dawn", released in early 2019, is a gem that often goes unnoticed in the vast sea of open-world games. As a standalone sequel to "Far Cry 5", it managed to carve out its own unique identity in the franchise while retaining the core elements that fans have come to love. In this in-depth review, I'll explore every facet of this captivating post-apocalyptic adventure.

"New Dawn" takes place seventeen years after the catastrophic events of "Far Cry 5", in a world forever changed by nuclear warfare. The story is set in the vividly crafted Hope County, which has undergone a breathtaking transformation from lush countryside to a vibrant, neon-soaked wasteland. The world-building in New Dawn is nothing short of remarkable; each location tells a story of its own, from the verdant beauty of the lush oasis known as Prosperity to the grim, graffiti-covered remains of a once-thriving city.

The narrative follows the player as the Captain, a silent protagonist, aiding a group of survivors in the fight against the ruthless Highwaymen twins, Mickey and Lou. While the plot may seem somewhat formulaic at times, the unique characters and the evolution of Hope County more than make up for it. The interactions between characters are compelling, and the moral ambiguity of some choices keeps players engaged throughout the game.

At its core, "New Dawn" is still unmistakably a Far Cry game, but it introduces several new game-play mechanics that add depth to the experience. The introduction of a tiered weapon system, which uses resources and crafting to upgrade and customize weapons, adds an element of strategy. Scavenging for resources becomes a crucial part of the game, creating a satisfying loop of exploration and combat.

The Expeditions feature is another standout addition, offering players the chance to venture beyond Hope County to exotic locales such as an aircraft carrier or a theme park. These missions break up the open-world exploration, providing fresh challenges and rewarding loot.

The companion system also deserves praise, with unique Guns and Fangs for Hire who bring distinct abilities and personalities to the table. These allies can turn the tide of battle and provide moments of humor and camaraderie.

In terms of visuals, "Far Cry New Dawn" is a visual spectacle. The world brims with vibrant colors, lush vegetation, and stunning post-apocalyptic vistas. The neon-infused aesthetic of the Highwaymen's strongholds contrasts brilliantly with the natural beauty of the surroundings. Dynamic weather and day-night cycles add further depth to the visuals, making the world feel alive.

The soundtrack and sound design are equally impressive. The music sets the tone perfectly, whether it's the serene tunes accompanying exploration or the adrenaline-pumping tracks during intense battles. The ambient sounds of a world reclaiming itself after devastation are immersive, pulling players deeper into the experience.

As usual, "New Dawn" offers substantial replay value. Once the main story is completed, players can continue to explore Hope County, tackling side missions, hunting for collectibles, and engaging in expeditions. The tiered weapon system encourages experimentation, as does the new game+ mode, which allows you to replay the game with your upgraded weapons and abilities.

Multiplayer and co-op modes are also available, adding even more hours of enjoyment. Whether you prefer solo play or teaming up with friends, "New Dawn" always has you covered.

Ultimately, "Far Cry New Dawn" is an often overlooked gem in the Far Cry series. Its captivating post-apocalyptic world, engaging characters, and innovative game-play mechanics make it a worthy successor to "Far Cry 5". The game successfully blends the familiar Far Cry formula with fresh ideas, resulting in an unforgettable experience. While it may not have garnered as much attention as some other titles in the franchise, "Far Cry New Dawn" is a must-play for fans of open-world games and post-apocalyptic settings. Give it a chance, and you'll discover a thrilling and beautifully crafted adventure that's well worth your time.

This game is WAY worse than Far cry 5. Here's why:
Lore: 
-In Far Cry 5, the villan was the Father, the leader of a cult.In order to arrest him, you had to get through his familly, which were unique characters(certain references are taken from the Bibile, which is really cool). This whole ideea was original and well executed. Do you know the name of the villains in Far Cry New Dawn? "THE HIGHWAYMAN".This is something i would expect to hear in lego ninjago, not in a major ubisoft game.Do you know who leads these HIGHWAYMAN?.TWO BLACK TWINS who have less character development then a MCchicken.
-Remember the cool protagonist from FC5, yeah no they buchered him.They turned him into a mindless slave of the Father, who has 0 lines in the whole game and who has no finale to his plot, exept be a part of the new protagonist's roster.
-All the other characters from FC5 serve no purpose here (lore-wise), like pastore Jerome.
Mechanics:
-Fighting:they are the same(not a bad thing, allthough vehicles are not as fun, cuz you can't really fight with them)
-Healing:This is a problem i have encountered. I ran out of medkits, so i wanted to get some.I wanted to craft them, but after searching for 30 min for the ingredient in the middle of the crafting box, i gave up and searched on google.Google told me that i should look for medkits while doing missions, in order to find them that way, but guess what, I ALLREADY DID ALL OF THE MISSIONS.So i was stuck with 0 medkits.
-Objectives:Half of the objectives in this game are to "FIND A WAY INTO THIS BUILDING", with a massive search zone.So that is fun.
Some more bad things that i noticed:
-My sniper riffle does 50% the damage a wood bow does, so that is cool.
-Enemies get 5xlife and 10xdamage increase because they painted their armour? (FR5 had a good explination for this, that being that the cult members were using the bliss).
There are more thing to say about this game, but if i haven't convinced you not to buy this pile of crap by now, then play at your own risk.

i'll admit. i am very biased. but theres 3 reasons why i dont like the game.

TLDR; great for the first half of the game. late game most weapons are useless and stealth becomes a cheesefest. most of the companions are dumb as shit, suicidal, or friendly fire the player. and the villains are infuriating to deal with because of their stupidity and railroading.


1: the weapon scaling and stealth scaling are horrible.
headshots with lower tier weapons still instakill higher level enemies.. but only after you destroy their helmet. which has a set amount of hp and is affected by the tier'd damage penalty if your weapon is underleveled.
as a result if you're using the tier 2 LMG on tier 3 enemies. it ends up being a detriment to try and get headshots. their helmets take somewhere between 10 and 15 shots to destroy. which is about as many as it takes to kill them outright with body shots. helmet shots dont deal any damage. so if you hit a mix of body and headshots it results in your headshots dealing 0 damage. and it just feels horrible.

this isnt a huge issue once you get tier 4 weapons as once you do most of the enemies have a reasonable amount of health and the helmets get destroyed in a few shots. but if you're like me and chain missions together back to back without going back to base to upgrade gear. you'll run into this problem during your playthrough and enemies will feel like they're just invincible to headshots. pair that with higher level enemies dealing enough damage to kill you in a few seconds and it gets pretty annoying.

oh. and dont even attempt to use any of the snipers. tier 3 50.cal sniper gets deflected by tier 2 enemy face masks and takes 3 shots to break tier 3 helmets. i didnt bother testing tier 4 enemies with it.
meanwhile the tier 3 bow can one shot tier 3 enemies with body shots for some fucking reason.

the game also feels like it funnels you into the wrath perk really hard if you dont get tier 4 weapons. since unupgraded punches with wrath can legitimately solo any ground mission in the entire game. as long as you're willing to wait in cover to let it recharge.

2: stealth is fucked late game.
Timber is doodoo at marking enemies. so much so that i've been spotted before he spots enemies more than a few times. Timber's range for marking is relatively small. but the big issue is that it seems to be LoS based outside of a very small radius. so your better off marking the entire camp yourself for stealth. marking loot is great. but thats about all he's good for.
and marking the entire camp yourself doesnt work on max tier compounds, because tier 4 enemies are cloaked for some reason? once you mark them their icon is only visible when you have LOS to their head. if they go behind a wall it fades away. this gets really irritating because they also tend to move around a lot, and sometimes have a dog with them. which makes it hard to take them out silently. theres also the fact that they're more or less immune to headshots from anything that isnt the bow and fucking arrow. (i dont mind the bow being good, i mind the bow being the ONLY good stealth weapon in the entire game and it being SO GOOD that you dont even need to get headshots)
The ghost perk from eden's gift also trivialises all stealth. to the point where you can full sprint through open areas and not get spotted. but since it doesnt apply to the 1 or 2 dogs that are in the max tier camps those dogs will spot you from half way across the map and start chasing you around. making it super wierd to actually use. 
once a dog spots you it will chase you and beep loudly. THIS DOES NOT ALERT THE CAMP, but its enough to freak you out the first time it happens. then when the dog SUICIDE BOMBS near you. the camp investigates the explosion. STILL IN STEALTH.

if no dogs are present; ghost mode is overpowered to the point where you can run from person to person doing takedowns as long as they're not 5 feet away from each other facing each other
if dogs are present; its useless because trying to use it like you've been using it will get you spotted by the dog immediately. and you'll probably have to resort to normal stealth anyway.

3: horatio is the only companion.
everyone else in the roster does fine until you start going to maxed out camps. at which point the only 2 that can do anything without immediately dying are gina and horatio. with gina having massive issues actually finding targets, and getting obliterated by flamethrowers. while horatio can litteraly solo an entire god damn max tier camp by infintiely reviving himself. and as long as YOU dont get spotted they wont sound the alarm and IT COUNTS AS AN UNDETECTED CAPTURE.

i could go on for a little while about the companions individually. but the short version is that everyone else in the roster is either too fragile and dies after getting 2 kills (nana), actively commits suicide or kills YOU on a regular bases (jerome, carmina and timber), or has a really slow AI that feels like its conflicting between staying in stealth and shooting back (gina and judge).
just because the PLAYER goes into stealth mid-fight (usually unintentionally). doesnt mean that the AI should immediately try to enter stealth as well and completely disengage from the fight, without actually leaving the fight. resulting in them just fucking standing there getting shot by an m60. (gina does this the worst, but she has the health to tank it so its kind of fine)
the only AI that doesnt do this stealth conflicting thing is horatio, hence: why he ends up having the most success OFFENSIVELY. dispite being labeled as a the tank.


this last point is just me; i dispise the twins as characters. i'm all for an evil villan. but the twins aren't evil. they feel dumb as hell and cocky as hell and theres nothing else to them. one of them is slightly more sane than the other and thats about it. they remind me of middle school bullies and it legitimately made me angry.

[h1]This game is like if Ubisoft tried to make a Mad Max game, but failed miserably.[/h1]

Let me begin by saying that I played this game completely in coop as I thought it would make for a more fun experience, and [b]oh boy was I wrong.[/b]

Don't get me wrong, me and my friend already played lots of bad games, but this one takes the cake. The experience is so miserable we just couldn't wait for it to finally be over.

Well, I can't really say it's all bad though, the game has one thing going for it, and that's its graphics. They look really nice, very bright, colorful and lively, definitely one of the prettiest in the Far Cry franchise.

However, that's all it really has in its favor, the gameplay is the biggest offender here. Everything has been designed to be as grindy as possible, you need multiple resources to craft pretty much every equipment you need, if that's not bad enough, they also have 3 different levels that you need to upgrade before you can even remotely consider putting a good fight against the enemies. But you can cut down that grind if you are willing to shill out a few bucks for some "Far Cry Credits".

Either way, me and my friend pressed on and grinded out the resources to get our characters a chance to fight, and what do we get for it: a few level 4 weapons that can barely kill the most common enemies and, a bunch of useless skills. [i]yay so much fun.[/i]

Now that I mentioned the enemies, they also have levels and what that means is that they will refuse to die unless you have a weapon of a higher level than them. So if you got a level 3 shotgun you can't effectively kill a level 3 enemy. Sometimes they don't even die with a level 4 weapon that deals 1200 damage (this is the maximum ammount of damage you can get without upgrades by the way).

But even then, you might be wondering: [i]"The story must be good right? it's like a selling point for Far cry games".[/i] Let me tell you that the story is godawful. The two main villains are just annoying, and you don't feel any connection to them like you did to Vaas or any other Far Cry villain.

Anyway, the plot involves you helping to build a base called "Prosperity", at no moment I felt compelled to build this base as it's just another way to force you to grind for useless junk. Moving on, after a while you meet with our old pal Joseph Seed from Far Cry 5, but now you are supposed to feel sad for him. Even though we were trying to kill him in the previous game for being a nut job psychopath, but whatever.

I won't spoil the ending here, because I am sure there is someone out there that really cares about the story. What I will tell you though is to stay the hell away from this sorry excuse of a game. Even if you managed to get a few laughs like we did, it's still not worth the time and money.

[b]Just go ahead and buy a good game instead.[/b]

This is my favorite FarCry game. It has a good balance of story missions and basic outpost missions, and the side weapons actually work! I usually just stick with a primary weapon and a missile launcher, but here there are many considerations, since melee, throwing knife, landmines, disc launcher, etc. are actually useful weapons. I like the ability to replay levels at higher difficulty within the same campaign, and the fishing and hunting mechanics are actually useful.

I see some improvements and addition to the gameplay, but with a story and characters as bland as U2 songs, it is nothing more than a completionist's wet dream. I had no interest in uncovering the next plot point apart from the fact that it would cross another objective off the map. It's the type of game that is best enjoyed in the background with a Discord call as the main experience as there are a ton of objectives to complete and items to collect. If you're into that then this could be for you, but for an engaging story you're better off without. 

The puzzles ("treasure hunts") are quite engaging and fun.

Quick notes as I played:

+Visually impressive; the fauna/flora is dense and beautiful.
+Settlements are fun to conquer, especially so if done undetected.
+Treasure hunts are fun puzzles, akin to climbing towers in earlier Far Cry games.

-Story is boring, characters are bland.

I pretty much like every Far Cry game I've played, and while this one definitely has a lot of problems it's still a great game. Thematically it seems a little confused, because you have the Mad Max thing going on with the highwaymen and the Joseph Smith-style cultist who acts as though he's a religious prophet. The aesthetic is really pleasing, though, particularly the use of deep shades of pink and green alongside a world that is both abandoned and strangely blissful. 

This game has microtransactions which are really unncessary since you don't need to access them to get any of the content, but it's very distracting, particularly if you play on the hardest difficulty. The enemy types are split into "tiers", so you need higher tier weapons to kill higher tier enemies. At first it's confusing, but after the game becomes strangely puzzle-like as you unlock new things in the most efficient order, it becomes a lot of fun. In the second half if you get the better weapons you can pretty much just churn through everything. 

There's 22 story missions and some other side missions. Some are mandatory because you need to upgrade the home base area to progress the story. The expeditions are actually more fun than the story missions. You get dropped off in a helicopter, run to an area to pick up a package, and escape to a set location to be picked up by the helicopter. You also get the obligatory "take over the base" missions, but in this game you have to surrender them to get harder enemies to occupy them to get more ethanol. Ethanol is what you use to upgrade the base and create weapons. You also collect scrap parts, but they're everywhere so you never need to go hunting them down. The crafting system is really quite simplistic. The only thing you need to farm for are these motherboard-looking items but the games gives you them for completing the expeditions so even that doesn't really matter. 

Beyond that you also have perks. You can get points for the perks by completing many optional tasks. There are so many optional tasks that you really don't need to go hunting down the perks. The game gives you way too many points for doing very basic things like freeing citizens that are trapped or hunting certain animals you come across. The open world is actually a lot of fun to explore. There's not really a reason to 100% complete this game since you get everything you need to beat the game by finishing about 75% of the content. 

This game's combat is a lot of fun, and just like the other Far Cry games, there is an emphasis on using stealth to sneak up on enemies to make the fights easier. I really like the parkour aspect. You can grapple up walls, climb ledges, and one of the perks gives you a double jump. Unlocking the right perks early on makes the game a lot easier. There are also a ton of different weapons and it's fun testing them out to find out which ones are the most effective. The saw blade launcher is the most effective weapon against difficult enemies. There's also a stealth pistol that deals exceptional damage.

The game overall is very easy once you know how to play it, but the second-to-last boss fight is very difficult. It took me about a half hour to complete because the AI plays defense and new enemies are constantly being spawned onto the map. It's a bit like Far Cry Primal, where the whole game is easy but the final fight is tough. You also unlock companions who will revive you during some missions. This makes the game way too easy since they will revive you whenever you die, but you die so easily that the game would be way more frustrating if they didn't do this. You can't use them during certain missions, however, so the game still has some very hard parts because of this. 

Overall I really enjoyed this game, but it does feel more like an expansion than a full-fledged Far Cry game. If they would've added in about ten more hours of story content or side missions I'd put it up there with Far Cry 1,2 and Primal as being just plain excellent. I did find the NPCs very annoying, however. At the same time they are some of the most expressive and lifelike NPCs I've seen in a video game so it sort of balances out. The animation and graphics are exquisite, but the audio needed a few additional songs since the game plays the same exact song during every combat sequence.

As much as I loved Farcry 5, Far Cry New Dawn doesn't hit that mark. I recommend skipping this game entirely, even on a sale. Some people say this game is underrated. I can't see how. People also say it's just Farcry 5 DLC and in some ways that is true, but I don't think that's why it's bad.

Farcry New Dawn "reuses" the Farcry 5 map. However, in practice it's so hard to tell. They changed the map so much you would never know unless someone told you or you look really closely. The map 'feels' completely different. Although Farcry new Dawn is a direct sequel to Farcry 5 so when it comes to the theme, it makes sense. The game isn't priced the same as Farcry 5. It's clearly a spin-off Farcry game rather than a mainline entry and it has quite a lot of content. The problem isn't a LACK of content, but the content itself.

The quests and missions are VERY boring. It feels like they took a lot of player freedom away in how you approach missions. I couldn't even bear finishing this game, I never even really got past the first real section of the game.

The boss fights are just mag dump bullet sponges and that's it. It's boring and not fun. The leveling system is horrible. Gathering materials to upgrade my base was so tedious and boring. If you thought the story would be this game's saving grace, think again. The villains are laughable, even if you didn't compare them to previous Farcry villains.

All in all, there's nothing here to really enjoy. It's clear that Ubisoft experimented with a lot of new ideas for this game. Unfortunately, they were bad ideas, as is typical Ubisoft fashion

[h1] Far Cry New Dawn [/h1]

Far Cry New Dawn is a standalone sequel to Far Cry 5, released in 2019. It takes place in the same fictional Hope County, Montana, but years after the events of Far Cry 5. Here are some key aspects of Far Cry New Dawn:

1. [b]Post-Apocalyptic Setting:[/b] Far Cry New Dawn is set in a post-apocalyptic version of Hope County after a nuclear catastrophe known as "the Collapse." The game features a vibrant and colorful environment, contrasting the traditional grim and desolate post-apocalyptic landscapes.

2. [b]Continuation of Far Cry 5's Story:[/b] The game continues the narrative of Far Cry 5, exploring the aftermath of the nuclear event and its impact on the world. Players encounter both new and returning characters from the previous game.

3. [b]Twin Villains:[/b] The antagonists in Far Cry New Dawn are Mickey and Lou, twin sisters who lead a group known as the Highwaymen. They are ruthless and unpredictable, providing a new dynamic to the series' tradition of memorable villains.

4. [b]RPG Elements and Expeditions:[/b] Far Cry New Dawn introduces RPG elements, allowing players to upgrade their character and weapons through a progression system. The game also features a new "Expeditions" mode, where players can leave Hope County to explore other locations and complete missions.

5. [b]Survival Mechanics:[/b] Players must manage resources, such as ethanol, to upgrade their home base and unlock new abilities. The introduction of a home base, called Prosperity, adds a strategic element to the gameplay.

6. [b]Guns and Vehicles:[/b] The game includes a variety of makeshift weapons and vehicles crafted from salvaged materials, reflecting the post-apocalyptic theme. These weapons and vehicles bring a unique aesthetic to the Far Cry series.

7. [b]Open-World Exploration:[/b] Like its predecessors, Far Cry New Dawn features an open-world environment with various activities and side missions. Players can explore the map, liberate outposts, and engage in dynamic encounters with both human enemies and mutated wildlife.

8. [b]Cooperative Gameplay:[/b] The game supports cooperative multiplayer, allowing players to team up with a friend to tackle the challenges of the post-apocalyptic world together.

While Far Cry New Dawn received positive reviews for its visuals, gameplay mechanics, and continuation of the Far Cry 5 story, some criticized it for recycling elements from its predecessor. However, if you enjoyed Far Cry 5 and are interested in exploring the aftermath of its story in a post-apocalyptic setting, Far Cry New Dawn might be worth checking out.

I really loved Far Cry New Dawn. And I couldn't say exactly why, but it was significantly better than Far Cry 5. For me, New Dawn was one of the best titles of the series.

The world of Hope County is colourful, neon, crazy but just beautiful. The scenery is gorgeous to look at and I found myself just enjoying the view of the world again and again.

The gameplay is incredibly fun in co-op. It's definitely nothing new, but typical Far Cry Gameplay: You fight your way through the world, conquer outposts, kill masses of enemies and what was particularly great here was the four-level system. Enemies, weapons and vehicles are divided into 4 levels. Killing golden enemies with level 1 weapons is therefore almost impossible. Many players didn't like this. But I thought it was kind of good. Because your character only feels really badass once you unlocked the golden weapons. The whole thing lends the game a certain uphill climb that lasts until the end. The skill tree is also very good (not too much, not too little) and the abilities you get at the end are a nice add-on.

The story is short, but interestingly long enough. There is little blah blah and more boom boom.

I also thought it was great that John Seed comes back in this sequel to Far Cry 5! Well integrated and with his own little story.

The map is a decent size and the fact that there are so many fast travel points makes the game very enjoyable. You don't spend hours travelling around like in other games in the series.

To summarise: A really great game and definitely worth the money in my opinion.

This is my first Far Cry game and I can't wait to play more of them. I can't believe I've waited this long to try this series because I love the gameplay. It also has graphics and the game runs super well. 

The controls, especially on a controller, are super intuitive and it was a really easy game to learn. There's definitely strategies to learn with stealth or going for certain objectives, but it's pretty forgiving if you mess up a mission or die. You're not punished by losing resources or set back super far. It's nice to have a shooter game that balances being challenging and fun well.

Only issue with the leveling system is that high level animals just absolutely wreck you left and right until you get better weapons. It really make exploring in the early game pointless because you spend too much time trying to run away from bears, monstrous buffalos, etc.

I find myself disappointed with this installment, which appears to fall short of expectations. There is a sentiment that this content could have been better suited as downloadable content (DLC) rather than a standalone game. The attempt to differentiate itself from Far Cry 5 while using the same foundation seems to have resulted in a less favorable outcome.

While I approached the game with an open mind, I encountered notable disparities in mechanics when compared to Far Cry 5. Certain restrictions and what seem to be artificial difficulty enhancements, such as inflated enemy levels, were particularly off-putting. Additionally, the absence of features like the arcade and editor, which were enjoyed in previous Far Cry games, was a noticeable omission.

The reload timing proved to be noticeably slow, and character progression felt less in-depth with limited perks. The requirement to purchase base perks before engaging in certain activities, turning the game into what feels like a puzzle, was an unexpected and less enjoyable aspect. It's essential to note that the known controller issue during driving or flying, present in Far Cry 5, remains unaddressed.

In essence, the experience with this installment can be likened to a 'Lite Version' of Far Cry 5, lacking some of the positive elements. My suggestion would be to forego this and instead explore more of Far Cry 5's custom maps for a more satisfying gaming experience.

I recently dove into the captivating world of Far Cry New Dawn, and I must say, it exceeded all my expectations. This post-apocalyptic installment in the Far Cry series is nothing short of a visual and narrative masterpiece.

The first thing that struck me was the breathtakingly vibrant and unique setting. The game's portrayal of a world recovering from a nuclear catastrophe is both haunting and beautiful. The landscape is filled with stunning hues of pink and purple, creating a surreal atmosphere that kept me mesmerized throughout my entire playthrough.

Gameplay-wise, Far Cry New Dawn offers a seamless blend of intense action and strategic thinking. The introduction of makeshift weapons and vehicles adds a refreshing twist to the familiar Far Cry formula. The Expeditions, in particular, are a brilliant addition, offering diverse environments and challenges beyond the main map.

The characters in the game are memorable and well-developed, each contributing to the overall narrative in their own distinct way. The bond between the player character and the supporting cast adds an emotional layer to the story, making every mission feel personal and impactful.

The game's soundtrack deserves special mention. It perfectly complements the on-screen action, enhancing the overall experience. Whether I was engaged in a fierce firefight or exploring the vast open world, the music added an extra layer of immersion.

Far Cry New Dawn's attention to detail is commendable. From the dynamic weather system to the realistic animal behavior, every aspect of the game world feels meticulously crafted. The result is a game that not only looks stunning but also feels alive and responsive to the player's actions.

In conclusion, Far Cry New Dawn is a triumph in the post-apocalyptic gaming genre. It successfully builds upon the strengths of its predecessors while introducing new elements that keep the experience fresh and exciting. If you're a fan of open-world shooters with a rich narrative and breathtaking visuals, this game is an absolute must-play!

When this game came out I didn't understand why people had a negative opinion about it. Now, after several dozen hours and several years, I finally see what the problems are. It irritates me that Ubisoft chose such interesting worlds to present. The colorful post-apocalyptic world is original and very rare. I can't name more than three games with a similar setting. I like the colors, collecting scrap, loot, but this game is just stupid. A cool idea made without any input. I may be wrong, but there is no sign of any will to do something big here, and there was potential for it. I love the Far Cry series, so it's hard for me to say negative things about these games. The game is not completely prepared for co-op play. The missions get spoiled and are boring, lackluster and undemanding. Poorly done grinding system. The weapon level system is stupid, I don't know who thought it was a good idea. The weapons are already prepared, the silencer, magazine or scope cannot be changed. Literally no casumization, I played with a person who doesn't like weapon skins and that can't be changed either. The silent protagonist. There are a lot of things I like here, for example expanding the base, bringing people to help in the fight, but these people have no soul. If it was like in Dragon Age or Metro, it would be phenomenal. As I said earlier, the pink and purple world after the bomb explosion is beautiful and interesting, but what if the locations don't present anything of themselves? It's nice to walk through the ruined lands from the fifth installment, but if the locations were as plot-driven as in The Witcher, it would make sense. The antagonists are irritating and stupid, maybe because they are women. Fighting these two bitches is tragically embarrassing. And that touching scene at the end, all I want to do is puke. There is a tragedy in the plot, and although it usually turns out positively when someone takes drugs and does some work. Here someone took the wrong drugs and made up shit. And back to Coop, only the host can talk to NPCs and improve the base. When playing as the latter, you have no plot or contact with the characters. The problem with reviews on Steam is that you can only choose that it was great or not great, so the option of descriptive reviews is useful. The game is average, and according to Metacritica one of the worst parts of the series. I used to think that each part was equal, now, after experiencing each of them several times, I conclude that FAR CRY 6 and FAR CRY 3 are the best games in the series. Far Cry needs a rebuild, a phenomenal plot, world and characters to return to absolute heights. It won't be easy, but I would love to see a slightly more serious part with plot dilemmas, a lively and interesting protagonist and antagonist, a full and diverse list of weapons and their parts. Additionally, more different takedown animations. I know that Far Cry is a fun game, we kill our opponents by exploding them and their vehicles. And it would be best to take the best aspects of each Far Cry part and combine them into one game. The Far Cry series needs love and passion, new ideas and a clear plan for itself. Less crocodiles in T-shirts, more showing guerrilla warfare. Far Cry 6 was close, but not there yet. Overall, this sequel and FAR CRY PRIMAL had the potential to be something positive. It turned out bad, the only thing you can see is that Ubisoft wanted to fix the mistakes and FAR CRY 6 already looks very good. To sum up, the game is average, you can have fun with it, but it is also irritating and strange.

So I just finished this game clocking in around a dozen hours. And I gotta say, I liked this one a lot. It is flawed and has some classic Ubisoft problems but overall it is better than the reviews make it out to be.


So what is this game about? Well it plays years after the events of Far Cry 5. You play some random dude or dudedette (your choice). You are on a train and supposed to help rebuild the country with some other people when shit goes south. You get introduced to "The Twins", the villains of this story and after a tutorial mission you get set out into the world.

First let me talk about the tone of the game. I know a lot of people didnt like this change but I personally enjoyed the more silly approach that this game takes. This tone is not only reflected in the charakters and world but also in the mechanics. I havent played many Far Cry games but I personally think this silliness works pretty well and I wish they would embrace that more often in future Far Cry games.

Gameplay was where New Dawn really shined for me. It's an FPS with an open world. You got weapons, vehicles, companions and perks to unlock. You do most of that by either spending ressources or doing missions. The gunplay is fine and the vehicles have that Ubisoft jank to it. But it overall works prerry good. Now there is one thing I REALLY liked and I wished the game had embraced even [b]more:[/b] [spoiler] You can get... "super powers". I dont know how else to call them. Half way through the game you unlock a certain power that lets you double jump, get a rage mode and other stuff. And I thought that was really cool and fun to use! [/spoiler]

Now the visuals are pretty neat aswell. I like the heavy use of neon-pink mixed in this post apocalyptic setting. It looked very appealing to me. And while there are a lot of copy pasted buildings, the stuff that is unique looks really cool.

In terms of audio I dont have much to say. There are a couple radio tracks to unlock, voice acting is mostly fine and the guns are... well... ok-ish. They lack punch. But they dont sound too horrible. So nothing to write home about really.

For the story... well. Thats a difficult one. It is overall... ok. You can smell the plot miles away and there are some things that I thought were plain stupid. Most of the charakters are also just... ok aswell. Except for a few they were mostly forgettable. 
And I think the weakest part by far are the villains. The Twins. Essentially two sisters with daddy issues. They dont really do much of anything, except showing up to shittalk you and then leave... And their final mission is a bulletsponge slog and just annoying. 
Also the ending was kinda weird and stupid... [b] BEWARE SPOILERS FOR FAR CRY 5 AND NEW DAWN! [/b]: [spoiler]I dont get Joseph Seed's arc... like how... after being responsable for the nuclear destruction of the entire world... it takes the death of his spoiled and power hungry son to realized that maybe, just maybe his views are flawed? And that he might have misinterpreted the "voice of god" wrong??? Are you fucking kidding me???[/spoiler]

Overall though the game is pretty cool. I had a lot of fun with it except for the last two missions (2 very bad boss fights). Sure the game has a lot of Ubisoft issues. It is, after all, a DLC for Far Cry 5 being sold as a standalone game. And it shows.  There are a lot of copy & paste environments and missions, micro transactions and the way they did difficulty is... odd... to say the least. Also there are no achievements, which is a shame. [b]BUT[/b] despite all that I still had a lot of fun! Mindless run and gun fun. But still, a lot of fun!

[b]Verdict:[/b]
I bought the game on sale for 11‚Ç¨ bucks and I think I got my fair share of fun with it. If you are looking for a loose and fun FPS (maybe in between some serious story heavy games as some change) to turn your mind off and enjoy some stupid shenanigans? Well, then look no further. Just make sure to buy it only on sale. Because 45‚Ç¨ is way too expensive.


[i] If you've made it this far then thanks for reading!
I hope you have a fantastic day!
Cheers![/i]

Far Cry New Dawn is one of the worst Far Cry games ever made. Probably the worst after Far Cry 6. I recommend skipping this game entirely, even on a sale. Some people say this game is underrated. I can't see how. People also say it's just FC5 DLC. In a way that is true, but I don't think that's why it's bad. Let me explain.

To address the FC5 DLC stuff. Yes, FCND "reuses" the FC5 map. However, in practice it's so hard to tell. They changed the map so much you would never know unless someone told you or you look really closely. The map 'feels' completely different. Also FCND is a direct sequel to FC5 so thematically it makes sense. The game isn't priced the same as FC5. It's clearly a spin-off FC game rather than a mainline entry and it has quite a lot of content. The problem isn't a lack of content, but the content itself.

The quests and missions are very boring. It feels like they took a lot of player freedom away in how you approach missions. Part of the problem is the RPGification of the game. There are tiers of enemies and weapons. Trying to use a Tier 1 weapon on a Tier 4 enemy would basically be impossible. The game tries to add railroads to the open world by placing harder enemies where they don't want you to go until you unlock higher tiers of weapons.

At least, that's how they wanted it to work. FCND retains the one-hit-kill to the head of other FC games. If you have AP rounds you can one-shot every enemy except animals and bosses. This makes the best gun in the game a silenced pistol which isn't even the highest tier. This makes weapon variety nonexistent. On top of this the enemies are very stupid. They feel even dumber than FC5 enemies. I don't think this is actually the case, but due to how much health they have they can survive things they shouldn't be able to which in many cases breaks the AI.

The boss fights are just pure mag dump bullet sponges. Boring and very unfun. The leveling system is horrible. Gathering materials to upgrade my base was so tedious and boring. If you thought the story would be this game's saving grace, think again. The villains are laughable, even if you didn't compare them to previous FC villains.

All in all, there's nothing here to really enjoy. It's clear that Ubisoft experimented with a lot of new ideas for this game. Unfortunately, they were bad ideas.

If Far Cry 5 was the black sheep of the franchise, Far Cry New Dawn is the redheaded step-child. I've seen a lot of complaints about the changes New Dawn makes to the Far Cry formula, including the RPG elements sprinkled in. Here's an overview:

Some of the base gameplay systems have gotten an overhaul. Outposts can now be scavenged to allow enemies to take them back, which then allows you to attempt to retake them at a higher difficulty. Weapons now also have an explicit rank, indicating which corresponding enemy ranks they are effective against. For example, a level 3 AK-47 will shred through any level 3 or below enemies, but a level 2 AK will give you a harder time. I've seen some complaints about these RPG-ification elements, and while personally I dont mind, if you do care about them, it might be worth your time to think carefully about picking this game up.
Personally I think the changes are fine. Retaking the outposts can be annoying since you can't discern the alarm towers ahead of time, and Ethanol is probably too scarce, but I managed to get the most important upgrades before taking on the final bosses. There were only a couple times where I needed to go scavenge items to craft a weapon I felt I needed.

The story is a bit hit or miss. The antagonists aren't particularly charming, and I feel like the previous game presented the taunts from the antagonists better. It also feels like the 4 of Far Cry 5 are better fleshed out than personality and lore-wise than New Dawn's twins. I sincerely cannot tell the two apart.

Additionally, the game plays upon the assumptions you had from the previous game. You're sat there listening to the story and at some point are presented the following thesis: What if Joseph Seed was right all along? You already get a sense of that at the end of Far Cry 5, but here it really challenges your notion of wrong and right, and if the ends justify the means. What is God's plan, actually? Was it good to have mowed down Joseph's siblings in the previous game? Do the ends justify the means? There are interesting questions here, and no clear answers.

The environments are just as beautiful as before, with some pinks and purples sprinkled about to spice things up. Clearly the environment team worked hard on this version of Hope County, even if it feels like they stopped talking to the environment team for Far Cry 5 about halfway through development.

The Guns for Hire mechanic returns, although you can no longer have two at a time. The roster is well balanced, and I didn't feel like I wish I had a companion from Far Cry 5. I did however, have an issue with one of the missions to recruit a GFH.

One of the worst missions I've ever played has to be the mission to recruit Gina: "Mo' Mommies Mo' Problems". An absolute nightmare of RNG hoping that she and the AI enemies don't ram into random explosive barrels, failing the mission. Just awful, took me legitimately 20 tries to kill all the enemies before Gina's car randomly explodes. Including the time the mission bugged out after killing all the enemies and just soft locked itself. Very frustrating, but luckily this is optional, and the only mission I really had a problem with throughout the game.

Another thing to mention are the map changes. Not sure entirely, but the map feels smaller than in Far Cry 5. The outpost count is significantly reduced, and a good portion of the map (The North) goes unused except for in 2 missions. This is explained away in the story as the dam having burst during the collapse, flooding the surrounding lowlands. In addition to that, the area is covered in Bliss, making passage impossible except for a select few.

The music selection is... fine. Nothing too special, a couple oldie hits here and there, with some odd choices from the late 2010's added for good measure.

Overall the game is fine. It serves as a good followup to Far Cry 5, and thematically feels more like a less buggy Fallout game than it does a Far Cry game. Is it worth the face value of $40? Hard to say, I'm sure I've paid more for worse. Is it worth picking up on sale? If you're a fan of Far Cry, definitely. If you're disappointed with Fallout 76, this is a good post-apocalyptic alternative. For everyone else, I understand if you chose to skip this one, but I definitely think it's worth a playthrough. I powered through in only 17 hours and had fun, for the most part.

Genre: open world, anti-human, first person shooter

Difficulty: Childs play (1/5)
Gameplay: 3/10
Gunplay: 3/10
Content rating: Not Safe For Life (5/5)
Overall score: Trash 2/10

 A downgrade of Far Cry 5, full of political messages (female supremacy, misandry, anti-Christian, anti-human...). 

 The trademark Far Cry gameplay is still there, but the downgrade with weapon and enemy levels alone takes away from the game. If you take this into account weapon selection is probably the worst in any other Far Cry game that I‚Äôve played so far. Despite its strong anti-Christian message, Far Cry 5 was still massively better in terms of gameplay.

 As with the other Far Cry games, the story is short and terrible (high school project level). In fact New Dawn seems to have the shortest and worst story so far (compared to FC 2, 3, 5 and primal). The nice upgrade system for weapons from Far Cry 5 has been removed and instead we have mostly butt ugly weapons made of junk that we can't customize, only upgrade their damage. There's also some level system where lower level weapons are handicapped against higher level enemies. With enough resources you can upgrade weapons to have whatever damage you want, apparently. I've upgraded a bow with 1200 damage points to 3000 and killed almost anything with one shot... 

 I don't have many words for the story as it made me cringe so hard I had to reset my face with a hammer. To add to it, there are obvious political comments and gameplay elements relating to real world politics and ideologies. I don't want real life politics in a game that is not about politics. Even if uplay (ubistoft launcher for their games) wasn't as bad as it is (an update of uplay deleted my Far Cry 5 saves), this game has left me with such a bad taste that I am not even considering buying Far Cry 6, or any other ubisoft game, ever again.

- game has a strong anti-Christian messaging

This game has a lot of good and a lot of bad. Don't truly know how to feel about it....

On one hand running around the world exploring things is pretty fun, the gun play feels fine, and overall I do think it's enjoyable both alone or with friends. Definitely a better experience with friends though because the friendly A.I. that can accompany you are pretty on the slow side. Also it looks good overall, I never had something out of the ordinary or a texture glitch through my whole play time so I'll take it. Nearing the end you also get some fun things that make the game extremely enjoyable so take that for what you will. 

Also being able to fish from the shore line and watching my pet dog rip a guy's throat out on the other-side of the river is a big positive, Love Timber and Nana, good A.I. friends. Hurks almost there but I swear they gave him the least brain cells because it's Hurk so he's definitely on some spectrum. 

Also I promise blowing people up mid cut scene may be the funniest thing I've seen in quite some time, this game cannot process that properly so it may break the game entirely, be careful. 

On the other hand grappling is still broken, your companions are almost worthless a lot of the time alone, and when you finally get around to finishing the story it's nothing remarkable. Villains seen before, stories already told, and really meh melo drama nearing the end will turn ya off from the main story. I've played it before on Xbox with another friend and the story really leaves you with nothing. Also repeating outposts is kinda lazy design so they wouldn't have to make any more, gotta play each one three times? So you put a marker of 30 outposts that need to be done? Lazy. Just like reusing the same map from far cry 5. It may be cool exploring key sections of the previous games areas after the bombs fall but uh, it's also lazy too bub sorry. 

Also asides from the licensed music used for certain mission segments throughout the game, the radio's gonna have a bunch of this weird techno crap? It sure fits with the highwaymen since they're a bunch of buffoons anyways but having to listen to it's gonna get old fast. Music may be subjective, but this stuff is crap. Bring back the 80's please I was born in the wrong musical era....

This games, weird....rating it feels wrong because it feels like a perfect middle of the road game that gets really fun when your not playing the main story. Just, a game that exists if you will. If I could pick a middle option I would but because I feel the game does enough good to not be worthless it's a thumbs up.

If you want a score 6/10. "Blowing things up is good, but your gonna need something more eventually"

Let me start by saying this is the first Far Cry game that I have ever played. I caught it on a Black Friday sale and bought it after having looked at it a few times before. Honestly what grabbed my attention was the graphics with all the bright colors and the post apocalyptic look the game gave off. I have to be honest as well that first person shooter games aren't really my forte because I really suck at the whole run and gun ordeal. However it did offer quite a few times in the game where I was able to scope out an area and make my plan of attack which this I was able to excel in far more easily. There are parts of the game where it involves some problem solving skills and you to complete some puzzles to complete a task which I loved this part of the game.

 There are some great guns for hire that make going on some of the missions far more easier. Gina in my opinion really gets MVP in this department, Timber easily takes MVP in the treasure hunt department. After maxing out all of Timber's skills by gaining his 40 kills Timber is able to tag and highlight where the treasure locations are which makes it super easy to find and collect everything! Horatio is quite a force to be reckoned with when heat really starts surrounding you from enemy attacks. His fury skill makes him a total tank and being able to revive himself as well is another amazing perk that is very handy. Carmina is great starting as someone to start out with and honestly I found myself sticking with her until I managed to get Gina. Pastor Jerome is okay but until he manages to unlock all 3 of his skill perks isn't the greatest to take with you when you are liberating an outpost, Carmina is a much better choice until unlocking Gina. Even after getting all of Pastor Jerome's skills unlocked I still didn't find myself using him really that often. I'm sure Granny probably would have been a good gun for hire as well but sadly she was the only one I was unable to unlock because I was unable to complete the sharp shooter test in the allocated time. All in all I was able to complete the game in about 80 hours (of course this was taking my time, doing tons of exploring, fishing, collecting all of the treasure, the only thing I didn't finish was the getting granny, and all of the expeditions along with  maxing all of the facilities, collecting all of the photographs and tape players) with my guns for hire only being level 3. All of the side missions, main missions, and treasure quests were completed. 

From a non biased standpoint I don't see why this game gets as much hate as it does. The graphics and colors are beautiful, the game in my opinion was truly a lot of fun. There were plenty of interesting characters in the game, and being a x box controller user on my pc I can say that the controls were very easy to learn and use. I only had a couple times where the sound of my game would start to lag with kind of a skip but this was quickly resolved with a simple restart of my computer and the game. I'm not sure if the issues stemmed from the game itself as I had no sound quality issues running anything else from my pc or if it was from my pc...either way it was a pretty quick and simple fix. 

I would definitely recommend this game if you're someone that is into story based games, first person shooter, open world, exploration, or even just post apocalyptic settings. From the gathering of my knowledge while playing this game playing this is evidently a sequel to Far Cry 5 so I would probably play that game first. However this is also still enjoyable even on its own.

100% in less than 20h? Yeah, get this game at a discount.

Gameplay-wise it's the most pleasant and addictive Far Cry I've played, I sat and played these 20h throughout 3 days. Yet, I understand why it got so much hate on a release.
The map is small and mostly recycled from Far Cry 5 which is a prequel to this title. There are even Joseph Seed and Eden followers in New Dawn.
The twin sisters are good antagonists although cliche as f*ck, but every time they appear on a screen some interesting things happen.
I liked the RPG-ish system implemented here. Enemies can be on four different levels of difficulty and you won't do much to them If your weapon is underleveled. On the other hand If you already obtained super powerful weapons the enemies on lower levels are laughably easy to bear.
Some people may say this system is unnecessary, but I personally really liked that possibility to gear yourself as fat as possible and feel like a super fast killing machine.
There is just a tiny bit of grinding to achieve this, but the gameplay - as said above - is very pleasant, so conquering outposts or participating in events that get you resources was actually delightful.

Ah... and the world completely doesn't feel like post-apo. They have everything, clothes, weapons, cars, food, water, electricity is running everywhere. A few mutated animals and ruins don't do much to the overall narrative.

Far Cry New Dawn is a short, but well packed piece of a game. Story and gameplay are very easy going. Crafting better equipment and gathering stuff to upgrade our base makes it addictive. I recommend this title to everyone who enjoyed previous Far Cry games.

Too much Far Cry. Not enough Far Cry.

If you're like me and just consider the new Far Cry game to be like the new version of FIFA: the same game you've always liked with just a few tweaks, then you'll be right at home. If you're hoping that there will be another major leap like 1 to 2, or 2 to 3, you'll be disappointed. This is basically another incremental change to FC3. The shooting feels good. Being the apex predator feels awesome. The tacked on RPG mechanics suck. The villains aren't terrible, but their presentation and the story sucks. Further degraded by the fact that the game constantly forces you to give up your weapons, watch terrible things play out to your friends, then get captured/beat up in first-person cutscenes, knowing full well you'd be more than capable of ending the game's conflict in the first 30 minutes if the game would just give you control.

But cobbling together improvised post-apocalyptic weapons, setting traps, and tearing through unsuspecting bandits is rad as hell. I also really dig the aesthetic. Just hanging out in the world is fun. Seeing how the characters have progressed since FC5 is also pretty cool (other than one major spoilery thing that kinda retroactively ruins FC5).

Chances are, you already know if you like this game. If you've gotten bored with Far Cry, this is not gonna change your mind. If you're still having fun with the formula and just want a new map with new weapons, you'll have a good time.

100 Hours, this game is bad. Don't buy this full price. It's really good DLC for Far Cry 5 that grew legs. They switched to this really weird leveled combat system which, just sucks, all the enemies have levels 1 to 3 and Elites. And they have hitpoint bars like in Borderlands.

These levels are also reflected on the weapons. If the gun play is going to be crappy like in Far Cry 5 I at least want to use my favorite gun that looks the coolest. In New Dawn you cannot have that. In Far Cry 5 I stomached the gun play cause I could use whatever gun I wanted to, and could customize it with my silly little skins and attachments how I wanted it and it didn't matter cause all the enemies die in a single head shot. 

Not the case this time around, in New Dawn the main difference between the levels of the enemies is it gets harder to hit them in the head, Level 1's have no head protection, Level 2's have a face shield, and level 3's have a full helmet so just can't tap them in the head anymore. Level 1 weapons do PATHETIC damage to Level 2 enemies, and vis versa level 2 to 3. Not all guns can be each level, so I can no longer use the guns I liked using in Far Cry 5 in the end game of New Dawn because they're not Level 3.

Why this game even bothered making "crafting" your weapons a selling point, because you really don't craft your weapons you basically just buy them for resources, they're ugly, even from a post-apocalyptic design prospective. A screwdriver as a bayonet? You SERIOUSLY couldn't find a knife??? You cannot change the weapons attachments or anything about them besides upgrading them with resources to be more powerful. 

And no you cannot make a weapon that is level 2 good against level 3 enemies, you CAN infinitely upgrade a weapon but the sheer resource and time investment to make your level 2 weapon good against level 3 enemies just isn't worth it.. 

The Expeditions were cool, loved them, they're unique and probably the freshest breath of air from this game. 

If this game had the weapon customization and gun play from Far Cry 5 I probably wouldn't hate it. But why they chose this weird borderlands style for this game was just confusing and it feels like they seriously stripped away a lot of the individuality from you the player. Also not to mention the story itself, it's weird and doesn't make a lot of sense that Eden's Gate decided to become cavemen, and now are good guys, and all the magic ooga booga stuff. I feel like it could have been written and designed better, but beauty is in the eye of the beholder in that regard.

The game reuses the map and is basically made out of Far Cry 5 assets, I have even found props floating around they forgot to delete when editing the Far Cry 5 map. (Which in this game is like 1 third smaller). I personally don't mind a recycled sequel.

I don't mind a recycled game if it does a good job closing it's predecessor. But it just feels like they removed so much, from quality of life to content from Far Cry 5 that it's like, why was this even a game and not just DLC for Far Cry 5...

Look, I have played several of the FarCry games in the series. This one seems to be the worst. I care for zero characters, I skip all the cutscenes, I was playing with a mate to share the burden of the horrible antagonists and bland gameplay.

This Farcry game makes me want to actually cry at how poorly created it is. Poor story, and on a technical level (the programming etc.) is also very poorly done. I think the worst example of poorly implemented RPG elements is putting a full magazine from a lvl 1 LMG into a static (buggy) lvl 3 enemy and not having them drop -  that's nearly 50 rounds. I had a Wolverine take an entire mag from a Kriss Vector. I can only suspend belief so much. How many direct hits from an RPG does it take to drop a human? If you think one, then you're in for a shocking surprise!

Farcry is a well established trope by now & much like Blood Dragon which outshone its main title, New Dawn is here for players who want to squeeze a bit more of the old reliable, free form mass murder/ driving sim from the far cry 5 engine. 

The gun play and vehicular interaction are both satisfying & combat is challenging enough on hardest difficulty to still feel rewarding. The engine is stable & runs fine with very few bugs. The usual hilarious npc routing, dialogue & physics abound.

I am incredibly disappointed however that main questline has the player bash several dogs to death in order to progress the story. Dogs in the overworld can be dealt with at the players discretion, but for this quest its beat down these doggos or the story stops dead. Highly tone deaf of Ubisoft, no surprises there really. This cowardly roleplay rests squarely on the heads of the project leads.

The exact same issue is present in the arena questline.

Ubisoft clearly hate dogs & should expect a visit from John Wick at his convenience

I'd recommend it, but almost exclusively when it's on sale. It is priced lower than FC5 for a reason, as it's basically a tasty dessert after the five course meal that was FC5. Same map with different locations and a fresh coat of (literal) paint. Recurring characters, including everyone's favorite cult leader Joseph Seed (as seen in the trailer). The twins are pretty brutal and can be annoying at times, but they're nowhere near the abomination that was the Borderlands 3 antagonists.

It's still a good game though, and I've got no hate for it -- but I also had a pretty good idea what to expect -- so set your expectations below FC5 and just have fun with it. Also, Gina is an absolute beast and can solo-clear outposts if you're a pet class person like I am.

[h1]The good[/h1]
- Resource collection, crafting, upgrades & progression system feel the best of any Far Cry game so far. Gathering resources actually feels like a useful activity, and you can keep upgrading your character perks and guns, seemingly forever
- An upgradeable homebase is always a good idea. It was a throwback to Far Cry 4 and Far Cry Primal 
- Expeditions are a very fun new type of mode. I really enjoyed these, and the gameplay is much better than the regular overworld outposts. I only didn't like not being able to run 3 star difficulty straight away. It felt a bit boring to HAVE to play the lower difficulties first
- It's cool visiting locations and characters from FC5 and seeing all the changes. This game should probably have been a FC5 expansion
- Amazing Graphics
- Amazing Sound Design
- Similar to FC5, very great gunplay
- There's automatic health regen now. Much appreciated
- The lore pages. They're probably not as appreciated as they should be. They always tell interesting stories or give you useful hints, often related to environmental storytelling, enemies, or some gameplay mechanic present right there. As a dev myself I was inspired reading these.

[h1]The meh[/h1]
- Weird Microtransactions. They didn't need to be in this game, it makes it all feel like a mobile title. At least they are optional and not too intrusive
- No Far Cry arcade. It wasn't expected, but would have been nice
- Ability to play coop, but no matchmaking. Feels a bit useless.

[h1]The bad[/h1]
- The villains are horribly written. They're boring. They're not interesting. They're barely present. They're not memorable. It's a shame because every Far Cry game prior to this had villains ranging from at least somewhat interesting to just incredible.
- Unlike FC5 there is no weapon attachment or weapon skin system. I missed it.
- Outposts are incredibly boring compared to FC5, and just like the expeditions require you to grind through lower difficulties before getting to the higher ones. Once you do play higher level outposts, the enemies are on ridiculous alertness levels, with the entire camp being alerted instantly even by your silenced shot from 10km away. I did manage to 3 star everything, but it was just plain annoying and incongruent with the rest of the game to have these outrageous AI pawn perceptions, and a mandatory low difficulty playthrough grind to go through.
- No quest unlocks after freeing outposts. Barely any dialogue variety or dialogue progression throughout all of the game. It's a step down from FC5. I'd say there are even very few quests in this game in general
- Just as the Living World activities seemed to have dialed back a bit on FC5, on this game they went back in the wrong direction. There's always enemies, loot goblins, care package drops, trucks that need capturing, hostages that need freeing, everywhere at every time. It doesn't matter what you're doing, it doesn't matter whether or not you've freed the nearby outposts. It's too much. You can never catch a break. 
- The hostage trucks seemed to be just broken in this game. Either I couldn't damage the driver cause of its weird spawning and driving pattern, or I could, but instantly killed the hostage as well with my single bullet. 
- Guns for hire are just terrible in this game. You can only have 1 instead of the 2 on FC5, and the one you do get is utterly useless in combat, even after max upgrades. It's a shame because in FC5 they were actually somewhat useful to have by your side (at least in singleplayer)

Being an avid fan of the Far Cry series, this game has hurt me more than any other game. 

Far Cry, which was known for so much immersive storylines and eye grazing environment, now lies in a gravestone, with New Dawn adding extra depth to it. New Dawn is what should have been an Add-On for the Far Cry 5 game, and not a standalone game in itself. The game could have been the Resident Evil 7 for the series, but it chose to ignore everything. A game with no valid storyline, the characters are lifeless, using the same places with a little makeover, the gameplay itself is very non-immersive. I usually play and complete all the Far Cry games, even replay them again and again, this one however I was not able to complete, and left it in about 60% completion. I'm really dissapointed in this game. People say Far Cry 5 being the weakest Far Cry, I agree yes but atleast the game had good story and it was realistic. This one has nothing.

After finishing this game, I gotta say I honestly don't understand why it has so many lukewarm 2 word reviews. Saying just "its great" or "its a bad game". I honestly don't think its neither. 

[h2][b]Let's start with the bad things: [/b] [/h2]
FC: New Dawn is a smaller game than FC:5 and of course it shows, the map is a lot smaller (which isn't really a problem) where it does show tho is in the number of bugs present in the game. There's a lot of annoying issues plaguing the game, in my time playing it ive found stuff like enemies getting stuck inside rocks on cliffs (They can shoot you, but there's no way for you to shoot them). Vehicles despawn EXTREMELY fast when left alone, it reminds me of GTA Vice City in the ps2 where you would just turn around and the car you've been driving for the last 10 minutes just despawns. 
Also overall, the AI is very very dumb compared to FC5. 
My other gripe with this game is how badly designed the "rpg elements" are into the game. 
Enemies in this game have a health bar and a level that goes from 1 to 4 (or "elite"). Just like in Far cry 5, the world becomes harsher as you progress trough the story, the regular enemies that wander the world become progressively a higher level, and they become harder to kill, have better weapons and wear better armor. To counteract this, the player has to engage in the open world content and side activities to grind for materials and Ethanol to upgrade a their homebase in order to unlock progressively higher level weapons and vehicles. 
The problem with this system is that you can basically just grind out materials, upgrade EVERYTHING and then just tackle the story missions with overpowered gear, making any sense of challenge just evaporate. That leads to a feeling of disconnect between what's going on with the missions and the current state of the world, since you'll be oneshotting everything with lvl 4 weapons while the enemies are stuck in level 1 or 2. It honestly feels so disconnected it takes away a lot of the fun (at least for me). 
While we're on that topic, the amount of microtransactions that are possible in this game are just laughable. You can buy materials, weapons, vehicles, outfits. But thankfully you can just unlock everything just by playing, and grinding materials doesn't really take much time at all, they are very generous with the amount of stuff there is to loot in the world. 
Finally, the story is, in parts very very weak (not to mention super short). The twins as villains are just awful, not fleshed out at all and you only get to see them like 3 times and they're annoying more than anything, and the whole "prosperity" story just feels like it goes nowhere, it doesnt really feel like the settlement is progressing nor that the people there is going anywhere. Spoilers for the ending: [spoiler]Also, deciding the fate of the twins and joseph  feels very impactless and the ending doesnt feel rewarding at all. [/spoiler]

[h2] [b] Now, onto the good things: [/b] [/h2]

[h3] The map [/h3]
While the map is small and shares the same layout with far cry 5, a LOT of care has been put into the vegetation, and to what happened to every building that was there in all these years since the apocalypse happened. Every landmark has a past, a lot of details, visual storytelling through the environment and written notes about what has happened there. Just exploring was a lot of fun in this game overall. The lighting is on point all over this game, its overall a very beautiful game to look at.
While the open world activities are very few (it's basically just capturing strongholds) they're very fun to do and the difficulty ramps up pretty nicely with the ranks. 

[h3]Expeditions [/h3]
This is a feature that i mostly overlooked when i bought the game but ended up being my favourite.  They consist of a total of 7 maps where you have to find and extract a backpack, and survive until a helicopter arrives to get you outta there. 
The maps themselves are very high quality, well thought out and have very interesting themes attached to them (An abandoned british aircraft carrier, a crashed space station and literally alcatraz, just to name a few ). These are pretty difficult and offer quite a lot of replayability since you can do them multiple times with increasing difficulty and very good rewards attached to them.

[h3]Story[/h3]
While the story is very short and very weak at parts, there's also a subplot where we explore what happened to the cult of eden's gate after the apocalypse, how their beliefs have changed (or not) and what/where Joseph has been up to all this time. There's a lot of supernatural stuff going on, and I wish there was more story focused on this part of the plot (but the story is very short overall). You get to meet a lot of characters from the previous game and get closure as what to what their fate has been in the apocalypse. Spoilers for the story: [spoiler] You even get to see what happened to the main character of far cry 5. [/spoiler]

Overall, I believe the bad stuff and the good stuff at the end just balances out and this ends up being a pretty nice experience, it's like watching a mediocre action movie on the TV in a rainy saturday afternoon, its a rewarding experience even if its not the best Far Cry nor the best game overall.

I wish there was a way to leave a neutral review.

To simplify . this game DOES NOT feel like a direct sequel to FC5 . 

The good:

-The music is really good. 

-the neon lights and paints look cool and give it a fresh look.

-Enemies are much smarter and operate several different tools like mortars , rockets and more.

-The enemies are cool I suppose.

-Companions are fun., . Carmina Rye is the toughest 17 year old girl i've met and you are usually happy to have her by your side,But the star of the companions is the pig . that little guy is a true clutch hero by self ressing and the rezing you it can save you from a wipe and the Sniper grandma that makes up for stealthly clearing out bases a breeze. as long as you are not in active combat Nany (the mentioned grandma) will clear up everyone without raising an alarm even in hard mode.Gina (the former Highwaywoman is a beast as a commando and will probably save your beacon more than once. The dog can be useful too, the little rascal saved me from a few chaotic expeditions .memorable mentions as useless companions: The judge for not killing absolutely anything,and being mute , Jurk Drubman Jr for dying all the time, hardly killing anything and having annoyign diologues and Pastor Jerome for setting himself and you on fire ..

-Difficult setting is really difficult, they are not pulling their punches here. the enemies will not miss and being discovered by the enemy and the alarm triggered is truly terrifying as enemies are really tough.

The bad:

The game does not feel like a sequel. like the cult is not even as evil anymore. they removed the several layers deep plot from the first one and they simplified it with "bad guys vs good guys" "gangs vs civilians" the story was overly simplified and it is not as deep or terrifying as FC5 as the main villains are your typical bad girls antagonist mad max style. it no longer explores the dangers of extreme cultism and far right which was the plot of the first one. it feels like a whole different director said "naw, far right is cool ! it is the criminals that you need to be afraid of"

-enemies are divided by normal, rare, epic and elite . and if you are shooting bullets at an elite enemy with blue weapons you may as well hit them with your fist .this artificial gate keeping takes away from the original far cries and it turns it more into "The Divison" where  heavily armored enemies and even animals are hard to take down unless you have the right weapons.

-companions can be pretty stupid. not moving out of the way of incoming mortars or just standing there in the open facing 5 enemies at the same time while you are running away. ressing companions costs resources now which makes it suck more as their stupidity is costing you .

-The world could had been set a bit more apocalyptic ,people drive cars and even helicopters as if fuel is not an issue. you would think people should be riding horse instead , There is plenty of ammunition so no need to use more improv weapons like saw launchers or bows and arrows .Speaking of which:

-Bows are different now as enemies are armored . so even though arrows hit harder than bullets (imagine that) they dont have armor piercing arrows so hitting an elite with an arrow will result in them running to sound the alarm ,silenced weapons is better in every way.

-Tons of grinding to upgrade your base.


summary: I feel like this game is the last jedi of far cry 5 . it completely re-writes the story of the first one (fc5) and you feel like you are playing something else completely. it is like the director that took over this expansion did not get the point of the first one.The director of the second sequel (spoiler ahead) implied Joseph Seed to be an actual profet and not a crazy far right extremist .Never mind him condoning torturing, brain washing, drugging and dispossing of people (angels) like trash.It just does not make any sense at all.

Unless you are really hungry for a FC game (that does not even feel like it) I would skip. or even better. play FC6 instead.

On it's own, New Dawn is alright. It's 5 with a new look, and by new look I mean pinkness. 
Now don't get me wrong, I do have to say I like the vibrant colour choice, rather than the often used boring looking apocalyptic colour set (brown, brownish green, grey etc), but otherwise It's not really impressive looking.
As for gameplay, again, it's mostly like 5 with some changes. The first change is no weapon customization.
Which I find lame because, even tho the weapon customization is very limited (literally just a sight/scope, silencer and extended magazine), it atleast allowed me use a gun I liked, with or without a silencer, with a sight I prefered, and uh, with extra bullets. 
The second change is RPG elements. Instead of enemies being the same, with or without armour, with or without an LMG or flamethrower, they're now in tiers. 
1st tier: Grey, 1 bar of health, no armour, Low damage weaponry.
2nd tier: Blue, 2 bars of health, tiny bit of armour (prolly just cosmetic), Medium damage weaponry.
3rd tier: Purple, 3 bars of health, armoured, High damage weaponry.
Elite tier: Gold, 4 bars of health, heavily armoured, High damage weaponry.
This change is, interesting, but personally I don't like it. Doesn't fit Far Cry in my opinion. (Weapons are also in tiers btw)
Third change is, well It's... [spoiler]magical I suppose you can say.[/spoiler]

I had fun just like in 5, but with the limited replayablity [spoiler](no new game+, story isn't as interesting imo, taking over the same outposts over and over again for more diesel isn't fun, especially since the difficulty gets higher until it hits elite and you need to start using armour-piercing rounds, unless you got the perk that allows you to take em down, no far cry arcade ;c)[/spoiler] I don't really think it was worth it.
Maybe it's more fun with a friend, but I wouldn't know. ;')

DO NOT BUY THIS!!
