Review is written while finished the story, all side quests and most of the achievements in game. I also have played and finished all previous game titles.
Overall the game is an interesting continuation of Far Cry 5 and I do recommend getting on a sale just keep in mind it feels more like a "DLC" rather than a standalone game.

Pros:
- Performance was very good on max
- Beautiful graphics; more vibrant than Far Cry 5
- Base upgrading and weapon crating/upgrade
- Interesting story to wrap up Far Cry 5 and some old characters are back
- The guy at base with the Guitar! Amazing songs, just wish there was a function to sit on the damn bench
- Music
- Pet dogs :)

Neutral:
- Story was nice and interesting but still felt that it could have been further expanded
- Gameplay flow is almost the same as previous titles
- Not much weapon variety but there are some new interesting weapons
- Expenditions, although being a nice addon they are too few and they are just there to gather resources and make game "feel" bigger
- Perks are just okay, but it could have used some more unique perks instead of just upgrading the old ones half of the time
- Characters feel plain and not memorable; Except for guitar guy and doggy :)

Cons:
- Feels more like a DLC to Far Cry 5 than a standalone game
- Some characters from Far Cry 5 just disappeared without wrapping them up
- No steam achievements
- Requires Ubisoft launcher
- Although having a "base" feels nice, it doesn't do anything apart from upgrading some buildings. They could have added raids or other events or some more freedom in designing it
- Higher tier enemies are literally bullet sponges even with higher level equipment
- Map is almost the same but smaller than Far Cry 5
- Too much pink!
Terrible motion sickness makes the game unplayable.

Far Cry: New Dawn is more of a DLC for Far Cry 5 than it is a full game, but overall it's still enjoyable enough that I can recommend checking it out on sale.

Edens Gift (Specifically wrath) is ridiculous.

With nothing but the reality shovel and Wrath, I beat Mickey, Lou, and Ethan to death in a combined total of less than 10 minutes.

If you liked Far Cry 5, then you will probably enjoy this, although my feelings on this game are little more mixed. This honestly feels like a DLC rather than a standalone game, and like 5, it's definitely worth it if you get it on sale like I did. It has recognizable locations and characters from 5, but it remixes them a little bit which is fine. it still has the same outpost clearing gameplay they've been doing since Far Cry 3, but now you can let bases be re-captured by stronger enemies in exchange for more resources which I thought was cool. The map also feels way smaller this time around. Hope County in 5 had so many interesting locations, but here I really didn't feel the urge to explore. The story was passable but I didn't like the villains as much this time around. The Seed family in 5 had clear goals and motivations which made them really interesting but also satisfying to take each of them down. But Mickey and Lou are just kind of Assholes who want to oppress and bully people because it's the apocalypse I guess.

Overall I would definitely say that this game was fun and worth my 8 bucks. The gunplay is still Far Cry 5 which is still incredibly solid. However I think my experience was bogged down by the small map, lackluster villains, and short length. Honestly would give a mixed review if I could

It is the same map as mostly the same map as Far Cry 5. Graphically it looks great. The countryside is beautiful, more vibrant than FC5. The villains were great as is expected of a Far Cry game and the story as well. Gameplay-wise it is different enough compared to Far Cry 5, I liked the addition of the home base and the different weapons that you can craft. The outpost mechanic is an upgrade as well compared to previous titles. The expeditions were pretty fun and the levels were well designed. There are less collectables which is great for completionists. 

I had the same issue with the protagonist as he/she is bland af. I liked that they removed the tedious kidnappings.

Bottom line, if you're an FPS lover you will enjoy this game both technically and for its core gameplay loop.  ALL developers can take a cue from the quality of life options available here such as FOV, separate aim sensitivity and FULL keyboard remapping.  Not to mention it runs fantastic and looks amazing with the HD textures pack.  Anyway, story-wise this nicely concludes the story of the Seed family so coming off of Far Cry 5 it's a nice addition to the arc.  The new antagonists are forgettable as most reviews already note but who cares, the gameplay mechanics and wide open world are fantastic to enjoy and explore, even if it IS a reskinned FC 5 map.  Thoroughly enjoyed my nearly 40 hours playing.
fun sequel to farcry 5 and wow MR. Seed!!!

I could never ever recommend this game. Time and time again i have tried to complete this game with a friend. Multiple online service problems with some game breaking problems for my friend. 

The story is so insanely boring. Feels like they are forcing you to have empathy for the villain and just take a massive dump on the FC 5. 
Its just the same same as all the games. But its way worse. Bringing nothing new, actually less then the previous games. 

I would think that the game would be good after many years of FC. But its just not. I'm not trying to compere it to much to the other FC in the franchise , But when a game have less content the its predecessor. I don't mind the lvl mechanic, but i hate the HP bar enemies have. Also the weapon rarity makes it even worse. If you like one gun for its simplicity, but it is common. then you will struggle to do harder things. only because its marked as grey. Since the games is incredible easy following this toddler mechanic. I would strongly recommend using mainly grey or blue tier weapons throughout the game. Don't bother killing animals except when you find a "Legendary" animal. The loot you are getting is something you will get anyway just when you loot bases. 


The game have 0 replay value, with most linear story telling. Without spoiling to much, but I really don't see how some of the characters have survived and why everything is ok as it is. 

As for graphics. There are some visual stuff here and there. but that is common for Ubisoft games (sad to say) Beside that, the vibrant collor is pleasing to watch and i don't mind it. 7/10 I guess? 

I wish i was a brain-dead person that played this game. I am to logical playing this game, i see so insanely many plot holes in the story it makes me sick. And the side mission are just not fun. You are suppose to learn about new people, but after that mission, you will just end up never seeing them again. Perk set is okey. Most typical you find in these kinda games. Just made it more boring to acquire. Some is just so unrealistic it makes me just sad. 

I had the most fun, when i throw rocks at my friends or some slight trolling. Beside that, we are just coping that the end will be good, but as for now we are doubting. Getting close to finish the game. 

The target demographic feels all over the place. Sometime its brutal, like a 18+ game other time its so goofy you are wondering if you want you 8 year old brother to play instead.

First off, I don't recommend this game to anyone if it's not on sale for at least $15 or less. But ultimately, it still has the modern Far Cry experience so if you're into that like I am, then you'll have fun with this game. There's a decent amount of weaponry and the callbacks from this game to 5 are cool. The soundtrack is also good, although perhaps not as standout as 5's. 

However, the game has too little unique content. The main story is laughably short, the map is only a fraction of 5's, and the weapon tier system is flawed at best. While New Dawn is often compared to 5, it's warranted as the game was built entirely off of it. Unfortunately, not much was done with this expansion of the Far Cry series and is really only there for those who couldn't get enough of 5. Play this if you liked 5 and don't mind the new RPG-like additions or else I wouldn't recommend it.

Game hits [i] way [/i] too close to home.

The atmosphere is beautiful, seeing my home state in shambles is something interesting. Though sadly the story is kinda mediocre, you get ~20 hours of playtime with mediocre antagonists and good gameplay, except for the fact that this is the game where the BS "Ranked guns vs. ranked enemies" thing started. If your gun is one level too low it just acts like a pea shooter. Many characters return (Except for Boomer, sadly) to either help you or fight you.

It's a good game at it's core, just burdened by bad gun-play and mediocre characters (God the Sisters suck, not that they're evil but because they are just so poorly written).

I've always thought that the devs for Far Cry desperately wanted to make a different game. The constant forced hallucinations or drug sequences, the crazy dlc concepts, and the out of the norm spin offs like primal and this. The game is good, I actually liked it better than 5 in some respects but it's short and in classic Ubisoft tradition the story is flaming hot garbage.

Positives:
The post apocalyptic setting was great, they made it really colorful and I found it more visually appealing that the base area in FC5.

I really enjoyed the addition of a main hub area that could be upgraded. The past Far Cry games felt like towns were mostly just a place to stop for the missions or to refill ammo, there was never any attachment to them. In this game you're main area is the town of Prosperity and acts as an anchor for exploration and adds some purpose to your actions.

The expeditions were also a great addition and I was disappointed there was only 7 of them. They overcome one of the hurdles that an open world game has, you can't make areas too unique or they'll clash with the map theme, but if everything is the same it can feel repetitive. The expeditions have you fly to a separate area to harvest resources, and the maps for them were overall more visually interesting than the basic outposts in the game.

They give perk points for almost everything you do and perks don't feel like they're always just out of reach. Then there are several that can be upgraded endlessly so after everything is unlocked you can just constantly pump up your ammo supply.

Finally being able to shoot Joseph Seed in his stupid face (heart but I'll take what I can get), not sure if this was supposed to be an emotional or conflicting moment for the player but I was spamming the fire key as soon as he started raising the gun to himself. There were maybe a few nanoseconds that could be shaved off between when they gave me the option and his death.

Neutrals:
They swapped to a more RPG gameplay style where gun hits show visible damage indicators. The tiers that were added make you go through different guns instead of just finding your favorite ones and using them constantly, but they removed all the gun customization so you can't change sights or add silencers, so some tiers won't have a weapon you like to play with the attachments you'd like. Having some enemies pose more of a threat can add some extra strategy to who you want to take out first. However, at the same time having outposts get retaken and upgraded just ranks the enemies up 1 tier but keeps almost everything the same. If you managed to take it without being detected once you'll probably be able to do the same copy pasted tactic again. Each higher tier enemy requires another perk to perform takedowns, but this just comes off as unnecessary at best and frustrating when you manage to sneak up on an enemy you can't kill yet. Just like in FC5 the DLC undercuts some of the balancing that the tiers add as well with a few tier 2 weapons and a tier 3 car being available from the start.

Negatives:
The story is crap, the twins are very 2 dimensional characters and they only show up a couple times before you kill them, they have no real presence. The friendly NPCs aren't much better, they tried to make an emotional moment over the death of one of them but I actually couldn't even picture who they were talking about when they said he'd been captured. It also has the FC4 problem of forcing you to step into an obvious trap. You have to leave your weapons at the door and they even expect you to handcuff yourself, who in their right mind would do this? All to save someone who is obviously going to die if you completely incapacitate yourself. 

The game is pretty short as well, it seems to have the least outposts of all the games with about 10. The map is the same as FC5 but the north 1/3 of it (Jacobs area) is irradiated and is only used for a few story bits. The last two boss fights, the twins and Ethan, are pretty much one after the other. Ethan is only an antagonist for a couple minutes and his fight seems like a yeti reskin.

This is Farcry without the long drawn out story, however I have had a lot of fun playing this and don't regret buying it. This game takes place after Farcry 5 and I just wished they turned this into a full game and a bit more thought into it. This could've been a even better game if they really went wild with the premise of a Farcry after the bombs dropped. Would've been fun and different from what they usually do.

I've not played a Far Cry game before, thought I'd give this one a go. The environment is absolutely beautiful - lakes, mountains, flowers, wildlife. And it's got the hallmarks of an enjoyable open world type FPS RPG, getting missions, exploring, hunting for loot etc. But the storytelling is weak; the voice acting is often abysmal to the point of insufferably whiny; there are tedious, swaggering villains (kudos for making them black women, that was a nice touch, though I've got to wonder where they found hair bleach in the apocalypse); and I found it actively distressing being obliged to kill animals, especially dogs. Killing horrible humans - fine. Killing dogs and other innocent animals - leaves me feeling queasy and upset. If you like games in this kind of genre, there are far better examples.

First of all, I didn't know whether to recommend this game or not, so this is more of a mixed review. Let's start off with the good things. This game is gorgeous; the environments are amazing, there is gratify and a lot of flowers everywhere. The world looks so beaten but vibrant at the same time and If you're a fan of the color pink, you're definitely going to love this one. 

The gameplay is a mixed bag. It starts off really tedious, some enemies are bullet sponges, but once you unlock a high-tier weapon, the game starts feeling like previous FC games. Some weapon animations are an improvement over FC5 but there is no weapons customization whatsoever which is quite disappointing. The story and characters here are very weak. I didn't care about any of them. The antagonists are weak and cringe, and a lot of the characters are just silly and generic. It's like they're not even trying with these games anymore.

The performance is good. I couldn't maintain a smooth 60FPS, but the drops weren't bad, definitely an improvement over FC5. 

[b] TL;DR I'd say if you liked FC5, you'll like this one, as long as you don't take it too seriously. You're going to have a fun time blowing stuff up.[/b]

A soulless entry in a dying franchise. Does not respect your time - endless follow/fetch quests, replayable expeditions & outposts, and a horrible perk point system with bottomless upgrades. All this game is designed to do is drag out your playthrough for as long as possible and tempt you with microtransactions. It's the epitome of everything there is to hate about modern AAA games, but at the very least you can use Cheat Engine because it's singleplayer. Even so, I couldn't recommend this to anyone. Play Far Cry 3 or 4 instead

I came pretty close to thumbing this down because honestly, the story wasn't good and I played it mostly to get it over with.

The world is nice and the companions are alright, makes you feel less alone in the open world to have somebody with you and you can even pet the animals.

But what finally won me over are the expeditions. They are like outposts but instead of mopping up all the enemies you need to find a package and escape with it -- AND mop up all the enemies on your way, because this is Far Cry and not Hitman, right? At the beginning I thought there would be like two or three of them just so you can get your hands on some special stuff for crafting, but there are much more. They take place in very different locations, from a stranded ship to Alcatraz to the ISS crash site. They are fun to play and I appreciate the effort that went into making them, because they always look gorgeous and feel atmospheric.

So yeah, all in all it's an enjoyable game!

Review Title: "Missing Catboys in Far Cry New Dawn: We Missed Out on an Adorable Fashion Opportunity"

Rating: 3/5

Far Cry New Dawn, the latest installment of the beloved gaming series, brings colors, chaos, and hope to a post-apocalyptic world. The game offers a diverse mix of action, adventure, and challenging combat, all seamlessly woven together. However, as a player, I couldn't help but notice one significant oversight ‚Äì the absence of catboys!

Catboys, those cute characters with animal ears that can bring a touch of life to even the most dramatic moment in Japanese culture. While the game features many animal characters and creatures, I missed the option to don kitty ears on my character. It would have been an excellent opportunity for individual stylization and the creation of a completely unique protagonist.

Developers could introduce catboys as a cosmetic accessory, perhaps earned by completing difficult tasks or obtaining rare items. We could choose from various types of ears ‚Äì from classic cat ears to wolf or bear ears. This functionality would not only add visual fun to the game but also motivate players to explore the game world in more detail.

All in all, Far Cry New Dawn continues to be an enjoyable experience, offering plenty of action and adventure. However, as someone accustomed to diverse fashion eccentricities in games, I must express my disappointment at the lack of catboys. The ability to create a character with cute ears would undoubtedly enhance the game's amusement and uniqueness.

Although the game lacks catboys, I would still recommend Far Cry New Dawn to fans of the series and players seeking an action-packed and adventurous experience in a post-apocalyptic setting.

not a good game

This Far Cry iteration is more compact. If you're not a fan of the large maps often found in newer Ubisoft games and you enjoy the typical Far Cry gameplay loop, then this might be for you. However, avoid buying it solely to enjoy the story; the game feels like it contains about 4-5 hours' worth of storyline, none of which is exceptional or even very good. The end of Joseph's story is polarizing‚Äîsome love it as it provides context for his descent into madness, while others think he was featured too little and that the story insults the character built in FC5.
I personally enjoyed the more manageable size of the game compared to something like FC6. What truly deserves praise is the level of effort invested into changing up the whole feel of the world. I anticipated a simple asset flip, but the degree to which they transformed the map and the weapon models is surprisingly impressive for a shorter spinoff. I would certainly welcome another smaller game like this.

A great continuation of Far Cry 5. The main story is short but you can spend a lot of time in the game doing side missions and exploring areas from the first game that look different after the time that has passed since the events of Far Cry 5.

The co-op works well and the game has become more difficult than the previous installment (which forced you to use inferior guns in order to keep it somewhat challenging) but the single player campaign is over before you know it. You won't be able to use all the weapons unless you're really into grinding and the fights aren't as grand as before. 

Characters are somewhat interesting although being forced to watch your character make silly choices (like not just shooting the kids and the two main antagonists right at the start when they kidnap 'm) gets more dull every installment. At some point you just don't care about the grade-C story writing any more and just want to shoot stuff.

All-in-all, recommended for the co-op.

It was alright. I liked some bunch of things about this one than i did about the previous title:

-The map was better,smaller,it was more colorful,the vegetation was more rich.

-The takedown animations were 10x times better.It made stealth more satisfying.

-The OST is much better than the previous one.

-The character costumization was better in this game,since you could have seen yourself now and then,it made more logic.

-Eliberating outposts was more fun.

-The perk system was better,not thousands of perks,just the essentials.

-Seeing The Deputy,as The Judge,it was nice,didn't really expect it.

The things i didn't quite like are those:

-The guns looked worse,some of them at least,they looked like some toys made out of scrap,not really my taste.

-Uncustomizable weapons,they should have left that in the game.

-The Saw Launcher..the worst gun i have ever seen in my entire life as a gamer. The gun itself is so stupid,i can't even look at it.

-The game has bugs,not many,but it has them.And they are quite unpleasant sometimes.

-The story.It felt very rushed,at some points it was good,but overall the story itself it's not that good.The twins were very annoying and their story wasn't very well explained.I didn't understand their motive. Joseph was back,but it wasn't something wow.He was the same as he was in the previous game,until the end,when he realized what he's done,his ending was good.If i have to rate this story,i would rate it a 6.5/10.

This game has it's flaws,but it has some good things too. In my opinion,if you played Far Cry 5,then you should play this one too,you might like the story,or the game itself more or less,It depends on you.Also buy it only at a discount,i don't think it's worth the full price.

Super dissapointing in almost every way.  Graphics were nice when they rendered as the devs intended, but character models frequently spas out and twitch unnaturally and textures also occasionally wig out and look artifacted/glitchy.  Everything else was a garbage fire and a downgrade from any previous Far Cry game.  Everything in this game felt like a joke.  The story was nearly nonexistent and not told in an at all immersive way, the charachters were goofy and overblown (in a lame way, not a funny way), the game mechanics were exactly the same as in the previous games; except poorly implemented.  Hunting animals is pointless and more or less a waste of time and ammo, there were no real choices you got to make as the main character, reviving teammates uses plants instead of syringes/medpacks and them dying means nothing except that you feed them some plants in the game menu then call them back, and they bring transportation with them so letting them die is anything but a bad thing.  i could go on but in a nut shell terrible/lazy writing + thoughtless/repetitive game mechanics = a rather lame experience.  Glad i got it on sale, wasnt worth the 12$ i paid for it, much less the full price.  Sad to see another great game franchise slip through the cracks and vanish beneath the bar of mediocrity that it can no longer reach.

And what really bothers me is that there are two assault rifles at the higest level both with silencers both with scopes they just look and sound different, but im still using a rocket launcher from 1 level lower because there is only a barely functional grenade launcher at the highest level.

If you liked Far Cry 5, this is just an extension of the story. Gameplay is very different. It was a refreshing change of pace and I feel like they tested some changes to the standard Far Cry Copy/Paste model. I believe some worked but they need to solve the repetitiveness of some of the new stuff. I really liked the challenges but after a certain point they became pointless once you get all your Perks and only have the ability to increase carry for Medkits, Ammo, and Throwables. 

This was a quick and fun ~20 hours. I didn't do just main story stuff, I tried to upgrade Prosperity as fast as I could. The game is not very enjoyable at the beginning without Fast Travel, but once you unlock that the whole game opens up. Once you get the Gold Weapon Crafting, you become a monster and run through everything, it was a good time being that powerful.

Tip: Liberate Outposts and Upgrade till you get Fast Travel. You can do a few and then try and get the trucks that have Ethanol on them and return them to the Outposts, get as much Ethanol as possible so you can upgrade the weapons crafting to purple/gold. Gold Weapons are crazy good but to get the circuit boards you have to kill the Beasts or do Expeditions and cost a lot of other resources so purple is probably easier earlier. 

Note: I picked this up on sale, so b/c it wasn't full price my experience was a lot better. I wouldn't pay full price for it.

[h1] (this review contains story spoilers) [/h1]

There's a TL;DR at the end.

My enjoyment of this game was mostly carried by my infinite and undying love for Far Cry 5. That being said, my same love of Far Cry 5 also soured my experience of this game. I will draw several comparisons between the two as this is meant to be the direct sequel. I had low expectations going in, was positively surprised within the first 10 hours, but then quickly realised that this is one incredibly under-cooked game. 

[b] The Graphics and Performance [/b]

Visually this game is jaw dropping, it's so damn beautiful and the scenery is incredible. The visuals were spot on and some places were honestly breathtaking to look at. I played on High graphics settings and it ran mostly stable 90-120 fps on a 3080. Sometimes the fps would randomly shatter for no reason but it was very occasional and barely worth mentioning. This game is quite GPU heavy though, so if your rig is closer to a 4-slot toaster than a functional setup, I'd be careful.

[b] General Gameplay [/b]

Gameplay-wise it's fun with some wrinkles. First of all, I don't mind the addition of damage numbers and such RPG-esque elements, I actually think it's kinda cool and the enemy ranking makes it fun to progress. At the same time though, the progression is way too easy in this game. A few hours of casually doing outposts undetected and I had already maxed out most of Prosperity, which was underwhelming. Enemy spawns are really weird and some AI mechanics had me puzzled. One time I saw a helicopter randomly pulling up in the middle of nowhere followed by two highwaymen plummeting to their deaths from said helicopter. Perks were pretty standard for a Far Cry game but I was very fond of the perks gained from New Eden. Double jumping was incredibly fun and practical, and it helped really pick up the pace of the game. Ghost was incredibly useful and is actually helpful; as for Wrath I found myself using it more defensively than offensively, and for an occasional traversal boost combined with double jumping.

[b] The Villains [/b]

I don't think the villains are inherently bad but there is a lot of untapped potential here. They weren't threatening or likeable, had no redeeming personalities, had a really vague backstory that I didn't care for one bit because it wasn't explained for more than 45 seconds, and it wasn't even satisfying to see them go down. Comparatively, FC5 portrayed a much more fearsome, don't-fw-me villain roster than Mickey and Lou. Even when you see them blow out Rush's brains in front of you, which barely served the plot in any way, it still didn't help their image as a villain. It would've been much better if they weren't so obnoxious and there was some way to distinguish the two in terms of personality. They would've benefitted from separate story lines for each so the characters are individiually fleshed out better, similar to how FC5 had regions dedicated to the 3 siblings, and through them Joseph's development as the antagonist was weaved into the storyline. They could've taken inspiration from FC3 and had one of the siblings and the main character to mix things up. You get the idea, there were so many things they could've done and they just didn't. For a game franchise that prides itself on incredible villains, this didn't cut it.

[b] The Missions [/b] 

To be honest, most of the missions were pretty fun. I had a good time with a majority of them. The little prison raid was awesome though it felt rushed. The derby thingy was one of the funnest missions in the franchise. The fight arena thing was great too. A lot of missions were very good, but a lot of missions were not so good, including all of the 8 side missions which were rushed way too hard. Some redundant "protect these structures", "shoot these targets", "find this thing" etc. etc. Although most main story missions were fantastic, the final fight against Mickey and Lou was the most abominable thing I've experienced in my lifetime of gaming. I won't explain why, see for yourself. Also, I won't bother mentioning the fight with Ethan, that deserves a wall of text on its own and I'm lacking the willpower to fully discuss how this game pulled a Riverdale and introduced supernatural elements for no reason.

[b] The Story [/b]

The story felt very promising at first but as it progressed it seemed the writing of it deteriorated significantly. It feels like this story was written by a Fiverr author who was given 10 bucks and a Snickers bar. My main issue isn't the actual content of the story but specifically how many broad jumps it took. In FC5 you had to really work your ass off to progress the story and it did a very good job of building up the villains, the sense of community and your own emotional commitment as a player to seeing the story reach its end. Here though, the sense of community, that should've been this game's major selling point, was not taken advantage of to the extent it should've been. There was barely any time to truly appreciate all the characters. I say "all", but there weren't even that many to be honest. There were plenty of old FC5 characters, which was super cool to see, except once you bring them to Prosperity you basically never see them again. Also, I wish there was more done to fill in the gap between FC5 and FCND, because it seems the lore is full of holes and difficult to piece together, and the game does not instill a sense of "what the hell happened here?" that would be fitting for a post-apocalyptic game.

[b] Completionistic Stuff [/b]

I achieved 100% in the game and mostly enjoyed the process of doing so. I'd like to note that I enjoyed the prepper stashes a lot, I think they were surprisingly polished and fun. I also liked the photo collectibles, I think those were very nice reminders of the pre-nuclear Hope County. The material collecting stuff was redundant as hell and it has Ubisoft plastered all over it. If you're doing this yourself, I suggest upgrading Timber as he'll highlight materials around him. The outposts were fun and refreshing, the level design was really quite good and there's so many ways to clear them. Expeditions were mostly boring, I wish I didn't have to repeat them 3 times each, that's dumb and a waste of my time. Generally, all of this grindy stuff would've been much more welcoming if there was an exclusive reward for doing so but there wasn't one so you'll only find enjoyment in it if you're picky about doing everything.

[b] Crafting [/b]

I don't mind the crafting element of this game as it fits thematically, but I'm disappointed that more wasn't done with it. There is absolutely no option to customise any of your weapons which is completely counterintuitive to a DIY weapon themed game. No scopes, suppressors or anything of the such which would've been the bare minimum. They could've expanded with some unique upgrades that are only unlockable through special means, such as collectibles, side missions etc., but I guess Ubisoft killed the golden goose when they settled on what was finally implemented.

[b] TL;DR / Summary [/b]

I think this game is definitely worth playing. The slating tone of this review mostly originates from me wishing it was a more worthy successor to FC5 as this game only lives up to about 40% of its true potential. However, standalone, this game is good and worth playing. Thinking about what this game could've been compared to what it is makes my eyes water. That being said, this game isn't bad at all and I would recommend giving it a go.

Honestly this feels like the weakest entry in the Far Cry series. The story which is by far the weakest part of the game is what really drives this home. It feels phoned in at best where I never once felt any sympathy or real relation to any characters. The antagonists are poorly written and cringey at best with barely any reason to be evil other than a quick flashback of their mother saying "please don't be evil like your dad." Some how this is supposed to sway you not to kill them in the end despite all the psycho killing they did where there's really no redemption. The other characters don't get off easy either as they each have 1, 2 missions tops of their small banter to give them the stereotypical character they are and move on. The other main good guy who is killed by the twins I couldn't feel any emotion for him dying as he has like 2 minutes of cut scenes and they are just more him being a hardass and bossy man without showing much in redeeming qualities other than "he knows stuff to survive." i.e. He's the stand in important character that dies to give you a reason to hate the villians. 

All that aside the RPG aspects I feel make the early game frustrating and annoying at best. The tier of gun you use only has the killing capacity for the same tier or lower enemy. This wouldn't be bad if the missions didn't keep taking away your guns to give you tier ones from enemies to fight tier threes. And the tiers make no sense either as my biggest gripe is that biker helmets are able to completely negate head shots. Yes the helmet will break but, only if you use the same tier or higher other wise you gotta mag dump your tier one into the tier 3 enemies head to hope it breaks the helmet since you'll use all your ammo on body shots otherwise. It's really bad for a stealth player since this will immediately alert enemies despite you getting a good shot at them and then basically being punished for not shooting the body or using a take down. The scavenging for parts isn't too bad except that end game you have to grind expeditions or hunting elite bison for computer chips because there's no other way than paying IRL currency to get parts which is also a major issue. The game almost limits some progression behind a paywall if you don't want to hunt or do expeditions so the crafting is annoying if you want those tier fours. All this comes into the issue that you have to do the higher level quests early on to get the better stuff. The game honestly doesn't get to be fun until you're at tier 3 which there's only 4 tiers. At this point you're at least on par with all the enemies except the elites but you actually have a fighting chance. 

The vehicles I honestly almost never used as the driving was poor and for some reason vehicles can only take like 2 shots before exploding. About 90% of my deaths were from a car blowing up next to me after having two pistol rounds shot at the tire. It honestly was better on foot as if you do scavenge you have to get out of your vehicle all the time anyways. Another big gripe is the wingsuit. This was a favorite of mine in the previous games but now unless you airdrop in you almost can never use it as the prompt almost never comes up until your 2 inches from the ground about to die from fall damage. Jumping from a cliff I'd expect it to let me use the suit given jumping 3 feet off some stairs gives the option for a parachute, but for a  150 foot drop the game assumes you're not gonna wanna use it then.  I can't comment much on the guns for hire since I refuse to use them as my experience with companions in games are poor when it comes to stealth and since Far Cry 3 I've preferred to be a lone assassin.
 
Overall I would skip this one, it feels more like a phoned in cash grab from Ubisoft. There's barely a skeleton of story. All characters are forgettable at best and the gun play isn't good until the end game. If you like to grind, stay away from vehicles, and can care less about story or characters than this game would be tolerable for you.

I'll make this one short and sweet without any BS: New Dawn is the true, actual DLC for Far Cry 5. If you keep this on your mind and grab it on sale, you'll get a lot of mileage out of it as it'll deliver exactly what you expect-- a continuation of FC5's story (though it does follow the non-canon bad ending), expanding on its gameplay and mechanics in a much shorter, condensed experience.

Sucks that this was advertised and released as a standalone game, because it can only be truly enjoyed as an expansion.

I did enjoy New Dawn, but perhaps that's because my expectations were low. Expectations are important because after I played Far Cry, which is not my idea sort of game, I did not expect much from Far Cry 2 but was blown away by the totally different concept. Even though I was used to it when coming to Far Cry 3, I just loved more of it. Then I played Blood Dragon and it was sufficiently different to enthuse me again. Far Cry 4 did seem a bit samey and so my enthusiasm for the genre was fading, but then Primal came along and the difference was enough to rejuvenate my interest. My expectations were again low for Far Cry 5 so I still enjoyed it but I had really decided that maybe enough was enough. New Dawn should have followed in the "different" style of Blood Dragon and Primal, but it wasn't. It was effectively an extension of Far Cry 5 with a few variances and not much else of interest. Plus the ending is dull and anti-climatic, relying on the "boss fight" concept rather than genuine effort at a finale. I'll probably play Far Cry 6, but only if I can get it cheap enough in a sale.

What an awful game from front to end. I only finished it so I could post this review knowing it didn't get better.

The "open world" essentially consists of 4 different POIs repeated 10x. Moving around the open world feels horrible. Your character makes jumps in cutscenes that kill you if you make then in-game. Jumping down hills can kill you. Made even funnier by your character surviving much faster falls when using the parachute. The movement all feels very "gamey" and not in a nice way.

The game is plagued by technical issues. The most annoying is that the game's icons on the open world (quest markers, supply drops, and so on) are literally broken on non-standard resolutions such that looking directly at an icon means it can disappear so you have to look off to the side to get it to show up. Other games have this problem too, but not games that actually say they support non-standard resolutions.

The RPG elements are unsatisfying at best, and meaningless at worst.

Story is ok, but the moment to moment writing is trash.

This is the worst Far Cry game I've ever played. I genuinely hope whoever was behind this game got fired and is never allowed to make a game again. A terrible, dreadfully boring story, nowhere near as humorous as the previous Far Cry games, or even as good. You would think, a game about one mans exploits, the consequences of one mans actions, would be about him. You would think Joseph Seed, the person who caused this apocalypse in the first place, is the focus of the story, but he's not. Its some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• pair of idiot twins who somehow worked their way up to the top of the food chain. Joseph is practically a side story, you have like one or two quests with him, then the last scene involves him. The rest of the story? Following the other idiots, who somehow survived in this wasteland. The ONLY interesting characters, are Nick Rye's family, past that? Everyone else has the worst stories. Mickey and Lou? The ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• twins who somehow rule this pathetically small world? They are awful villains, their banter is actually annoying, and their boss fight is ridiculous. They have health bars that are beyond reasonable, even when you knock their stupid ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• helmets off, you don't deal any more damage than you were before, even spamming headshots. The definition of bullet sponges, while they also deal maximum damage to you, even on the easiest difficulty. I had to actually take the game out of the hardest difficulty for this fight and it still took a half hour. There is absolutely no reason for the second to final fight making me spend the over a half hour, running around in circles, on fire, and being sniped, surrounded by dogs that constantly stun lock you, OH and the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• twins constantly stun lock you as well. The worst boss fight in any video game I've ever played. And their sappy ending? Their sudden sentimental behavior towards each other and the main character, even though they've been sadistic, murderous psychos the entire game? Was a horrible excuse to try making me feel bad for killing those pieces of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. The one following that? Even ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• worse. Tenfold. I mean its easy to avoid damage since its a melee boss, but god ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• dammit it has to have double the health of both twins combined. Sure, maybe the story surrounding the final fight had me intrigued, because I only cared about about Joseph and his story. Joseph is not the final boss. Oh, remember when I said pathetically small map? This game should have been a DLC for Far Cry 5 with the size of the map. In 5, you had 4 massive segments of a giant map to explore. In this one? You have maybe a quarter of one of those segments. And yet, somehow, in the smallest map possible, it is still impossible to find quests. The majority of the hours I have on this game, were spent wandering around the same few places trying my hardest to find the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• missions this game provided. Oh yeah, the selling point? The ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• super powers you get? Are also pathetic. You get a double jump, a speed boost, something that makes you a tiny bit more stealthy, and like one other stupid, minor effect. I was hesitant to trust the bad reviews, but I wish I did, I wish I got the time wasted on this dumpster fire back, I wish I never spend a dollar on this game, but the past is in the past, and all I can do now, is warn other people not to even bother. The story is garbage, the missions are repetitive and downright stupid, the "powers" are pathetic, the game is a bore, the villains are terrible, and the map is practically microscopic compared to literally any other game. Please, do not waste a dime on this game. Even if its given to you for free, don't waste a second playing this garbage. The ONLY thing I can really praise, is the land you play on. Its beautiful, floral, and full of unique wildlife. That's it. That is the only part of this game I will sing praise to.

Far Cry New Dawn offers an exhilarating and visually stunning gaming experience set in a captivating post-apocalyptic world. The game successfully combines the familiar elements of the Far Cry series with unique gameplay mechanics and a fresh storyline. The vibrant and colorful environments, combined with the intense action-packed gameplay, keep players fully engaged throughout their journey.

The game's compelling narrative introduces intriguing characters and presents an intriguing exploration of the aftermath of a devastating global event. The addition of RPG-like progression elements adds depth and a sense of accomplishment as players upgrade their abilities and gear, enhancing the overall gameplay experience.

Far Cry New Dawn excels in its open-world design, providing players with ample opportunities for exploration and discovery. The diverse landscapes, from lush forests to desolate wastelands, are meticulously crafted and offer a visually immersive experience. The game's dynamic day-night cycle and weather effects further enhance the atmosphere, creating a truly immersive post-apocalyptic setting.

One of the standout features of Far Cry New Dawn is the ability to recruit and customize allies, adding a layer of strategic depth to the gameplay. The engaging gunplay mechanics and a wide variety of weapons allow for creative and thrilling combat encounters. The seamless integration of co-op multiplayer also provides an opportunity for players to team up with friends and tackle missions together.

Overall, Far Cry New Dawn impresses with its captivating world, engaging gameplay, and strong narrative. It is a worthy addition to the Far Cry series, delivering an exciting and memorable gaming experience that will keep players entertained for hours on end.

Don't waste your time. Uninstalled this, refunded, and went back to the far superior Far Cry 5. I understand the negative reviews saying that this is a step down from Far Cry 5. What I don't understand are the positive reviews saying "it's more of the same formula as Far Cry 5" which it in no way is. It's a generic feeling watered down version of a Far Cry game with mild looter-shooter elements like enemies with health bars. The last thing I want is Borderlands mechanics in my Far Cry games considering the last two Borderlands games sucked balls (3 and Wonderlands). Since it was only $8 I would've just kept it if it ran decently but even on the lowest settings it's optimized like crap. Even Cyberpunk 2077 runs better. Stick to any other Far Cry game unless you don't mind Dollar Store knock-off quality games.

The game that introduced the tier system when it comes to guns enemies.

If you have a tier 2 gun, you do almost no damage to tier 3 enemies, but you one-shot tier 1 enemies. The funniest part is, the enemies you kill don't drop their weapons if it's a higher tier than yours. This applies throughout the entire game and serves as the main way to guide the player throughout the story/map.

Granted, you don't HAVE to follow the easiest path, I absolutely brute forced my way into capturing a few tier 3 bases with my tier 2 guns, but be prepared to die A LOT while doing so.

This entire feature absolutely KILLS the fun of Far Cry. In Far Cry 3 or 4, immediately after they let you loose. you could run and take over ANY enemy base you wanted, even at the complete opposite side of the map. Their way of ensuring difficulty was TYPE of enemy, AMOUNT of enemies, and WHERE the enemies are. Not some artificial "tier" that grants their gun the power of a .50 cal sniper rifle while maintaining the fire rate of an AK-47.

It seems odd even from a logical standpoint, the visual "upgrades" from the different tiers of weapons is that they look less like generic weapons and more like random trash bolted together in the SHAPE of a weapon, wouldn't that do less damage?

Speaking of that, no weapon customization, at all. There are presets and that's all you get, if you want a suppressor on your rifle then pound sand. You either have to find another rifle with a suppressor on it, or choose a different silent play style. (Within your own tier, of course!)

What if we turned Far Cry 5 into a terminally mid looter-shooter with enemy levels and item rarity? 

I'll tell you what happens, you make Far Cry worse. 

The actual gameplay is still good, but Ubisoft seemingly took all of the worst things from RPGs and looter-shooters and put them in New Dawn without any care for how it would impact the play experience. The antagonists (the sisters) are also kind of unengaging. I'm writing this review a year and a half after giving up on the game so I do not remember their name. The guy who definitely isn't just a fictionalized version of Jared Leto is still a fun villain, though. And I like that the player character from Far Cry 5 came back as an NPC companion (who doesn't talk, to maintain the canonicity of the Far Cry 5 being any gender or race and having any voice the player wants).
Heavy Handed Microtransactions in a singleplayer game.

I guess I would recommend it, if it's on sale. I got a double deal, Far Cry 5 + New Dawn for fifteen bucks. FC5 alone was 60, lol. New Dawn is just OK. It looks much better than it seemed like it would from all the bad ads and preview still-shots I'd seen. It has good graphics, if not a little skimpy on textures in places, and the colorful scenery has some the update features of FC6, like destructible trees while bombing through the forest. The interface is a little different, which is fine. But the gameplay is more arcadey to me. A little too much focus on constant, fast action with rarely any time to just cruise around and explore. It's hard to try and discover new areas without constantly running into those blm/antfa types every 30 seconds that can take 10-15 .30 cal lmg or 3 or 4 .50 cal BMG slugs to the chest before they go down. Luckily many of them are so wrapped up in spray painting everything with hot pink graffiti that you can walk up behind them and take them out before they can gang up on you. It's an OK game, but I think the producers were just focusing on the wrong things much of the time, instead of trying to tie good gameplay and good storyline together, along with the obvious and unrealistic demographics going on. For me, post apocalyptic settings are always an ideal setting for a great game, this game just feels more like a quick cash grab that's aimed at the younger generations with lower attention spans that are attracted to bright colors and constant action that doesn't necessarily have to make sense. 

My score for this game is 6.5. Not horrible overall, but a pretty shallow and uninspiring, fast action type of game, with TOO MUCH PINK. (there, I said it) I'm not very sure that I'm going to finish it.

Far Cry 5, but less gigabytes. It is a really good sequel to Far Cry 5.

The first hour was amazing, a lush forest, new post-apocalyptic setting, but after 5 hours the novelty wore off and it turned out the game did not have much to offer.

Finished the whole game in 20 hours, didn't even try to speedrun it.
Played on highest difficulty, never upgraded the health station for more health, still made it through without a sweat.

There are items for crafting, but they are not relevant as you barely need to do any damage to kill things anyways.

The random legendary bears in the woods were more of a threat than the final boss fight.

I'd rate this a solid 8.5/10.  If you like Far Cry, this is one to play.  Good story (play FC5 before this one), good game play, I like guns/ranged weapons and there are lots to choose from with pros/cons, loadouts can suit your owns strengths.  You can run through it for a challenge, or grind/collect stuff to level up and gain advantage over the enemy.  This game is well focused for an open world game.   I liked it about as much as Assassins Creed Valhalla (although that game is much bigger and longer).  Nothing revolutionary here (like Horizon Zero Dawn) but a strong and solid game.

I actually enjoyed playing this game more than Far Cry 5.  I'm almost 40 hours into this game, and I feel like I might be close to finishing it,  So if that's true New Dawn will take me half the time to beat as Far Cry 5.   This takes place in the aftermath of Far Cry 5, so it is essentially the same map re-skinned, however it was visually different enough that for me it was an advantage (I loved the landscape in FC5 so much I was daydreaming about moving to Hope Montana - minus the cultists).  New Dawn was new but at the same time familiar.  This game is clearly much more than a large DLC pack, but maybe not quite big and new enough as Far Cry 5.  

Why did I like this better?  Being my second Far Cry game, maybe it was because everything was already familiar to me.  The weapons, vehicles, the flow of the game.  I had already developed a bit of a strategy by end of the first game that I was able to walk into this one more prepared.  In this game I used a bit more stealth (re capturing Outposts) and it made the difference.  I liked the enhancements of this game, visually, also the Roster was simpler (I didn't really take advantage of the specialists in FC5).  I liked how you could re capture each outpost at higher difficulties each time.  I also like that you can make the difficulty fit your needs.  Too difficult?  Grind/collect a little more to level up and gain an advantage.   Do more challenges to get more Perks.  Do some expeditions to get more raw materials to craft.   And re-capture outposts to level up your home base.  New Dawn felt more focused (maybe more arcadey as others put it), but as someone who isn't a hard core gamer who doesn't like to be an expert at the game (like Witcher 3), I liked the streamlining from FC5.  Took me a while to discover armor piercing and incendiary bullets, but once I did it was an absolute game changer.  I no longer even needed my wingman most of the time.  

In Summary, I think people who didn't recommend the game were upset because it wasn't exactly what they wanted.  But I think this game went a long way to accommodate multiple types of player strategies, skill levels, and experience levels.   It definitely gave more structure vs FC5, but I think that was a good thing.   In the end, go in with an open mind, see how the aftermath of FC5 plays out, play it the way that suits you, and have fun.

I don't hate it, it looks nice, runs nice (130~ FPS RTX 3070 & AMD 5800X3D), there's a pretty interesting but ultimately underwhelming tier system for outposts and other off the map missions but its nothing special.

Overall I would only reccomend this game to a fan of the series who's already played the other ones, other than that, I would just play FC3,FC4, or FC6, they are all much better.

Title: Far Cry New Dawn: A Post-Apocalyptic Adventure Packed with Twists

(Spoiler for Far Cry 5 a little bit into the review)

Rating: 4/5

Far Cry New Dawn takes players on a thrilling journey through a post-apocalyptic world, serving as a standalone sequel to Far Cry 5. Developed by Ubisoft, this first-person shooter game injects a vibrant mix of action, exploration, and storytelling into a familiar open-world formula. While it may not revolutionize the genre, Far Cry New Dawn offers an enjoyable experience with a unique twist on the franchise.

One of the standout features of Far Cry New Dawn is its stunning visual presentation. The vibrant and colorful post-apocalyptic setting, juxtaposed with the ruins of a devastated world, creates a striking contrast that is visually captivating. The game's attention to detail is commendable, from the lush landscapes to the dilapidated structures that populate the environment.

The story of Far Cry New Dawn is set seventeen years after the nuclear catastrophe that occurred at the end of Far Cry 5. Players find themselves in a world where society is slowly rebuilding amid the chaos. The narrative introduces new characters, including the ruthless twins Mickey and Lou, who make for compelling antagonists. While the overall story might not reach the heights of its predecessor, it offers enough intrigue and emotional moments to keep players engaged throughout their adventure.

The gameplay in Far Cry New Dawn remains true to the series' roots. Players will engage in a variety of missions, which can be approached with different playstyles. The Gun for Hire system returns, allowing players to recruit specialists with unique abilities to assist in combat situations. The addition of makeshift weapons, crafted from scavenged materials, adds a layer of customization and resource management to the gameplay.

The game's world is filled with outposts to liberate, treasure hunts to embark upon, and side quests to undertake. While some of the activities may feel familiar to series veterans, the post-apocalyptic setting injects a fresh sense of urgency and desperation into the experience. The expeditions, which take players to new locations outside the main map, are particularly enjoyable, providing a change of pace and a chance to discover valuable resources.

Far Cry New Dawn's cooperative multiplayer mode allows players to team up with a friend and tackle the challenges of the wasteland together. This adds another layer of enjoyment to the game, as players can strategize and coordinate their actions, further enhancing the sense of camaraderie within the chaotic world.

One area where Far Cry New Dawn falls slightly short is in the depth of its mechanics and progression system. While the gameplay remains solid and satisfying, the RPG elements and character progression feel somewhat limited. The upgrade tree lacks complexity, resulting in a sense of shallowness that could have been further explored to add more depth to the experience.

Overall, Far Cry New Dawn is a worthy addition to the franchise. Its vibrant world, engaging storyline, and action-packed gameplay provide an entertaining experience for fans of the series and newcomers alike. While it may not push the boundaries of the genre, it delivers an enjoyable adventure with enough twists and surprises to keep players invested. If you're looking for a post-apocalyptic shooter with a familiar but captivating formula, Far Cry New Dawn is definitely worth a try.

How Is it?: As someone who has fully completed every FarCry Game in the current franchise this one I'd say definitely holds up even being one of the in between spin-off games. How long is it?: It is short and I was able to 100% the full progression and buy/unlock everything there is to in only 53 hours. Are the Graphics good?: The graphics while not being as good as its predecessor (FarCry 5) are still beautiful and I found myself admiring the environment multiple times. Hows the story?: Honestly its story seemed limited since it was so short, in my opinion maybe if it was longer they could have done better with it and the villains of the story were just straight villains with a sort of "I'm an ass, just because" and even when the game tried to make them have a backstory or anything it didn't really change anything and left me still thinking they could've been more fleshed out. The best thing about the story is that it follows up on its predecessor after the bombs had been dropped, which I think is a very cool concept since this explains what happened to everyone's lives after and how they survived. Overall Rating?: Everything considered 6.5/10, the game is a spin-off which I can understand for why it's so short but because of that so much is practically cut and leaves the anticipation after finishing FarCry 5 to a sort of "let down" feeling. They took a huge concept and minimized it to its bare bones. Even so it's probably the best spin-off game so far and in my opinion could have been a candidate for FarCry 6

Honestly the Far Cry games are going downhill at this point. 3 and 4 were great but 5 started the downward trend with the protag getting captured fifty million times. As for this one, the follow up? Fallout: Far Cry? It's feeling more like an arcade game with each game. The animals have gotten so ridiculous and extreme now that you can unload an LMG into one and not even stop it from attacking, let alone kill it. Enemies are accurate beyond belief, nailing you all the way to the horizon when you're moving evasively and at full sprint. The perk system isn't as good as 5, having less perks and far less utility in the ones that are there. Weapon selection consists mainly of just multiple skins of the same weapons that have stats depending on how expensive they are. Despite being a full price title, every attempt is made to push micro transactions to make getting the best weapons easier.

Graphics: Pretty much the same as 5.
Sound: Ditto.
Gameplay: Roughly the same, but with tougher enemies, especially animals.
Story: Basic bullies and trying to take over, take them out.

The take? It's a step down and more repetitive despite having far less to do. I give it a 5/10.

This game tries to tell a story and fails. I wished for the entire duration of play that it would resolve...it failed to deliver that resolution. After 10 or so hours of grinding to upgrade weaponry to "legendary" and get all the "perks", I played thru the lion's share of the story in an evening. This is not Far Cry. This is another game, another style, another experience entirely. If it had been divorced from anything to do with the Far Cry franchise, I would have had a much better and more positive opinion; but the immediate comparison to anything to do with Far Cry 5 made this game fall flat on it's face. FC5 is without a doubt, my favorite in the collection, so there was really no way for this game to rise to that level.

If you haven't ever played Far Cry, don't start here. If you have, don't saddle yourself with the disappointment this offers.

The gameplay of Far Cry New Dawn is similar to its predecessor, offering a mix of first-person shooting, exploration, and open-world activities. Players can engage in various missions, side quests, and activities such as hunting, scavenging, and base building. The game also incorporates elements of RPG progression, allowing players to upgrade their abilities and equipment as they progress.
The post-apocalyptic setting is appreciated for bringing new challenges and gameplay mechanics.
It's worth noting that individual opinions on games can vary, and it's always best to check more recent reviews or play the game yourself to form your own opinion.

After beating the game once, i want to give a quick review about this game (NO SPOILER SO NO STORY REVIEW)

(NOTE) : This is Full Far Cry game that sets years after the collapse happened, which depending on how you play it, it might took you 20 hours to beat it first time. 

(WORLD/ENVIRONMENT) : Despite the Apocalyptic settings, the Environment are still lush, instead of dead depressing wasteland instead we got an Apocalyptic world that is lush and colorful but still includes the Ruined and Abandoned remnants of what was Hope County

(GRAPHICS) The graphics were uh.....for me it looks worse than Far Cry 5, The coloring which makes Far Cry 5 looks realistic is totally absent. But definitely has it own apocalyptic art style thats pretty on its own way. Performance wise, im a mid end user but likes playing on higher settings....I notice more FPS drop and stuttering in New Dawn compared to FC5. but im, sure if you have a nice rig you wont notice a different.

(GAMEPLAY) : Though still a Far Cry. this game tries to be a bit different in terms of Gameplay. its a bit more RPG-ish not only theres enemy leveling, but also Weapons and Character Attribute, some people not like it, but i appreciate what they were trying to do with it. besides it makes combat more difficult (of course you still can play on easy). and for weapons they entirely removes the customization system, Which i despised :(

(EXPLORATION) : From my experience. i liked to explore Hope County after The Collapse. but as the game progressed i just sort of dont care about it at all even still there are interesting collectibles and story you'd find while exploring.

(OVERVIEW) : This game tried to be different, but in the end it still has those repetitive gameplay loop that other Far Cry games has, and this game has no replay value whatsoever. I wouldnt recommend this game to anyone, even if that someone played far cry 5. This game feels like an unnecessary sequel to it. i give it a (6.8/10)

A fantastic sequel to Farcry 5...I think it is also a better game.  Components and crafting are great, I love the Expeditions which feel almost arcade like and take you out of Hope County.  Good catching up with New Eden again and working through the story with a nice nod with the Judge. Lots of opportunities for taking objectives in new ways.

On the story it doesn't really bother me.  I like the feel of the game since the world has ended and your're fighting a larger organisation (The Highwaymen) of which the twins are only a small part (hence the supply drops from other chapters).  The fact that the place is still riddled with Highwaymen even after areas have been liberated is also great. Farcry 5 has nobody to kill once you have wasted all three siblings so it gets a little dull!

Only downside is Herk.  Absolute car crash of a companion.  Constantly complaining about dying, constantly shooting his rubbish rocket launcher badly and constantly not reviving me when I am down.  The dog on the other hand...and the sniper? Fanstastic.  Getting 15 kills with Herk was painful...Nana didn't even break a sweat...she is the grim reaper encarnate.

Honestly, I always get bored of the numbered Far Cry games about a third of the way through.

That's honestly why I really liked New Dawn: It's about 1/3 of a Far Cry game.

$40 is a bit steep, but if you can get it on sale for $10-$20, New Dawn is a fun time.

The Twins are nothing special as antagonists. I don't think they deserve the hate I've seen, but they're by no means iconic. Still, I was so painfully bored by the generic villains in Far Cry 5, The Twins actually come across as doubly interesting by comparison. 

Combat, vehicles, perks, companions, and "stuff to do" are all boilerplate Far Cry staples. If you like those, you'll like this...

For the most part, the Far Cry series are classics. The series belongs every bit in the same conversation with the other full 3D shooters that laid the groundwork for the genre, beginning with the frantic evil of Quake (which Bethesda has most graciously granted a recent update which utterly revived the game), progressing with the high adventure and chatty NPCs of Half-Life, followed by the brilliant RPG and stealth elements added by the original Deus Ex, which gave us the first real taste of non-linear game-play and open world exploration (notably also recently revived by a brilliant mod called Revision, available here on Steam), and then expanded into further open world goodness with the first Far Cry.

Far Cry New Dawn isn't the best in the series, but it isn't the worst either. Those honors, in my opinion, belong to Far Cry 2, Far Cry 4 and Far Cry Primal. I won't say any of those games are "terrible", but some of the Far Cry entries set a very high standard, notably Far Cry 3, which still felt entirely enjoyable by current AAA gaming standards just months ago when I played through it again. With the exception of the first two games, Far Cry and Far Cry 2, the entire series maintains high fidelity graphics to this day. Some of the Far Cry games do have better settings and game-play mechanics than others (by mechanics, I mean stuff to do in the game, more than the gun-play, which has been remarkably consistent throughout the entire series) and for that reason I'd say Far Cry 3 is still my favorite (c'mon, Citra, the classic pixel-babe experience of our time), followed by Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon (which was an absolutely rocking fun and stylish game, a real booster shot for the series), then Far Cry New Dawn and last place would go to Far Cry 5, which I felt barely made the grade. It was a shame that the Hours of Darkness add-on for Far Cry 5 suffered from so many performance issues, and Far Cry 4's setting just didn't appeal to me visually or geographically, a game I found too dull to get into, especially after just having had an utter romp with Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon.

So Far Cry New Dawn takes Far Cry 5's gameplay (much the way Blood Dragon was an extension of FC3) into a vibrant post-apocalypse (not a bad twist, considering the existing abundance of shooters set in a drab post-apocalypse) and adds some colorful spins on the resident wildlife, as well as some weapons that stand out from the rest of the series. While it doesn't boast the 3 juicy add-ons that Far Cry 5 received (FC5's add-ons were great, they were each like a whole new game within the game with huge maps of their own to explore), it's still solid, classic Far Cry in all it's open world, shooty goodness.

Animals are, ONCE AGAIN, stupidly bullet-spongy, but I suppose, since in this entry of the Far Cry series the world is full of mutant animals, and the animals appear to have boss versions and such, they decided to go a bit the ARPG route. It's not quite as bothersome as it is in say Far Cry 3 or Far Cry 5, where those games are presumably supposed to be realistic (but just aren't, ever, because Ubisoft's designers make braindead decisions with their otherwise great games...).

I preferred the ability to salvage outposts and let enemies retake them so that you could re-capture them at a higher tier over Far Cry 5's "Outpost Master" mode, as it felt integrated into the game. At first I felt Far Cry New Dawn's map was too small, but when I realized this replay element it changed my outlook on the game, and brought the game up to speed with what Far Cry 5 offered for gameplay. That and the addition of some mini-maps inside the game via the available "expeditions" really rounded out the content-to-value ratio for me.

Sadly the game suffers from occasional performance issues which require you to reboot periodically, similarly to the Hours of Darkness add-on for FC5. Also, I found several of the weapons just wonky-looking, a shame, since the game is better than FC5 but has inferior weaponry. Also not sure that I enjoyed the weapons having "levels", a large deviation from the rest of the series, and quite unrealistic.

8/10 - the series, once again, COULD GREATLY MERIT FROM SURVIVAL ELEMENTS THAT MAKE USE OF ALL THE MEAT AND FISH YOU HUNT. C'mon... Talk about 1-dimensional game design.

Far Cry New Dawn is a spin-off to the Far Cry series and a direct sequel to Far Cry 5. Set 17 years after the events of Far Cry 5, the game takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where the player has to survive and fight against a new enemy, the Highwaymen.

One of the main features of Far Cry New Dawn is the open world, which is stunning and immersive. The game takes place in a vibrant and colorful world that is both beautiful and dangerous. From lush forests to desolate wastelands, the environment is filled with a variety of wildlife and enemy factions. The graphics are impressive, with vibrant colors and sharp details that make the world come to life.

Gameplay-wise, Far Cry New Dawn is similar to its predecessor, with a mix of exploration, crafting, and combat. The player has to scavenge for resources, craft weapons and gear, and take on missions to progress the story. The combat is intense and satisfying, with a wide range of weapons and abilities to choose from. The game also introduces new elements, such as the ability to recruit specialists and upgrade facilities.

One of the highlights of Far Cry New Dawn is the story, which is engaging and well-written. The game follows the story of the player, who is a survivor of the nuclear apocalypse. The player joins a group of survivors known as the Prosperity, led by the charismatic Thomas Rush. The Prosperity is under attack from the Highwaymen, a group of raiders who are pillaging the countryside for resources. The player must work with the Prosperity to defeat the Highwaymen and restore order to the wasteland.

The characters in Far Cry New Dawn are well-developed, with their own personalities and motivations. The player interacts with a variety of characters, including the members of the Prosperity, the Highwaymen leaders, and other survivors. Each character has their own story, and the player's choices can affect their relationships and outcomes.

Overall, Far Cry New Dawn is an excellent addition to the Far Cry series. The open world is stunning and immersive, the gameplay is engaging and satisfying, and the story is well-written and engaging. If you're a fan of the Far Cry series or post-apocalyptic games, then Far Cry New Dawn is definitely worth playing.

I will recommend to any full on Far Cry fan, but don't expect the polish and quality of 3 through 6.  From the overall, look, artistic style, voice acting, and some really unfortunate, at times, dialogue.  This is like a B-Team version of a Far Cry game, with some similar assets, but without the polish.  You might say, some aspects they dropped the ball, but I'm not sure if they were ever carrying it THAT SAID....

I did enjoy this game, in all of it's imperfections.  This feels like something 10 years older than it is.  The Twins were quite diabolical and were among the best voiced characters with the better dialogue.  They could have been better fleshed out, to make them more interesting, but they definitely gave me the feel of really wanting to destroy them, so in that aspect, they did the job quite well.  There is at least one weapon introduced, that I have not seen before, that I got quite a bit of fun out of.  I played it on Hard difficulty, and a few of the companions are just dynamite, quite fun to play with.  I also love the idea of revisiting Hope County many years after the collapse to see who survived and get some closure on the story.  I wish they would have really treated this as one of the numbered releases, and bump up the overall quality of most of the elements.  The final boss fight, actually requires some strategy to work out, so that was fun as well and a welcome change.

If you grab it on sale, you really can't go wrong.  Enjoy it for what is it and revisit some old friends.

I just got the game not long ago and I already like it a lot but I don't love it. Far Cry 5 set a high standard for me for New Dawn and there are some things that I like about the game but there are also some things that I don't care for. I like that they made it mandatory to hunt different species due to the trade system instead of just selling skins for money like Far Cry 5. It's also nice that it isn't just find a grinding method for money and get all the guns that you want and that you are forced to collect different materials in order to craft the weapons that you want.  I also like that then enemies will get more difficult through out the game making it necessary to upgrade your stuff through out the game. Now what I don't like. I personally played Far Cry 5 stealth and I did really well but it is very difficult to do in this one from what I find. I would love to be able to add a suppressor to any gun I want even if I needed to get materials to craft it. That is my one biggest complaint with New Dawn and it isn't just the lack of being able to put a suppressor on any gun but just the lack of gun customization in general. Other than this one big complaint, it is a great game and is really a good game when comparing to Far Cry 5. I would recommend this to someone looking for something different to play but the lack of gun customization is the biggest downfall for me personally.

The game itself is probably teetering between a 6.5/10 - 7/10.  Definitely not anywhere near the best Far Cry but still enough fun at moments if you are into these types of games.  However the boss fight is by far the worst boss fight I have ever played in a game.  Literally the worst.  It's hard to believe a professional game designer came up with until your remember that the goal was probably to extend the game's playtime as much as possible so Ubisoft could pass it off as a full priced release.

Far Cry New Dawn, the game that just wouldn't leave me alone! I mean, seriously, this game is like a clingy ex who just can't take a hint. Every time I tried to shut it down, it would just keep running in the background, begging for my attention.

For those who haven't played it, Far Cry New Dawn is a post-apocalyptic first-person shooter game where you play as the Captain, a survivor trying to rebuild society in a world ravaged by nuclear war. And while the game is a lot of fun, it's also a bit of a stalker.

No matter how many times I tried to quit the game, it would just keep running in the background, hogging up all my CPU and RAM. 

But despite its clinginess, I have to admit that I had a lot of fun playing Far Cry New Dawn. The open-world gameplay was as engaging as ever, and the post-apocalyptic setting gave the game a unique twist. Plus, the graphics were really impressive, and the storyline was surprisingly engaging.

Overall, if you're looking for a fun and engaging post-apocalyptic shooter, then Far Cry New Dawn is definitely worth checking out. Just be prepared for a game that just won't take no for an answer.

I have been having fun with this game but I wont exactly recommend it. its playable, but its like they tryed to copy every other post nuke game and got all of it partly wrong. Gold star. 

comparatively to the main game, everything is "crafted" and in tires, however each a level 1 gun will do little to no damage to a level 3 enemy, resulting in some guns just being strait up better then others. without customization, it severely limits your choices, and with increasing rarity materials, it limits it even further. You can also just buy, as in real world cash, some guns. Im not surer why every tire of the saw gun causes it add more saws so it fires like a shotgun, id rather just have it single. 

for whatever reason they also made some things, mostly custom parts, drop from a chance pool at specific areas. it effectually pads out the replay ability of the node, if you wanted something specific, but again, you can just pay real world cash for it. the replay system also gets harder the more you do it. 

One of the things I will say I like was the expedition thing. It is required to craft max tire gear as its the only source of circuit boards that iv found so far (other then some epic trade ins, but you need epid gear to be able to damage them), but it gives enough to craft a gun within one or two runs. The reason I like it however is it drops you into a semi large open map area with drastically different locals. These are often reuses assets from the DLCs and cut areas from the main game, but its a nice change of setting. Some of these areas seem to be very far away from where the game is ment to be set (Montana to Alcatraz prison being about 19.5 hours), and we are asked to believe that the raiders adhear to the same style and command... but at that point im just nit picking. 

Pading out the gamepaly seems to be a theam with it, and thats why I will say its not woth the full price its being asked for. On sale, maby. its amusingly fun. but do not expect a full game.
