This whole game is built around microtransaction. Most basic stuff like fast travel is locked behind upgrades/perks. This should be included in the game right from the beginning.  You also have to level up your weapons and abilities to defeat the higher level enemies you encounter when you progress further in the game.  You can unlock this using perk points or upgrade materials, but you really have to grind for these. You also can buy them with real money with the "conveniently" placed buy button in your upgrade screen. I stopped playing after a few hours in. I am not going to waste my time grinding for all this and I certainly not going to spend actual money to speed this process up. Do not waste your money on this one. It is not worth it.

In short, this game was definitely worth the money (I got it on sale in a bundle with Far Cry 5 and had all the deluxe upgrades). The story was solid, not super repetitive, unlike its predecessor, and took about 16 hours for me to complete. I also finished all of the side missions and outposts to three stars. Overall, I'm very satisfied with the game. After Far Cry 5's storyline was "meh" (despite having beautiful graphics and fun stealth mechanics), I was intent to wait for Far Cry 6 to go on sale some time after release. I think this game rekindled the fire for Far Cry and showed me again what it could be. Lots of great challenges, great scenery and graphics as usual, and the classic enemies you love to hate. I'm not sure why this game didn't get more attention, but I know that I'll most certainly be tuning in for the series' next installment later this year.

Far Cry New Dawn is an action-adventure game set in a post-apocalyptic world where players try to survive in a devastated Montana. The game is full of action, adventure and suspense and offers players an incredibly fun experience.

The game takes place after the events of the previous Far Cry 5 and players must confront a group called the Highwaymen who control the area and terrorize the locals. Players have a variety of different weapons and equipment to choose from, allowing them to customize their character to their liking.

The game also offers the ability to build your own base, which is important for improving your abilities and getting better equipment. Players must also collect resources and resources to upgrade their base and weapons.

The graphics of the game are fantastic and thoroughly crafted. Players can enjoy stunningly beautiful views of post-apocalyptic Montana and each location has its own distinctive features. The sound effects are also great and help players perceive the game's surrounding world.

Far Cry New Dawn is a great game for fans of the Far Cry series and for anyone looking for an action-packed adventure full of suspense and fun. The game offers a wide variety of activities and challenges, meaning players will never get bored. I recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun and adrenaline-pumping experience in a post-apocalyptic world.

If you thought post-apocalyptic America could not get any worse, think again. In this game, you will be running around the irradiated ruins of Montana, fighting off mutated animals, and hostile motorcross bandits.

You will also be fighting alongside a bunch of kooky survivors who seem to have learned everything they know about combat from '80s action movies.

The game is fun. It is Far Cry 5 that has been dipped it in a vat of neon paint and radioactive waste. The new "Expeditions" mode is especially cool, where you get to take your squad on little trips to places.

All in all, if you like blowing stuff up, shooting things, and driving around in a rainbow-colored muscle car, you will probably enjoy this.

[h1]Positives:[/h1]

+Gunplay. It's not the best I've ever seen but it's well done and enjoyable.

+Good ties to Far Cry 5. You see how some characters have grown up, got children, and how some never did grown up.

+Soundtrack. Some amazing tracks and some good ones. Overall very nice.

+I like the post apocalyptic re-design of the weapons.

+It gets rid of the repetitiveness  of the main missions from 5 where you do a couple of missions then blow up a building then repeat.

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]

-Glitches. My god. I played this game 3 months after release and it's still buggy. Missions won't finish and require a restart. Following NPCs is a chore since they never go to the mission and hunt anything outside their path and start trouble with nearby enemies I can't even see. Whenever I fast traveled I got a glitch that has a chance of maybe 75% happening, the statistic is out of my ass but to me, It genuinly happened most of the times, I cannot move when fast travelling. I have to fast travel again to another place then back and hope it doesn't happen again. or I have to die completely then respawn. Also happens when you fast travel but sky dive. You just stand there in the air.

-Unfortunately it takes a lot of the negatives of 5's story. Slow pace, nothing is meaningful.

-Bad villains. like really bad. Cliche to the bone.

-As much as it is a [i]sequel[/i] to 5. It really isn't. Yeah it has some characters from before but nothing really happens. At the end they just tie some loose ends very forcefully.

-Silent protagonist. I just don't like them. i might tolerate them in a choice based game but not in this.

-RPG elements feel tacked on. All they do is make the main mission's impossible without grinding out to get more resources to put in the camp so you can just get [i]stronger[/i] weapons to be able to damage the enemies.

-Because of the RPG elements. There is no longer weapon customisations. Which is a bummer. Weapon you like but not the scope you like? Too bad.

-Only 1 new weapon. [i]one![/i]. They are lazy as lazy can be.

-It shares a problem with 5. Weapons are below your armpit so you can't really see them while your playing. It just looks dumb. I like to admire my weapons while playing an FPS, Not see the tip of their nose!. And don't come to me with "it's more realistic!" [b]You can double jump in the game![/b]

-Near the middle of the game Joseph seed gives you some extra skills that are superhuman. I like them, like double jumping and super strength and stealth. But while playing CO-OP, It doesn't transfer to your buddy.

-MTX. Most skins are now purchasble with the [i]far cry currency[/i] but in order to actually make you pay, Unlike 5 where it was easy to get them, Now you have to do a single camp multiple times and every time there's a percentage to get 1/4 from the armor set specific to that camp.

-Recycling of NPCs. I saw the same NPC like 8 times. And she isn't a background character, She gives you the treasure missions like 5.

-Typical Ubisoft open world design of filling the map with boring things to collect and do.

-I did all the of the main missions and unlocked nearly every specialist and partner and did most of the side missions I got and still I haven't unlocked the whole map. This game barely uses it's map. Unlike far cry 5 where I unlocked it all while normally playing.


[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
Some things better than 5 a lot of things worse than 5. So overall, I say don't buy it.

Like most recent Farcry games, this is another one that doesn't fall short but falls off a cliff instead. 

They have changed the formula for Farcry games for a while now and in my opinion is only making the game go downhill, even though this is a full price game it is filled with enough bugs and glitches or even AI issues that you would most likely encounter at least a handful in a play through of the game. I am or was a fan of the Farcry series but the direction that the team producing Farcry is heading not a good one as there was a lot of weird/terrible decisions featured in Farcry New Dawn. For example, why is there paid micro-transactions in a singleplayer story game? and i know there will be people who says that there is multiplayer gameplay and it isn't fair to call it a singleplayer game but the co-op experience doesn't do anything for the game at all, it's the same content that you play in singleplayer without a dumb AI companion running around. Speaking of content, there is no replayability, there isn't anything cool that you get hunting unique animals, there isn't anything you can do with the base or ethanol after you maxed it out so its just sitting there,there is no point to leveling up certain skills as they have little to no use, you can scrap the outpost for ethanol that you don't need(after a certain point). 

I'm just writing down what comes to mind as i write this review so it might not even be coherent but so is this game.

tl;dr
If i knew how the gameplay and systems was like before purchasing Farcry New Dawn, I would have payed for a game that actually deserve my time and money.

A good but underdeveloped sequel to FC5

This game ties up some of the loose ends left in Far Cry 5 and gives a satisfying conclusion to the story of Joseph Seed however it isn't without faults. It removed many of the things I liked about FC5 and things I did not like. It is much more grindy, lay heavily into crafting new weapons and vehicles with resources that supposed to be scarce but you end up with so many that it doesn't really matter, adds base building that is relatively unimportant visually and story wise, and the driving force of any Far Cry games, while compelling are underdeveloped and could of heavily benefited from more interactions and backstory. However, it is not a bad game, the gunplay is awesome, something as a gun nut, I appreciate a game trying to at least be somewhat accurate at time to functionality and appearance. My favorite guns of FC5, the Sin Eater and MG42 made a reappearance which was great.  The graphics are great just like in the original however the varied scenery of FC5 is not as noticeable and certainly seeing Purple everywhere gets old after awhile. The Highwaymen are some of the coolest looking bad guys in the series in my opinion, I love the design behind them and once I got my hands on a highwayman outfit, that is what I wore for the rest of the game. Also, one of my main complainants with most Ubisoft games on Steam is that they do not have Achievements. In the end, I wish the game was a little longer storywise, more things to do on the side that aren't repetitive, and the Twins, the main villians, to be a little better developed however it was a blast to play at times and the Treasure hunts were fun. I would suggest you get it on sale in the Far Cry bundle like I did. I hope Ubisoft listens to its playerbase to improve its future games and also add achievements on Steam please!!!

A sequel to far cry 5, and so much worse. Don't know how they screwed up a sequel, all they had to do was keep game systems consistent. Instead of weapons doing real damage to every enemy, it can takes entire mags to kill one dude. The fact that dumping 20 rounds into a bear's head doesn't kill it is frustrating and moronic. FC5 allows you to (usually) kill an enemy instantly with a headshot, encouraging accurately placed shots instead of spray and pray. Weapon tier system is trash, AND they removed weapon customization so screw you, you can ONLY use weapons that come with a suppressor pre-attached if you want to use stealth. Saw gun thing is okay, but I really don't like using it. Only real benefit is it's ricochet mechanic.

Same exact gameplay as FC5, yet botched. Enemies instantly see you half of the time, so stealth is idiotically difficult. Ubisoft decided to change keys around, so parachute is now "f" instead of the spacebar and you can no longer use the scroll wheel to switch between weapons. Why would they do this? FC5's controls flowed nicely, then this game comes along and scrambles it up.


Scavenged parts system is fine, considering it's semi-post-apocalyptic. It's cool to see old characters. If want to buy it on sale, fine, but know it's not nearly as good as FC5, which wasn't especially "good" to begin with.

(Editing this review following the end of a second play-through, March 2023)
 
The good: a relatively slick, polished game that could be said to refine the Far Cry formula. More streamlined than Far Crys 3, 4, and 5 - in a good way. Looks and sounds very good; runs almost flawlessly. On my first play-through (2021), I had a solid 60fps maxed out at 1440p on my system of the time (i7 9700k, GTX1080, 16GB RAM). The game delivered over 50hrs on my first play-through. Playing a second time two years later, I streamlined things considerably by using fast travel and skipping some dialogues. This cut the play-time to just under 30hrs. The story is moderately compelling and generally doesn't impede the free-play mayhem until later in the game. The (still expansive) open world edit of Far Cry 5's Hope County focusses the gameplay. The mechanic of repeatedly taking outposts with more alarms, rewards, and higher-level enemies works well. Repeatable away missions to other, smaller, play areas were a nice addition. Also fun were the light puzzles and problem solving sequences involving hunting down parts at locations or opening abandoned prepper stashes. This is something that might be developed further as it provides a relaxing counterpoint to combat. 

The less good: certain game mechanics that impede player choice and/or bear witness to weaknesses in writing. For example, the repeatable away missions to seven other locations are a great idea and generally fun, but I disliked the 'hold the fort' mechanic at the conclusion of these missions, where you have to hold enemies at bay for a few minutes whilst waiting for a rescue heli. The option to perform these missions entirely via stealth (a la the outposts in the main game space) would seem more in keeping with the overall logic of the game. Later in the game, there is a somewhat frustrating race-the-clock sequence of rescuing hostages before bombs go off. More puzzles that the player can solve at their leisure and that, perhaps, flesh out the story would seem more in keeping with the open-world game-play that, in my view, is the strength of the Far Cry franchise. Finally, the end-game sequence includes a couple of boss fights. Whilst this is a matter of personal taste, I found these slug-fests a bit tiresome.

On the whole, Far Cry New Dawn did not engage me quite as much on a second play-through, but was still enjoyable overall. The open-world gameplay, taking down outposts via stealth, etc., and the RPG-esque ability to upgrade your character and weapons were, for me, the most appealing parts of the game. Like many similar games out there, things can become less enjoyable when, in its drive to tell its story, New Dawn forces the player into more linear, pre-scripted scenarios and sequences - but I admit that this is very subjective.

An actual sequel to Far Cry 5, this feels like a stand alone expansion. Post apocalypse Montana isn't that different from the open world of Montana in FC5: just with mutants, radiation, and people LARPing Mad Max in full cosplay with live ammunition. The story takes place years after the ending of 5, though it does give you some follow up and ties up some loose ends. If you were disappointing by the ending of 5, this might make up for that, despite how predictable things tend to get as it seems Ubisoft still uses much of the same formula with their writing.

If there's anything different to be said about gameplay, its that its FC5 with just more options to be ridiculously OP by mid to late game. With the Gifts of Eden you get berserker damage, invisibility, and double jump all while unaccounting for the workbench that lets you craft weapons and upgrade them to absurd amounts of damage. By endgame, with the combination of skills and upgrades, you'll likely have more bullets and rifle rounds on you than the entire US with more missiles than a rogue nation overcompensating for penis envy, while being nearly invisible to most enemies until you decide to finally give them every flavor of death you have. Expeditions make an appearance in this game, which is welcome due to the amount of materials you get from them and can farm them which brings me to one of the drawbacks: the grind. This game is more grindy than FC5, waaaay more. You always have room to increase certain skills, you can always upgrade your guns just a slight more. Sky is the limit with how far you can push your ammunition capacity in addition to weapon damage and throwable capacity. If there is a cap, I sure don't know about it, and I'm already capable of holding dozens of rockets, and thousands of bullets and flamethrower fuel. Once you get to midgame/endgame, it really does feel like just an exercise in how broken you can get.

Do I recommend? Sure, if you don't mind the material grinding. Otherwise its just FC5 with a post apocalypse paint job and super powers.

It's a nice Far Cry game, only one quirk that I have with is that it kind of runs bad on a very modern/recent computer. This has kind of been somewhat of a thread with Far Cry games in and of the past but in essence on older technologies it wasn't such a big deal only that today with really beefy hardware it's a bit of a shame really.  As the saying goes: Can it run Crysis? But, can it run Far Cry?

The game is playable and enjoyable enough though, even though somewhat janky with framerate drops in certain areas and during certain situations which isn't the end of the world because overall it feels smooth enough, I just wish that it ran more stable/consistent on higher frame rates but the content is really what matters here and this is what I really like about these games and generally from Ubisoft games, is that the games are in essence fun to play and offer decently good storylines with pretty good voice acting and action. Again, optimalization could and should be better IMHO but that is looking and hoping to the future for.

(Far Cry) Games do look amazing though, and this is I think a balance that's been struck between performance and visual quality that has to sacrifice some smoothness in order for its presentation to be in effect as it is.

Talking of quality, I really enjoy the storytelling that is interweaved with basically constant action in game and in a way since Far Cry 3 (Far Cry 1 and 2 had sort of a minimalistic approach to storylines/storytelling but that doesn't mean that those were bad) this has been something of a reoccurring theme and something that has been keeping me coming back for more, because next to the casual/loose/funny/entertaining storytelling the game has the tendency to sometimes make a serious point in its (literal) storytelling just like with some scenes it depicts so whenever a new game comes out I tend to think what will it be and to wonder, what will it show next? Opposite to just always complaining how the formula is copy and paste in which sense as the old adage goes: if it's not broken, why try to fix it?

I am kind of fine with it.

I like what is on offer here and hope that there will be more games brought out by Ubi, here on Steam and in a way hope that it will be possible ea. that the company will have a long life to continue to give.

Before I started playing this I heard only bad things about this game. But I was pleasently surprised. The game brings fun and new game mechanics never seen before in other Far Cry games (big fan of the series). I didn't care for the story at all and skipped most of the cutscenes when i could, although I did like Josephs storyline. The game has it's limits, but I consider this game to be a DLC to Far Cry 5, and youll get a lot in return. Get it on sale if you can, I don't think this game is worth $45, if you can get it for under 20 bucks its a pretty good deal. I enjoyed the game.

Pros:

Better game than 5 in story, performance, graphics, gameplay, gun and enemy variety, and polish. But in doing so it feels like this is the game that 5 was meant to be or at least the mechanics and lvl of polish of this was suppose to be on or a part of 5 and was instead cut so they could push out 5 half baked and rebundled and resold the good ideals as this game. It feels like blood dragon but IMO better with a better story but loses to blood dragon in humor, self awareness, satire, and crazy weapon types (no lazer ninjastars and portable mini guns). I do feel it's a bit pricey, about 10 dollars more than it should be priced and that if you own five, you should definitely play this one, but wait for a sale especially if you bought 5 full price. However if you're a new player or a fan of the series and didn't play 5 I would say this is a must buy but again the price is a bit much for a non-mainline game so buy at full price if you're truly interested else wait for a sale. Also I would recommend you skip five completely. This is a much more fun game and feels like the snappy gunplay you expect from a FC game where 5 did some strange things so that all the guns felt very samey and also introduced projectile speed where every other FC game was hit scan. The damage in 5 was also tweaked in a weird way so that technically on paper different guns did different damage but in practice almost all guns took the same number of shots to down the same enemies with few exceptions. For example even though revolves in 5 deal 1 or 2 points (out of ten) more damage than most other pistols, it felt like they took the same number of shots to kill most enemies. Only difference was that the other pistols had less recoil, faster fire rates, and could support attachments including silencers.

All that changes here. Each gun feels unique again and they all have interesting feelings that differentiate them. No longer are all revolvers the exact same and barely stronger than non revolver pistols with the lack of attachements. Now in this game magnum type pistols do much more damage than their regular counter parts and you can feel that in the form of significantly few shots to kill. Non hand cannon guns have their own advantages such as better handleing, more ammo, better accuracy and fire rate, all things that truly make them still viable with reduced damage where as in 5 the handling and damage difference was barely noticable but the accuracy and recoil felt like the only major difference. Unfortunately you can't select your attachment of choice but this forces a variety of gameplay styles and gun types that didn't exist in 5 cuz everything there was so similar. People might not like being unable to customize but the way it was done in 5 stripped variety and worth from guns in the same class with few exceptions. Here each gun feels like it has a role and works well. For example a rifle with a bayonet will let you do take downs on enemies who have spotted you if you have a running start and they are faster to transition from melee and shooting than regular melee, ever so slightly.

Cons:

However nothing is all sunshine and rainbows. This game is filled to the brim with microtransactions and completely designed with them in mind. Nothing is hard to get but they system is there to remind you that it is there to capitalize on everything. Every weapon can be upgraded to do an extra 5 percent more damage of it's base value and this can done infinitely and the price to do so doesn't change. There are certain skills that are also like that such as the amount of ammo you can carry or med packs you can have at one time. Weapon upgrades cost resources you can farm or pay for. It's annoying but the upgrade system further fosters the variety by allowing a player to upgrade the damage of a gun they like even if it's not legendary teir to a level more powerful than a legendary. But yes the game is designed to keep you grinding and if you like the gameplay loop of classic farcry then this is for you but it will get old very very quick because of how small scale this game is and the lack of a new game plus mode. The materials for weapon upgrades are easy to get but if you pay money you can "buy"-pass grinding completely which is where this milk machine shows it's true colors. I haven't started a new game yet so I don't know if upgrades to weapons carry over and only your character is reset but whatever the case the microtransactions are completely not worth it and shouldn't be in the game

Edit: Last I remembered, you lose all your upgrade progress on weapons, gear, and skills if you start a new playthrough. Like I said, no NG+.

Conclusion:
This game is only good for the story and gameplay and they are very fun with nice characters and could have been so much more. It's great given how short it is though and I'm actually impressed that this game got me to remember the story more than all of FC5. You do lose a fair bit of impact if you didn't play FC5 and imo it definitely does make new dawn feel a lot better knowing the context of 5 and how much certain characters have to change to with the world. Former badasses are nobodies now and old enemies have new purpose and reflect on what they've done. You get to judge if it was right or wrong.

I personally don't think this is worth the $40 price tag. If it's on sale and you're really curious (or determined) about what happens after five's ending, then sure. That, and co-op are the only reasons why I finished this.

While I originally wanted to play as Rook again, I'm actually glad that wasn't the case. Seeing what *was* our character a shell of their former self was just devastating. Especially bringing them around other characters and hearing their interactions.

It's easily possible that I missed notes, recordings, and graffiti, but one little flashback is not enough for me. If anything, Rook falls in line with the franchises previous villains more than Mickey and Lou could ever hope. They both came off like a pair of brats that were having a tantrum, and the only real depth added to them is at the end. Ethan is the exact same. He wanted something, didn't get it, and proceeded to have a tantrum.

Fixing and adding onto Prosperity seemed interesting at the start, as did re-exploring Hope County, but it wore off very quickly. Especially with the repeatable outposts. It made some of the mechanics almost feel like a phone game. Liberate 3 outposts for the next building upgrade! Want to upgrade your weapon? Try an expedition! The fact that you can, if you wanted, just opt to use real money to buy them just adds onto that.

It's a strange one
It's not necessarily a bad game, but sometimes it does just feel like nothing more than a reskin of far cry 5
The base building aspect is cool, but apart from letting you craft a couple new items, it serves as nothing more than a story building system, although it does force you to go out and explore in order to upgrade, which i find quite cool.

I'm actually a fan of the antagonists, the calm/crazy aspect of them and how they essentially balance each other out is quite cool. I just wish they played a bigger role in the story.

The lack of currency is definitely this game's biggest drawback from both a lore and gameplay standpoint, let's take the Fallout franchise, for example, lore wise, society and the world as a whole are ravaged and destroyed, with a few pockets of civilisation here and there, yet they still manage to have a semi-functional currency system, while in this game, where lore-wise society is rather restored and functioning, they rely on the trade of raw materials, gameplay wise, you'll almost always find that you have an excess of materials, sort of rendering the whole system useless, while in far cry 5, i often found myself short on cash.

Other than that, the core gameplay loop differs from fc5 only slightly, while this could be seen as a negative, i'd say it's a positive, because it retains what made fc5 good

overall, i'd give it a 7/10, it's defo worth picking up and playing and not as bad as people make it out to be, but it has its drawbacks

Woohoo, more post-apocalyptic goodness for the masses! Thankfully, we got a Mad Max inspired take this time instead of another Fallout rip. That and its bright and colorful, which is new and interesting.

Now... there is a lot of talk about this game being some shallow reskin of Far Cry 5, and that really couldn't be farther from the truth. I'd go so far as to say that people who garner that opinion have probably barely played the game and likely just sat there AFK in order to get some hours in order to make their review look legitimate. Yes, there are some locations from the original story that survived for the sake of this games story, like Jacobs ranch being re-purposed as the Prosperity settlement. But that is because the game IS the sequel to Far Cry 5 and takes place years after humanity has begun to repopulate - in Hope County. Most of the locations are new and original, overtaken by plants and wildlife changed by the Bliss and radiation.

Now, the gameplay is essentially the same as FC5 with a few tweaks and even some supernatural powers near the end (getting that double-jump is the best thing to ever happen in a FC game). There is a clear attempt to make FC more RPG oriented and it comes off more like a excuse to hide a butt-load of secrets and player choice options. Like, Ubisoft REALLY wanted people to explore and dig into this world. The 48 hours I have played this game do not include completing all of the challenges, buying all the weapons, vehicles, or even all the difficulty versions of the expeditions. Nope, and I didn't obtain all the cosmetic options and costumes yet either. Holy crap!

One major issue, in my opinion, is that the vehicles are underutilized (which I found to be a issue in FC5) but here its even worse. For all the cool rides you can buy and play with, there really isn't any reason to do anything with any of them. There is literally multiple tiers of vehicles and I used them for maybe a quarter of the game. The rest of it, I spent just running around because I was doing challenges and collecting everything in all the areas/conquering all the tiers of each base. This game, THESE games, really need more vehicle challenges so we can use these cool vehicles we can get.

Anyhow, I'd say this is a definite gem. It's best played after a whole lot of FC5, and it'll give you a little something different when it comes to after-world asthetics, yeah?

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

This game is just Far Cry 5 DLC with a higher price tag and new name slapped on. It takes the fun aspects and of FC5 and makes them worse and adds annoying mechanics. The game becomes extremely repetitive near the end of the story (which its VERY short) that it feels like a waste of time. The twins are sloppily put together as antagonists and are just boring. Finishing Joseph's character arc is a nice addition but his ending is underwhelming after already ending off the other antagonists of the game. The main story has little impact and could be completed within a few hours if not for needing to upgrade and find specialists and ethanol to continue upgrading. Upgrading as a whole becomes boring and repetitive after realizing they cut down most of the map from FC5, removed most outposts, and make you repeat those smaller amount of outposts 3 more times to level up. The weapon system was also heavily downgraded just to make a false sense of difficulty to the game. My only positives are that the game itself looks very vibrant and nice. The other positives, they already perfected in FC5 and just took the assets over. Overall, Far Cry New Dawn should've been an additional DLC to Far Cry 5 that isn't worth its retail price. If you plan on getting this game, wait for a steep sale and play Far Cry 5 first.

WARNING: Mild Spoilers for FarCry 5 (this game IS a sequel to that one, after all)

Honestly, its a shame this game got slept on. Its gunplay is fun, and it takes a lot of mechanics from FarCry 5
that I thought could use some improvement and fixes them.

Previously you were kind of disincentivised to do side quests and radiant rescue missions, because it gave you Resistance Points and would get you kidnapped into a mandatory story mission when you were just trying to drive across the county to unlock a new Gun For Hire. Now instead of Resistance Points you get perk points, which helps you level up faster, so yeah, now I actually want to rescue people I find on the road rather than run away from them.

Supply trucks after a point became useless, because the weapon they'd have in them is already in my inventory. Now they ALWAYS contain craftable ingredients, and the Ethanol trucks that can sometimes spawn will help level up your home base.

Your home base! I love the base building mechanic, not only getting passive perks from upgrading your base but also seeing it visibly change. Now unlocking new vehicles and weapons isn't something you just assume will happen with story progression, you can see what is needed to do it and beeline towards it.

At first I was a bit iffy about the RPG mechanics - health bars over enemies, damage numbers when shooting, tiers of enemyes etc - but it helps me work out if the weapon I have will actually kill an enemy rather than pinging off their helmet, and it works well.

Outposts! Previously you just liberated outposts... cause, well, it was something to do I guess, and SOMETIMES it would unlock garages (but sometimes not even that). Now you get ethanol from them AND you can choose to pillage the place and abandon it, meaning bad guys will come back stronger (and with better loot!)

It even does a good job of tying into the FarCry 5 plot and answering "whatever happened to that guy?" without you NEEDING to have played the last game to get it.

Honestly if you like arcade style shooters and post-apocalyptic sessions, this honestly is a pretty fun post-apoc game. You can even use the multiplayer to have a friend tag along. 

Recommended!

Overall, FC games are pretty cookie cutter.  This one adds a 4 level rank up to gear and other gameplay elements.  It adds expeditions which are like standalone assault/capture the flag missions.  Crafting is a necessary part of ranking up your gear but isn't too painful.  There is a goofy "sawblade" gun that's a bit OP and I'd rather they just didn't have.

The big problem I have with the game is the animal spawns are ridiculous.  I often reach some minor location to find all the bandits dead and some random animal(s) in the area that killed them.  NPCs will be in the middle of quest dialog when *bam* wild animals show up and try to kill us.  The worst are the legendary animals which are max level regardless of your stage in the game and, far from being hard to find, I run into them constantly.  I had one show up right after the Sharky mission right at the exit.  It feels pretty sucky to wipe out an entire base of bandits and then be all "oh no, a yellow level pig, let's sneak around the long way and hopefully it won't notice us".

There are "coins" in the game with a microtransaction element but it's very optional.

I'm very glad this game happened. It's great to get to go back to Hope County and it was cool to see a re-imagining of everything. Many things that I loved most about FC5 are destroyed by the nuclear annihilation, such as the family, the cult music, and planes. I didn't find the enemies compelling, compared to Far Cry 5. It's still good though. 

The expansion on companion skills is great, though I miss having two characters with you. I really like the addition of resetting outposts for better resources! It's nice to have a reason to do it and I'm glad that you don't lose them over time, without choice. The base-upgrading was cool, but not amazing. The expeditions were fun, but I wouldn't miss them if they were gone.

[h1] A NEW HOPE (COUNTY) [/h1]

This has to be my third favorite entry into the Far Cry series for the gameplay, it's vast, more brutal than ever, and offers a ton of content for being one of the expansions in the series. Weapons are chunky, stealth is viable, gun-for-hires are diversified and individually useful, and the all new crafting system is great for grinding. 

But f*ck me is the story pretty awful.

The twins, main villains of the game, are boring, stereotypical, and forgettable. They hardly do anything evil and when they do they act like it's AMAZING when it's just meh. Major spoilers ahead.

Joseph Seed returns, with a son. Where did this son come from, and bore from who you may ask? Dunno and dunno. At first, he's very intriguing and entertaining, but as the story progresses it really leaves a bad taste in my mouth. All of the "good guys" are equally uninteresting and shallow, save for a few returning characters. But their characters are barely built upon either. Even when they kill important character A and make it seem like you've known this guy forever and it's such a tragedy, you realize that he had maybe 2-3 minutes of screen time and did absolutely nothing but moan and complain. I understand this isn't a full fledged entry but if you're going to make a semi sequel then at least put some effort into the story. 

I don't let this take away from the fun, though, because there is plenty more gameplay than story and that's what you really play this game for anyway. I hope to see implementations of the gameplay loop reused in FC6 if it EVER COMES TO STEAM BECAUSE I AM NOT GONNA BUY IT FROM THE GODFORSAKEN UBISOFT STORE BECAUSE F*CK UBISOFT AND F*CK UPLAY THEY SUCK AND I HATE THEM

I like to think of this game as a sort of Indirect Sequel to Far Cry 5 itself.  In the Aftermath, we see a transformed Hope County & a plot that one part Borderlands & another Fallout inspired.  We're reintroduced to some characters that was seen in the original Far Cry & visually Hope County in a Post FC5 looks beautiful visually.

Everything you've done in Far Cry 5 can be done, but you're operating a Base and upgrading it this time, but much of the game world is excluded(the areas which were Jacob & Faith Seed's areas are left out in New Dawn mainly with slight exception to the Prison Complex).  Combat is about the same as FC5, you interact with the world, hunt & trade your spoils for parts, seeking out treasure hunts, with the upgrading of the homebase, you also allow yourself to craft better weapons from Common to Elite Tiers, and the same goes for vehicles whether Ground, Sea or Air though limited on those.  As for Outpost Liberation, there are quite a few in the area, but one option added is the option to Scavenge Ethanol after a Liberation which basically makes the Highwaymen take it over again and you gotta take it over on a harder difficulty.

Story was Meh, but it had everything that made it Far Cry, but since it's a spinoff there's no DLC & it is scaled down from FC5.  Not bad for an indirect sequel spin off, and if you must give this game a try, then I suggest waiting for a Steam Sale.

50 hours later:
Starting a new game can sometimes require a bit of patience, especially when you have to do what the game wants you to, instead of what you want to do. Getting into the story, meeting people, with a whole land to explore and discover is however something I really love! I love the randomness of just choosing where to go and doing something there!

Much like in Far Cry 5, we now have another pair of bad guys (girls?) running stuff, making life miserable in Hope County, Montana. You're weak, you have more or less nothing except for what you pick up, and all you gotta do is get a move on, and start working.

Everything is so worth exploring, because it can only get you stronger, and you get to know what the hell happened in this place! You reach a certain point where things get easier, but also again harder. I played on HARD-ASS difficulty and felt I had control through the entire game, but ofc...sometimes you die...sometimes you die alot.

After completing everything, I finished the game, and even though I felt I had enough of the game in the end, I really had much fun with it, just like the other Far Cry games. Just buy it. I don't care if you do it on sale or not. It's fun! Worth playing!

Tedious, boring, repetitive. Bullet spongy enemies (I literally had to use a trainer for infinite ammo to kill a bear, because dumping all 4 mags from assault rifle - the maximum you can carry at the beginning of the game - did about 25-30% damage to it), annoying issues that have been present in the earliest games in the series (infinitely respawning enemies in most locations, etc.). On top of that, the story is meh, the dialogue is cringe, and I want to shoot all of the characters - not only the enemies, but the supposed allies as well. In fact, I want to shoot the allies more than I want to shoot the enemies.

The issue with Far Cry (and Ubi games in general) is not that they keep repeating the same basic formula, it's that the execution is always shoddy, and the same issues appear again, and again, and again.

Pros:
- doggy and big ass murder piggy as companion choices
- some of the mutated wildlife looks cool
- the map twist this time is pretty cool with weird flower fields and such, very nice
- the shotguns feel nice, but they are also the only somewhat useful weapons in the game, so this is not really a good point

cons:
- everything else
The combat is really annoying and idk if this should really qualify as a standalone game, but overall it has been pretty fun.

[h3]Far Cry 5.5[/h3]
For the uninitiated, the main Far Cry series has become something of a mildly absurd take on Dictators or the Apocalypse or some other very dramatic scenario, that is then followed by what I refer to as 'half games'. What amounts to a very big, stand alone expansion. However, in New Dawn's case, it's the only one (so far) that is remotely narratively connected to the events of its associated full game. That said, almost all Ubisoft games reference at least some other Ubisoft game.

I will also state that these half games started after Far Cry 3. Far Cry 1 and 2 remain unique entries in the overall series ‚Äî I have not yet played Far Cry 6 at the time of writing. FC3 has Blood Dragon, FC4 has Primal. FC5 ‚Äî New Dawn.

[h3]There's one major flaw with this game[/h3]
You may be aware that Ubisoft recently left Steam and has now slowly made their way back, as a result many of their titles do not have Steam achievements. Well, who cares, right? The game has achievements itself and they unlock things on Uplay ‚Äî conversely, who cares about achievements at all. 

All valid. However, ever since Far Cry 3, this series has become a checklist simulator. Without said achievements, personally speaking, the 'checklist' aspect of this game feels underwhelming ‚Äî Clear the outpost, find the treasure, climb the tower, open the map, do the random events that show up ‚Äî in fact, this game even allows you to [i]very literally[/i] hand over the taken over outposts back to the perceived enemy such that it increases the difficulty of said outpost and thus rewards you with more resources to upgrade the base. I suppose it's pertinent to mention the idea of the game~

[b]General Premise:[/b]
You'll play as 'Cap', a customizable character that is tasked with recruiting specialists and upgrading the facilities in Prosperity by obtaining resources for both crafting weapons and gear as well as the facilities.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911357223

The cast of characters in Far Cry has always been rather odd, perhaps placed just for levity in an otherwise serious situation. Irreverent.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911356934

The game's map is just a re-imagined version of the map of Montana used in Far Cry 5. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911357857

[h3]The Gist[/h3]
Much like most game series these days, it's 'more-of-the-same' ‚Äî though, this one feels like it breaks the proverbial fourth wall a bit more than its predecessors regarding its gameplay.

[quote]If you've found this review helpful, consider following my curation ‚Äî [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am not sure how its possible for the story to be as bad as it is. Out of every game I have played in 25 years this has the poorest least believable villains and sub villains, Its so bad that you find yourself thinking that it must get better at some point because it would be unfathomable for the entire story to be this bad. But it never gets better.
This next paragraph was originally me explaining that outside of the story the game itself mechanically and looks wise is decent but ultimately that made me feel like I was defending the game somewhat and it does not deserve to be defended. 
This game is not worth buying.
car go brrr

What the hell even were they thinking about making this story??? I do not understand how they simultaneously seem to intentionally make it as stupid as possible while also lacking any self awareness.
By far the worst antagonist in the series. Completely unlikable with no goals other than to just be complete c#nt$ to everyone. Writers try to redeem them at the very last second but I was so ready to commit domestic violence that it ruined any possible empathy. They were seriously so annoying I would cringe any time they open their mouths. 
Gameplay is super meh, to an offensive extent. Guns and shooting is good, but they really push you towards micro transactions if you don‚Äôt do the lame missions to gather materials. The last bossfight with the twins is SO BAD. They were just bullet sponges that would literally eat dozens of c4 charges AND shots to the head without dying. Meanwhile you are being attacked by dogs which are just as annoying as usual. After that the ending is so unnecessary and ridiculous, I can not put it into words. Just google it and be completely confused. 
To sum it up, it is an EVEN MORE UNFINISHED version of far cry 5 without the redeeming attributes such as interesting characters. At least ubisoft had the mercy to end it in half the time of the other games. Despite this, it is worth 5 bucks on sale, but I would be furious if I paid full price for this medicore game. Even at $10 I feel ripped off though.
Its fun to avoid the story and jost go fishing.

This is the worst Far Cry in the series.

Take Far Cry 5, throw out half of the good stuff, keep all the flaws, sprinkle some additional artificial difficulty on top and wrap it in saturated magenta wrapping paper. That's how you get Far Cry New Dawn.

Here are some things they added that make this game so much worse than the others:
- Stupidly long reload times. Just adds artificial difficulty to stretch out playtime. It also constantly ruins the flow of combat.
- Unnecessary Tier System. Basically turns enemies into bullet sponges if you don't have the equivalent tier weaponry against them. Once again, unnecessary difficulty.
- Sprinkling crafting materials across the entire map and forcing you to hunt for them. Just another way to artificially extend playtime because you need the crafting materials to craft weapons.

See the pattern yet? This game fundamentally lacks enough fun and interesting content. All this artificial difficulty might be tolerable if the game itself is fundamentally fun, but it unfortunately isn't. The NPCs are bland and boring, so you don't particularly care for them. The antagonists feel more like entitled teenage brats rather than a terrifying psychopath, so the cutscenes lack impact.

Just replay Far Cry 5 instead. Or any other Far Cry in the series. This one's not worth even on a sale.

SUMMARY} Honestly. I love this game to death. I played it when it first came out on xbox and nearly got 100% on the game. While the main story is pretty short(only took me 12 hours and I was taking it extremely slow for a second playthrough) the post-game is great. You can upgrade your guns to be wildly OP and just obliterate enemies while retaking outposts or completing expeditions. I bought this game and Far Cry 5 for 20 bucks during the Christmas sale and I believe that's a steal. I would take these two games over Far Cry 6 any day of the week! Please buy this game when it goes on sale again it's well worth the price!

 I hope Ubisoft starts making Far Cry games like this and Far Cry 5 again. The mute protagonist allows you to create whatever character or characteristics you want for your player! The customization on the otherhand is VERY watered down or even non-existent compared to Far Cry 5. You can't customize aspects of your gun and there is a very limited amount of outfits in the game. The story is short but sweet same with the map. Personally, I'm fine with them reusing the Far Cry 5 map. I think it adds more lore and character to this side of the Far Cry world. Similarly, it was a joy catching up with the cast from the original game. This game feels more like a continuation or extension of Far Cry 5 and I LOVE IT for that! 

At the end of the day, if you hated Far Cry 5 than you'll most likely hate this game. But please give it a shot. For 10 bucks on sale this game is a STEAL! I would even call it better than Far Cry 6!!! While I still haven't been motivated to even finish the Far Cry 6 campaign I have loved grinding both this game and Far Cry 5's post-game.

I've been playing the franchise for a while and have loved pretty much ALL of the games thus far. I am still in the wee hours of this one but I'm already liking several aspects of this one that weren't in older versions. I like that you can repeatedly take settlements for more rewards and the perks system seems a little more fluid. I am also a Die Antwood fan so when I first heard the music I giggled a little. They are nuts & I can get down with insanity especially when their music really does set the tone for the "bad guys" in the game. I do love that you get to choose your gender at the beginning and for some reason I am also able to have facial hair as a female character. Screw it. She has mutton chops. YOLO! *clears throat* I like that they didn't mess with the controls I'm so used to and added being able to build up Prosperity. It seems to be less...repetitive. Don't get me wrong, it still is. But comparatively...it's a vast improvement. 
I may add to this later if I run into anything else of note.
Bit of a weird story, but I appreciate the characters and scenario. It's not worth the money though, this should've been a DLC of FC 5. Buy it on a sale and you're good to go.

SOME MINOR DETAILS THAT COULD BE CLASSED AS SPOILERS IN REVIEW....



So I was genuinely happy when I finally completed this game, I was glad it was over...
The storyline is extremely short (12 main missions in total!). The game can be completed in around 5 hours if you didn't have to spend time upgrading your base and finding components for better weapons. 
The levelling system in this game is pathetic, the enemies have 4 levels ranging from, I could sneeze and kill them, all the way to unloading over 200 rounds of ammo to remove half of their health bar. 
I know that it is based on the Far Cry 5 map, but this is the most cut down game I have experienced - the number of outposts has been cut down, and the only way to make up for that is by allowing you to essentially hand it back to the enemy so you have to take it down again - with the caveat that the opponents are going to be more difficult the next time you try to take it and you get some base building material from it.
Also, compared to Far Cry 5, stealth is much harder, the enemies can see you much further, can fill up their spotting bar much much faster and their hearing is incredible - this all makes for a frustrating experience if you enjoy playing stealth.
Another issue is that the gun levelling system is stupid, 'oh look ive put some ducktape on a rifle increasing its damage by 100%'. So the level 1 assault rifle will take over 1000 rounds to kill a level 4 standard enemy, stick some tape on it and some plumbing components and suddenly it can take them out in 10 rounds. 

My main issue with this game are the two main protagonists, the Twins, are evil for the sake of being evil. Their actions are utterly bewildering. All other Far Cry leaders have reasons for being evil, Vaas was on drugs and being mentally abused, Hoyt was a slaver. Pagan Min was a dictator and they really spent time on his back story. The only redemption of this story is that it completes the character arc for Joseph Seed (The Father), it wasn't the worst ending for him - but the fight with the Twins is ridiculous - The fight with Ethan is stupid too, and has more in common with Dark Souls than it does with any Far Cry game. 

Positives... I do like the base building aspect but I wish every upgrade visually upgraded the base - I want to see what my hard work has achieved. The specialised loot locations are actually ok, some might dislike it (if they like to discover things while out exploring) because the game tells you where to find these components - personally, it forces me to see places on the map that I would probably never visit. The game is very pretty, very vibrant colours and graphically very impressive- however, the game does stutter quite often (even if running on decent hardware).
Overall, not sure I would even recommend this game even if it were on sale at 90% off - just use that money to buy Far Cry 3/4/5 instead, or use that money to save for Far Cry 6 instead.

Like every other FarCry game, this is a great open world title to explore. As of writing this I have done 99% of all items in the game (just no co-op medal) and this took 40hrs. 

Story: A very engaging but very short story in terms of cut-scenes and character back story. The story mostly is stretched out by needing to upgrade various attributes to easily beat the remaining story missions. 

Graphics: The game looks beautiful even without the graphics update. Keep in mind this will depend on your PC. A mid-end PC should be able to run this game no problem. 

Gameplay: Similar tasks, controls and exploration as any other FarCry game. Lots of weapons, tools and options for taking over outposts. It is a huge improvement that outposts are now re-playable at higher difficulties when you choose to. Most of the world is open right from the beginning after you reach your new base. 

Value: For getting it on sale it was worth it for about 30 hours of fun. The last 10 hours was me just chasing around all the collectables I missed. I probably won't play this again but moving on to other games. There just isn't much to replay value once you have finished the game. 

Overall: 7/10

Previously Ubisoft made a Far Cry set in the distant prehistoric past. This one is set in the near future. Post Apocalyptic one. As a post-Apoc game it is ridiculous: very little radiation, no human mutations, animal mutations that have done little more than change the color of their antlers. 

As a Far Cry game it isn't bad.  Much better than FarCry 5, the source of both the map and the assets used in this game. Not once did the game pull me out of exploration and base-attacks to follow some stupid story. FarCry 5 did that to me constantly. It may not be as big as it's papa, but it has more than enough since it costs less. 

When the game first came out I got it for $40 for the Play Station. It is probably worth that to any fan of the franchise that doesn't need a compelling story. The two female villains are just as realistic as the comic book villain of Far Cry 5, except in this game you can avoid dealing with them most of the time. 



conclusion

If you can, get it on sale. Unless you must have to see deer with maroon antlers. It is a bit of a cash grab. New story, old assets. Same experience as any other Far Cry game.

sheesh

This felt awkward.
For start, I think it's one of the worst post-apocalyptic games I ever played. The setting feels naive and childish, like Madmax mixed with Wasteland and put into kindergarten lunchbox.
There is pink colour everywhere, which feels annoying at some point, the Highwaymen gang looks like circus clowns - guys like these would be cut down one by one by peggies survivors in no time. What can I tell if they turn their music (kinda cringy and out-of-place looking in this setting) on full in outposts. They walk into motorcycle helmets all the time and that looks stupid.
But two main nails in the coffin of this antagonists are their bosses - two wanna-be Harley Quinn twin sisters. You feel no threat when you see them, the only time they really beat your ass is when your protagonist makes dumb move to let them look cool. They are the definition of "A lot of bark but no bite". Honestly, I was hoping the real gang boss will show up after I finish them off, but no, these clowns is all the game has to offer. You just cant take them seriously and feel yourself like an adult in the room of unfamiliar first-grades in McDonald's happy birthday party.
About killing these walking graffiti markings - they have levels now. And I was pretty surprised when I decided to clear my first outpost three times in a row (yes you can clear any outpost an infinite amount of time now, mainly to get an X currency and some outfit parts) and noticed that to kill 2 elite soldiers which spawn on lvl3 outposts, you need, say, to shoot them like 10 minutes of real time with first-tier weapons you get at the start. And you cannot kill them from stealth - you need a lot of perk points to learn to do that. That felt just disgusting.
To get perk points you still need to complete achievements which became stupid in this part. Like, kill X enemies with low-tier type of weapon, after that medium-tier, etc. Not that hard but but feels poor-made and at some moment you may find out that you did not kill enemies with shit-tier SMGs, for example, and miss some points. After all, you need to spend 2 mags of a gun into enemy to kill them if, said enemy is one-tier higher than your said gun. Looter shooters are just idiotic mess when you need to spend 50 rounds into enemy's head to kill them.
To not die that fast and to kill faster you need currency. A lot of currency types and a ton of each for decent upgrades and guns. So prepare for some grind at the start. And boring looting process. At some point you can perform expeditions which give you wnough materials for one legendary-tier gun craft - so just do that instead of sniffing every rock around for 2 cogs or 1 circuit.
The upgrades of your camp came from FC primal, but now you only need the currency given mainly from outpost clearing. And you now 'must' clear them, if you don't wanna end in bossfight with low-tier weapons or one hp-bar and guarantee yourself hours of 'fun' with them.
To sum cons of perks and currency situation - I have some good news for you - you can get those with one click - and filling up your credit card info tab, because you can pay-to-win here. Yes, like after first minutes in camp you can just upgrade everything to level two and make this game feel easy-breasy with not power of skill, but power of $$$. I see that it works with clothing and transport skins, but when you can literally make your character invincible with microtransaction it just  makes you feel betrayed.
The only good thing this game has to offer is Joseph Seed story part and ending. And still, the fate of our character from previous game - FC5 - who is presented here - is kinda non-logical. The only thing that didn't make me feel like I threw time and money in the void here.
If you are a large fan of Far Cry and FC 5 in particular, you can play this for last hours of story and outposts clearing, otherwise - walkthrough it on YouTube or play some Rage 2.

Well...this game, by far, is my favourite game. Out of all Far Cry games and every other game there is. Far Cry New Dawn has faced its fair share of criticism, in my opinion for no reason. The game looks absolutely beautiful and breathtaking and is a great sequel to Far Cry 5. The game is one of the few games that are actually able to make me feel at home and happy. The story is the main thing most people arent happy with, and to a degree i can understand that. The twins arent really interesting characters and the final boss fights against them are a pain in the ass. But make no mistake, they are just a means to the end. The main story is the one with Joseph, for me at least. The twins are only there to bring a challenge. To bring a reason to defeat outposts, and thats about it. The main part of the story is indeed with Joseph and the people from New Eden. The game perfectly shows human behavior but it also opened my eyes in many ways. The way we destroy and kill just for our own pleasure. Far Cry New Dawn made me aware of a lot of things and i never regretted playing it for a second. Deffenitely check it out :)

Edit: Still one of the best games in 2022 :)

This game is nothing but a disappointment. I just recently purchased Far Cry 6, and I have come to the following conclusion...

Ubisoft makes high quality games when they name their series with a number (Far cry 4, 5, and 6), and in between they desecrate out garbage titles such as Far Cry New Dawn and Far Cry Primal.

This one in particular is especially pathetic and just completely sad because it piggybacks off the ending of Far Cry 5, kinda teasing a worthy sequel. What you will get in return is nothing compared to the caliber of Far Cry 5. You will chase the high Far Cry 5 left you with, and you wont make it 30 minutes until you conclude that playing this trash was a bad decision.

It takes all the good, seriously enjoyable aspects of Far Cry 5, throws them in the air with a bunch of other useless reskins and remodels of the entire game like a tossed salad, and ultimately spits out an unfinished and not well thought out "Far Cry"

I still haven't finished this game 2+ years later, and I have no intention to do so. It loses me every time I try within 48 hours.

DO NOT BUY THIS. PLEASE LISTEN TO ME. I DON'T WANT YOU TO BOTH ENDURE THE PAIN I HAD AND SUPPORT UBISOFT

Pretty decent game. Lots of potential in the free roam. I'd say it's in my top 10 all-time favs (and I've been gaming since the original DOOM). There are a few glitches, but overall it's a good game. Free world roaming is ... freaking ... AWESOME!

Definitely different for a Far Cry game but still a Far Cry game.  They did a number of different things that it takes a a minute to adjust to.  Like get skill points and resources, as well as reusing Outposts.  Its like they wanted to try a bunch of ideas and see which ones stick.  I really like the "improving Guns-For-Hire" mechanic.

I do like it.  It doesn't feel as long of an endurance race as previous Far Cry games, and its just big enough of a map to keep things interesting.

The story is compelling, IMHO.  Its interesting to see the continuation of Far Cry 5 as an epilogue.

Very good

This is one of those games that shows why some indie games can get a 3/10 and a tripple A game with the same amount of content can get a 7/10.
Cons:
Every car drives at like 40mph
No more planes (unless I gotta upgrade the garage or something)
Looter shooter crafter upgrader game. Weapons can get upgraded infinitely, some perks can get upgraded infinitely (though I assume perk points run out at some point). This means that half of the game is hiding from level 3 guys, and the other half is running around punching people's helmets clean off. This also means that the weapons you find are borderline useless.
Some plot points are stupid. [spoiler]There's a bunch of times that you meet the twins, and you could go siko mode on them, but the game makes you wait. After they're gone, you turn the whole base upside down with nothing but your fists.[/spoiler]
The specialists are downright forgettable. I even forgot about Rush. Then they have this scene with everyone around his grave, and the second that cutscene is done, I'm back at Prosperity, and this npc says "You and Rush sure do great work keeping everything in order".
The twins especially do this thing after you complete a mission where they'll say "That was mine meany, I'm going to kill your family". While it paints them as bad people, it's actually understandable. Every villain (or once was villain) has understandable motivations. Even though this game probably isn't cannon, in this hypothetical Joseph Seed definitely gets "I told you so" points. The highway men might be terrible dog eaters, but 1. It's the apocalypse so go ahead, and 2. They have every right to be scared of a dude who can 1v1 fistfight a bear. The twins sending those radio messages are basically just doing the bare minimum to keep them from getting overthrown by the mob.

Pros:
Otherwise, normally the npcs have good lines that detail what's going on in the world.
Some of the lines in the sidequests/specialist missions are absolutely great.
Triple A amenities like great graphics, controller support (With some buttons broken like Far Cry 5), tons of side missions, bases, animals to hunt, fish to catch. Ok stealth, vehicles, gunplay, and of course, online Co-op 2 player multiplayer.
Throwing is still great. Throw your weapons, throw a rock any time you like, throw bodies. What's new (if I remember) is shield throwing. Shields are really fun to pick up for the sole purpose of throwing at enemies.
Some fun weapons, like the saw launcher 2.0, the slingshot, the bats. The upgrade path style of the game kills the fun of all the other ones for me. Even the slingshot/the fists are fun, until you upgrade the hell out of them and become one punch man.

While this game is semi short, fundamentally flawed, and mostly not fun, it's good to have another game on the Far Cry engine. It might not be fun to shoot someone's head 5 times to get their helmet off, but it is fun to throw bait and watch them deal with wild animals. It's fun to throw remote c4 onto a person, punch them and detonate it. This style of game is great for the main line of the Far Cry games, but looter shooter games (even borderlands) have this serious tone to them, like "I have to take this base over so I can get my upgrades" and it takes the life out of the game. All of the fun you can have in this game, you have to go out and earn it. In games like battlefield, pubg, even Far Cry 5, you'll find yourself in these situations whether you like it or not. There will be a bear that pops out of nowhere and you gotta fight for your life. There will be a tank and you gotta blow it up. There will be someone else looting in the building you're in and you gotta decide whether to go after them or hide. In Far Cry New Dawn, you just punch that fucking bear and go looking for more bears to punch.
Every pro in the list has some sort of asterisk. 6/10 still good, but there are much better games to waste your time on. (Wow, even the conclusion is an asterisk) I'd just play it for its short story then uninstall.

best FC game - siimple

The gunplay is good, but only if you're not fighting enemies of a higher level than your weapon. The whole gun/enemy tier system is bad. The melee system is terrible, as is shooting-while-driving system. Both of these have main story missions based around them. The three "infiltration" missions are increasingly frustrating and will make you want to quit the game. The AFGNCAAP-style main character just doesn't work. The story is terrible and completely nonsensical. The perk system is achievement based so you're forced to grind though kills with all of the terrible weapons to get upgrade points. The one thing this game does get right is how outposts can be reset at a higher difficulty so you can clear them again. Of course that's spoiled by the fact that the game is based around micro-transactions so you'll be forced to grind outposts and expeditions to level up your base and craft higher tiered weapons. Why is a single player game based on microtransactions? Because it's not designed around single player, it's designed around 2 player coop! Does that make sense? No. But that's the way it is. Have I mentioned all the bugs yet? There's lots of bugs, especially with the ziplines. Overall, you're better off just replaying 3 or 4.

Far Cry: New Dawn is severely underrated. It's my favorite one out of the entire Far Cry series. It's story is a bit lackluster and you could complete the campaign entirely in a few hours, but it's everything else that makes a Far Cry game. The side missions, the characters, the expeditions. The stealth, for sure. All of it comes together to make something beautiful.

In my playthrough of a game called 'Days Gone' I recalled New Dawn several times in reference to it's superior stealth and gunplay, and overall connection story-wise to the world it created.

I won't say much, as almost anything is a spoiler, but I for sure would recommend you get this game if you want to have a fun time with your friends

Oh man where do I even start with this fucking game. Well I do recommend this game simply because I do think the developers did a good job building upon the story of Farcry 5. However the snipers in this game make Chris Kyle (R.I.P.) look like a complete chimp. I've never seen such accuracy in my entire life. Then we have the RPG and Mortar enemies, my god I've had more explosive ordinance dropped on me than the Korengal Valley in Afghanistan. Finally we have the deadliest animals known to Montana, The Mountain Lion. These vicious putty tats will not only fuck you up while walking through the forrest, but they will also come out of no where while you're trying to liberate a camp. Overall I'd say give this game ago, just don't expect to be Rambo. Especially on the harder difficulties.

Best Yorkshire puddings
By Barney Desmazery
A star rating of 4.8 out of 5.
996 ratings
Rate
607 comments
Magazine subscription ‚Äì your first 5 issues for only ¬£5!
Preparation and cooking time
Prep:5 mins
Cook:20 mins
Easy
Makes 8 large puds or 24 small
The secret to getting gloriously puffed-up Yorkshire puddings is to have the fat sizzling hot and don't open the oven door!

Share on twitter

Email to a friend
Freezable

Play Video
Ingredients
140g plain flour (this is about 200ml/7fl oz)
4 eggs (200ml/7fl oz)
200ml milk
sunflower oil, for cooking
Method
STEP 1
Heat oven to 230C/fan 210C/gas 8.

STEP 2
Drizzle a little sunflower oil evenly into two 4-hole Yorkshire pudding tins or two 12-hole non-stick muffin tins and place in the oven to heat through.

STEP 3
To make the batter, tip 140g plain flour into a bowl and beat in 4 eggs until smooth.

STEP 4
Gradually add 200ml milk and carry on beating until the mix is completely lump-free. Season with salt and pepper.

STEP 5
Pour the batter into a jug, then remove the hot tins from the oven. Carefully and evenly pour the batter into the holes.

STEP 6
Place the tins back in the oven and leave undisturbed for 20-25 mins until the puddings have puffed up and browned.

STEP 7
Serve immediately. You can now cool them and freeze for up to 1 month.

It's a pretty standard Far-Cry release, but it really should've been a DLC for Far Cry 5, not a full priced release, and that is my main issue. No quest-lines within the various people you recruited to your cause after recruitment, no special base defenses, etc. The story itself was predicable and flat, and not that long. Upgrading the main base advances the storyline, that's about it. The perk tree (not a tree, just a grid) was small and I had 50+ unspent perk points towards the end with nothing to do. 

TLDR: Cheaply made Far Cry game, wait for a sale if you like the series.

This game is a total upgrade when it comes to game mechanics compared to FC 5. Here are my takes on the game.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Pros[/h1]
 + [b]Upgrades[/b]
I love the total gameplay but what I liked is the upgrade mechanics. I mean you can upgrade anything in this game. You can upgrade your weapons (all of them), and some of your perks are upgradeable as well. And your home base is a bonus! Hope they continue this mechanic.
 
 + [b]Weapons[/b]
I didn't know how to use the piercing ammo until now. The weapons have a lot of abilities that vary depending on the enemy that you'll encounter. Though they removed the customizations which exist in FC5, however, I'm still impressed with what they did on weapon mechanics. Good job!
 
 [h1]Cons[/h1]
 - [b]Achievements[/b]
Again, Ubisoft, let's not put achievements that require an online buddy. Not all of the players have a buddy playing the same game. Come on. 
 
 - [b]Expeditions[/b]
Just like on [i]Achievements[/i], I just hate this mission because it is just fun to play when you're with a buddy (I don't know, maybe I just wanted to play alone). And also, they tied 4 achievements for this mission. What a shame. 
 
 [h1]Neutral[/h1]
 ~ [b]Story[/b]
The story is amazing! For starters, the story takes place right after the FC5. But as much as I like the story, it's just too short. Seems to me this is just like a DLC.
 
 ~ [b]World[/b]
Since this is just a continuation of FC5, expect that the map will be the same, except it is a smaller version and post-apocalyptic setting. But they still managed to create a wonderful post-apocalyptic world (can you believe that?

[hr][/hr]


So, all and all, this is a wonderful game. Buy this if you want a story continuation of FC5 and you enjoy the FC series.  

So the $50 question, should you buy this at full price or not? The short answer is don't. The game is too short and some of the repeating mission is just good to play when you have a buddy. Buy this on sale.

Far Cry New Dawn, where should I begin...

I suppose I will start with the good parts.

-The guns for hire have a mix of new faces and old. I particularly like the shitkicking grandmother "nana".
-the new system of crafting weapons and vehicles in tiers was pretty cool. I actually liked the aesthetic of the weapons, barring the vomit inducing paint schemes you are forced to have on many of them.
-It was fun to drive through areas and go "hey wait a second I know where i am!"
The game is BEAUTIFUL. I have the advantage of running a very powerful machine but even so, the game looks great.
-There is actually a nice progression system, at least in my eyes. I remember in the previous title you were fairly overpowered from the start but in New Dawn you have to be careful to be equipped for the enemies youre going to be facing.
-*beards and mustaches for male characters*

And now for the bad. Be prepared, this will be a long read.

-First and foremost, the game is WAY too short. Seriously, there is less than half the content in this game than there was in the falls end region in 5. I managed to beat the entire game in a day.
-The guns for hire system was changed to only allow one at a time. This was upsetting because a: it required me to do more work and b: i miss the quips they had with eachother in the last game.
-There isnt any customization to the weapons in the game. Find a rifle you love and would like to put a suppressor on it for stealth missions? Too bad, you gotta see if there is a similar weapon that has one and use that.
-There is a severe lack of customization in the game compared to 5. There are few outfits, no skins for vehicles or weapons and as mentioned before there is no weapon customization.
-While the game looks pretty, the colors are seizure inducing. it seems the developers love hot pink. But on top of that, we also have shit that just doesnt make sense. White deer with red antlers, animals that have somehow evolved bone patterns on their fur, fields and forests of flowers in all kinds of colors. and the water is actually, genuinely blue.
-The map has its recognizable spots, but for the most part I couldnt tell where I was. I beat fc5 three times. I know the map well. I can understand there being some landscape change over almost twenty years but not this much.
-The vehicles are few in number (which is understandable i suppose) and in my opinion all look kind of the same. white paintjob, red decals and weird welded diamond plates everywhere. theyre honestly pretty ugly to look at.
-Most characters from the previous game do not return and their fates remain unknown. That wouldve been fine if it didnt exclude so many characters. 
-Some parts of the map I just never visited because there was nothing to do there except collect resources. by the time i got halfway through the game, i already had more than I needed.
-The lore is far harder to come by. Not so much for lack of it, but the fact I beat the whole game in half the time it took me to fully complete the falls end's section in 5.
-The tier system was cool and all, but it was only there because enemies are tiered too now. There are several sections where your weapons are taken from you and you end up having to use tier 1 weapons against tier 3-4 enemies. Just isnt feasible.

Overall, I am very disappointed in this game. It shouldve been a 20-30 dollar expansion to Far Cry 5.

Not sure what to say here. Yeah, it's kind of just an expansion for Far Cry 5, and I loved 5, but I absolutely hate this. I really can't put my finger on what it is that ruins it, but I guess all of the "new" features are just kind of lame. Play 5 instead.
