Falls further in to mediocrity with every other Far Cry since 3
Story is garbage and the antagonists are the worst in the series by far.
The only redeemable element for solo play is the environmental graphics. The devs responsible for those are on point.

Those saying it's pay to win are kind of off base. You *can* pay for the convenience of a higher tier weapon immediately but all the enemies in the game are scaled to where you are at story wise. Even then you can one shot a tier three enemy with a tier one gun if you break their helmet and get a headshot but by the time you see a tier three enemy, outside of wildlife, you should naturally have tier 3 or 4 weapons.

Difficulty is never an issue with this game since stealth is completely broken, the AI are braindead even when fully alerted by unsilenced gunfire, and toward the end of the story you get sicko mode and just can blitz any outposts with a machine gun.

[h1][url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2451719157]It was about time[/url] you released a decent "Season Pass" for "Far Cry 5", Ubisoft![/h1]


Anyway, here's a short fragment of my experience with the game so far.
I saved a woman from some Highwaymen and seconds later she got killed by a wolverine. Fast forward a few minutes and an outpost I was attacking called in reinforcements who were killed by a couple of skunks which ultimately helped me liberate the camp. After the outpost liberation cutscene, a bison immediately trampled me and was instantly attacked by a bear as I was getting up to run away. A few hundreds of meters away from the previously dangerous location, a wolf jumped me, at which point my "doggo" companion Timber [i](which you can pet at your leisure)[/i] fought the wolf long enough for me to take it out [i](I was done running...fu(k it)[/i], [b]AND[/b] he also mauls, mangles and mutilates all my enemies. Oh right - he can also ride with you in vehicles [b]AND[/b] brings you gifts every chance he gets.

Eventually, I decided to return to my settlement and call it a day, only to be welcomed by some random dude who said, and I quote - "There's an old lady out there called Nana who can shoot the d!ck off a mosquito."
I decided not to call it a day anymore. I went after her. The rest is history. [b]AND PRIVATE![/b]


But all jokes aside, [b]fu(k me![/b] This entry in the amazing "Far Cry" saga, although viewed as more of a huge DLC for "Far Cry 5" [i](though you won't be annoyingly kidnapped anymore in this one)[/i], is [b]extremely well optimized[/b], has beautiful graphics, a really cool soundtrack, tons of replayability, an awesome story with some very memorable and unique characters, [b]AND the best and funniest part of it all - it's WAY better than Cyberpunk 2077![/b]

And all this for [i](if you don't get it on sale)[/i] only 45 bucks. What more could you want? It's like "Far Cry" and "Fallout" had a pink baby! Now I don't know about you guys and gals, but I'm enjoying the heck out of it.
[i](oh, and there's a new, semi-settlement builder mechanic which is actually quite fun and motivating at times)[/i]

Far Cry shares the game mechanics of all the Far Cry games before, and so, if you liked playing them, chances are you will like playing this. The game itself was surprisingly short, especially when compared with Far Cry 5, for which this is a direct sequel.   Mission are fun, but I agree with the other reviewer who said that they were pretty bland. As always, a lovely story, but not the depth of the other games, in fact the final boss battle was with a character you had barely any interaction with during the game. I bought the game on deep discount, so I can deal with the game being so short, and shallow, but if I had bought it at full price, I'd have been annoyed. This would have worked better as an add-on to Far Cry 5.

Easily the worst Farcry game. Lazy and shallow writing, Companion dialogue isn't synced to the events in the story, very little to offer in terms of content and flat/boring antagonists. There's also a point in the game where you can literally roadblock yourself on a major story mission where it becomes impossible to complete without having invested in two specific perks, which it gives you zero notice of and requires you to quit the mission to grind more if you don't have them, then do the mission all over again. I payed for this game and didn't even finish it, uninstalled at around 12 hours.

Short version: It's not "more Far Cry 5". Spend your money on something else, because you'll have a high probability of disappointment

Long version: I'm playing this game WAY later than it was released and roughly 3 years after I played the original Far Cry 5 game. New Dawn is an okay game for the most part, but If you liked the story around Far Cry 5 and are expecting MORE Far Cry 5, you are going to be greatly disappointed. The game play is all there fore sure, but THIS story writing is sub-amateur at best, and that's being polite. You're not given very long to make an attempt to care about the characters. The antagonists are a GREAT idea, but poorly executed. The whole time I was left wondering "why don't I just kill them now? Why go through all this?" Yes, I realize "there would be no game then", but if that's the defense, then that just justifies my claim about the poor story writing. Unless it was $5 and I had nothing else to do for the next 16 +/- hours, I wouldn't waste your time. Just watch a "Let's Play" of the game, if one was ever made.

If you've purchased and enjoyed it, then I'm glad you got your money's worth. I didn't, in my opinion

Not a bad entry into the Far Cry franchise by any means. It's just shorter. I liked Far Cry 5 much more. Still, co-op games that allow you to play an entire campaign together are few and far between these days, so credit to where it's due. In terms of story I wasn't too satisfied. I like the Joseph stuff, but the new villains just didn't live up to the Far Cry standard. It's a hard thing to get right and I empathize with the writers who have to follow characters like Vaas and the Seed family. Overall, a fun ride for $12 on sale.

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
I finished the game before reviewing

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
I liked it. If you can get it cheap on a sale and want an allright open-world FPS with crafting and upgrades then you'll enjoy it.

If you are tired of Far Cry formula then skip it ‚Äì it doesn't do things that much different to peak your interest.

If you like Far Cry formula then this is another variation of it and you will get what you expect for the most part. Do bear in mind that this is probably one of the worst Far Cry games.

[h1]Description[/h1]
It's a goddamn Far Cry game for crying out loud. If you played anything in the series from Far Cry 3 onward then you know what to expect, so I won't describe the game here. Look to my review of Far Cry 4 for a description.

I will, however, talk about features specific to New Dawn:
it uses same map as Far Cry 5, but it's set in a post-apocalyptic future of that area where most of the civilization is now a ruin overgrown with vegetation.
There are resources which can be obtained in many ways, from looting enemies or finding hidden caches to capturing enemy outposts.
crafting is used to make every weapon and vehicle as well as improving some other features like effectiveness of healing. Each weapon/car needs to be unlocked through crafting before you can equip it at a base. You can also loot weapons from defeated enemies, but that won't unlock them for equip at a base ‚Äì you will only have it until you get rid of it. You can also unlock new tiers of weapons and vehicles by upgrading your main base.
Each weapon, vehicle and enemy, even animals, is now tiered from tier 1 to tier 4. Tiering is important to keep in mind because you will do noticably less damage to enemies of higher tier than your weapon. This may lead to some tedious upgrade grind if you don't enjoy the mechanic.
You gain perk points used to buy skills through completing objectives and challenges like killing enemies with specific weapons on each tier. This encourages engaging with enemies and exploring even if it's not a part of a quest.
Other mechanics like buddies (NPCs that follow you and help in combat) or stealth takedowns, throwing rocks to distract enemies, even mission and gameplay structure etc. are very similar to Far Cry 5.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ Still as fun as other entries in the series[/b]
I've seen a lot of people complain that Far Cry doesn't evolve and why are people play this series when every game is the same.

It's true that Far Cry has a formula ever since FC3, but is this a bad thing in itself? Look at how many people keep winging at Blizzard for killing Diablo with Diablo 3 and Immortal. Or how Fallout 3 killed the franchise. Or Baldur's Gate 3, Doom 3, Doom Eternal, Resident Evil 4, Resident Evil 7 were polarizing for changes to formula.

Ok, point here is that if you expect a Far Cry game, then New Dawn is that. It has some new things added onto it's already establish skeleton, but it generally feels similar. If you want a different game, then play a different game. It's not enough IMO to hate on a game just because it iterates instead of revolutionizes.

[b]+ Presentation[/b]
Lush, colorful landscapes filled with high grass and forests and overgrown ruins are pretty to look at. Audiovisual design and quality is on a good level. I had fun just walking through the map, exploring different locations and scavenging for resources.

Noteworthy are the animals. There are all mutated, strange-looking versions of animals we know. For example ‚Äì deer have white fur with red-pinkish antlers. While they are still functionally just the same deer as in Far Cry 3-5 ‚Äì the visual distinction makes them more interesting and I like it.

[b]+ Good variety[/b]
Because of the mechanics of the game encouraging you to do different things for materials ‚Äì this entry feels somehow less samey. That is only if you are willing to do all those different activities and don't find them tedious.

Resource economy gives you several ways of obtaining different materials. If you don't want to engage with resource grind for crafting weapons then you can just do quests including expeditions which reward a lot of craft mats.

Both outposts and expeditions can be repeated with increasing difficulty levels for more rewards. You can't repeat them on low levels, but there are enough of them to get all resources you need before advancing to the next difficulty tier in my experience, even if you are crafting lots of weapons.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Microtransactions[/b]
Real money transactions have no place in single-player games that you have to buy. If you want a freemium-type mechanics then make your game free, you assholes.

However, I will admit that the way I usually play games - exploring, doing side content at my leasure and going out of my way to grab optional resources and search for new areas to raid ‚Äì I did not experience a starvation of upgrade materials.

It's still a shitty thing to include microtransactions in a non-free game.

[b]- Stupid story[/b]
My main issue is again with how unlikely this all seems. We have a bandit faction that numbers in thousands in force and I am supposed to believe they really have problems with a small group of local survivors? It's even stated in the game that the bandits are spreading all over United States, so they are literally a standing army united by the main antagonists. 

FC4 had 2 military forces constantly in combat and felt much more authentic and plausible. FC5 was more ‚Äûout-there‚Äù, but it was implied that peggies weren't really being violent or aggressive before the events of the game, so it would be more understandable that there would be more normal people living around the area.

Honestly, I don't even fully understand how such regimes filled with bad guys are united by a single ruling pair of sisters. If you propagate a culture of stealing and murder then you can fully expect your own men to steal and murder each other, very possibly yourself. Relying on an army of ‚Äûloyalists‚Äù recruited from the biggest scum on the planet seems like a good way to have a bunch of trigger-happy and ambitious morons to try to take you out for a chance at being the man in charge.

And then we have Joseph Seed and his antics... to say more would be spoilers, but I'm severely disappointed in how the plotline is set up and resolved.

This is the worst story and the worst plot by far...

[b]- Characters[/b]
‚Ä¶ which would still be fine if the characters worked, but they don't. The villains are boring and bad. It's funny that whenever games try to sell a female villain nowadays they always have to be dumb meatheads who punch and shoot people. Pagan Min was a much more effective villain despite killing 1 and lightly injuring 1 more person on the screen, compared to the twins who kill people whenever they are on the screen.

Villains aside, the rest of the cast ain't any better. Story characters like Seed aren't given enough time to flesh them out. The new companions aren't much better. Hurk is still the comic relief, but so is the granny sniper. Yes, granny sniper. I prefer games to choose a tone and keep it. Meanwhile we have scenes where children are given unpinned grenades to hold, while at the same time having idiocies like the sniper granny.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
This is the worst Far Cry game I played (the only ones I didn't play was Primal and 6) and it still sits at the level of quality that can objectively be enjoyed. It all depends on the player ‚Äì if you wanted more Far Cry, then you will find this to be fun. Probably less fun than others, but still engaging enough to play through it.

I'd give Far Cry New Dawn a
[h1]5/10[/h1]
It's overall a mediocre title. I recommend getting it on a discount as you wait for Far Cry 6 price to drop to something reasonable  considering how formulaic the series is. They are simply not worth full price.

Now, onto the Far Cry Primal, which I've heard both a lot of bad and a lot of good about...

I liked the ending to Far Cry 5. There, I said it. (Spoilers for the ending of Far Cry 5 ahead, though the existence of this game probably already ruined that for you.) It may be an unpopular opinion, but I appreciated that, for once, we didn‚Äôt vanquish the bad guy, save the day, and walk off into the sunset. Joseph Seed kind of won. So I‚Äôm a little bummed that the very silly developments of Far Cry: New Dawn walk back a lot of that bleak, dark finale. That said, the very familiar Far Cry gameplay formula is just as fun as ever in the post-apocalypse, and I had a blast clearing outposts, hunting for treasure, and absolutely brutalizing the Highwaymen who have seized control of what‚Äôs left of Hope County, Montana.
Much like Far Cry Primal was to Far Cry 4, Far Cry: New Dawn is a standalone sequel to Far Cry 5 that redresses the same map, but here the events are set years later instead of millennia before. (It‚Äôs not mandatory, but to really get the most out of it you‚Äôll want to have played Far Cry 5 first.) Many characters return, you‚Äôll revisit locations that have been damaged or otherwise altered, and the events of Far Cry 5 are mentioned often.

playing this after far cry 5 has already brought me to tears & i've barely begun XD. i truly believed everyone died at the end of far cry 5 in the collapse, & all my efforts were for nothing. but honestly, meeting carmina? & then seeing KIM?? & GRACE? & NICK? ALL ALIVE? bruh. the joy that filled my chest was like no other & i GODDAMN CRIED BC I THOUGH THEY WERE ALL DEAD. 

onto the game itself: the crafting system of this game is giving skyrim/elder scrolls online. it is slightly annoying, but still. the music makes me think of pacifica in cyberpunk (RATATATATATA). i like how the controls carry across games and you don't have to relearn anything. it's great. & the landscape is so unfamiliar, yet so familiar, at the same time. i also like how they turned john seed's old ranch into their new base, lol (it's what they deserve, honestly). & i like how you have to build it up with ethanol & actually work towards a goal, etc., & seeing remnants and forgotten memories of eden's gate. yes, i spoiled myself for who the judge is, and it breaks my fucking heart. (i also cried in the ending of far cry 5 bc of ending up in the bunker with everyone seemingly dead... i got the canon ending). & the links between this one & far cry 5, OOF. we stan. 

the far cry series is fkn great. & i am so excited to continue playing this game!

Compared with Far Cry 5, New Dawn has a lot of innovations in weapons and gameplay. It can be said that it is similar to the latest Far Cry 6. I think Far Cry 6 may be inspired by New Dawn to make a game. A game very similar to New Dawn. Far Cry has always been my favorite series, both in terms of gameplay and shooting experience, this series has always been very good. I think New Dawn is more fun than Far Cry 5, at least in my experience on consoles. The shooting feel is very similar to Far Cry 6, and the experience on the console is very good. The plot is also very novel and does not feel very annoying. If you were to rank Far Cry, I think Far Cry 6 did the best job, and in second place is New Dawn. So it is a recommended game, but it is recommended to buy it when the price is reduced.

I wish I could give this a neutral review. The main issue is that this was released as a full game. It should have been an expansion which would have been excellent addition to Far Cry 5. Some small issues were the lack of development for the main antagonists and the weird ending boss. Overall the game does really well as a Far Cry addition and adds new and interesting developments to the game concept. The story is a decent length, just not for a full game. I would say ¬£10 is justified for this game.

I have a weak spot for the Far Cry series and as such I will still recommend this game. I did however find it a bit lacklustre compared to some of the earlier Far Cry games.

Far Cry: New Dawn is essentially a continuation of Far Cry 5, with some recurring characters. You play in the world that has slowly begun to flourish again after the bombs fell. People have been steadily rebuilding civilization... until there had to be an opposing force, known in this game as the Highwaymen, lead by the Twins, Lou and Mickey.

It's hardly any different than any other more recent Far Cry game. You help the good guys operate missions against the bad guys, the bad guys push back and take from you, and then you retaliate and wipe them all out for good. I enjoy open-world games that give you a lot of guns and a lot of freedom to roam about, like the Far Cry series, but I can understand that not everyone is that excited about seeing this formula being recycled yet again.

The guns feel a little recycled from earlier games as well, but there's also plenty of "apocalyptic weapons," i.e. weapons that have been made from scrap. I dislike how a lot of the Elite-rank guns require circuit boards that you can only get from grinding Expedition missions. Especially near the end, I wish that instead of that being the only source, you could also get them from Elite enemies or something, or supply drops.

As for the story, it started off strong. The Twins are intimidating and unpredictable, and there is quite an uptick in brutality compared to earlier titles, but honestly it became mediocre near the end and the decimation of the kingpins of the Highwaymen was also anticlimactic. 
Also not really a fan of the return of Joseph and Eden's Gate in this game. I would rather have them move on from the closed book that is Far Cry 5 and not add them as a bit of a side-aspect of the story in this game. It just feels out of place.

All in all not a bad game but it really is no breakthrough in the Far Cry series. They should soon ditch this style and come up with something more innovative, as the franchise is getting stale by now, if it hasn't before New Dawn already.

And for the love of God... leave Hurk out of the franchise already.
game 10/10

It's pretty good.

The enemies can suck, alot of weapons stop being usable, and the a.i companions are brain dead. But overall it is a really good Far Cry game. The atmosphere looks great, especially at night with the aurora's and stars. Joseph Seed isn't a stupid idiot, the sisters are very killable, and Horatio is an absolute monster. Some of the guns also make the game quite streamline, along with the perks you get cutting down tedious movement and gameplay hassles. Storywise it's fine, you'll get most of your enjoyment out of the gameplay. Try this if you're a fan of Far Cry 5 or looking for a quick and easy shooter.

This game released in 2019, yet you can only have one save and it auto saves. So missed some of a cut scene because you got a phone call or had a kid come and talk to you? Shame because it auto-saved as soon as the cutscene was done, so you just missed it.

For a game with good graphics and gun play, it's a shame that the annoying parts of the mechanics make this so bad. Recent games are just a far cry from the games that made the series great.

TL;DR-
Gameplay: 5/10
Story and Characters: 2/10
Writing and Dialogue: 3/10
Graphics: 9/10
Music & Sound: 6/10
Length: 6/10
Replayability: Don‚Äôt Make Me Laugh/10
A game that features the return of Joseph Seed and still sucks anyway: God ain‚Äôt here/10

-REVIEW-

Ok, so I was aiming for a funnier intro, seeing as how it took me this long to find a more recent Ubisoft game that I actually hate, but‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt. I‚Äôll be honest, I had a feeling I‚Äôd finally run into a game that I‚Äôd actually have some beef with, but what hurts even more is the fact that this is coming on the heels of my discovery of Ubisoft‚Äôs decision to turn off all online features to their classic game lineup, which means all the DLC will also die on September 1st.

I guess I‚Äôm just getting sick of how foolish Ubisoft is becoming. I mean, you have bad games? Sure, I get it. The classic games are super old and likely don‚Äôt have quite as much attention? Yeah, I can see that being something to discuss. What isn‚Äôt okay is when this announcement comes right out of the blue, with only a short time for people to back up their files before they‚Äôre screwed. It certainly doesn‚Äôt help that multiplayer isn‚Äôt the only thing we‚Äôre losing. Honestly, why does DLC still require online access.

If you ask me, I think the only game that should‚Äôve been dropped by this table flip is the game I‚Äôm covering right now. Seriously, how do you make a post nuclear apocalypse game WORSE than Fallout 4?!

Ok, guess we‚Äôd better wade through this purple haze river. The story begins some time after the nukes drop and Hope County is now shrunk to half its size(I really wish I was making that up). The people have come out from their vau-er, underground hidey-holes and slowly begun reclaiming the earth. Hopes are high at first, until a group of ne‚Äôer-do-wells led by twin sisters begin raiding and stealing from the innocent. So the hero has to stop them! The greatest hero of all, the‚Ä¶*reads* SECURITY CAP-wait, what? *reads again* Security captain. Aw, crap.

Yeah, let‚Äôs be clear here: the story absolutely sucks. I am absolutely baffled how we can go from a fanatical family of siblings putting a young rookie cop through layers of heavenly hell as (s)he seeks to save Hope County, only for the end result to be more akin to the book of revelations, to ‚ÄúOh no! Neon colored bandits zomg!‚Äù That‚Äôs pretty much all it is, and while the two featured villainesses are certainly big on style and have excellent voice acting, they have virtually no substance. There‚Äôs maybe one scene that takes a passing glance at their past and that‚Äôs it. There‚Äôs one other segment involving Joseph Seed and his new family, but all that leads to is a villain born of jealousy, something we‚Äôve all seen before. It would‚Äôve been at least somewhat interesting if you‚Äôd‚Äôve gotten to choose between Joseph and this other villain, but even that wouldn‚Äôt save the game from annoying predictable moments, watered down versions of characters featured in the last game, and an overall sense of emptiness that just makes the plot so ‚Äúby the numbers.‚Äù

Speaking of by the numbers, gameplay is pretty much the same, and does little to improve things. In fact, one of my least favorite aspects is how base capturing works. As opposed to past games which just gave you a whole bunch of bases to nab, here, it goes like this: each base can be captured multiple times, each subsequent time more difficult and more rewarding than the last. While it does add things like more alarms and more guards, the major letdown is the fact that you‚Äôre essentially going after the same bases over and over and over again. The only other big gameplay feature is the ability to go to other locations in the world to participate in glorified fetch quests. These quests may throw in their own unique rewards, but it‚Äôs just more of the same: sneak around and kill things, only this time, grab their stash and haul back to your ride. It‚Äôs something, I guess, just more of the same that barely adds anything. Even crafting got shafted; now all we can make are premade weapons and vehicles. That‚Äôs the worst part of gameplay in general; if it hasn‚Äôt already been done to death, it takes a step backwards.

What really frustrates me is how such a bare bones game still manages to look as good as it does. While the graphics haven‚Äôt taken any big leaps forward, it‚Äôs still all very pretty to looks at. Hell, between the bandit bases and the environment in general, this may be one of the most colorful Far Cry games out there. In terms of music‚Ä¶yeah, it‚Äôs not as good. Granted, it‚Äôs subjective, but I‚Äôm not sure anyone‚Äôs going to jump for joy when their great american classic rock got traded in for the biggest hits from the‚Ä¶40s? 50s? Seriously, I feel like New Dawn was trying unnecessarily to be Fallout with the music choices. The bandit tunes are marginally better, but I didn‚Äôt get into them as much as I hoped. I wouldn‚Äôt say that stuff is terrible, but then you turn around and play Cyberpunk 2077 and wonder if the New Dawn bandit tunes were CDPR‚Äôs ‚Äúrejected tunes‚Äù list. It‚Äôs just so in your face that it feels like it doesn‚Äôt belong.

For those who follow me on r/SeriousSteamReviews, I‚Äôve officially decided this will be my last Ubisoft game for quite some time. The only one I really have on my radar at this point is FC6, and that‚Äôs really only because I‚Äôve heard the ‚Äúplay as the villain‚Äù DLCs are good stuff. I‚Äôm not happy making this decision, especially since I‚Äôm certain there‚Äôs some good Ubisoft games out there, but between the Assassin‚Äôs Creed roller coaster and the very badly made decision about scrapping older online content, it‚Äôs safe to say this company has fallen far from what it used to be, and considering how the latest AC games have microtransactions on them as well, I don‚Äôt believe they‚Äôre going to recover anytime soon, and that‚Äôs assuming they even care to. Thanks for reading!

7/10.

Far Cry New Dawn is definitely Far Cry. So your mileage may vary.

There is a tight story here, and unlike Far Cry 5 they don't lock it away behind hours of grinding if that's not your thing. The villains are pretty meh for a FC game. The silent protagonist thing is still here, with all the drawbacks that comes with. But there's fun to be had, and a progression system that actually feels like progression, which is better than it's been since FC3, probably.

I went into this thinking it'd be more of the FC5 experience, but it was surprisingly different enough to be enjoyed while similar enough to be interesting. All in all, not half bad.

nice games

The epitome of Ubisoft mediocrity. 

It seems like with every game Ubi makes, the worlds become more bland, the story is more barebones, and the games become more grindy. Far Cry 5 was already the worst Far Cry game they've made, and now this is even worse.

This game 100% wants to encourage you to buy microtransactions. As soon as you start exploring the world you'll find enemies that are a higher "tier" than your weapon class. So you'll collect materials, loot locations, and buy upgraded weapons to stand a chance. The problem is, the endgame (as in, the final 2 boss fights) is designed around the "elite" tier weapons. And to get these, you have a to grind out special co-op focused missions to get a material that you can't get anywhere else in the game. (bet you just want to make it easier and just buy it huh?). The structure of the game and the drive to "buy" more with real money is truly disgusting.

Most of the game, I was doing quite already with tier 2-3 weapons. But the final boss fights were such utter miserable slogs against enemies that have 1,000,000 health, that you basically have to fight them with elite weapons or you will just have a miserable time. Which I did. And while fighting the Twins, there is a constant stream of dogs that chase after you, grabbing your leg and unfuriating the fuck out of you.

This game truly sucks, and it's clear that Ubisoft cares more about $$$ than making games that are interesting, innovating, or fun.

Only buy if on sale and a Far Cry fan?

While I really enjoyed Far Cry 5, New Dawn is a half-arsed attempt on transferring the Fallout vibes into Hope County and leeching off the likeable NPCs from the predecessor. But while the Seed family had at least fleshed out personalities the twins are shallow cutboard highschool bullies. The main plot is thin at best and the mission design is weak just like the gun play.
The only thing on the plus side is that the co-op is more player-friendly as the co-op partner is not barred from essential perks such as additional weapons and health.

The only reason I am pulling throgh is my completionist attitude, but I will not touch this game again, good thing I got it on sale.

Do not buy this at full price. It should be / is DLC for Far Cry 5, using an altered version of the same map and similar story.

As with all modern Far Cry games, the world is great and the game play is fun, but Ubisoft insisted on sabotaging this to try and squeeze more money from you (even more so than usual).

They've padded it out with a bullet sponge enemies and huge amounts of unavoidable crafting/grinding to pad the length, and then have the fucking cheek to sell 'coins' (for real money) to skip this and make it less grindy again. It's like selling you a car with no wheels and then charging extra for them as a 'favour' to you. Don't piss on me and claim it's raining, Ubisoft.

If you haven't played Far Cry 5, buy that. If you have and want more, buy this on a steep sale. I got it for about ¬£10 and it's probably worth that - if the usual Ubisoft/Microtransaction/DRM nonsense isn't a deal-breaker for you.

Nice short follow up to FC5

New Dawn is a slightly different game in terms of mechanics compared to FC5. It involves leveling up home base, weapons and stuff. The story is a sequel to FC5 though. It is also slightly tougher than FC5 (simply because FC5 is too easy). Graphics are pretty and voice acting is good. For better story experience, get it together with FC5 if you haven't have one.

6.5/10. Entertaining, light and funny. The same intuitive and pleasing gameplay of the Far Cry serie. Roger Cadoret is priceless and his dialogues in some expeditions are pure gold. Boring story and poor antagonist designs but we don't play Far Cry for the story anyway, right ? The soundtrack isn't impressive, but I did love that one mission with disco music enough to go listen to it again online. Horatio is bae.

It's not that New Dawn is a bad game, it's sort of OK.  

On one hand it looks great.

But if you have already played Far Cry 3, 4, or 5 then there is not much new on offer. The story is far less engaging and the enemies are just bullet sponges. Or you are stuck in a tight spot vs overwhelming odds, killed, wait to respawn, repeat until you get lucky.

Menus and crafting are tedious.

Actually the more I think about it, the whole thing is a real drag compared to FC 3, 4 and 5.

I am a long time player of many FPS, looter-shooters, etc. And while I found some of this Far Cry game to be good, and I did have some fun times during the game, I must say there were a few areas of this game that really made me regret even installing it. So, no, I can't recommend this to other people to play. Sorry. I'm going to go back and play one of the other Far Cry games and just put this back on the shelf, where it really does need to stay.

Not a game. This is a dlc for the price of a full game. Which is a shame, because I really like the Far cry 5 characters and it was nice to see what happened to them and to myself as the protagonist of the previous game. It's not bad, it's just too short and too expensive for what it delivers. And the ending is meh. Just buy this if it's on a very good sale. Don't buy it full price. It's not worth the money.
Edit: Btw, don't buy it even if it's on sale. Don't give them money for something they'll take from you later. Specially a mediocre game like this one.

Ubisoft has started REMOVING single player games (yes, base games, not just online DLC) that customers BOUGHT, from their library. 

If you are thinking about buying this game (and "BUY" is the plain wording on every Steam store page), be aware you may only be able to play it for the next 6 weeks, before Ubisoft REMOVES it from your library.

Ubisoft also thinks it is clever to put the game on promotion for new suckers just before REMOVING the game.  Ie AC Liberation HD was on promotion price last week during the Steam summer sale, this week the store page says the game will no longer playable in 6 weeks time.  

The Steam store pages (links below) for AC Liberation HD, and Silent Hunter 5, both have notices saying "Please note this title will not be ACCESSIBLE following September 1st, 2022".  Even though you BOUGHT these single player games, you will not be able to access them.

I am setting my review on every Ubisoft game I own to negative.  If you think this practice is unacceptable, please comment, upvote the review, or leave your own review.

Another pretty cool game in this franchise. Read some reviews that said this should be a DLC as it was short, and while it was shorter than the other recent games, it still took me 23 hours to beat this game as there is alot you can do if you choose to.

Game had some solid challenges to it and looked, sounded, and had excellent characters as well. 

After the exciting start (as is the signature of this series), the first thing that jumped out was just how colorful this game is. The colors were bright and vibrant (which is also a reflection of the events that had happened) and it looked amazing. The game play is pretty much the same as it was starting in FC3 (maybe 2, but I didn't like 2 that much), and since I played FC5 and this game back to back, everything was easy to pick up as they are mostly the same game (what isn't nowadays) which is probably why I liked this alot and think it is an underrated game.

This game takes place 17 years after the events of FC5. Seeing the land and some of the familiar faces was pretty cool and how it all changed and remembering what it looked like before was a little insane. I thought they did a cool job with this game and I think if you play them back to back, you will get the same feel I did. 

Had a few different things to do in this game, but for the most part, alot of the changes were just a way to grind out resources so you upgrade to the next level or weapon which was fine, and offers a good challenge, especially with each level you push it.

Also, I was able to max out the settings, and this game will strain your CPU (unless you spent about 10 grand on it) but It ran at an average of 90FPS which was awesome. No screen tearing and ran very smoothly except for a couple of spots. Ran great, looked great, played great. Fun game with new and old characters, and like I said, was very cool playing back to back.

Did 9/11 happen in the Cars universe? The thing I really like about Planes is that we learn that WWII happened in the Cars universe. Which means there was a Cars Hitler, a Cars holocaust, a Cars Pacific War, a Cars D-Day, a Cars nuking of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, a Cars Rape of Nanking, a Cars Battle of Iwo Jima... This leads to so many important questions, like: were the Cars Little Boy and Fat Man nukes sentient? Was it a suicide mission? Are ALL Cars nuclear weapons sentient? Did Tsar Bomba have a personality? What kind of car was Car Hitler? A VW? A forklift? Was there a Cars 9/11? Were the planes hijacked, or were the planes themselves radicalized? I could go on Edit: I just realized a Cars 9/11 gives a whole new layer of meaning to the phrase "let's roll"

I feel like this game has me hating the antagonists for the wrong reasons.

You see, Fc5 had goals. It had characters who HAD goals that conflicted with other characters. Even Joseph could barely control his siblings at times. These twins, Mickey and Lou? I feel like someone spent ages coming up with backstory for them, making sure each sister had a distinctive personality and ambitions. Then someone told that writer that they already made the game with their first draft. Basically boiling them down to PINK SISTER ANGRY GRR and BLUE SISTER SMART BUT ALSO ANGRY GRR. And this falls so flat because there isn't anything shown to the player that these characters are intimidating at the least. I would compare them to two girls whining to their father that they weren't able to kill the bad man/woman who keeps killing their friends. NOTHING is fleshed out about these two, most of their dialogue is through vague threats at the player and their lackeys for doing/not doing the thing that just happened. There was a point halfway through the game where you are FORCED to do something stupid with no alternative so the twins can be "Badass" with no repercussions. Again, I feel sorry for the writer/ writers that were on this game, because they obviously did not get enough time to write the story they wanted to write.

Also, even placing an OPTION to buy guns with REAL money in these games is just insulting to the average player. Mobile game versions of monitization DO NOT belong in pc/console games. Its like having a man in a business suit ask you for 5 dollars to get you a soda from your fridge so you don't have to get it yourself; and if you don't pay he straps 20 pound weights to your ankles so you can "Feel like you deserve it."

Don't get this game. Not for the cut content nor the story. There is nothing here.

(sorry for the long and badly written shitty review!)
Far cry New Dawn is just Far Cry 5 1.5 with minor adjustments to the gameplay except for the RPG mechanic which I will mostly highlight the review on. 
 
RPG mechanics are an interesting feature for the game but are kinda lackluster and kinda badly implemented since trying to use any weapon beneath the enemies rank like a rank 3 AK will still take about 2 whole mags or more to kill a rank 4 enforcer. LMGs are also turned into a joke against rank 2-4 ranked enemies even if the LMG is rank 3 and the enemy is rank 2, he will still take 20 rounds. 
 
Stealth has also been affected by the RPG mechanics i feel like since you need perks to takedown higher ranked enemies and have the same ranked bow to successfully one hit kill an enemy which make stealth annoying sometimes, throwing knifes also don‚Äôt one hit kill rank 3 (maybe even rank 2) and all enemies rank 2 and above have helmets so ranged stealth kills are focused on the boy except if you have piercing sniper ammo. 
 
The base rusty guns with slow and janky reloads are a nice addition along with the makeshift attachments like screwdriver bayonets, random pieces of metal around the gun or some electrical tape to either hold together the gun or an attachment that really adds character or make the guns seem different to the generic black/gray guns that in other games all melt together. The biggest problem with guns is the general lack of them, there are about 69 guns in total which sounds like a lot but that number has to be divided by 5 for each weapon like SMGs and ARs. 
All guns also have presett attachments so maybe only one of the assault rifles suits you because it has a suppressor which wouldn't be a problem in FC5 since you can add suppressor to any gun(not really). The lack of guns complaint is definitely me being spoiled but seeing that FCND is just a smaller version of FC5 which had much more guns is kinda disappointing. 
 
The big usage of purple in the apocalyptic Hope County is a nice feature which differentiates itself from Fallout, Stalker and Metro with their sometimes overgrown but mostly bleak wastelands. The creatures and especially the legendary ones look cool and fit the vibrant apocalyptic landscape everything has turned into. 
 
Changing out money for scraps and parts which are used for guns and vehicles is a good idea to make it more different from FC5 but can get annoying when trying to get rank 4 guns. The addition of Ethanol is ok and was at first annoying/hard to get but just scavenging an outpost over and over again leads to finding ethanol becoming unnecessary, i had my base at level 2 and 4 thousand ethanol which made all other outposts useless except for killing enemies. 

 Summary. 
RPG mechanics were cool and interesting but pretty poorly implemented and kinda ruined stealth/made perfect stealth runs much harder, Guns look cool but are kinda ruined by the RPG mechanic and are generally lacking in amount, landscape is cool and distinctive from other post-apocalyptic games, scraps and parts instead of money is a good idea but can get annoying and outposts are pretty useless if you have enough ethanol. 


So in Summary it's a 6/10 even if i list more negatives than positives, if you want a Far Cry game then buy FC3-6 and see this game as a short add-on to FC5 instead of a full Far Cry Game.

Short development cycles always gave us the most interesting unique FC games. I guess they feel it‚Äôs safer to take more risks. Following one of endings in FC5 gave us a cool experience. The changes are substantial and divisive enough to mean that it'll be hard to say for sure if you enjoy this. This review will spoil FC5 if you haven't played it.

+ Core game play. The game is built directly out of FC5. The following points detail the changes. 
+ Less substantial game play changes. The overall movement and interaction system has been subtly improved even more. Everything is beautifully smooth. A different set of more violent lethal take downs are back. Since people were unhappy with the blunt take downs. All weapons are no longer customizable as they are mostly makeshift versions made with unique models and specific capabilities. There are resources to collect and spend now instead of just money. This was implemented very simply. Locations have single pickup resources. Other objectives offer resources as rewards. Certain objectives have certain types.  
+ Outposts. After capturing them the first time. You actually have the option to face harder versions of them finally. You have the option to abandon them and this will cause the more difficult force to take control. Sadly, there is no dynamic attacks for the enemies to take them this time.
+ Extraction. Off map missions become available. During these missions you go to other locations to retrieve something of interest. These are basically very large outposts with way more enemies. You choose how to play it out. After retrieving the object of interest, you must stand your ground until you get picked up. This is a simple, but fun addition using the games regular mechanics.
+ Hunting. Playing into the mutated environments animals are different from what they were. As a result, playing into the RPG combat more threatening classes of animals exist. Killing them is more of a battle as they often have strong defense. The higher tier skins can be traded for higher value materials.
+ Exploration. Seeing the transformation of Hope County is nice for those who enjoy world design and exploration. Yes, this world is designed under the colorful world scheme that was a fad at the time. This one is quite simply the best. Forcing it to constrain to a realistic natural environment worked great. If you remember the background details of FC5 you will have a good time getting some follow up on what happened to all the people and places. That's it for gameplay.
+ Soundtrack. The soundtrack is awesome if you don't mind the genre. The idea of designing the theme off of "electronically distorting" the FC5 country version was really cool. All the songs follow that resulting style. The baddies love playing their trash "rave" music really loudly so you get to enjoy terminating their asses and put to a stop. As territory is taken the radio station goes back to playing classic varieties of music. Which is a good bonus to immersion.
+ Story. I actually really liked it. Certain parts were very campy. Others were fun. While others were very cool and unique as far as game stories go. Following through on the apocalypse ending in this style was very interesting. Playing the FC6 Joseph dlc makes it even cooler. Most complaints seem to be they just disagree with the decision. There is nothing definitively wrong with what happened.
+ UI. There is a bunch of new UI stuff to do with the RPG combat. Individual segments of it can be shut down in the options. Most other things can be shut down piece by piece too.

+/- Combat. Has taken an RPG turn. Enemies have different amounts of health and armor based on progress/difficulty. Weapons now have tiers. This is something that‚Äôs always been a thing, but the differences were tiny and obscured. In this game its very pronounced. Weapons traditionally were good because they were inherently better than others. Not this time using low tier weapons will have a significantly harder time against higher tiers. This change comes with the benefit of a larger difficulty curve, but a loss of realism. Normally a head shot would be very lethal against any enemy (with specific exceptions). This doesn't apply this time. Reactions to this is mixed. I have mixed feelings about it as well, but was fine with it in the end. If you‚Äôre unsure you will probably be fine with it. It does take a moment to get used to in game as it needs to be taken into account. 
+/- Coop. It‚Äôs a thing again, but still super janky as the engine has no ability to properly instance for more than one client. So, the second player is still tethered to the host.
+/- World Scenario. Despite how some find the circumstances of the story absurd. It‚Äôs really not when you actually think about the way things are laid out. It was a nuclear strike so death would be largely random. The trash of modern society will still be here and create opportunity for them to become leaders in the new world. That's what happens to Hope County. A cringe morale relativistic millennial society fills in what was Hope County. The scenario plays out differently elsewhere as indicated. Other places are more stable and better off. This is why your character comes to Hope County. Your here to try to restore order. That results in you getting pulled into the Hope County story scenario. It‚Äôs hard to say what they were playing at, but certain factors make it seem that restoring Hope County to what it was before the cult is the good (non-left-wing culture) making the stuff you‚Äôre fighting the bad. 
+/- Silent Character. Your silent like you were in FC5. I'm torn on this. Certain elements of the story make me say it‚Äôs probably a good thing, but in others it‚Äôs kind of awkward. Some parts feel like moments that are better without you talking because a massive variety of vastly different responses would be valid and it allows you to react as yourself. When it comes to others it seems wrong that you‚Äôre not speaking to them because what you would be saying is much narrower. 

- Smaller and shorter. Of the short dev cycle games (FCBD and FCP) this one is the smallest in overall length and map size. It does however have to most changes to the systems.
- Simulation range. This is an understated problem effecting all FC. The range for game play entities is too short. Things can spawn within line of sight. Things disappear quickly. These too combine for random encounters repeating rapidly in your vicinity. This affects all the relevant mechanics in a negative way. Causing immersion and realism breaks.

I almost didn't play this because of the FC trash talk. I'm glad I eventually did because it was a great experience overall. FC takes a lot of heat for being the same thing each time even though that‚Äôs better than changing and destroying everything. Each game has its own subtle nuances with this one being more pronounced. This one has the largest game play changes and as a result took a lot of backlash. It‚Äôs worth trying to see a different iteration. Clearly a lot was learned from this based on FC6.

Ok so.. I am both relieved and shocked to find out I in fact do not have the most hours on this game. I'm like 4th or 5th or something. Definently top 10. Anyway I've doubled my hours from the first review so I wanna give it a refresh. However, not much has changed in my opinion. The game is still a Far Cry 5 DLC. Much of the game is a reskin, there's hella bugs and problems.. but here I am still playing it. Mainly cause of the Highwaymen. They look cool and I just love a Apoloalytic free roam first person shooter. But by this point, I can act out the scenes better than these NPC's do in cutscenes and while talking to them. I've probably spent more time Playing this game than they spent making it. 

The game's likely dead and the fandom behind it is gone, but here I am still playing. 

Anyway there is something new I would like to point out. While the microtransactions are shitty and do very little, I found one positive to them. Namely the perk points and crafting materials. While it doesn't feel good to spend 10 bucks on a few perk points and crafting stuff when you can grind them for free, I learned that those things that are bought in the store can be new game transferable (like the oufits and weapons bought). Whatever you buy transfers to every new game so technically you can just keep restarting and have a bunch of crafting stuff and perk points at the start. Now i wouldn't recommend doing that on a game that's dead, but I burned 10 bucks to learn about this so.. do with it what you will.

FC:ND is largely the same experience as FC5. Stupid, enjoyable guilty pleasure with very little gameplay alterations, and only worth getting on discount. Not much to say here really, It's just FC5 with some reskins and minor gameplay tweaks.

The Good Stuff:
+ It's basically FC5 but pinkier and with no annoying recurring gameplay interruptions necessitated by the need to show too many antagonists. You can treat this as an expansion to FC5 with all the pros and cons of that approach.
+ While weapon customization is gone, the weapons you build have clearly defined roles which lets them be a little more unique than in FC5.

The Bad Stuff:
- If you expected the post-apocalyptic setting to force some kind of major gameplay changes, think again. This is Far Cry, there's no risks taken here. 99% of the time you won't remember the game is supposed to take place after an apocalyptic event.
- Just like in FC5 - mandatory Ubisoft connect and in-game purchases. Sigh.

After seeing all of the bad reviews for this game I was not looking forward to playing it, however suprisingly I enjoyed it alot more than I thought.  This might be because I enjoy RPG mechanics which don't really fit FC that well but I thought made an make a short game feel longer but having to collect things to level up.  For a completionest like me it was not very hard at all and all the extra resources made getting the better guns and equipment not feel like a grind since I was already going out of my way to get them.  Main story with the highwaymen is very weak and unintresting however all the stuff that connects it to FC5 I find tons more compelling.  The boss fights in hard mode felt a bit damage spongy but with the OP LMG's they can be killed pretty quick with some luck.  Fairly buggy and decent open world, wish they changed more from 5 besides just landscapes, destruction, and colors.  Also really hated replaying the same explorations and outpost 3 times with different level enemies.  I don't really wanna play FC 6 except for the Villian DLC's but for me this is a decent ending to the far cry 5 story. But wish the real ending to the game was a bit more besides killing or saving Joseph.  Anyway 6/10 won't play again but I'll have some good memories.

Pros:

Cons:

It makes no sense when a moving car can figure me out in 0.5 seconds while both of us moving to different directions, especially if you are from a helicopter. IDK why i am playing this but anyway,
Overall, if you liked FC5, you'll probably like this as well. It's a relatively short campaign , set in many of the same locales as before, and with many of the same faces as before. Unexpectedly, especially if - like me - you come from many hours in Fallout's Wasteland, its world is one in which nature bounced back beautifully from nuclear apocalypse. FCND kind-of ties up some elements of FC5's storyline, although its story is much less developed, but then it is a much shorter game than FC5. Otherwise, it has many of the same strengths, and most of the same weaknesses, but it does have a nice new "Expeditions" mode that takes you to exotic mini-maps to collect extra resources. However, one thing that it's sadly missing from FC5 is an excellent soundtrack. 

In summary, if you want just a little bit more FC5, and a peek at a post-apocalyptic wasteland that's actually quite beautiful, then this is worth checking out. But perhaps wait for it to be on special offer on Steam (or your preferred vendor).

Maps/10

Compared to Far Cry 5:

- "same" map, but really feels like it's a new one due to drastical changes in the environment. Some sections are cut off, so the map size is maybe two thirds of that in FC5
- fewer people, more (mutated) animals
- fishing is still in
- drugs are out
- can have only one companion instead of two
- no boats and planes roaming around, so you can finally hike/fish in peace
- two crazy black women instead of two crazy white dudes as antagonists
- you are not the "hero" this time, rather his independent agent
- there is a very simplistic RPG system here with 4 tiers (normal, rare, epic, legendary) for weapons and NPCs. Although it's arguably unnecessary, it leaves the "one shot, one kill" gameplay of the Far Cry series intact, while giving the player a little more sense of direction and progression. It mostly forces you to gather some materials and then commit to an upgrade choice, unless you want to grind more materials and craft other high tier weapons as well.
- all points of interest can be completed by gathering all the materials on their site. While this is a nice functional addition to POIs / map progression, it can be very frustrating when you are a completionist and bad at searching props
- some gameplay aspects are now embodied in your upgradeable base. Gather materials to upgrade facilities, which then improve your stats (like health) or unlock quick travel via helicopter, craft vehicles in the garage, add map markers at the cartographer
- of COURSE this game has outposts to conquer. Difference here is, after conquering you can either keep it as a respawn/crafting station, or abandon it; this will then repopulate it with enemies of the next higher tier
- expeditions: you can travel to some completely new locations and usually steal something from the bad guys. Maps I've seen so far were an abandoned aircraft carrier, giving me huge FC1 vibes, and a spooky post-apocalyptic amusement park. Each expedition also comes in multiple tiers, if you're up for some grind.
- skinning: While in Far Cry 3, skins were used to craft items directly, in Far Cry 5, they were just converted into money. New Dawn is a middle ground, where you convert skins into materials and then use those for crafting. It works well as long as you can ignore the idiotic idea that Elk Hide produces Duct Tape and Wolfskin produces Copper
- experts: much like in FC Primal, you have to find experts before you can upgrade facilities to certain tiers. The associated quests are pretty fun

All in all, New Dawn is a fully fledged game and a worthy entry to the series. It looks like it acts as somewhat of a guinea pig for trying out (or leaving out) game mechanics as little mutations (hehe) to the FC game formula. FC5 is still the greater title and should ideally be played first, as  New Dawn is the direct successor and many of the characters make reappearances.

Far Cry New Dawn, a spin off to Far Cry 5 which comprises of an extended DLC campaign which continues 17 years after.

Dawn is in my opinion a Falloutesque, post apocalyptic first person shooter. The game is still set in "Hope County" however now, the law of the land is non existent, areas are overgrown and colourful with poisonous beauty. Animals run rampant and so does the breakdown of human civilization. The map is open world and very visually appealing much like its predecessor.

We have the survivors, the highway men and the remnants of the Edens gate Zealots which comprise of the land. The existing game play from Far Cry 5  is still entwined with a few differences.  Weapons that require crafting as well as boats and aircraft. Compounds can still be taken, but you will acquire a valuable resource called Ethanol and it is required to upgrade your community to further enhance your gameplay (health, gun upgrades ect). Perks are attained as per usual, this includes hunting for animals and doing various challenges and grinding. You can also roster a friend to fight with you as per previous series. Enemies are highlighted by their level which indicates their difficulty and this is the same for missions. The mechanics also differ in areas such as takedowns.

As for the story itself, it is a closure to the Far Cry 5 series. There are new overlords called the "Twins" who take the charge of the Villains in New Dawn. But the story runs deeper and crosses elements with the ghosts of the past.

I didn't really come across any troubles with this game. It does require the Ubisoft interface and unfortunately the game does have several elements of micro transactions.

If you do wish to explore life after the events of Far Cry 5 and seek closure on the particular series, then New Dawn will offer this without hugely extensive depth but to the point.

Me and My best friend bought this game after playing through Far Cry 5 together and thought trying out Far Cry New Dawn wouldn't be so bad but boy were we wrong

The enemy tiers are pretty annoying for us and it made the it less like a original Far Cry game (With no health bars and tiers) and it even stops you from having binoculars from the get-go! (You have to unlock them as a perk) and the game also doesn't let you customise weapons you've obtained like in Far Cry 5 which makes the advancements feel a little less rewarding. The story in this is good in some places but it just doesn't feel fulfilling enough to play through to the end when you get to about 15/16 story missions in which is why we just gave up with it. 

Far Cry New Dawn is definitely not exactly made for Co-op either, for example, most story missions required you to drive and it will only be between you and the npc of that mission and your co-op buddy would need to either steal a nearby vehicle or literally sit on the vehicle your driving, this wasn't too bad but overtime it did get pretty annoying. In most cases with story missions, my best friend would randomly get booted off my game and one time it even stopped a mission from continuing so I had to do a entire mission from scratch again on my own. In Far Cry 5 the co-op gameplay with story missions was really well implemented but with Far Cry New Dawn it just feels likes it's just been put on at the end of development as an extra bit to the game.

This game definitely should've just been a big DLC for Far Cry 5 rather than being sold as a standalone game for such a high price for the little amount of content that you get out of this in fact you are better off buying the DLC for Far cry 5 and playing that instead.

If you want an extra story-line to Far Cry 5, get it on a sale, but DO NOT buy this game at full price and find a game that is much more worth your money and time.

[h1]Like most other games in the series, new dawn has some of the typical open-world flaws, but ultimately it‚Äòs one of the series‚Äò best entries.[/h1]

to start with one of it‚Äòs negatives, the story in far cry new dawn is very weak and lacks weight and focus. not that previous far cry games had stronger ones, but those had at least one or two excellently written and interesting characters like Vaas or Pagan Min to compensate for the weak plot. In New Dawn, not one single interesting or fleshed out character is found. Some characters from Far Cry 5 make a return, but they weren‚Äôt particularly interesting back then and they haven‚Äôt changed for sure. Joseph Seed makes a return as well, but while he had this creepy and mysterious aura and was charismatic af in fc 5, in new dawn he only plays a rather minor role and just seems to be a shadow of himself. the two new antagonists, evil twins Mickey and Lou who lead a group of bandits are downright tame and boring compared to preceeding antagonists, too. The only characters who come close to beeing memorable are Hank Drubman (another returning character from fc 5 who is clearly inspired by some of the goofy roles played by Vince Vaughn) and a somewhat crazy young pharmacist you meet early in the game, but they both only get one mission after which you barely interact with them again.  

what really shines on the other hand is the game world. instead of following the typical post-nuclear cliche of a total devastion, the game shows a regenerating nature, that comes back to life stronger than ever without the harmful influence of mankind. Far Cry New Dawn is probably the most colourful and beautiful fps i ever played and i couldn‚Äôt get enough of the absolutely stunning sights in the game, full of vibrant strong colors and lush vegetation. The game world is what kept me coming back and it‚Äôs one of new dawn‚Äòs biggest strengths. i didn‚Äòt even mind the collectibles this time around. Even though i usually hate collectibles in open world games, here i almost even welcomed them, because they gave me a reason to explore as much of the fantastic map as possible. they even made sense from a story-viewpoint: you‚Äòre in this big, hostile post-apocalyptic world, just trying to survive and rebuild a community, so that‚Äôs what you would actually do in that situation. scavenge the environment and collect ressources. apart from a few outlandish and supernatural elements during the last third of the story, i found the whole premise of new dawn actually much more believable than that of far cry 5. further considering the looks of the game, it is a small wonder how stable, smooth and bug-free the whole game runs, even on the highest setting. Apart from falling through the world one time, i experienced no crashes, no glitches and no significant stuttering.

the smaller scope and linearity really work wonders for the game. sure, the weapon roster and number of vehicles are very stripped back compared to fc 5, but again, it‚Äôs post-apocalypse, so no airplanes, helicopters or tons of exotic high-tech guns.

fc 5 was a great game, and new dawn builds on that foundation, enriching it with some neat twists. it‚Äôs not free of the common problems of the open world genre, but the only really bad thing about new dawn is it‚Äôs awful mumble rap soundtrack. this makes it the second-best game in the series, only surpassed by far cry 3, proving the unwritten law of the far cry series once more: the odd numbers and the spin-offs are the better ones, the even numbers are somewhat weaker.

I honestly don't know what the hate was about for this game. Finally got around to playing it, and it is gorgeous. I found later on that even with elite weapons, the enemy variety and difficulties forced me to actually make plans when taking outposts, and to be careful. The story was passable, with by far the most interesting part seeing how Joseph's story continues after the massive cliff hanger of Farcry 5. I played Farcry 5 many times, and seeing how the story continues and how Hope County changed was especially interesting. I wish the map was more the size of the previous game, with a lot of key locations still being around to see, because other than a few a lot of locations weren't even there, or the landscape changed in ways the bombs in 5 would not have changed. Bombs don't build mountains, guys. I would have liked to hear more about the deputy's story other than the tiny bit of info scattered around, but other than that I will be playing this again whenever I play through the Farcry games again. Gameplay was great. I recommend.

A solid open-world action game with a unique artstyle and atmosphere. I like the unusually optimistic and colorful portrayal of the aftermath of Nuclear Armageddon. The Highwaymen are among my favorite enemies out of all the games I've played. I find their style highly appealing and more than once I found myself wishing I was given the option to join them. They seem to have fully embraced the new rules of the reborn world, unlike our allies who seem a bit... stuck in the old ways? Honestly I found them bland. Not sure if there was intentional social commentary behind making the enemies violent young rebels and the good guys resolute middle-aged traditionalists, considering it's not something I've seen discussed, but I couldn't help feeling that way. As for the Twins, they were okay villains. They worked fine for the story. 

The gameplay itself is simple and fun. It feels significantly less cluttered than other open-world / Far Cry games. Increasing weapon/enemy tiers kept combat challenging until the end, though I would have loved being able to customize weapons with items found in the environment instead of the weapons coming with scopes and screwdrivers attached. Taking over outposts stealthily is lots of fun and I like that we can replay them at higher difficulties for increased rewards. Adds a lot of content without bloating the map. 

For me the game really only has one significant drawback and that is the forever boat ride through the fog. It is extremely tedious after the first time and I wish there was a way to skip it.

The short version:
The gameplay was fun and the ending wasn't horrible. The companion AI is pretty bad. Not horrible, but there were times where the companion would follow a bad path to attack the enemies, or just stand over me doing nothing while I was dying. The game was pretty short. Worth it on sale, but not worth $40.



The longer version:
The gameplay is as fun as the others. You take down outposts, but they added the ability to give up the outpost and re-take them. Though when you do, the enemies get harder and more plentiful. You also gain extra resources by giving up and retaking the outposts. You can re-take them as many times as you want, but they stop leveling up on the third cycle. Also, you gain less fuel (a resource to increase your town) by not sneaking, but not by a ton, and since you can re-take the outposts, it isn't a big deal overall.

The storyline wasn't bad, but wan't great either. Honestly, it was as memorable as any of the others. The only difference between this game and 3, 4, and 5 is that in 5 years when I think back to this game, I'm going to remember that they didn't decide to go with either a bad ending, or a slightly better, but still bad ending.

You craft weapon and vehicles, and the materials are found either through scavenging camps (marked on your map when you pass them), by killing the wildlife and turning in their skins, or by doing expeditions. The top-most tier of weapons can be leveled up via crafting, but doing so only increases the weapons damage by 5%. I assume that you can level them up as many times as you want, but didn't test it myself.

Expeditions are mini-missions that are also repeatable, and just like the outposts, they level up, getting harder but giving more rewards. Your goal is to grab a package and once you do, the enemies track you down while you have to wait for a helicopter. The amount of resources gained does not change whether you use stealth or not.

The level system is that you gain perk points by either doing missions, doing events as you wander around, doing outposts/expeditions, or completing challenges. For some of the perks, you can buy multiple ranks, such as being able to carry more medkits, or holding more ammo, but they aren't too big of a deal.
At a certain point in the game something happens which unlocks 5 more perks, with a total cost of about 40 points. So if you get to the point where you have an abundance of points, but haven't unlocked those skills, it may be worth it to hold onto the points.

As you progress, some of the enemies will get harder, and the topmost difficulty are elite enemies. These enemies can not be tracked through walls like the rest of the enemies, which was a cool feature, but I felt this feature was under-utilized.

The biggest issue I had with the game was the companions.

Companions, for the most part, are weak and die easily. There was one that I got early on and was my favorite, as they used silenced weapons, which is always useful, and another that was amazing, but not silenced. Overall 2 of the eight were good, the rest were meh. Some of the characters know each other, though, and having the right party member in the group for the mission gives an extra line of dialog. Oh, and when enemies spot your companion, they do not spot you, so your undetected bonus isn't removed.

That being said, the AI isn't great. There were times where I'd tell them to attack, so they run all the way down and around to the other side of the map just to get the shot. Whereas had they taken two steps to the left, they would have had a clear shot. They also ran THROUGH the area, which made every enemy target them, which led them to dying. On the upside, getting them back is easy, as you just spend three readily available crafting mats. There's not even a cooldown. Though there was a time where it bugged out and wouldn't let me summon any companions.

Companions are horrible at following you and take forever to catch up at times. So if you go down, it takes them a while to get to you. If they don't die first. Or, you know, just stand over your body looking around at the nearby enemies, not even attacking.

There was also many times where I would tell the companion to attack, and the game would think that I was pointing behind the enemy, telling them to move there. I found that aiming at the enemies knees/feet had the most consistent positive results.

There are micro-transactions in the game, but they don't matter at all. As far as I'm aware, everything you can get via micro-transactions can be gotten through some relatively easy grinding.

The game was pretty short. I did more grinding than necessary to complete the game, but less than what would be needed to get "everything".

My rule of thumb for short-medium length games like this (as well as movies) is $1 per hour spent enjoying the content. So it's not bad to get when on sale, but not worth full price.

I don't get why this series is so popular. It get's repetetive after the first 30 minutes already thanks to directly throwing you into the game cycle. You get micro transactions smashed into your face at every chance.

But most of the time it brings you straight to the map screen and you have to manually select the mission.

Good game and decent Far Cry. It's different from other FC installments in that you don't level your character. You level your "base" and different aspects of it so you have access to better equipment. It takes some getting used to, ESPECIALLY if you play FC Primal before this! Also, it's really worth advancing the story until you meet an old protagonist and THEN liberate outposts, etc.  You gain abilities at this point in the story that are helpful for all the side stuff.

Greetings!  Today we‚Äôll be reviewing ‚ÄúFarCry New Dawn‚Äù a FPS with heavy RPG mechanics and from a series known for the crazy stories.  I was a huge fan of the previous game, loving the story and overall game play so I‚Äôve been very excited to dive into the sequel.  Question remains, is this worth your time?  Let‚Äôs discuss!

Press B to Drop Your Weapons:  At the core I consider this a FPS with strong RPG elements; you level up, explore and play a silent protagonist in an open world with heavily scripted missions.  You have a great degree of freedom when it comes how you approach the open world content and many of the missions but there is also a fair bit of scripted scenes that you have little to no control over and any options you do have (usually letting someone live or killing them) have no real effect on the game.  The graphics hold up very well and the audio (both music & effects) is top notch.  The game is very colorful with a great variety of things to see and at no point did I feel the game detracted graphically from my enjoyment.  I will note that the villains did not keep my attention as much as the prior game but they did a serviceable job.  There is also a ton of content; I broke 60 hours having completed most of the content the game had to offer on ‚Äòtough‚Äô (normal) difficulty.  Many of the missions have a layer of humor that the world takes seriously and I found myself at least raising an eyebrow to some of the story.  I don‚Äôt mean this in a negative way as the game never felt like it took itself too seriously while it avoided treading into a full comedy.

I‚Äôve Been Here Before:  In many ways this game can feel like an expansion pack from the previous title, but that is only surface deep as this game is its own game with new mechanics, new characters and a new story all written in the same world after the ending of the previous title.  You will go to areas that you remember from the previous game and it is done well without overly focusing on the fact that it is a sequel.  You could easily jump into this game without even playing the prior.  It is great seeing the world evolved after the apocalypse and seeing old areas completely redesigned through time, radiation and a new generation of inhabitants.  The game has some very colorful set pieces but none of it really felt out of place within the story.

It‚Äôs a Far Cry:  I love this game, well worth the time but it does have some glaring issues.  The biggest issue I had was a well known controller bug where the reverse (and descend) buttons wouldn‚Äôt bind.  There have been some work-arounds found but none of them worked for me.  So when I needed to descend or reverse I had to just use the keyboard.  This wasn‚Äôt a huge issue but it was prevalent throughout the game and did effect my play experience.  The game could be argued as repetitive in some areas but I used these as an excuse to listen to podcasts and play ‚Äòcasual‚Äô during these segments.  Some might find these areas of concern but they did not affect my play experience.  The game also uses the Ubisoft Launcher which can be a deal breaker for some.  I also found that the health bar of vehicles could sometime be a bit misleading; I had vehicles explode on me while at 90% health.

This game easily has 60 hours of content and even more so if you explore and ‚Äòmake your own fun‚Äô.  I could also see a lot of enjoyment from co-op though I never was able to try that out (none of my friends have this game).  Even with some of the minor issues I had I highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys FPS games out there that deviate from the corridor shooter or multiplayer deathmatches.  Enjoy!

Yes I know you can keep playing after you finish the story, but meh, I probably won't.  All in all a good game to pick up on sale or in a bundle, but you can beat it pretty quickly. Far Cry New Dawn is a fun game, but unfortunately short. After spending close to a day's time playing this game, I found myself running low on content. The story is good, and the side missions are as great as ever, but 20 hours in and I had finished the main campaign. There is no arcade mode, essentially meaning no competitive multiplayer, or user generated content to make the game continue past it's intended lifespan. The new gameplay elements are incredibly fun (the ones added in as unlockable perks about 3/4 of the way into the game) but only served to speed along my experience. I do however, enjoy the aesthetic, characters (returning and otherwise), and plotline (although the perceived main antagonists are lackluster at best, they do have an interesting conclusion). Progression has been slowed down, and while it does slow the game down a bit, I found it surprisingly enjoyable. 

The game is cheaper than it's predecessor, valued at $40 (‚Ç¨35.19 , ¬£30.17, I'm using a calculator here, not Steam), and is quite enjoyable, but shamefully short. If you plan on buying the game, it's best to wait for a sale.

Oh, and it doesn't work on Linux. It used to work with Proton but after an update the ground ingame got transparent which makes it very hard to enjoy.

All in all, not a horrible addition to the franchise. Built with what seems like extra/re-used assets from Far Cry 5 the game looks beautiful with surprisingly good facial animations and visuals. The mechanics in turn also have the same fluidity and responsiveness as its predecessor. That being said, the narrative is all over the place. The story is a pseudo continuation of Far Cry 5, so if you enjoyed that story then there are some interesting tid bits to be had here and there. However, The antagonist(s) are rather dull and unconvincing, I had to grit my teeth more than a few times over how cringe they felt. Aside from the main story there's not much side content to really sink your teeth into (of course you still have the ubisoft staple outposts to capture). With collecting "Ethanol" being your main gatekeeper for unlocking new tiers of weapons and vehicles. There are companions as well you can recruit and level up, though their system is pretty bare bones. The music and sound design served well enough, setting the tone and mood relatively well. While being vastly shorter than Far Cry 5, I still logged about 18 hours on a pretty casual play through. If anything I'd wait to grab it if you see it on sale. This game isn't a life changing experience but if you got some time on the weekend and are looking for something to play with your buddy then i'd say go for it.

Final Verdict 6/10
