After all the negative hype over FC New Dawn, the price in the UK was driven down to ¬£10, so i snapped it up, expecting a big disappointment.
It turned out to be worth every penny. Yes, a bit short for a full blown game at ¬£39, but i would pay up to ¬£30.
The FC franchise has a way of changing each FC just enough to make it interesting, from FC3 to FC4 to FC5, FCPrimal, all a bit different, but keeping the same Outpost format, and plant usability for various medicines.
FC New Dawn is no exception; i particularly liked the Outpost Master with  a purpose, i.e. Scavenging an Outpost, whcih earned more Ethanol etc. Ethanol is the main currency in FCND.
And the graphics are stunning.
The weapons are pretty much standard FC; sniper rifles, shotguns, assault rifles etc with a few more thrown in.
Fast travel is restricted until you undertake some Expeditions, another nice novel touch.
Also an upgradable base made a nice change.
Another welcome new feature was the upgradable weapons - again the upgrades had to be earned.
.
Wait til then next reasonable price drop and buy it, the Scavenging and Expeditions alone kept me going for ages. If you like FC you wont be disappointed.

People who shit on this game are wrong. Is it similar to Far Cry 5? Yes. Is there a lack of weapon customization? Yes. Is it unoriginal and uninspired? Absolutely not. This game has a perfect amount of style. Best of all, the pacing actually makes sense, being my main gripe about 5. The world is the perfect size for the story and you don't usually find yourself feeling like the game is out of order. The villains are a little generic, but the music is a big plus. The rap really fits this punk-style post-apocalypse. Even better, it ties up loose ends after 5's ending and the story has characters with depth. It was awesome to the see the development of the Rye family. The ability to replay outposts is also super fun. Expeditions are even better, and after playing 6, I can see where the inspiration for it's missions comes from. Hunting and fishing actually have a purpose as you trade different animals for specific resources rather than just cash. The difficulty is much more dynamic as 5 was just way too easy, generally. This really doesn't feel like a glorified DLC. Give the game a try, its a ton of fun.

Thankfully the microtransactions only really need to be used if you want a nice costume, but everywhere else you can use "Far Cry credits" to buy crafting equipment, perk points, things you can't craft at the point in the game you are. Everywhere I go I feel like they're trying to sell me something and I'm playing a big ad.

This game is worth the money - It is a good game, good selection of guns, a decent selection of vehicles, a decent story with a decent ending.  A very good perks selection, a decent amount of missions, was maybe a tiny bit sparse with the story missions, but overall quite decent.  Great graphics and sound and the vehicles handled quite well, although the way the helicopters handle in this game and many other games is absolutely terrible.  The best helicopter handling in a game was the original Grand Theft Auto Vice City, all other games I have played with helicopters the handling is absolutely fucked including GTA San Andreas, GTA4 and GTA5, it just seems to get worse and worse and more uncontrollable and generally speaking if a pc or console game has helicopters, just don't bother using them at all for any reason because the handling sucks so badly they are completely and utterly uncontrollable.
Lastly, this game is worth the asking price.

So Far Cry: New Dawn as a whole i give it a 6/10. The game play is the same as FC5 with difference in weapons crafting (There's weapon tiers), enemies also has tiers (tho you can kill them with weaker weapons) but its just plain better to just craft the next tier weapon, Outpost clears is similar to FC5 with the added benefit of retrying liberated outpost to get extra loot as soon as you clear them (enemies gets stronger too), also the later half of the game you get unique perks that gives you abilities like super strength or stealth cloak,  those are fun when clearing outpost.Overall the game play is good but the story tho... honestly the only bright side is meeting people from FC5 and see how are they doing in the post apocalyptic setting, the main antagonist The Twins, for me is not likable they character seems bland and they dont seem to have this evil goal or any goal for that matter that their are working towards, theyre just there to makes peoples lives worst, and theyre not even good at it. Oh well i say this but the setting of the game and the highwaymen are good enough to atleast make me finish the game.

Mediocre - I still remember playing the original being amazed by that opening scene. Looks like the devs forgot what this game was about and instead it's just more of the 'unlock zone after zone'. Playing slowly is NOT rewarded, exploring is NOT rewarded - you end up being carrying thousands of pieces of useless gear because all the enemies are tiered - there's no completionist rewards outside of "shooting x enemies with a y". And, crime of all crime, there are in game purchases. You read that right - IN GAME (IAP-like) PURCHASES in a full price title. These mostly unlock cosmetics and weapon packs which - since you never see your hero - is a total waste. I really don't get this game - it's not TERRIBLE - there's some fun action and decent gunplay for say 30 hours - but don't go slow like I did - just quickly upgrade everything (I'm 7h on normal difficulty and never died once).

This is a relatively short game. I even managed to finish it under 30 hours playtime, so it's actually true to say that Far Cry New Dawn is some kind of "add-on" from Far Cry 5.
But I love this game, much more than Far Cry 5. Why?
It has dazzling visuals and powerful story, more powerful than Far Cry 5. The characters themselves make more sense, not some "flat-void" like which we can sense and feel from the 5.
It even has a more advancing gameplay style than the 5. You basically have to upgrade some stuffs at homebase to achieve true "bang-bang" experience, which makes the sense of true progression.
It even has a better sense of challenge then the 5, since the 5 is so easy (except the final dungeons of the 3 bosses which has more challenge). You can't summon more than one roster to accompany you which is a better move than the 5 since it give you more challange.
A short game by Ubisoft? You may feel pessimistic about it but somehow these guys MADE it. And it's really a good one.

Far Cry New Dawn

First of I just want to say that if you havnt played either Far Cry New Dawn or Far Cry 5, I would say that you should buy Far Cry 5 first just because its so connected with the locations from 5 and modded after the nuclearwar and some of the characters are there.

Story: If we are going to talk about the story its a bit diffrent from the one in Far Cry 5  because it isnt like regions and bosses like in 5. Its just the twins and their outposts that you can do a new thing called scavange when you liberate the outpost again but you get more loot and the guards are more armoured. By the way, the money in the game isnt realy money or so. You have to craft weapons which is a fun consept and to complete the story I think you need to upgrade your base to max so to do that you need to go to all the 3 people on the map at the outposts like in Far Cry 5. 

If you wonder how long the story is, its about 25-27 hours if you liberate all outposts  and do all sidemissions and so. It is pretty good still but if you think its short can you buy it on sale and it is on all the big ales I think. I bought it on the "Chinese new-year sale".

Gameplay: The gameplay is amazing like in Far Cry 5 but a littlie bit better for example when you takedown a person its a better animation and to take down all level 3 and 2 armourd people you need to get 3 perks but I would say its so worth it. Nothing to complain about.

And with finally completing New Dawn, I have officially fully [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/LordGay/recommended/13520/]played.[/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/LordGay/recommended/19900/]each.[/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/LordGay/recommended/220240/]and.[/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/LordGay/recommended/233270/]every.[/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/LordGay/recommended/298110/]Far.[/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/LordGay/recommended/371660/]Cry.[/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/LordGay/recommended/552520/]available.[/url] on Steam! Now, Ubisoft, come back to Steam so I can buy 6 :)

[b]Longer Review[/b]

I have basically the same pros and cons list as my FC5 review. Except there's no forced plot progression in New Dawn. Which is a plus.

The biggest thing for me, and I'm mostly mixed about it, is the new "RPG" elements... Enemies have health bars and "ranks" now. (Apparently they do in 6, too. So I guess Ubisoft is officially moving in this direction). Far Cry 5 was already a far cry (hahahahahahahaha) from how FC1-4 played. New Dawn furthered that even more from the "Far Cry norm". It adds a certain challenge to the game but it just doesn't feel like a Far Cry game. I miss the gameplay from 3 and 4. The manual healing, the crafting, the actual usefullness of hunting... I played the entirety of this franchise (excluding 6) within a couple months and I'm already nostalgic for Far Cry 3 and 4!

Besides that, it's a fun game. The story is pretty good. Although, it is EXTREMELY dull in the beginning, it gets good around the end of Act 2. (MAKE SURE TO PLAY FAR CRY 5 FIRST. This is a direct sequel to that game). 

I love the Mad Max-ish type post-apocalyptic world. I love how everyone dresses and the vehicles are kinda like Mad Max too. I mean, bikes with a mounted gun on the back is great.

Companions are... ok. You can only have one of them this time, and the AI for them is dumb as rocks. Also, they literally get stuck on rocks sometimes. It's frustrating. Nana, Horatio and Gina are the best ones to get as soon as you can. They help the most. 

The voice acting is also top-notch. The villains are pretty cool and ruthless. Classic Far Cry nutcases. The other returning characters are fun to see again.

Usually my reviews are pretty lengthy, but there's not much to say about this game besides "It's cool." Play it to have a nice conclusion to the Far Cry 5 timeline.

I'll try to keep this simple:

If you liked Far Cry 3 a lot - but thought that Far Cry 4 did things a bit better (the guns, the setting, the QoL improvements) then you'll understand exactly what I mean when I say: Far Cry New Dawn is just plain better than FC5


Everything that annoyed me in 5 is basically gone, the atmosphere is infinitely cooler 

maybe it's just me cause I actually live in a cabin in the wilderness - but Montana got dull after a while and radiation/mutations fix that right up 

I found the quasi-familiarity of a nuked-Montana (rather than being repetitive) fascinating and eager to see the same places post-boom boom

Remember when FC5 gave us the Kriss Vector (and then took it away cause they're jerks) but only like 200 rounds of SMG ammo (which the full-auto vector spits out in seconds)? New Dawn lets you upgrade your ammo carry in PERPETUITY 

Legendary animals are decent mini-bosses and legendary weapons feel POWERFUL like (they did in FC4) once again 

Companions are better, story is a cool follow-up to FC5, and the saw-blade launcher is almost worth installing this game alone

Again, FC5 was fine...I liked it...I just liked this more

Let's get some things stright: The story game play of the game definitly lacks in many ways and you'd be done with the game within a few hours. However..if you do everything the game has to offer then you'll really enjoy it and stretch the game for as long as you deem enough for you.
Anyway, what  I really liked about the game is the whole crafting system and supply gathering, aswell as how abilities and such are handled. Quick travel is so much better (after you upgrade it to the 2nd level tho..) and let you travel to any place you visited. i absoltly loved Timber, the most useful helper character in the game. That dog is the best...which makes everyone else kinda useless, when it comes to exploring and enemy location inforation. Speaking of helper characters....there are a lot less then in FC5 and you can only have one follow you...which is the reason why Timber was by my sides basicilly all the time throughout the game.
But nonetheless, i had a lot of fun, even if the main story itself definitly could've been better. Love the improved machanics tho

A lot of the enjoyment you get from this piggybacks of how much you enjoyed 5. I loved 5, I love this. I'm a longtime fan of fallout and it was nice seeing a new take on post-nuclear war life. I found this to be a bit more realistic. It's a not a full game so don't expect that. It's so fulfilling seeing where all of the characters from 5 ended up and seeing the old locations. So many easter eggs. I found the plot really interesting, particularly the parts that involved Joseph. I've played 52 hrs and have completed all of the main, side, and treasure missions, and I'm still not bored yet. My favorite part right now is the expedition feature. You get to complete missions outside of Montana for rewards. So far it's taken me to Florida, New Orleans, Alcatraz, and Iowa. The maps for these places are super detailed/accurate and quite large too. There are bits of lore everywhere and It's super interesting to be able to see other parts of the world in this universe. Highly highly recommend.

I enjoyed the game, but not sure why it wasn't a large DLC or Season Pass for Far Cry 5.  The storyline starts with you on a train that crashes in a post-apocalyptic world, and the action starts right away.  You are saved by a group of folks who live out in a safe area called Prosperity, and the highwaymen led by the Twins are after you.  For some reason that storyline really sucks, but once you get further into the story it has its own story within the story that really works well as a sequel to Far Cry 5.

If this is what an apocalyptic world looks like, then let's drop the bombs.  The world is beautiful.  The sky has colors like northern lights.  The flora of the area is bright and vivid.  Animals look rugged and sometimes brighter than they should be.  It's a beautiful world to explore and this is where Far Cry has always shined as a game, the exploration is a blast.  The world doesn't look all that much different than the previous game, but following creeks, running through the forest, or eventually squirrel diving through the air to cover more ground is stunning no matter where you are.  The scenery does not change all that much, though certain sections are definitely more swampy than foresty.

The action is good, not great, but good.  You get to craft weapons as you collect resources by killing people and taking over bases.  There are a wide variety of melee weapons and a variety of guns including objects you can lob too.  The action started out easy and worked well by progressing towards a much more difficult enemy.  The enemies themselves did not vary too often.  While there are animals to fend off as well as highwaymen, the majority of the time you will be killing highwaymen and they kind of all look the same.  As the storyline progresses enemies are harder to kill unless you have the upgraded weapons, and it makes for much more intense battles as you try to conquer another outpost.

You have the option to purchase perks like access to upgraded weapons, being able to move around silently, silent kills, and more.  Eventually, you get access to weird out of this world, a la Far Cry: Blood Dragon, type of perks like double jump and other additional perks.  The game is the same as all other Far Cry games, you can play the missions only, or you can venture and hit up all of the areas on the map and collect all of the resources you can, discover all of the prepper shelters for added collectibles.  The one new resource that I don't think existed in the previous game is that now ethanol is a key component to upgrades to your base, crafting certain weapons, and more.  You can find random plane drops for ethanol, that you typically will have to fight for when you find them.  You can find some by highjacking an ethanol truck and bringing it back to an outpost without blowing up.  Even highjacking them without blowing it up before trying to make it back to an outpost before being shot and have the enemies blow it up was difficult at first.  Or, you can take over outposts.

Outposts are areas with a large contingent of highwaymen.  You shoot your way in, or silently take them out one by one until you take it over.  If they see you and they sound the alarm, reinforcements will arrive and just make it frustratingly more difficult than it should have been.  Once you take over an outpost, you can get some extra ethanol by giving it back to the highwaymen.  Taking it over a second or even a third time keep increasing the difficulty of taking over the outpost.  But each time, you will get more ethanol.  Increasing the difficulty once you have the appropriate weapons to even try it was quite fun and really amped up the ante on the intense stealth or intense shoot outs.

Eventually, you do need to collect a lot of resources in order to upgrade your base, which then allows you to upgrade you skills like crafting better weapons.  You cannot win this game without upgrading, which means it requires a bit of grinding.  While it took me quite some time to beat, I was collecting quite a lot more than I would have needed, and I think that easily you could finish the game in less than 20 hours, or take as long as me and almost 100% the entire game.

If you like the Far Cry series, then this will feel just right.  If you liked Far Cry 5, then I would suggest that this is a must as it really is a good sequel storywise.  There's not much that's new to the series, but hey if it's fun, why not give it a shot.  I definitely recommend it.  Now to wait for Far Cry 6 on Steam.

Just...wow. For what's basically a glorified expansion to FC5, this is giving me absolutely none of the pleasure. Everything is wrong. Everything. I don't mind that there's some experimentation with the formula (though I wish it had been as the beginning of a new "Cry" spinoff, which would've been more appropriate), but someone at Ubi should've taken an editor's knife to this mess. The gameplay is stiff and requires hard-won perks to restore basic character performance. Enemies are bullet sponges unless you drop the difficulty all the way down, and even at this level the wildlife is more invincible than ever. The visuals are noisy and look unnatural in a way that doesn't manage to be satisfying or creative for the post-apocalyptic setting. Above all, crafting is now an intrusively major thing, and not in a way that feels appropriate or earned, just a cheap excuse to make you grind to find the fun and, insultingly, create a pathway for Ubi to squeeze microtransactions from you. Moreover, the bland, overgeneralized, cookiecutter materials for it oversaturate the environment and turn a Far Cry adventure into a Fallout scavenger hunt, except with a fraction of the variety and even less of the reward. And nailing the coffin is that the story and characters, at least so far, are too generic and underdeveloped to even give us a compelling reason to put up with all this. I just hope 6 is a different animal.

I would count this game as a DLC made into a game as it is literally far cry 5, but with a smaller map and a few changes.

Other than the map being smaller and there being PINK everywhere.

The only true difference is the whole gameplay mechanics.

Instead of your usual shoot enemy with any gun and they die. The enemy has different levels of difficulty. Now this is a cool feature and all, however it's been made very poorly.

Does it work? Sortof. However the weapons is where the issue lays. After playing for awhile you will get to a point in the game where you mostly fight high difficulty enemies. Problem here is the weapons ALSO have a SET difficulty lvl. So if you wanna use a lower level silenced weapon on a high level enemy. You can't (or well you can, but good luck)

Theres no way for you to customize the attachments either which is quite a shame. As some guns would be fun to use, but without a silencer they become harder to use making the very few top tier guns the only ones you will use.

This makes the game extremely repetitive as well you will feel limited to just a few guns that are actually usable against high lvl enemies.

For the story.. Oh lord.. Oh god. I wont spoil anything, but if you came here because you loved Joseph Seed in Far cry 5.. You will be extremely dissapointed.

Even if that is not the reason the story in this game is just not interesting.
Offcourse some people will enjoy the story, but generally it's very all over the place.

Imagine if Far Cry 5 and Mad Max had a one night stand, and Far Cry got an abortion but the fetus somehow survived and was raised by aggressively mediocre writing. I don't hate this game, in fact there is a fair amount I somewhat enjoyed while playing this but the cons overwhelmingly outweigh the pros. I'm not usually the type to actually write out a pros and cons list but I'm making an exception because this is such a mixed bag but it doesn't really deserve a f@cking essay. Spoilers ahead.

  Pros
- The art team behind the weapons in this game did a pretty excellent job, I loved the up-cycled junk weapons look
- The newly brainwashed Deputy returning as a gun for hire was pretty neat but I'd have liked if the character was explored more and had a more conclusive redemption arc instead of being stuck in side character hell.

 Neutral
- The superpowers you gain late in the game are cool but very out of place for a Far Cry game (Far Cry Instincts sucks)

 Cons
- Another lame unvoiced protagonist. One of the weakest points of Far Cry 5 was the lack of a voiced protagonist, without any back and forth between the main character and their antagonists you lose out on the tangible personal vendettas of characters from previous entries in the franchise and instead are left with playing as a boring self insert.
- So many ideas, characters and concepts feel very half baked, the team was given one of the more interesting settings of a post apocalyptic world, where you can create any number of diverse and interesting groups to fill this new world but instead we get a Gen Z biker gang and the almost not boring tribal Eden's Gate.
- No weapon customisation, feels like a huge wasted opportunity and a pointless step backwards.
- Tiered enemies and weapons feel like artificial difficulty, I get why it was done as without it there wouldn't be this harder second area like with Far Cry 2, 3 and 4 but its was poorly executed and lame.
- Mickey and Lou are terrible antagonists with zero of the redeeming or interesting qualities previous antagonists feature.
- Joseph along with the entirety of Eden's Gate feels like a massive letdown comparative to the buildup they had in 5, and the new Seed child, Josephs adoptive son Ethan Seed is particularly a boring, whiney manchild.
- micro transactions in a single player game, including purchasable high tier weapons and perks.... what the hell Ubisoft.

There are so many better things you could do with your time and money, please don't give it to Ubisoft.

I didn't enjoy Far Cry 5 much, so at first I wasn't curious about this game. Then after 1 month of releasing, it was on 50% discount. My friend bought it and so did I in order to play coop. Here's some pros and cons -

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*]In my opinion, the graphics is better than Far Cry 5.
[*]How the hell does the environment become PINKY by radiation?? I don't know. It looks childish, but it's fun (at least for me, xD)

[*]Photo mode

[*]Short story
[*]Fu**ing Superpowers
[/list]
That's all I can remember...

Sure it‚Äôs pretty unremarkable and doesn‚Äôt do anything to significantly innovate the series but I still thought that Far Cry: New Dawn was pretty fun even if it does carry a lot of the same shortcomings that Far Cry: 5 did. Easily the biggest improvement from 5 to this game is the incredible atmosphere, which is just dripping with equally beautiful and haunting environments brought to life by eye-catching colorful environments and evocative imagery, artistically speaking this is the best game in the series since Far Cry: 2. Another thing I just loved was the weapon models, there were basically just reskins from past games but they didn't feel like it with excellent post-Apocalyptic touches on them like exposed batteries powering red dot sights or screwdrivers taped onto assault rifles for bayonets. Unfortunately, the other big addition which is the RPG mechanics isn‚Äôt the best. While some of the changed progression from past games feels good, a lot of it feels out of place like the health bars and the lack of customizing weapons which detracts a lot from the combat sandbox. The storytelling is just as if not weaker than Far Cry: 5 with a large lack of big moments and the blandest characters in the whole series with the twins easily being the worst and least intimidating villains in the series. I think this is only one or two steps below Primal in quality if not just for the fact that this game just tries a lot less than Primal. With Far Cry 6 being so mediocre, I think Ubisoft needs to completely renovate the series for the next entry, or else it is going to become as mediocre as post-Syndicate AC games.
Franchise Been always AWESOME for CO OP

Now THIS is how you turn a negative into a positive.

New Dawn fixes so much of what was wrong with 5.

Principally connecting the mechanics together. Now you have to do side missions and level up both your self and your weapons in order to beat the outposts and main missions.

There is a tighter story here while still giving the player room to breathe. No meters to fill and be pulled out of the immersion. The characters while not as charming as the original cast (mostly due to how short it is compared to five), still come off as worth doing their quests.

The soundtrack is killer and the atmosphere oozes post-apocalypse.

And the ending is makes the experience worth it.

I do wish it was longer, but at this point, the far cry formula has really worn out its welcome, so I am glad it was a short, but sweet journey.

Edit after playing ~10h:

Game is okay-ish. Or worse, you're supposed to follow someone (as in, someone talking to you, not "stealth follow" or anything), but see something to loot like 10 meters back and decide to go get it? Mission failed. Reload last checkpoint.

Honestly, a really great example of what the Far Cry series is as a whole, and what it will continue to be in perpetuity. This is an open world game, exclusively. Any attempt to break up the monotonous drivel of clearing out every marker on a map is poorly executed to such a degree that I didn't even bother finishing this one. It's a problem that also exists in every Far Cry game before and after this one, so skip those in the future too. The shit attempt to incorporate RPG mechanics by having higher level enemies be essentially unkillable unless you have the pre-requisite level weapon is done so sloppily and black-and-white that you essentially are playing the game to exclusively upgrade your weapon level, not for perk points or map completion or the "fun" of the game, those don't exist unless you can get to the next level and actually do damage to the bullet sponges they start to throw at you.

One thing to focus on with this game, and 5 and 6 especially, is just how shitty every single mission in the entire game is. There was not a single mission in FC5 that I remember fondly, yet I do remember consistently hating nearly every mission in the game. This game is no different. You are either protecting some NPC spewing out some of the poorest written, lowest quality dialogue you can hear in a video game (honestly quite an accomplishment considering the Borderlands series exists), or driving the slowest car imaginable in a gauntlet that is either nearly impossible or laughably easy (and always boring as shit and impossible to control), or walking. Just walking. You do a lot of that in this game, and the airdrop-fast-travel is unlocked late enough in the game that you are forced to traverse quite a bit of the completely empty land between landmarks. A generous 1% of the game's map area is filled with anything, or ever has a mission take place on it. The other 99%+ is completely empty land, nothing to do, nothing to look at, and often absolutely zero enemies to fight, human or otherwise. This leaves the 1% to do some really heavy lifting, and it unfortunately falls so short I was a little surprised. Every single mission is just so, so bad. The map is lifeless and boring, the enemies are walking bricks with little dialogue and no idle behavior, the weapons are boring blocks just there to separate them from you, the skills and abilities are nearly pointless, with the powerful ones introduced far too late in the game and the skill tree being roughly 50% worthless, nothing in the entire game compels you to continue playing one second longer.

its like skyrim with guns

While I will say that nowadays you can get the game pretty cheap, and can still find some people to play the game, I'm gonna be reviewing this game as it's full price, and as a standalone Far Cry game. While a lot of people, (including myself) would've just wanted this to be DLC for FC5, they figured that it deserved a standalone spot. Honestly, it makes no sense, since it's literally reused assets and textures from 5. I stand with a lot of people who would've wanted to see that horrible film director DLC replaced with this, making 5 have 3/3 outstanding DLC's. One thing that steered me away from the game for a while was all of the damage numbers, and random bs that they had in the gameplay videos. What no one told me is that you can turn all of that off, and make it look like an original Far Cry game. The positive points I will say about the game, is that it's cool they made an ending for 5, after it left you off on a cliff hanger. A lot of people wanted to see Hope County through, and some felt that it was a pretty anti-climatic ending. They brought back SOME of the people, and most of them you can't even use as a companion. Also, all of them are decrepit and pretty useless now, leaving your character as their figurative grandson who's getting called to get some kids off their lawn. Mentioning the enemies, the twins are some of the most unlikeable, boring bosses in Far Cry. Seriously, I can't think of another Far Cry where the final boss was not only boring story wise, but also terrible combat wise. Seriously, the last mission fighting them is just you running around in smoke screens for 30 minutes, spraying into their heads over and over, while helicopters are shooting you, dogs are biting you and bringing you into animations, people with LMG's, shields, they throw every character at you in an endless wave until you kill these JUGGERNAUTS of bosses. Not to mention they will literally hide from you to summon more enemies to slow you down. I was spraying them consistently, and used more than 200 mags between the both of them, on an ELITE gun. Bringing up the ranking system, they now have it to where the enemies, and animals, can be between 1-4 levels. Each one gives them an additional health bar, and an elite pretty much has more health than an armored tank. There is no money in the game, and you literally have to craft EVERY. SINGLE. THING. Vehicles? Gotta craft them. Weapons? Gotta craft them. Literally anything? Gotta craft it. These weapons that you craft, you can't change any of the attachments! What are we doing with these pre-made classes? Also, you wanna fast travel? That's a camp upgrade for some reason. The takedowns are locked behind a perk wall, making it to where you have to spend around 30 perk points, just to do a takedown on an elite. I'm not gonna lie, after clearing all the forts and beating the game, I think I barely got 30 perk points, since they want you to buy them with real money. (Yes, you can buy perk points with REAL MONEY) The crafting is ridiculous, seeing as I couldn't even make 2 guns after everything in the game I did, and looting like I'm in Tarkov, taking anything that I can carry. It's so obvious this was just a cash grab, and it's blatant within the first hour. Even the first mission for the story, has you just looting materials to upgrade the base. THE FIRST MAIN STORY QUEST. There have been multiple missions where you have to play the game a completely stupid and useless way, because you're locked behind a perk wall. Don't believe me? Try playing this game stealthily at all like the old ones. Unless you got those 30 perk points, you're just gonna be throwing knives, and hoping they insta kill. Also, get used to using semi automatic guns, or burst fire, since that's gonna be the only weapons besides the m4 that drops on the ground from them. It seemed like every single weapon was either burst, or single fire. Also, no one cares about those saw blade weapons, this isn't Rage. All in all, if you can find the game for under 10$, I guess it's worth it. But for the 30$ that they charged people for this when it came out? I feel bad. There's only 10 outposts, and 22 main missions. I think it took me 8 or so hours to do it all, compared to the 28 I just spent beating 6 and all of it's content. The only people playing this are super-fans of 5, and even for them, this game is just a disappointment. If this was DLC, it would've been perceived so much better. But, we are grading this as a standalone Far Cry game. And by far, this is the worst Far Cry game ever made.

Actually the review is between yes and no ‚Äì but leaning towards no.  I‚Äôve played this 1.5 times (once of normal then on hard) ‚Äì I just got bored second time around.  What is the point of the girls ‚Äì they hardly feature?  And as with other FarCry games, all you need is a handgun, silenced sniper rifle, LMG and the dog as a partner.  The dog is by far the best bit and I love the touches of him riding in the side car or truck!  But It‚Äôs too easy to get what you want and then it just becomes boring. Take away fast travel, limit health, reduce weapons and vehicles and add more random missions.

Let me be clear on the outset here that while I recommend the game I do not think it's worth the current $39.99USD price tag. Get it while it's on sale. 

While this is definitely the sequel to Far Cry 5, they did things to the gameplay that I both approve and disapprove of. I like the more in-depth gun game, the enemy scaling, and the outpost scaling system. I liked the new expeditions mode. I wasn't a fan of the map getting smaller, as they ended up cutting and redrawing Hope County so much I found myself in an uncanny valley of sorts. Maybe "confusingly alien but familiar" was intentional. I also wasn't a fan of the story, I found the antagonists to be a step-down from the prior game's bad guys. The psychadelic graffiti-aesthetic they had was cool at first but got kinda boring and repetitive. 

In short it's better on the technical aspects but fell short in the story category. Overall, if you liked Far Cry 5, you'll like this game too.

Cons: (Mild)

- Weapons don't have upgrades, you get the gun/weapon as it is either with or without attachments.
- To upgrade any aspect of your weapons or character health or crafts ...... you must upgrade other buildings and sections with it that you may not be interested in.
- No options in the story, it is linear, only some tiny difference in the ending.

It was a nice experience and a good wrap for Far Cry 5

This is a semi-direct sequel to Far Cry 5. Its the same game format but set in a bright post-apocalyptic Hope County. The difference between the 2? Far Cry New Dawn is a janky mess that introduces new enemy classes that make it much harder to play early on. requiring you to choose perks just to be able to take down people. I thought i'd be playing a far cry game, where i walk around the map, collect stuff, liberate outpost, do some cool quests and see some entertaining cut-scenes. But no, you wont get this experience. All of the sudden you are back to 2005 on a single-player first-person World of Warcraft where you can't kill enemies unless you waste your time to get a number to get bigger. Want to liberate an outpost? Well, humans in this one are born with a +2 genetics, so your +1 weapon can't fire bullets that can breach their skin.

Fun to play immediately after Far Cry 5 and explore the post-apocalyptic versions of areas you just visited. You need a high tolerance for grinding, but I enjoyed being able to retake outposts for better loot, and the "expedition" missions to other locales were entertaining. Loved the visuals and mutated animals. Definitely not the most memorable story or villains, but still a decent entry in the series.

The game was just fine, i liked the fact that it built upon FC5 since i really enjoyed that game. Unfortunately it cannot compare itself to it, the story is promising but lacks connection to the characters to make it quite as good as it could be, really the only characters i cared about were the ones connected to the previous game and i think it may have to do with the fact that the intro wasn't as good as in FC5.

 It's the same when it comes to gameplay, it's not bad but i think it could have seen improvements, the grinding system just wasn't for me, especially since it means you have to do the same objectives multiple times at different difficulties in order to get better weapons, vehicles etc which are absolutely necessary to play the game and not be stomped by some random npc wandering by the road. The basics however are good, that is to mean handling, controls and such.

Something i was annoyed with as well is the fact that the map was so small compared to FC5, it's the same map but ca 30% of the map have been cut out. This doesn't necessarily have to be a bad thing but after paying for the game it felt as if i got a dlc for the price of a full game, overall i think this might have done better when presented as a huge dlc for FC5. There is also less content in this game than it's predecessor, probably because it's more grind focused which i personally don't prefer, although some do.

Visually the game looks great, a lot of vibrant colors and nice scenery, the design is obviously similar to the previous game in the series but it didn't feel repetitive since all locations had been changed in some way and i enjoyed seeing how the old world and also characters had changed over time.

An addition i really liked were the raids where you are flown out to a location filled with enemies to infiltrate it and steal supplies. You can choose to be stealthy or go in guns blazing and it's really fun, there is probably a good 10+ additional hours of fun if you want to do them all since they are all in different and varied locations.

Overall think it's a fun game that will last most up to maybe 40 hours, 
It's especially worth playing if you liked FC5 and i did have a lot of fun playing the game but i would pay the full 45 dollars for it, i got it for ca 20 dollars on sale and i think price was reasonable so i would say it's worth up to 30 euro/dollars.

The only grinding that you'd ever have to do was to be able to craft certain guns, but there's the option to just pay to get them as well if you feel like it's too much work.

Post-ending edit:  The game ends with a typical "Elite enemy" slug fest.  Three enemies, elite level, huge health bars, shoot them until they're dead...  Go ahead and skip this game, Far Cry fan or no.  Play literally any other game in the series and I can absolutely guarantee it'll be more fun with a better story than this one.



Original:
I love Far Cry.  I've played Far Cry, FC Instincts, FCI Predator, FC2, FC3, FC3 Blood Dragon, FC4, FC Primal, and FC5.  Somehow, in 9 games from the same series, including 6 that follow the same basic formula, I don't remember being bored or frustrated or having to "power through just to finish" - until New Dawn.  And honestly, this game does have stuff going for it.  It keeps to the working formula overall, revisits Hope County from FC5, has characters that fit a Far Cry storyline, and an interesting world that feels pretty packed with stuff to do.  But the one, blaring thing that they changed pretty much kills all the rest of it:  RPG elements.

The Far Cry games, starting with FC2, have been all about approaching most objectives however you want.  If you want to infiltrate the biggest base with a pistol and a throwing knife, go for it.  Storm the gates with a car covered in C4 and a machine gun in your pocket as backup?  Why not.  Want to hunt bear with a bow and arrow and rabbits with a rocket launcher?  Get on out there, champ.  Weapons have strengths and weaknesses as they would in real life, but all of them are useful and will get the job done if you do it right.  The weapons are tools, and it's up to you to make them work well.

But here we are, in the new age of skill trees and stats and "gear scores", and now your M60 machine gun won't kill that grizzly bear inside of 150 rounds because the bear is a Tier 3 enemy while your gun is only a Tier 1 gun.  Need to storm that outpost to get resources?  Aw, sorry - there's an Elite enemy in there that will take more ammo to kill than you can carry, guess you'll have to come back later.  Get attacked by a random mountain lion while going to your object?  Dang, that's a Tier 3 mountain lion!  Drop your assault rifle and run away!  All of a sudden, your gun determines whether or not you can advance.  The answer?  Ignore all the Tier 1 garbage, rush to get to Tier 2 so you can get that Tier 2 SMG they give you now from the Ubi club thing, then do your best to rush to Tier 3.  When you get to Tier 3 weapons, make sure you don't scavenge one of your outposts a third time, or else it'll be covered in Elite enemies that you can't really kill yet.  The problems go on...

Also introduced in this game was, of course, a crafting system - the other bane of gaming's existence for the last decade.  For a long time you could craft things like medkits and the like, but now your crafting system gets you weapons and vehicles and - because it's now a post apocalyptic scenario and of course we have to rebuild a civilization rather than doing literally anything else that's actually fun - upgrades for this home base of yours.  It's a very simple system with a few different resources to gather, so it doesn't bog it down too much.  But that need to search for resources just distracts from that Far Cry magic of "go fight your war, call us if you need something".

I'm only about 5 hours into New Dawn and honestly... I'm powering through just to finish.  And that pains me, as I played Far Cry 4, Primal, and 5 back to back after getting them on sale recently and each one just made me more excited for the next game.  If you don't mind the RPG tier system garbage, then honestly there is a lot to like here so far, which is why I'm still willing to continue on to finish the game.  But if you're a long time Far Cry fan and just want more Far Cry... maybe go back and play one of the others - or go into this one ready to stomach it.

I really hope New Dawn will also be the final sunset on this RPG system, and they bury this idea in one of those old Seed brother bunkers never to been seen again...

Honestly I loved Far Cry 5. I spent so many hours playing it and ended up cosplaying as a peggie. It was a game that I honestly did not want to finish. Fast forward, I finished 5 and was iffy about New Dawn. I read reviews on here stating that it should have been DLC and had quite a few bugs. I eventually started while on my comedown from the Far Cry 5 energy and when I started, I was quite disappointed. The story did not make sense with the timeline (such as survival of x characters), I was quite confused how survivors were able to live live out of their bunkers within x time (for some reason I thought it was 6 years) and how x,y and z are a thing. The more I played this game, the more it grew on me however I have a few points

1) expect bugs. I know it's Ubisoft however the number of times I would get into a vehicle after it spawned from a garage and it exploded or how I would phase into the environment (such as rocks) was ridiculous.
2) The antagonists are fun and all however they are not the bad guys from the previous games. Their characters are mediocre and not as fun which is a shame as if Ubisoft had them appear more or even just cause more destruction than what occurred in the game, they would be sitting up with Vaas or Seed.
3) The soundtrack. The soundtrack is great and all however needs more songs. The number of times I would raid an outpost and "Fatty Boom Boom" or "S**t just got Real" by Die Antwoord or hop into a car and "Tequila" by Bill Black's Combo or "Daydream Believer" by The Monkeys would just repeat was stupidly irritating. Come on Ubisoft, you should have had more songs in this game.

With these things put aside, the game is like Mad Max meets Rage which was quite cool. The series did not really need this game and I agree that it could have been DLC as it is pretty much just a reskin of models and such with only 1 new weapon and some other things (spoilers) added. The game relies more on a crafting element and base building compared to others in the series which is cool. I'm happy to see more of Seed and get a conclusion to him however this game did not need to be (but it still happened). It is a nice filler in between 5 and 6. If you are looking at purchasing this game, pay $40-$50 max but not the full retail price. I completed the game over a week and a half (100%) with only up to 4 hours a night (if lucky) of game time (my hours in this game are due to the game not shutting down properly and still running in the background while I slept and worked a 10-hour shift). 

To conclude, I have to give this game a 6.5-7/10. :)

After going through the insanity of America in FarCry 5, in co-op mode with a friend, I find out that there is another game that carries out the events of FC5 and a sequel to it, and that made me want to play it because I enjoyed FC5 and was surprised there is a sequel and wanted to see what could happen after everything that had happened already, so I and the same friend from FC5 decided to play it.


Long story short, the magic of FC5 didn't carry over to FarCry New Dawn. 

But instead, it was a new dawn for the game design philosophy, one which embarrassed grinding, RPG elements, and leveling up stuff you use, and it didn't work out.

The real mystery to me whether this new dawn of designing the game was the pitfall of it, its story, and its fading magic, or the story was bad from the start and the game didn't have any magic, to begin with.

The premise of the game was promising, to continue the events of the previous game and the idea of meeting the Father once again and it starts good, it starts pink and vibrant, but, as you will end up discovering, its all colors and aesthetics and no substance.

Even playing the game in co-op didn't help its case (I don't like open-world games but co-op makes them fun, especially FarCry games). 
For example, you can't initiate missions, interact with some characters, do some stuff unless you are the party leader so the other person in the party just has to stand there and wait for the party leader to do everything. You can't contribute to leveling up, with resources and stuff unless you are the party leader, quite a real cooperative experience...

It just felt like a drag, could it be because things are familiar from the last game and as such boring? you would think it would feel just like being at home,  I don't know but I can't help but blame the levels system and RPG mechanics, weak unmemorable characters and grind and grind and more grind, it just saturates the entire freaking game and ruins it, and makes it no longer a FarCry.


I do not recommend this game, absolutely not if you are going to play it solo, but in co-op? maybe, but is that a recommendation if you can only enjoy the game in co-op when it's not a co-op game by design?

It's a Far Cry game, so the gameplay is definitely familiar and a lot of fun.  Weapon acquisition and crafting in this game is somewhat similar to how it works in survival craft games like Rust or The Forest, which is new and makes completing your arsenal more of a fun challenge.  Outposts can (and indeed, have to be) completed more than once to more forward in the story, which is fun sometimes and mildly tiresome other times, depending on how you feel about outposts.  Both of those things make it familiar while still having something new to offer, and re-visiting Hope County post-Far Cry 5 is pretty cool.  It's noticeably shorter than earlier games, though‚ÄîI played through it in about 25 hours, whereas earlier games have taken me a little over 50 hours to finish.  Overall I'd recommend it, but wait until it goes on sale to buy it.

This was a weird one for me.  Let me first say that I am a bit biased, Far Cry is one of my favorite game franchises out there and honestly I couldn't tell you why.  That being said I went into Far Cry: New Dawn with low expectations as I had heard a lot of mixed things about it, but hot damn if I wasn't pleasantly surprised.  To make this coherent and relevant I should first address the issues that people have with the game.

1. To much grind
This one has some ground to stand on in a sense, but honestly for me it was never a problem.  Getting the materials you need is as easy as taking a camp and spamming E for a minute then done.  And then you can get a ton of resources by doing the expedition missions.  I was never lacking any resources, in fact I just started making garbage because I had to much.  And it should be noted I did all the level one expedition missions.

2. The villains are very good
To be honest I kind of liked them, especially their ending, all around I liked their dynamic, granted they were not as good as Pagan or even Joseph but I still think they were solid villains all together.  Though sometimes they just did some weird stuff that made no sense.  Like when they force you to confront them and they make you free some people and that somehow makes you have "less power", just weird.

3. The story isn't very good
Well, Far Cry isn't exactly known for it's writing is it?  No, the problem here are the characters.  Throughout the whole game I really felt like this was written by two completely different people.  Most the game is spent in Providence or whatever (I don't even remember) and most of the characters are forgettable, their story is generic at best and I had no real feeling for them.  They had some good characters like Roger was fun, same with Irwin, and Hurk still gets a chuckle out of me.  Anyway these characters aren't just sad or weird as their traits they are actually fun.

What had me hooked was Joseph's story and New Eden, honestly the story should have revolved more around them.  Their story and it's relation to real biblical tales is always making you question whether this is truly from God or just some mad man's illusions.  Joseph comes out more human, a man who had lost everything, the writing isn't always great but this game has some moments that really got me to think.

5/10 - The game itself is fun, I can't say much for the combat or gameplay, it's Far Cry 5 if you like that you'll like this.

This game is a DLC sequel to Far Cry 5. Same setting (similar map, and still called Hope County), same Joseph Seed, same cult; you're just doing slightly different stuff with them. Going from 5 to New Dawn feels like going from Star Wars episode 6-Rogue One. Same series and overarching villain, but a different story with different characters and slightly later on chronologically. 

Onto the game in its own right...

It's good, but the main antagonists are WAYY more annoying than intimidating. They never interact with you unless you can't fight back and then all they do is talk shit and beat you. 

Ignoring those two fuckwits, I had fun. If you've played a far cry game you've played em all, this one's just a bit shorter. 100% completion would probably be like 22 hours imo, which is incredibly short compared to any other AAA singleplayer games being released. Honestly could be as short as 10-12 hours if you only go for the main missions. An average first playthrough probably takes around 18 hours (15 if you don't stray from the story a ton, and around 21 if you're going for every mission + collectibles).

I really like the tiers of enemies and how every outpost starts at tier 1 then you beat it, "scavenge," it now has tier 2 enemies, and so on up to 3. It allows you to choose how much you want to be challenged in the early game, and allows significant, yet still fun, engaging, and very rewarding replayability in the SAME save file. It's also an incredibly easy and fair way to gate late game quests, as you need to be geared and have health upgrades before you can take them on. It was also really fun being late game and having one or two outposts left and just plowing through all 3 tiers. The contrast between the enemy difficulty is really cool to see back to back. 

However, I would NOT pay full price for this. It's good, but it's so short that I'd say $20 max is the fairest price. At $20 it's worth it, at $10 or lower it's a steal and you should definitely check it out.

The more i play this game the more i hate it.
All previous FC (Blood Dragon don't count) atleast tried to be kinda realistic but NW is like "shut up and give me your money".

Action take place around 20 years after FC5 , so Hope Country should be a nuclear wasteland but  instead we got Barbie world all colorful, deep  blue sky and flowers everywhere only what is missing are unicorms.

You play as another voiceless, faceless, nameless someone who came to Hope Country on train full of ppl to help defeat some bandits that get resupply by Jambo Jets but instade your train got wrecked so everyone but you dies. Perfect savior. 
Later you met all old friends from FC5 and you help em fight evil twins (srsly the worst antagonist in series even worst that true enemy in FC3) by going to New Eden ans asking Joseph for help.... Even better idea.

So you think okey story is stupid but maybe shooting is fun? Wrong!!!
ND got new tier system. So if you wanna hurt someone your weapon tier must be equal or higher of enemy/animals or else you gonna feel like shooting with BB gun.

So how to get better weapon? The answer is grind. A lot of grind. First you must get fuel to upgrade all facilities ,then do 5 side missions to get back 5 ppl.
And now real grind begins. Cause to make weapon you need some gears some parts, tons of titanium (300 titanium to make a AK-47 and where you find titanium ?ofc in safes thats in every location or hunt grizzly) and electronic parts (you get em only from legendary Bizons so you need legendary weapon to kill em).

But hey there are good news if you don't wanna grind and just focus on shooting you can alwayse spend another 50$ to buy ubi points to unlock 4 weapons and spend another 50$ for more toys.

Final thoughts:
Standalone DLC made with minimal efort for double cash grab. Buy only on sale if you don't care about logic or good story in game and if you don't mind to grind or pay to finish the game.

The main villains are pretty uninspired but the actual world is really quite awesome. Not too big but gives a better pace because of it. If you've played any of the Far Cry games previously you know what you're in for - assault the bases, do a little light RP levelling and crafting, and do the main story as you feel comfortable.

Overall a good solid entry, let down by the boring villains. Luckily the lore says they're part of a larger organization so hopefully we'll revisit post apocalyptic Far Cry again in the future, and have someone we can love to hate against us.

Far Cry New Dawn is a interesting game that basically plays into the senses of an rpg fps, you play as the Captain who has to save Hope County from the Far Cry version of the Borderlands  Pandora Psychos. The game is a contiutation of the Far Cry 5 Joseph Seed saga, so if you didn't play FC5, don't touch this. It's a mess without it. 

To put it simply, you got one job. Kill the Highway-man and make sure that your home base is still standing, when I first play this game. I was overwhelmed to be quite honest with you, as a fan of the FC series from starting the renown FC 3 to the illustrious FC 5. I can simply say one thing: 

Far Cry New Dawn is definitely not the freaking same as any of the Far Cry games. It is something completely different on so many levels here, Ubisoft thought it would be fantastic to make all of the enemies into 4 levels. 

1 - is your starting level, which would have starting weapons such as a rusty gun, rusty rifle, a rusty launcher, and so on. 

2 - would be more of the makeshift weaponry but they also don't have that much damage

3 - would be more of the makeshift weaponry but it's becoming more modernized to actually cause real life damage but still it can be rather laughable to a level 4 enforcer. To the point where you kinda just wanna throw the controller down and go search for more materials. 

Oh I forgot, you have to search for more materials which isn't actually that hard if you have wallet money. Yep. That's right. Microtransactions as if it was a Sim City's app on an Iphone as far as you can see. The materials however can be worked with if you kill enough animals to get the said materials but those are also level based as well. 

Now with all of these levels, they're not really a big huge gripe to be honest. It felt natural and more realistic to actually attack someone but the problem is that this game is really glitchy. From takedowns being one of the MOST RELEVANT moves of all times get blocked by not being at the right distance of the said target, to actual markings of certain enemies to simply disapper to keybinding moves not being able to do the action for any reason. I can count so many times when I got shot or killed or even fall because the game didn't want to work. It felt like I was fighting AGAINST the game instead of working with the game to get to my goal. 

And with all of these levels, you would think that upgrading the said levels would actually cause a form of buff or even damage reducing to lower level of weaponry that the enemy might hold? NOPE!!! NO SUCH THING!!

You can literally get killed quicker with a rusty pistol and honestly that is just messed up for the fact that Ubisoft didn't even put the handiwork to actually give the player the meta. It does make it challenging I will admit and it does feel good when an outpost is finished and you are completely standing on a pile of bodies. Yep. You can drink that victory cold champagne because it does feel good to be the best when the world hates you the most. But I'm going to be honest, I'm rather tired of Ubisoft keep doing these things to this series. 

Finally my main issue with the game: I don't like all of the dream, acid dream sequences. I think they're a waste of time, none of the said dream sequences made me want to question my motives and question so much if anything. They were a waste of just programming, yes they were interesting via creativity but I don't feel anything after I went through the standard Far Cry acid trip hallucination dream. 

The big bad two villians are not that interesting and they actually are not that entertaining. They feel like they're just kids who are playing raider of the thunderdome, when in reality villains proved that your situation is grim and that it's impossible to actually win and when you look into their back story. You can see some of the problems of both sides but with the big bad two villians that we have, I don't really feel anything when I look at their backstories. 

Throughout the game however, you have gun for hires, which are partners to help you through your journey whether it's a mute who likes to shoot arrows or a grandmother with a sniper rifle. I honestly can say that they didn't help nor they did assisted my journel, I felt I was always getting caught because of something the AI did rather than what the actual mission was at hand. 

Your perks and new upgrades are rather dull and boring, nothing of interesting whenever you need it to be and nothing of interesting whenever you want it to be. What does that mean? It means you have to get a perk point to get scopes so you can identify the enemy, something you thought it was going to have automatically but it didn't. Also you need to get perk points so you can takedown more enemies over time but that's kind of a whole issue becuase it's very rare if you're ever gonna get a chance to take them down. The enemies are more receptive depending on the level and those wonderful guns that they have doesn't actually slow you down. It's like you're a level 1 and they are level 3's the whole time and that's just the starting levels. 

It would be understandable and a little sloggish of Ubisoft to include crafting materials for armor and ballistics like they clearly did for the Highway man but honestly that's clearly asking too much. 

Sad to see Hope County go away but honestly Ubisoft messed this game up so much, I'm glad I can finally finish it. 

Far Cry New Dawn gets a 6/10. 

Pro: New weapons and a meta system. 

Con: Everyone can still kill you.

[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Far Cry¬Æ New Dawn falls into the first person shooter genre, which was developed by Ubisoft Montreal, Shanghai, Toronto, Kiev and Red Storm.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2566784365

[h1] Story / Gameplay [/h1]

Far Cry New Dawn is set in the same Hope County area as Far Cry 5, but is scaled down to the north and east and the action takes place 17 years later. When the members of Prosperity dare to leave their bunkers, the Highwaymen - led by sisters Mickey and Lou - already hold control of large parts of Hope County. Only the border to the apparently deserted northern part of the map is controlled by New Eden, who patrol the highwaymen outside their area at night and see themselves as the successors of the Peggies (Project at Eden‚Äôs Gate, the Christian fanatical antagonist organization from Far Cry 5).

The game begins with the player character, who can be either male or female, and other fighters take the train to Hope County to support Prosperity. The Highwaymen derail the train and kill all survivors of the train accident except the player and Thomas Rush, who are separated. The player is found by Carmina, daughter of the leader of Prosperity, and won over for the resistance against the Highwaymen. As with the previous games in the Far Cry series, Far Cry¬Æ New Dawn is an open world game in which the player can explore and interact with the entire world. The player saves Thomas Rush (who will soon be kidnapped and killed again) and wins other characters, some of which are already known from Far Cry 5, for Prosperity. It turns out, however, that Prosperity cannot win against the Highwaymen on its own and needs the help of New Eden. Its leader Ethan is the son of Joseph Seed, the main antagonist of Far Cry 5.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2617387094

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ Freedom, you can do what you want
+ refreshing story that distances itself from the usual parts
+ impressive natural landscapes
+ believable protagonists who play their roles flawlessly
+ good scope and various side missions
+ atmospheric, often dynamic background music
+ Hunting and production is straightforward and cleverly integrated into the gameplay
+ Fast travel available
+ Memories feel productive and these have been translated well into context
+ extensive range of weapons with noticeable differences
+ proper vehicle controls

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- poor hit feedback
- often ridiculous AI

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Far Cry¬Æ New Dawn gives you a visually appealing and lively open-world sandbox in an apocalyptic game world full of dangers. Clear purchase recommendation for those who like the Far Cry range.

Overall, really disapointing. 

I am a fan of Far Cry 5, while it was way more streamlined and casual compared to the past few titles, which were Streamlined and Casual versions of their older games, this one hit a certain nerve of going too far. We have barely any weapons, 5 had like 20 pistols, this one around 4, the other game had tons of rifles, this one has around 5. We have 3 boats you can buy, a handful of verhicles, 3 Helicopters and Planes? They're just outright gone.

The map at least seems smaller, the story was also kinda disapointing, as the premise was cool, with a landscape full of nature turning to chaos thanks to a few Mad-Max-like villains, but it all felt shallow and underdeveloped. I mainly bought this tho to finish off Joseph and find the Dep, the Dep ended up as a Hunter with no voicelines and Joseph threw away everything when his Kid died.

Honestly this ruins Joseph as a whole, his whole thing was "lets sacrifice everything for a new world" and you know, it was *kinda* goin well, you had a small clan of peaceful lads, a son, a nice village, but the MOMENT youe asshole son dies, you throw EVERYTHING away. All the lost lives, destroyed land, fired bullets and crucified Farmers for nothing. As "you are the true chosen one" or whatever bullshit he says. Like yeah, cool, you killed Ethan and ate an apple, sweet, cool, but does this mean the Cap was the one preparing everyone for the Fallout? No, that was Joseph, hell, he probably didnt even lose a single family member or anything, Joseph fought against all odds, let his family be un-avenged, lost tons of members in his clan, and ended up giving all of that up to the MC, who, as far as we know, didnt do shit and now just sits around drinking til old age gets him. So Far Cry 5's story, all your work, all your fighting against the Cult, and all the work getting closer to Joseph in this game all ended with you killing him (or letting him chant to himself where uUuUuUUuUU iS hE sTiLl aLiVe oR iS tHe oThEr oPtIoN cAnOn??) and letting the little village burn to ash. What a depressing ending to such an interesting story.

I loved Far Cry 5's ending, and honestly the ending was either actually god (as like how the fuck do you explain shit like the apple) or it was a nuke sent by north korea (as i dont think he actually found a nuke lying around) and as noone outside hope county started rebuidling it before or after the years underground, i think the whole planet was destroyed/purged, so it had to be some Power from big daddy G in the clouds. And now everyone died and we end this whole story with some nobody being seen as the "chosen one" and doing fuckall with that? No DLC where we see what he does, not even Far Cry 6 tells us anything, as its a new universe. Such a cool and unique ending like Far Cry 5's was just outright wasted on making you, the cool and new MC feel special.

That stuff aside, I like that you can spare the twins, and that Mickey even leaves a little Letter if you do. But that aside, this game feels empty, less alive than 5 (yeah its a wasteland so it shouldnt be alive bla bla, you get what i mean), has less content than 5, less unique Companions than 5, a worse soundtrack than 5, a worse story than 5, and most importantly, it was outright less fun. I am really sad this saga ends like this, give us a dlc or something to have a nice ending, or at least explain what the Cap did after the ending.

But for now, Gameplay, Story, Content and Enjoyment-wise, this is just Far Cry 5, but worse.

TLDR: Bad story basically not there, feels and plays like dlc, no replayablity, only good this for me was FC5 references.

I really enjoy this title more than the mainline one that came before it (5). It is a refreshing take on the usual shenanigans of the series, really showing that Ubisoft can still surprise us with creativity. It's sad that the smaller projects get less funding and focus, but they at least get a lot of love when a team is motivated. Also, this feels a bit like it is meant to just be DLC, but it is honestly like an entire game on its own! I definitely recommend giving this one a few hours of your time.

I was worried about this FC Spin-off that it could be a RPG/loot shooter like Borderlands or pretty much the crappy analogon to Shadow Warrior 2 or Wolfenstein Youngblood. But thank god I was wrong, yes it has some elements of those but not that much and it's still an enjoyable FC game even though I would still say it is overall one of the weaker FC games out there but still worth it if you like the series.

What are those RPG/loot shooter elements? Well weapons and enemies have a level now, but only between 1 and 4 and every weapon is still unique, you won't find the same weapon like 30 times just with different stats like in Borderlands. At least you don't level up your character. And then enemies also have hp bars and you see damage numbers. That already sounds bad and I usually hate that, but you can turn those off in the menu if you want, but I actually get used to those.
There is also some kind of loot but that's pretty much just ressources to craft weapons and such. I did not found that too annoying, actually exploring is fun in this FC as well. Sadly you only find minor amount of ressources and also only the less valuable ones. I explored a lot and pretty much always was low on ressources and could just buy few weapons per level.
You can also buy ressources with real money, but there is no need for that as you are actually supposed to do some repeatable missions: the Expeditions. Those gives a lot of ressources and also the more valuable ones. 
In other FC games I was that high on money later on that I could simply buy every weapon I want, in this one you have to grind more for that. What also sucks in this FC is that you cant modify weapons: every weapons comes with a fixes set of attachments.

The game is kinda grindy tho. You are supposed to not only free the outposts once, but 3 times, on every level from 1 to 3, same with the expeditions. And even with that all grind I did everything in the game, bought after weapon, vehicle, boat and heli, got all achievements and still just needed 35 hours for that.

The twins as antagonists were pretty boring and generic, same with the whole story. In fact there aren't a lot of story missions in it and a lot of those are very similar and feel more like sidemissions, like find a specialist for your base.
Still I liked that some characters of FC5 return in this one. 

Overall I'd say this is probably like a 6.5 or 7 out of 10. It's solid. I guess I only like Primal less.

Good: More Far Cry 3/4/5 core gameplay loop.
Bad: Big Bad is bad just for the sake of being bad, like someone from Captain Planet.

Don't care: the "beating baddie base upgrades it" mechanic isn't really interesting, and feels like it needed more work.  OTOH, you can at least reset bases individually BEFORE you reach Act III, so if you enjoy one particular base, you can just do that one more often. After finishing Far Cry 5, I held off on getting Far Cry New Dawn. I read the other reviews and the negative comments that it feels like a Far Cry 5 DLC with a smaller map. When it finally was on sufficient sale during the Autumn Sale, I purchased it. 

The map is basically the same. Everything is pretty much the same with the obvious changes that would be noted in the ending of Far Cry 5. I think the environment is very thematic and can be beautiful in its own way. Unfortunately, that's about the extent of what I do like.

The AI is still incredibly accurate as well as incredibly dumb, Enemies will hit you from across the screen but still run to the same cover in the same pattern as the other games. Enemies line up to be shot at, and the only reason that they are difficult is the weakness of the guns and the massive Hp that the game gives them. Wild animals are almost always a waste of health and ammo for me at this early part of the game, Killing a wolf with a SAW or shotgun shouldn't require an entire clip and then some. Meat sponges rarely make games fun.

Leveling gear requires finding ethanol to upgrade the home base, ethanol to upgrade the particular location in the home base (armory, infirmary, garage, etc), and then the gear for the item itself. Its not difficult to find supplies, but tedious and grinding. Allowing the Highwaymen to retake outposts to gain Ethanol just seems lazy and lacking creativity from the developers.

Its true to the Far Cry formula, but its probably the most slow paced, boring version of the series that I have played. I plan to continue to play the game and hope that leveling my character and gear as well as exploring the land and story make the game more enjoyable. At the current moment, I can only recommend it if heavily on sale and already a fan of the series.

Update 12/17/21: I've leveled up some of my weapons and gained some more "Guns for Hire". Like Far Cry 5, Sharky and Hurk are pretty funny. The remaining characters are pretty bland. Kills still require a full clip on certain enemies, but are getting more realistic. I'm willing to continue to progress and try more of the story and base advancements.

Update 12/21/21: So I've beaten the game already. Incredibly short and the story is very predictable. Last few missions require stealth and driving (two things I hate to do in Far Cry games). Last bosses are huge meat sponges with select weak spots. I leveled up my guns, and it got easier but not more enjoyable. The game was okay, but its still the worst Far Cry I've played to date.

(SPOILERS AHEAD)




I really like the Far Cry series, and after beating this game I truly suggest only buying it if you want to know what happens after the end of FC5. The only thing that really matters is the end, and it's not really worth all the 10~ hours you put into it. Too much grinding, and a bad story. They took what I loved about Joseph and Eden and crushed it. In FC5 it was just some mad man that thought he was a messiah, and that was amazing. It had a fantastic story and was fun to watch play out. FCND took that and stepped on it. It made a main premise of the plot magic powers you got from Joseph's tree that was 'sent from god' Taking that mad man messiah look and makes him right. Why would they do that?? They had a solid plot and Joseph could have not had some magic tree and the plot would have made more sense, and looked better. The Twins were alright villains I guess, but forgettable. They have little to no depth, and only want power. For almost all the villains in FC5 I felt bad for them in some way or another. They had depth and they cared about something. The Twins only made me care for them in Mickey's dying breath where she gives you some sad story. We get no time to really see who they are before they die and the plot forces you to the next mission. Don't even get me started on Ethan. They just reskinned the Yeti and made that the final boss? Really? Ubisoft has gotten lazy, and it shows. Overall I'd give the gameplay 5/10, story 6/10 and villain(s) 5/10.

I'll give you some advice, gamer to gamer. Skip EVERY cutscene.  

Farcry: New Dawn starts with some fun gameplay, sure. Maybe you'll even find it more fun with the new features of New Dawn, like the double jump. Or maybe the special skill, Wrath? Maybe you'll like the saw shooting crossbows. Maybe you'll enjoy the- 
Wait, no. That's it. Every new feature in New Dawn over Farcry 5. I didn't even once use Wrath. I wonder what it does. 

The writing and execution of the story is some of the most stupid trash Ubisoft has ever come up with, and I've played A LOT of Ubisoft titles. I sat through the slog of every cringe cutscene, only to find that the story just gets worse. The story tries its hardest (and I mean HARDEST) to tie up the events of Farcry 5 to a nice resolution, but fails catastrophically. At first, I liked that they recycled characters from Farcry 5, until I noticed that every asset New Dawn offers is just a lazy reskin. 

The game area is also two thirds smaller than Farcry 5, but you could easily see than an entire quarter of New Dawn's map is barren and only exists to serve a single mission which ends when you've punched a grizzly bear enough times. I'm not joking. Punching a bear is coincidentally also the best that the story has to offer, and most of the games production value was clearly focused on the bear punching mission. 

I really wish I didn't know what happened to the end of the stellar Farcry 5 timeline. I wish I could unsee the superpower cutscenes. I wish I could unhear the obnoxious twins. I wish I could unfeel when the uPlay launcher decided to ignore my commands to save and revert to a frustratingly old save (I've literally lost 8 hours of my current 24 hour playthrough to the void of the uPlay cloud, and there's still no fix). I don't even want to know what Wrath does. 

Skip Farcry: New Dawn and save up for Farcry 6. 
You're welcome.
