If you enjoyed Far Cry 5 at all, you'll enjoy Far Cry: New Dawn. The two have a lot in common, seeing as they take place in the same fictional world about two decades apart from one another. However, the feel of the game is more inline with its story: it feels post-apocolyptic, and the "mutated" world is absolutely stunning and wonderful to explore and play inside of. The enemies are straight up obnoxious, which just makes killing them more satisfying and the AI is about a 7/10 in my book. 

I enjoyed the story and the game and if you enjoy the Far Cry series in general, I think you probably will, too.
Good game but a bit to short, its like a dlc.

Started off interesting, but went downhill quickly. A new setting in a post-nuclear world was a good opportunity. There was a lot that could be done with a home base. Sadly, it was all wasted by eventually tying the plot to the terrible story of the main game. The home base turned out to be a big nothing-burger too. A few upgrades to unlock useful things, but generally just something you grind parts for to unlock story progression.

A key departure from the main game are the RPG elements that give enemies hit points. Weapons get stats and you can upgrade to higher tiers. Obviously, some upgrade parts are extremely scarce and wouldn't you know it, you could spend some real money to get them instead. After clearing every object on the map, I still couldn't unlock top tier stuff. I think I could try to farm the rare material by grinding the legendary animals that are a pain in the ass to track and take down. After killing a few, the game didn't even reward me with the right parts, so it feels like it's very conveniently buggy.

RPG system works for enemies first, until you start running into things than need fifty sniper headshots to take down. The final boss fight took me half an hour of running around in smoke, looking for ammo refills so I could keep shooting the ridiculous bullet sponges running after me.

I like open world games, but I don't want to ever touch another far cry game ever again at this point.
Personally yes, I'm a very big Far Cry fan and the futuristic apocalyptic world makes it so much better.
Exact replica of far cry 5 with different storyline.

Warning a lot of text and some spoilers in this review.

So I beat the game took me 16 hours total but if i were going to only do the main quest i would of taken me just probably under 12 which just does not seems like a game worth my time, most games when you reach that 12 hour mark you get that halfway mark or such, hell a game such as Red Dead 2 12 hours you probably just finished the first major heist in the game. I think when they were developing the game they thought that a way to restrict the player and add more runtime to the game was adding the need to retake outpost to upgrade the base so you unlock health weapons and such, and to be honest it is really only worth getting the tier 3 purple weapons since you dont see the elite enemys much only when you retake the outpost to tier 3. I will say adding resource missions to the game where you get materials to craft said weapons is a great idea so you are not scrounging around to find shit to make a better shotgun or such.

Pros:
- The gunplay is actually decent compared to other farcry games
- For the same map with new paint they change alot and actually make new places interesting
- Some really fun and enjoyable missions
- Some companions are nice and actually cool ( Cheese boy gang)

Cons:
- The game map is small so you end up having a sweat but very short game
- I might have missed it but you can only have one companion at a time which kinda sucks
- The companion ability unlocks are really sloppy  with each needing 40 kill to fully unlock all of it, some easier then others and dependable on playstyle
- You can buy the locations to all of the music, stashs, and photos in the game and even after you get them all which i did you get nothing for doing it
- Near the end the missions turn into a slow burn and just drag on

(SPOILERS)
You end up fighting the twins in a very anticlimactic fight where they are just elites one with a flamethrower and one with a sniper, both pretty easy to kill then they give a speak of how blah blah it could of ended different and blah blah" one of the speeches to make you feel bad but in the end it just falls short due to the fact that they are just poorly written and just such the fun out of the game and they are not even the end game boss the end game boss is this stupid "shoot the giant glowing orange shit on this dude to kill him" fight and honeslty i have never been more bored in a boss fight then the last two in the game 

All in all I would give this game a solid 6.5/10 its a fun game but the end game just ruins it and i know this was basically a enhanced dlc for farcry 5 but it just falls short of being fun at the end

Very cool setting. The story kind of feels like a continuation of Far Cry 5. However, weapons feel more "rpg-ish" therefore enemies can kind of sometimes feel like bullet sponges. Nevertheless, it is fun and has that post-apoc setting and feel to it, if you want to have that scratch itched. Of all of the DLCs, I think this is the only one worth getting honestly. The load stuttering, as usual, is still present here like it is in Far Cry 5. You just have to get used to it and you barely notice it.

tl;dr: villains suck, uplay launcher sucks even worse, overall decent game, good visuals, cute pets, hurk is a beast.

the villains suck and dont really work as villains since a diplomatic approach on their part would be more beneficial for everyone if they have any regard for resource management, uplay launcher is just so unintuitively awful, and i dont know why ubisoft wont do anything about it.

but otherwise, its a good game if you ignore everything i just mentioned. visuals are really good, gameplay is better than far cry 5 imo, and i have spent hundreds of points into unarmed damage since you can upgrade it infinitely. i will achieve one punch man status one day.
Pleasant time eater - love it

about as fun as watching paint dry.

coming from someone who loved fc5, too

Mediocre, but enjoyable overall. There are some downgrades from far cry 5 such as the vehicle variety, perk progression, not being able to mod weapons, the rather simple story and the characters who are not as interesting. It is still a decent game though.

Honestly this game was a nice little treat. Yes they could have spent more time adding quality of life changes to coop, and making the base building a bit more in depth, but overall it was a well balanced game with a pretty damn cool story line. After playing the main story and looking at the game from an outside perspective, the storytelling, the visuals and feel of the various activities and transportation methods, and overall game-play meshed together make me think of this game as an extremely young spiritual Prequel to the Borderlands series if Borderlands were a tad bit more grounded. 

I recommend this game to anyone looking for an intriguing story or fun coop experience.
yes

Far Cry has a saving dynamic where you cannot save during missions - if you quit, you'll lose the entire mission. That's not such a big deal for a quick mission, but you can get locked into missions that are over an hour of playtime. I'm an adult, I have things to do, and I have a chronic illness. This isn't accessible. I may make an effort to return this game even though I'm 19 hours in- I try not to patronize inaccessible games.

I was expecting something similar to Far Cry 5 but it's somehow way worst. The world is set after bombs have dropped and it looks nice. The biggest issue of this game is AI. Game was released in February 2019 and they haven't fixed it at all. Your companion who's literally following you everywhere randomly stops following you and in most cases won't join you in your ride. Enemies look like they're sick fighting because you can come up to their face before they notice you and even when all of them are alerted they don't do much and sometimes forget they're in fight. There is one mission where you have to escape with motorcycle and shot enemies, for 80% of mission they're just crashing in random objects and other 20% you can knock them down with one hit.

So overall i have no idea how this game has "Mostly positive" reviews but it's a lie. Only good thing is i bought it for 10$

I can really only recommend this game on sale since it is more Farcry primal than Farcry 5. It adds plenty of new mechanics like an interesting remix of the economy since cash is now worthless. They finally made a way for you to re-liberate outposts in an interesting and rewarding way. They also added a tier list for weapons, vehicles, enemies, pretty much everything. I was afraid the game would feel exactly the same as Farcry 5, but the changes up to the map and  the mechanics makes for a mostly new experience. However,  The lackluster story, lame main antagonists, and the truly abysmal experience with the Ubisoft launcher, I've had to go full task manager on it about every other game launch, made this game a 6/10 for me.

Pros:  -Like the character customization, and the more abstract styles due to the post-apocalypse theme
          -Gun-play is smooth and the takedowns are brutal 
          -Expeditions are great and makes a bit for the much smaller main map size
          -Same map as Farcry 5 but is edited enough to be acceptable as a new games map
Cons: -Art style causes near sensory overload and need a bit of suspension of disbelief considering how 
           fucked everything got not to long ago in the story
          -The entire game is downsized from the previous one in most every reguard, there are no planes, less 
           vehicle variety, smaller map, shorter story, bland undeveloped antagonists, pond deep allies
          -Upgrading the main base "Prosperity" has almost no significant visual changes while upgrading it,
            which is a large focus of the game, the only things I could notice was a tarp being replaced with 
            trees and some facilities getting slightly more stuff, and there are areas in the base that are blocked 
            off despite being made in farcry 5, it would be nice to upgrade it from a small squatter camp to an 
           impregnable fortress, leaving no space wasted,
          -Every roster ally other than the dog Timber sucks ass, Timber seems to be the only one who fights 
            anything alongside their useful abilities.
          -The current existence of the Judge just shits all over Farcry 5s protagonist and turns them into a 
           useless bumbling ally that has a character shift so unbelievable that its best to forget theyre the same 
           character 
         -Theres plenty Im forgetting rn

The Far Cry series has never tried to be something its not. It is what it is and will continue to be, hopefully. If you've played one, you've played them all. Its like a fever dream. The AI is insane. Bears attacking a Moose, bad guys attacking a random passersby. Someone comes running out of the woods suddenly with a flamethrower, everyone burns to death in less than a minute. Good times. Oh yeah, the storylines aren't bad either. The characters are somewhat one dimensional, but its Far Cry, spectacle over substance, but not a complete wash either. I loved it. I'm not going to compare the soundtrack to Far Cry 5 as that wouldn't be fair. As it is, the soundtrack is bangin, really fits the vibrant, dangerous post nuclear vibe. I love the visuals, the concept makes for a lush, beautiful world. Prettier than Far Cry 5, dare I say. Highly recommend.

Game just crashes to desktop REPEATEDLY and at random.  No way to tell when it is going to happen and there's no error message.  You play and then suddenly the screen goes black, then you are back at the desktop and the Ubisoft launcher is trying to sync your game with the cloud.  Have tried every single option people have posted online about how to "fix" this and none work.  We are now FAR away from the video drivers (nvidia) that were thought to be a problem for this game (the recommendation a couple years ago was to go back to an old driver).  Trying this today will break some of your newer games.  Locking your screen refresh (another suggestion) does nothing.  Turning off or leaving off HDR does nothing.  The game just doesn't work.  NO other game I have has anything remotely like this problem.  It is organic to THIS game.

New Dawn and FarCry 4 are my favoirites of the FarCry series. I recently started playing New Dawn again on my amped up Windows 10 PC and now I can only play for about 15 minutes before the game RANDOMLY CRASHES to desktop... This is so annoying... Far Cry New Dawn's post-apocalyptic version of Hope County is essentially the same one we know from Far Cry 5. Once again the locals are being terrorized by armed gangs speeding around in infinite trucks while furious bears and homicidal turkeys leap from the bushes to claw at anything that moves. New Dawn adds a couple new twists to the series' formula‚Äîat times you can leave Montana to visit other states‚Äîbut nothing to make it feel like a wholly different game. This is Far Cry 5 again, just on a smaller scale and with more pink flowers.

It's years after the nukes fell at the end of Far Cry 5, and your nameless character has been traveling the country by rail, helping survivors rebuild the post-apocalyptic United States. A group of highwaymen (not that cleverly called the 'Highwaymen') derail your train and leave you stranded. After making your way to a small community called Prosperity, you venture out into the overgrown remains of Hope County, fighting the Highwaymen, conquering outposts, gathering resources for crafting, and enlisting a small cadre of colorful companions like an elderly sniper and an enormous, rampaging boar. This goes without saying, but never bring the sniper with you. Always bring the boar.

As you help out the locals you gain perk points that can be used to unlock skills in any order you wish, a nice and loose ability system that lets you focus on whatever is most important to your playstyle, be it melee damage, stealth kills, or traversal tools like the wingsuit (fun for sightseeing and bailing out of burning choppers) and grappling hook (mostly just for treasure-hunting in bunkers and caves) . A few perks, like how much ammo you can carry and how hard you punch, can be upgraded endlessly, giving you even more flexibility in your build. A set of five new skills introduced near the end of the game indulge a bit more ridiculousness, giving you fun powers like a double jump and limited-time berserker strength.

Now when I swing my spiked baseball bat at a rampaging bear it sails comically through the air. The Far Cry games have always cast you as an army of one, but New Dawn turns you into a legit superhero. These powers are novel for a bit, but feel a little unnecessary when I'm already able to insta-kill with stealth takedowns and spawn an endless supply of helicopters.

Combat is the same frantic and fun gunplay as in the past few Far Cry games. Vehicles and barrels explode, fire spreads across grass and trees, enemies recklessly charge and scream and bombard you with mortars or light you up with flamethrowers, with the occasional wild animal or friendly citizen getting caught up in the chaos. Speaking of wild animals, my loyal boar Horatio compliments my ranged attacks as a tank, scattering screaming Highwaymen like bowling pins so I can more easily pick them off with my sniper rifle before running in to clean up with my shotgun or knife.

The longer a companion is with you, the more skills they develop, and midway through New Dawn my big pig (really the only companion I used) was even able to self-revive himself, meaning I could turn him loose without having to keep an eye him. Plus, Horatio has lots of personality, paddling around in the water while I'm fishing and sometimes falling asleep and snoring softly while I'm hanging out in Prosperity. You can co-op New Dawn with a friend, but seeing an enraged boar headbutt a truck onto its side is pretty priceless.

There are plenty of familiar landmarks on this smaller version of the map (radiation has closed off a portion of it) and several familiar (yet older) characters from the last game are still around. I think we're meant to feel a bit wistful about Hope County‚Äîa quest has you collecting old photographs to help you remember what the landscape looked like before the bombs‚Äîbut it's hard to feel like there's much difference between the world's chaotic past and present, and Far Cry 5 was only just last year so it's not exactly a nostalgia trip. You can make a few expeditions out of Montana, raiding larger and more imaginative enemy outposts off the main map, like an aircraft carrier on the coast, a ruined amusement park in Louisiana, and even Alcatraz. 

These expeditions are much more challenging than outposts in that they spawn unlimited enemies until you escape via a timed chopper rescue, so they can't be taken down by stealth alone‚Äîthe bad guys will find you. Plus, you can't just glide to safety in your wingsuit when things don't go your way: these are self-contained excursions that you either pass or fail. You can escape with loot or die and do the whole thing over, which gives expeditions a bit of tension.

The big bads of New Dawn, twin sisters Mickey and Lou, are so inconsequential I almost forgot to mention them. Unlike the Seed family in Far Cry 5, they aren't constantly subjecting you to long, drawn out speeches (thank you). The twins only appear a few times, and mostly just issue brief threats over the radio to remind you they exist. It's considerate of them to basically leave you alone while you completely dismantle their entire army, but it makes your final showdown with them just another bullet-sponge bossfight.

I completed the main story quest of Far Cry New Dawn in about a dozen hours, and spent a few more mopping up side-quests and exploring. It's brief compared to Far Cry 5, and completable without fully upgrading Prosperity to access the highest levels of gear and vehicles (though you'll definitely want to unlock the best weapons). While it's good fun at times, New Dawn is really just a quick trip back to Far Cry 5's Montana that hasn't changed much beyond a post-apocalyptic paint job.

SPOILERS: While the gameplay is what you'd expect, fun and allows freedom, it doesn't make up for a wank story. The Highwaymen are criminally underdeveloped, as well as their leaders Mickey and Lou, who have less screen time than Pagan Min, and whenever you kill them, Ubisoft tries to garner the smallest amount of respect for them (or specifically Mickey). Good villains who are well developed make you feel for them, the twins backstory can be seen in a single cutscene. That's it! And I can guarantee that most people who bought this game were interested in the end to the storyline that Far Cry 5 started, and holy shit it was bad. Joseph is barely even seen, and if I remember correctly, he's only in 3 or 4 missions. He also has a random ass son who's just shoehorned in, and his character design and to a degree "arc" is bad. Whiny, bratty, hates his dad, and spoilers, once you beat him, he instantly feels bad and apologizes, then he dies, Joseph is sad. Then now is where Joseph realizes the error of his ways and he asks you to ultimately kill him. And it doesn't really matter if you do or don't, he never appears again, then the game ends. This should've just been paid DLC for Far Cry 5, maybe replace the zombie DLC with this one.

A weak spinoff of far cry 5, with uninteresting characters and an uninspired storyline. It seems like someone was mad that Joseph wasn't put through enough, so they made this game where he spontaneously has a son, and that son is a monster for no real reason or purpose, and burns down what little Joseph had left. Then the writers tossed in a couple black female villains, as an afterthought, and had them be mildly annoying with a halfassed "tragic" backstory. Music was also phoned in, nothing original and memorable, just a bunch of trendy licensed material. It is nice that they included a "streamer mode" so you can turn pretty much the entire soundtrack off, and listen to your own music or a podcast instead.

I'd say this is maybe worth 10, 15 dollars. And only then if you're truly desperate for more hope country content. Otherwise best to just pretend this entire game never happened, which is what I plan to do starting now.

Far Cry New Dawn is the successor of Far Cry 5, and it carries along the backstory plus follows the same game mechanics from the previous title. It feels like a deluxe DLC of a game, but it‚Äôs decently impactful as a standalone game to enjoy and adore. There can be multiple natural improvements, but the published version is still fun to grind some hours on. Far Cry franchise always loves to experiment with uncanny twists in every title, whether it be crafting system, story twists or whole UI and environment.

[h1][b]Story without spoilers:[/b][/h1]
[b]Continuity from previous title-[/b] After the nuke from Far Cry 5, People are living in bunkers under the devastated Hope County. After six years of retaining underground life, everyone is shocked to see nature self-healed. All the communities started the lifelong nourishing of humankind. The impact of Father (villainous priest) has decreased as he went missing for merely 17 years.

[b]Progressive plot-[/b] Even with all the peace and prosperity, there will always be a villainous group taking birth. Not much long after the beginning of prosperity, two twins, Lou and Mickey, violently attack Hope valley with their brutal groups. This peace turned into a warzone will present a variety of missions and twists all along with the story.

[h1][b]üéÆGameplay:[/b][/h1]
Unlike traditional post-apocalypse slum sceneries, it presents you with an exceptionally vibrant open-world environment that includes multiple activities to conquer. It‚Äôs not just a survival game. It‚Äôs about survival, ambition, hunt and regaining multiple chores. You start in train wreckage while getting attacked by a violent mob known as Highwaymen. After escaping them, your journey of retaliation starts. You will craft some low to high tier weapons along with ambushing and winning over the outposts with your roster (co-op AI). Looting and Leveling up becomes easier as you progress through the gameplay.

Even though the primary missions contribute solely to your game progress, the side quests and hunting aren‚Äôt left alone. They are quite in-depth and immersive on their own. Attacking an armoured gang isn‚Äôt a straightforward task. That‚Äôs why you need an alias that you can trust. Doing side missions rewards you various items from rosters, materials, money and sometimes powerful gear. As every territory-based journey starts from a base camp, Prosperity acts as a home base for the peaceful community lead by Rush. You can upgrade various segments of the home base like cartography, garage, expedition and much more. They all require some hefty build materials, but in the end, they ease your gameplay in multiple ways.

You are never action deficient throughout the game. Even travelling through point A to point B will cause a random ambush ready to surprise you. The map is not very huge, but having an auto-drive feature can always act handy. Everything feels amusing and smooth. It‚Äôs a genuine blend of story and side quests grilled with an overdose of action. Hunting is not really in depth, but there‚Äôs a sufficient variety of animals to hunt and trade their skin for some extra bucks. Remember, it doesn‚Äôt matter whether you are on land or water. There will always be a ferocious animal ready to take you on. Not only that, there are some hybrid animals too that might stomp on your corpse pretty quick. Difficulty options were well-segmented to establish a do-able and challenge ratio.

[h1][b]üì∑Graphics:[/b][/h1]
Easy 10/10. I don‚Äôt think there can be anyone disliking this piece of art. Not only the colours are vibrant, but the development is also top-notch. Enriched detailing and interaction with the environment always bind you to a strong thread of excitement. The blend of flower valley and devastating action somehow turned out pretty well. And the addition of Photo Mode just boosts your quench of capturing beautiful moments. You can also download extra texture packs to transform this heavenly environment into beyond imagination artwork.

[h1][b]üìùMain Pros and Cons:[/b][/h1]

[b]Pros-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Pleasant environment.
    [*]Concludes Far Cry 5
    [*]A useful dog companion who can sit with you in car. 
    [*]Smooth gameplay.
    [*]Good arsenal of weapon and armed vehicles.
    [*]Hunting and fishing.
[/list]

[b]Cons-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Dumb Roster AI.
    [*]Short story.
    [*]Silent Protagonist.
    [*]Not being able to modify/kit out you weapons.
    [*]Somehow bows impact more than a MLG.
[/list]

[h1][b]üè∑Ô∏èTips to new players:[/b][/h1]
As you don‚Äôt need separate equipment to tag your enemies, wander around the targeted place and scope of your gun to easily tag them. Roster AI is pretty dumb, so I suggest you either use Timber or Horatio. Initial missions want you to engage with outposts and ethanol convoys, so lockpick and vehicle repair perks will be most handy in the beginning.

[h1][b]‚úâÔ∏èMiscellaneous Information:[/b][/h1]
[b]Expedition-[/b]
Expedition probably acts as the difficulty factor of the game. Dropping you on the waypoint through a helicopter and makes you execute a solo raid against multiple enemies. Tag the package and escape the premises. Executing a successful expedition unlocks a higher tier mission next time. You can access them from the Prosperity home base.

[b]Similarities and Dissimilarities from Far Cry 5-[/b]
[list]
       [*][b]Similarities-[/b] Same silent protagonist who is experiencing the events instead of making a personality. Same location but with additional after nuke changes. The cult theme in addition to wildlife crafting. Roster features ascend again.
       [*][b]Dissimilarities-[/b]Far Cry New Dawn isn‚Äôt that free in the open-world aspect. You are just collecting resources for the home base. The story is not even half the size of Far Cry 5. 
[/list]

[b]Info about DLCs-[/b]
There are multiple DLCs available, ranging from high tier weapons, vehicles to fancy skins. Hurk legacy is probably the most useful one, as it provides you with a good calibre weapon and an effective gun mounted car. Rest DLCs are fine and not harmful to acquire. Texture DLC is free, so make sure to download it if your PC can fulfil the requirements.

[h1][b]üòáHonest Rating:[/b][/h1]
Being a fan of the Far Cry franchise, playing each new title is a fun experience. But calling Far Cry New Dawn a standalone game is hard to digest. It showcases more like a duplicate Far Cry 5 with map enhancements but half the content. The best part is probably the conclusion for Far Cry 5 ending, that you can experience in New Dawn. The asking price is too high, so please wait for a huge sale. If you never tried a Far Cry game and like this style of gameplay, then start with Far Cry 5. Otherwise, all the OG players should play this one too.

Rating: 8/10

OUT-OF-TOWNER DESTROYS LOCAL FAMILY ESTABLISHMENT 

So I got this at its lowest price yet along with Far Cry 5 when Far Cry 6 was announced. I'll be honest, I've only played 3(and bits of 2) and never even finished it. Every subsequent game though was like Ubisoft giving me better and better settings with New Dawn definitely being the peak. A colorful, vibrant, post-apocalyptic world was like ticking every box for me. Having also an FPS itch for quite some time, I finally sat down and finished a Far Cry game. My impressions? Mixed but edging on the positive and I'll explain why.

Far Cry: New Dawn uses Hope County from Far Cry 5 with a new skin as its setting, kinda like how Primal used the map from 4. The intro sets up the story from the nuclear explosion at the end of 5 up to the new society emerging. It focuses on a particular settlement of survivors and their rivalry with two sisters who lead a pack of vicious highwaymen. You play as an outsider, man or woman, who has been called to help rebuild but ends up going in an all out war against them, uniting with various misfits and the cult of New Eden from 5 along the way. It's a pretty basic premise which checks the Far Cry boxes. 

There isn't really much character development for the empty vessel that is the silent protagonist, everything unfolds as expected and I can't even say in good faith that the Sisters had anything of value narrative-wise. You encounter them in various points of the plot as is expected from Far Cry villains but their characters and dialogue are pretty basic and they end up being very forgettable. Probably my major gripe with the game, how cookie-cutter every aspect of the narrative is. The lore bits and piece, on documents and such, didn't help either and some pop-culture references were simply arbitrary and didn't add anything other than being there for the sake of them.

Let's see where the true focus of the game lies though and this is in the crafting mechanics, clearing the map and the solid gun-play. The latter is where the game truly shines. Every gun is responsive and feels great to use. The difference between the starting ones and the elite ones which will accompany you near the end, is a million miles away. It is truly an empowering feeling, grinding your progression, unlocking perks and the best guns. You will become an unstoppable killing machine with quite some options on your hands considering the various gun categories. It's where you'll find the most fun, customizing loadouts and trying different tactics according to such loadouts on the level scaling enemies. The level scaling itself, is quite more fair than in other games and didn't hinder my power trip, just added the right amount of challenge as the tiers elevated.

For said tiers to elevate, you need to upgrade your base which is tied to progressing the story and for that you'll need ethanol. Ethanol is the main crafting resource, gas in a Mad Max logic, and you'll get the biggest amounts of it by liberating enemy camps and claiming them for yourself. Everything has four tiers in the game(gray, blue, purple, gold) and so do the camps. You have the option to let the camp go back to the enemy in exchange for more ethanol. Consequently you'll be facing enemies of the following tier the next time you liberate it but you'll also get more ethanol. It's a nice cycle but in the end it was boring to me. I was grinding constantly through random events such as liberating prisoners, stealing ethanol trucks, hunting, getting supply boxes from the enemy and completing treasure hunts so I was drowning in most common resources and sure, camps provided some rare resources needed to craft better weapons but I just reached the second tier of camps and then stopped. 

The main problem of the game other than the narrative is repetition. If you do every camp on every tier you'll get 40 liberations but I don't think anyone would go through all that hassle and continuously be having fun. The only incentive would be to get all the weapons and vehicles but even in the 24 hours of my playtime, I had more than enough stuff for variety, to match my preferred game style and complete the main story pretty easily. This could have been rectified if there were 40 camps but this would also mean a complete new game and not the quicker made Far Cry 5 spin-off that Ubisoft intended. 

The base upgrades make your life easier. Stuff like higher tier companions will help you greatly and stuff such as maps marking resources I found completely useless. Essential upgrades include the ability to craft better weapons and vehicles but if you want these you should probably upgrade Expeditions. Expeditions are missions outside the main map which also have tiers, so of course you get to play the same missions 4 times. It's the easiest way to get rare crafting materials for the best weapons but again there wasn't much need for me to pursue them with all the general grinding. I just did a bunch to get some elites weapons during the end of my playtime. This could vary though as you may want more weapons faster. 

What I found most worthwhile in all of the game was probably the companion system. They can be of great assistance once they've racked up 40 kills with all their abilities unlocked and make your life a hell lot of easier in every step of the way. Every companion comes with their own unique mission in order to unlock them and these were some of the best missions in the entire game. Other than that they have great personalities and I liked pretty much all of their quips as we navigated the world together(and of course, you can pet the dog and the hog). They also vary vastly in terms of abilities to suit every possible game style. Again though, there is simply no need to spend a whole bunch of time and upgrade all of them. As with weapons and vehicles you'll have your favorites with whom you'll finish the game.

My final remarks on gameplay would be this overall feeling of how many things were not needed. I didn't use many of the utility items such as throwing knives, bait, grenades etc. I was mostly crafting med packs and enjoying the solid gun-play. There was no need to try things like the fishing mechanic, no incentive, it was just there. The game is so small in scope, story-wise and in terms of the map, that most of these options in every aspect will be left untouched. 

The presentation of everything is stellar though, I would have really liked for this to have a good story with such beautiful art direction and music. The graphics were pretty nice also and considering I don't have the newest of rigs, I didn't get many frame drops with every option on ultimate and some on high. That being said I had quite some crashes, I had bugs such as the mouse not clicking while I was in the map which made hit ctrl-alt-delete to continue playing and the game taking forever to load on some instances. Problems which would completely go away once I cleaned up broken registry items and tuned up my pc which leads me to believe that there's something truly effed up going on with the DRM and Ubisoft Connect.

To be honest, I'm recommending this game because it was fun. If you've played many Far Cry games you could probably skip it(except if you really want to know the end of the Far Cry 5 story) but in any case there is worth in solid gun-play in a generally beautiful setting. Get this cheap as I did and just waste 20 or so hours. I should leave you with the fact that I personally hit a boredom stagnation around the 15 hour mark which led me to play other games for some days before getting back to it. In any case, your mileage may vary, if any of all these sounded appealing to you there are certainly many worse open world time wasters. This one doesn't overstay its welcome and it's the main reason that barely keeps it worthwhile.

[h1]The Premise[/h1]
[h3]This review contains no spoilers.[/h3]
[b]Far Cry New Dawn[/b] (FCND) is a first-person open-world shooter set in a post-apocalyptic version of Montana (USA). Players impersonate a random survivor, that reached Hope County via train, only to barely escape a dangerous accident. After finding the makeshift base made by locals in the area, the protagonist agrees to help them against the Highwaymen, a gang that threatens everyone with submission or destruction.

[h1]Quick Sum-Up[/h1]
[table]
[tr]
[th]üü© [b]The Pros[/b][/th]
[th]üü• [b]The Cons[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
1. Wonderfully looking and dynamic open-world.

2. Satisfying combat with enjoyable gunplay.

3. Good challenge level on the hardest setting.

4. Secondary quests feel unique and varied.

[/td]
[td]
1. Generally forgettable story and characters.

2. Side-activities become tedious in the long run.

3. Balance problems late in the adventure.

4. Issues with co-op partner progression.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[tr]
[th]üü® [b]Bugs & Other Issues[/b][/th]
[th]üîß [b]PC Specs[/b][/th]
[/tr]

- Takedowns are not always reliable.
- Outposts cannot be reset in co-op lobbies.
[/td]

- NvME SSD
- 1440p Display
[/td]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2506603496

[h1]In-Depth Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Pros[/h3]
[b]1.[/b]
Exploring the post-apocalyptic Montana really feels like a lively, dynamic experience thanks to the numerous random events that can happen regularly. Resource convoys, enemy patrols, gunfights between various factions and brutal animal packs, are all factors that can influence a mission or side activity at any time. Generally the encountered NPCs react realistically to such events, as well.

[b]2.[/b]
Weapon feeling, sounds and impacts feel satisfying and realistic against the enemy: grenade launchers have foes fly away, same goes for point-blank shotguns, while more exotic weapons have custom effects like setting things on fire or ricochet ammo, lock-on missiles. The arms variety is good, with options for also stealth if needed. Enemies have average AI and will use cover, grenades often. 

[b]3.[/b]
Just a few shots from an average bandit are all it takes to down a player on the toughest setting. When it comes down to Elite enemies or animals, they may very well one-shot the protagonist(s) there and then, depending on the situation. Using ramshackle weapons against higher-level foes incurs in heavy damage penalties, further adding to the difficulty especially early on.

[b]4.[/b]
Side and main-missions that involve specific characters or treasure hunts all feel unique, and have their own little "mini-stories" to discover, for those that want to take time reading lore documents. Not only that, but often these operations feature unique puzzles, gameplay elements or situations that force to change approach radically.

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[b]1.[/b]
Except for the last story chapter, the rest of FCND's adventure proves utterly mediocre and unremarkable as far as good stories are concerned. The stereotyped "chaotic evil" villains don't have an ounce of charisma, same goes for the various NPCs that mostly try to be amusing / stand out, only to end up being cringe at best.

[b]2.[/b]
Exception made for Treasure Hunts, all other side-activities, in particular "loot zones" and outposts, become a real chore in the long run. Each enemy outpost can be captured then abandoned again to face a harder version of it - that doesn't change much though, apart from rewards and enemy scaling. This has to be done many times to get all the upgrades.

[b]3.[/b]
Once top-tier weapons and a good amount of perks are acquired, the difficulty drastically lowers, simply because most enemies will be obliterated instantly by such mighty weapons or armed vehicles. In particular armed helicopters are a huge abuse, since they can clear entire outposts without enemies even being able to shoot back. 

[b]4.[/b]
Only the lobby host will be able to upgrade the base facilities, get certain story-related perks or initiate fast-travel and other interactions. Progress in the story is not saved for the eventual co-op partner, only resources are. This becomes frustrating because the second player will basically have no place to invest their share of the earnings, and be locked out of some progression skills as well.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2507502519

[h1]Gameplay Breakdown[/h1]

[b]Exploration[/b]
Is performed on foot or with the use of ground, sea and air vehicles such as cars, jeeps, boats and helicopters. Progressively better and faster vehicles can be unlocked at the garage after the proper upgrades have been performed to the home base. The world is rather large and dotted with points of interest, secondary quests and secret areas - most of them can be found manually or located by buying the relative map from traders, for a price in Ethanol, one of the main currencies. Mostly, exploration involves travelling from point A to point B in order to clear the next point of interest.

[b]Combat[/b]
Plays out in an FPS fashion, with players eventually be able to carry one sidearm, two main weapons and a heavy one, plus a variety of throwables like grenades, molotovs, C4 charges and knives. Melee weapons are also an option, although not recommended in most cases, ranged ones are just better. Enemies come in different archetypes like snipers, assault troops, melee specialists and so on, differing in level as the game progresses. Animals use the same system, there are some rare ones whose pelts can be traded for great amounts of resources. Armed vehicles are a thing later on, they are overpowered mostly and make fights very easy.

[b]Side Activities[/b]
Comprise quests, treasure hunts and some collectible hunting as well. The locations are sparse and often difficult to find, however the trader maps completely remove this hardship. The puzzles required to complete hunts and collectible finds are enjoyable and in the first case, unique for each instance. The rewards are really good too, so totally worth doing.

[b]Character Progression[/b]
Mainly comes from perk and weapon unlocking. Passive skills are unlocked with points granted by completing challenges, this encourages taking part into varied activities and using different weapon types or other means to kill enemies. Weapons are unlocked at specific benches at one's home base, each "bench level" upgrade enables crafting a new roster of weapons using the crafting materials acquired during missions. The same system is used for vehicles, consumables and ammunition types.

[b]Expeditions[/b]
Are external missions, oriented towards stealth, that see players engage into "heists" of sorts against fortified Highwaymen outposts. As soon as they are discovered, and endless stream of enemies will converge on players, which happens anyway once the package is acquired. The ultimate goal is to escape to the extraction helicopter with the loot, within the allotted time.

[i]It took me, along with a friend, around 23 hours to complete FCND on the hardest difficulty setting, while also clearing all the secondary quests and activities. The overall quality is good, replay value is very low, and ultimately I wouldn't suggest purchasing for the full 45‚Ç¨ price - I recommend waiting for a sale instead.[/i]

One of the best in the Far Cry series so far, I would say kind of tied with FC5, although they each have different strengths and weaknesses IMO

Pros:
- Nice graphics
- Nice gameplay (shooting feels great, vehicles are good)
- Convenient fast travel, but not as much as in FC5 (cf cons below)
- I really liked the story better than FC5's. We get to understand Joseph's motivations and he seems a lot more human and friendly.

Cons:
- The companion system isn't as good as FC5 because 1) you can't have 2 companions at the same time and 2) it seems that when a companion dies, you have no choice but to pay resources to resurrect them (in FC5, you just have to wait for a while)
- Unlocking air drops can only be done pretty late in the game. Fast travel can also only be unlocked after a while (but sooner)
- The tier/level system is pretty meh. In particular, it's too harsh: enemies with a higher level are so incredibly hard to damage. They shouldn't have made such big differences between levels I think. Particularly since on the other hand, weapons don't seem a lot different between tiers (yet despite looking similar, again trying to damage an enemy of higher level than your weapon will be really tough.

NB: For those of you who care about not wasting SSD writes & space, I'd recommend making sure you disable the HD texture pack. The game looks already great without it, and disabling it saves about 19 GiB (compared to a 20 GiB game size without said pack, so installing the pack will almost double the game size :o).
The game is cool but challenging. Who wants adventure I advise!

I don't know what it is but I really did not like Far Cry New Dawn. I guess coming from the nihilistic ending of Far Cry 5 which led into this I was already a little pissed off since the previous antagonist not only survives but takes a mentor role this time around and not just that but the two new big bads Mickey and Lou are absolutely insufferable. I understand that you want to motivate your players with a villain you want to kill but why are these two the least likeable turds I have ever had the displeasure of facing. And no this isn't coming from the fact that they are women, Far Cry 4 and 5 had great secondary antagonists that were women but the thing is they were well written characters with either tragic pasts or they were blindly following a leader due to power. These two are just selfish assholes that just annoy me. I will sing some praise for the world design even though it's just a condensed Hope County but the addition of vibrant pinks and blues is really eye catching and marvelous. Funny enough it really reminds me of something Die Antward would have created hell even the highwaymen remind of Die Antward. But outside of that the game just doesn't do anything for me. It's quite literally Far Cry with RPG elements and now as a way to try and add a sense of scaling or progression you level up and unlike higher level weapons with pre-selected mods on them which for some reason makes me irrationally angry for some reason I guess because I can no longer customize my weapons to fit my play style even though these kinds of weapons have existed since FC3 but making it the whole arsenal just feel cheap. Also for a game that is a direct sequel to the previous game it REALLY feels like an expensive DLC and the fact that they added micro-transactions to help progress in the story also kind of annoys me even though its not the first time Ubisoft did something like this. All in all I just can't recommend this game it just feels cheap and often lazy and coming from a F tier ending this feels like it should be a "what if" sort of deal not a full fledged sequel.

I must say, Far Cry New Dawn is a very odd continuation of the series. That is not to say it is bad-- quite the opposite, in fact-- but rather that it is unlike anything ever seen before in the Far Cry universe. While I did not agree with some of the character continuations from Far Cry 5, seeing returning characters in an almost completely new game was quite a joy. Experiencing Far Cry New Dawn with playing Far Cry 5 borderline religiously (pun intended,) brings me near to tears looking at the destruction of the locations I knew near and dear to my heart in the old Montana. Far Cry New Dawn brings a new take to the genre, having much more RPG elements within it, while still keeping it's core shoot-em-up, action-packed FPS feel of the previous games. Truly, I believe this is one of the greatest stories and games of the Far Cry universe.

That is not to say this game is without fault, however. In fact, these faults can be quite plentiful. The story at its core, without spoiling anything, makes one cringe. Not in the way that many stories can, tearing at the heart-strings and manipulating your feelings in every way possible, but in a way that almost feels like you've abandoned the 5th game of the series. [spoiler] One quite noticeable part of this was the joining up with Joseph Seed, and seeing the result of the "Judge." I can not physically believe that the Judge was the same character which I terminated all of the rest of the Seeds and survived a literal apocalypse with. [/spoiler] However, I do believe the story is a quite faithful continuation of the characters, at least those that we see, and it's always nice riding and raising hell with the "old friends."

The gameplay aspect, however, in comparison to Far Cry 5, leaves something to be desired. I personally dislike RPG games, yet thought this was an amazing action game nonetheless. However, the map size was *drastically* reduced from Far Cry 5, and being unable to visit the extent of the mere medium sized map of Far Cry 5 makes this game almost feel like a DLC, as opposed to the entirely new game it was supposed to be. Additionally, the campaign felt almost repetitive at times, yet that is to be expected with yet another Far Cry game.

This is all to say that overall, I thoroughly enjoyed my time playing this game. Despite the criticisms I have of it, I do believe it to be a game 100% worth playing, AS LONG AS you have played Far Cry 5. To someone who is new to the series, I would recommend one of the earlier games, as this is primarily driven by previous knowledge of Far Cry 5's universe.

Follows the story line of Far Cry 5 but seems a lot less developed. A bit of a half game DLC as another reviewer has mentioned with half the number of missions and area to explore. 
The world just doesn't seem as big as Far Cry 5 even though its based around the same world. And the apocalyptic quality just doesn't make sense. How did everything become and so green after only 17 years. There should be massive patches of blight which are only seen on the world boundaries for some reason.
The story is not really as gripping as that of far cry 5. The missions seem limited and there aern't many main story missions.
There really aren't many side quests except the initial quests when you find the guns for hire or specialists. For some reason they reduced the guns for hire to only one and you can have only the specialist guns for hire (and not the random freedom fighter you find). Though the leveling up for the guns for hire is interesting. 
The outpost quests become repeatable which is interesting but in line with the story don't really make much sense. It seems like you could take over every outpost without it affecting the story at all which makes it really weird and detached from the game. They just become resource points and mines. 
The Weapons have become a lot more varied and interesting compared to far cry 5 with weapons which look interesting and made out of scrap. You can no longer loot and store weapons which doesn't make sense but atleast there is more choice.
And the damage and enemies is..... well..... worse. much worse.... They've introduced a weird leveling up of weapons and damage and its just lost its realism in comparison to far cry 5. In far Cry 5 sometimes the damage is a bit weird but New Dawn goes to another level with this. A high powered shot no longer kills and enemy with one shot.... what the hell is that. 
And being gunned down with a machine gun should kill you quite quickly.... Not hit you a bit and allow you to walk away..... or in very weird cases (with mounted machine guns) knock you down with no real damage..... WTF i'm not shooting them with rubber bullets. Why did a developer think that made sense.

Despite these issues its not a bad game and I did enjoy it overall.... just its not as fun as developed as Far cry 5 though the weapon selection is far better.

TLDR:
It's like ordering a pie and finding out it has no filling. It's a grotesque example of how large corporate developers maliciously corrupt and ruin. It feels like they've actively tried to dissatisfy the player. They've managed to sap all sense of reward from this franchise for me. It's either boring or frustrating with a side order of cringe and eye-roll. I genuinely detest this game so much I felt compelled to write a review.

It's been a *long* while since the days of Far Cry 2 & 3 whereby the franchise was "re-founded" and it shows in all the worst ways, yet it has made no progress in game-mechanics. There is *so* little evocation in the writing of this game, I swear it was written on toilet roll over the space of 15 minutes. I can't care about the recruits and I care even less about the antagonists, it all literally means nothing. It's like they took Borderlands 1 as some kind of narrative role model. *SMH*

I don't feel encouraged or even capable of using my brain to solve the problems in the game any more, as it has taken such a happy-go-lucky stance.

The RPG-light levelling system that they introduced to pad out their copy-paste game play and encourage you to spend money on their micro-transactions means you no longer have any idea where you stand with the weapon you're holding. It could be a minigun but that won't matter if it's level 1 and chunks of potato are flying out the end.

I shot a guy in the face with a .50 cal rifle at 4 yards, he looked *mortified* that I'd broken his ski-mask, subsequently spotting me using the eyes that *should've* flown out the back of his head at almost 1000 meters per second.

The "elites" they've introduced cannot be spotted/marked. They *love* to fire RPGs at you every 5 seconds 
knocking you on your ar*e with impunity and it's not even an anti personnel weapon, it's a shape charged rocket propelled grenade meant for light vehicles.

I could go on with all the flaws but honestly it's depressing and I'd want a paycheck from UBIsoft to bother.

Let me preface this review by saying this was the first game in the Far Cry franchise that I have played to completion, and immediately after, I purchased Far Cry 5. Although New Dawn may not be "the best" example of a Far Cry game, it stands on it's own as a really great product. 

First I will address the negative aspects of the game, many of which have already been voiced by the community in comparison to its predecessor, Far Cry 5:

1) New Dawn is a "looter-shooter." You are going to have to scavenge enemies and raid stash houses to maintain supplies, and obtain access to new equipment.

2) The "game world is small" and undeveloped. This is in comparison to FC5, which is true, and there are significant visible portions of the map that are inaccessible due to an arbitrary line being drawn around them. 

3) "Bullet sponges." As you progress in the game, much of the "challenge" in fighting opponents will come from their use of overpowered armor and weapons. 

Now let me offer some counter points on why these supposed negative aspects may or may not matter to you as a player, and what makes the game good:

1) The "looter-shooter" aspect is not as present as you may think. I've never found myself being short on ammo or supplies. There are a few resources that are more scarce than others and can be tricky to find without deliberately hunting down hidden stashes, and you need these to unlock or upgrade certain weapons and vehicles, etc. However - this is an aspect I really enjoyed as a player; exploring old ruins and sniffing out treasures across the map is in itself a rewarding gameplay aspect, and there are many ways to "farm" certain supplies quickly if you just want to get it out of the way. 

2) The "game world is small" compared to other Far Cry games, but one doesn't really feel this. Even for a player coming straight from FC5, the map has a diverse range of different terrains and regions, and the "character" of certain areas has been amped-up in New Dawn. It is a completely different world, and while there are some areas that are recognizable or recycled from FC5, New Dawn adds a lot of original new structures and little "twists" to the map in different ways that you will just have to discover for yourself. Not to mention, there is the option of embarking on "Expeditions" to 7 brand-new, detail rich maps to explore. 

3) The problem of having "bullet sponges" as enemies in late-game is valid, as it can make you feel as if you need to grind more to upgrade your gear, or lead to simple frustration when you are getting creamed by a boss who has just absorbed multiple explosive rounds to the cranium at point-blank range without flinching. This makes the game feel a little "cheap" in its design. 

However, have you considered tackling these objectives with a friend in CO-OP mode? This changes everything. Even a low-level noob with dirt equipment is ten times more deadly than the AI allies, and you'll soon find yourself in absolute hysterics at the creative ways two players can dominate in boss fights, outpost takeovers, and just random tomfoolery. The CO-OP mechanic is something that this game absolutely nails, and is one of the main reasons for buying this game.

In addition, this is still Far Cry, and there are many ways (including exploits) to take out every enemy. Geared-up players will eventually want to finally have something that they can unload their heavy artillery on, while other players may find more satisfaction in stealth tactics and diversion. There are definitely some "cheap enemies" along the story path of this game, but persistence and experimentation will allow any challenge to be overcome. 

In conclusion, I would treat this game as an "expansion" to Far Cry 5 - all the basic game-play mechanics are still rock-solid, and it delivers on the Far Cry promise of making the player feel like a real survivalist - with a little neon spray paint thrown in.

not to mention the amount of bugs. cougars that appeared "friendly" that stood still, unmoving. despawning entities (even animals!) from a long enough distance. leaving an ethanol truck to quickly take over an outpost, then coming back to find out the truck despawned and isn't there anymore. i need my fucking ETHANOL, ubisoft!

i'd get this on a heavy discount, more than half off. looting and hunting is some mindless fun, but don't expect anything super solid.

Here's the thing, this is a budget title by Ubisoft standards.  Even though it's replete with needless DLC and microtransactions, if you are retarded and fall prey to its MX schemes, it nevertheless a budget title by Ubisoft standards.  I'm not surprised that it's short, dull, and repetitive.  I got it for $20.  However, while it could have been a short, six hour romp a la Blood Dragon, it is a treadmill.  There are plenty of issues, from the tonal retardation of the plot, to the demonstrably awful gameplay loop.  Yet, most of its flaws stem from the damn treadmill.  Take Mickey and Lou.  These villains are seemingly able to maintain power through the sheer stupidity of everyone who comes in contact with them.  They are entertaining enough as someone you'd like to put a bullet in and, as such, I would have been fine with them going out like punks in the end.  That would be deaths they deserve.

Instead the final battle with them turns them both into bullet sponges, soaking up hundreds of rounds while you try to avoid sniper fire and fire fire.  I guess someone thought the only thing better than a single bullet each would be several hundred.  Isn't that just the theme of game: why do anything if you can do it a dozen more times?  New Dawn is not trying to please the player, this padding isn't about content, it is about convincing you that spending more money on this crap would improve it.  It won't.  Blame what you will.  The game had seemingly six months development time.  Even so, that doesn't mean the game has to be painfully dull or unnecessarily padded.  There's POTENTIAL fun to be had, it's a Far Cry FPS, but the game doesn't capitalize on its good ideas and instead emphasizes the bad.

The guns handle nicely, and the enemies are responsive.  There's some fun in assaulting the bases, and some of the writing around New Eden is even interesting.  The crime here is tortuously prolonging the plot and boss fights, selling microtransactions to speed it up, and confusing padding with progress.  Throughout the story, you are forced to act like an absolute cretin.  While I thought it was to to pretend Mickey and Lou present a credible threat and make them seem like villains, by the end I realized it's because you are for expecting any level of intelligence or creativity out of this game.  If you have any motivation to buy, and I can't believe they have the balls to call it this the "Complete Edition" with microtransactions, this purchase is a cry for help.  There are way better Far Cry games, and way better shooters out there: play one of those instead.
Bullet sponge enemies and lack of weapon customization ruin the game play

While I'm recommending this game, it's really an average version in the Far Cry series and I'd call it Far Cry 5.5 with stuff missing. I suspect it was a money grab at throwing some version out there using the previous engine. I'd more likely consider this to be a DLC for FC5.

This seems like a partially stripped down version of FC5 and limited things to do compared to previous versions. Luckily I got this on the cheap via a sale, so I'm getting my hours worth out of it. The story is a bit of a drag, there's not a lot of replay value and they've got the city building/perks so skewed that you'll finish the game before you max anything out just trying to max things out to finish the game. 

While Fallout didn't do bad on portraying a post-apocalyptic world, this game feels like they just used it to set a small border around the playable area. Most of the weapons look sad as they've attempted to make them look like they were laying out during a bomb to rust and then someone pieced them together. Graphics are good overall as usual with the series, although I couldn't really get into the vibe as much with this one.

Performance and stability were excellent as has been my experience throughout the series. I'm running a 1080ti and maxed everything. No lag, no crashes, no gameplay issues.

I went multiplayer through the story and it worked mostly well the entire time. They obviously forget during design that two people might be in there, so missions where you drive a car with a NPC don't allow the other person any transit. Quest tracking, perk points and about anything specific to the host have all the same flaws as FC5 had (only the host is really getting most of anything).

You can't have multiple saves, so if you want to do different things in SP *or* MP, well, you can't. You can only have a single character at any given time, so if you're hosting a MP game, you can't do anything on your own game without the other player missing out. MP was obviously an afterthought, just like's it's been since FC4 (which didn't even work).

So, I'm disappointed considering each FC game has mostly been a step up on the previous version. I enjoy the series though and even if this is just a sliver of what FC5 was (I really enjoyed most all aspects of it), it's something. If I'd paid full price for it, I'd have felt robbed. Find it on sale and enjoy it for what it is.

This game should be titled Far Cry 5: Claptastic Extra Wubs Edition.  It really is a DLC-caliber sequel story set in Far Cry 5's Hope County, as written by the cast of Borderlands.  If it were sold as such, I'd recommend it whole-heartedly, but Ubisoft wanted a full release price tag on a half-finished product.

That being said, the art direction is fantastic.  If you're looking for an FPS to show off your graphics card and deliver a vibrant, almost psychedelic look at the post apocalypse, then this is your game.

Just wait for a sale, half off or better.

Because everything else about this game is half off:  The map is half as big, the cast is half as big, there are half as many missions, the story's half written; and worst of all, there are two chief protagonists, whose characters added together do not equal the development of even half a Vaas.  Cut scenes hint just slightly at back stories that could be fleshed out so well by a talented writer, but Mickey and Lou get almost no time to shine.  It's like a character designer got stoned, watched Mad Max, and said "Oh, man, Master Blaster is awesome.  I wish he was in a video game."  And that's it:  the main baddies are reduced to Brains and Brawn, but the only time you actually interact with them, they play as the exact same Heavy unit, but with different skins and weapons.

Far Cry 5 was the first game in the series I played. I thoroughly enjoyed it and played through 3 times (2 on PS4 and 1 on PC). I was skeptical about New Dawn as I don't generally like futuristic shooters since the guns become a little unreal. This game, however, definitely made the post apocalyptic guns work very well and the shooting is top notch as most all Ubisoft games are. The story was amazing and brought a lot of closure to the FC5 story. I will likely be going for the 100% in this one since it is so addicting to just cruise around and play in the world.

After completing the game once, they promise that in a new game, all unused perk points will be kept and all prestige weapons as well. All lies, you start from scratch with nothing from the old game; and the only reason I started over was because of that.

This is a nice Far Cry game. It picks up where Far Cry 5 ends, so you fight your way through a good sized open world, fighting against baddies and annoying animals as always.
I think this game is a little bit shorter than the other Far Cry games. Especially Far Cry 3 felt like a long game, but this could be because you couldn't skip the cut scenes.

The game uses the same mechanics as Far Cry 5, so you'll find yourself right at home if you played that game. It is equally as astonishing beautiful as the previous Far Cry games, although I don't find the pinkish color palette especially appealing.

All in all a great game with 20+ hours of gameplay. Pick it up on sale if you get the chance.

I'll be giving this a solid 3.7/5 stars. The 1.3 stars is obvious, game engine is hella clunky / glitchy, setting felt a bit dated, yet refreshing. The game improved heavily on the gun play and color enhancements. The villains were lame and uninspired. 
The 3 stars that carry this review has to go to the finishing story of Joseph Seed. In my humble opinion, he's been the best antagonist FarCry has ever had. The dynamics of conviction, passion, family... it all came together nicely in FCND. I still prefer Far Cry 4 as far as the atmosphere of the setting goes, but Hope County Montana has been a great setting to play in, giving more emphasis on hunting & fishing. Customization was lacking and you'd have to purchase most of the items in the store, or complete time consuming challenges that were hidden away in a poorly optimized menu. 
All in all, the experience was decent, and on sale for < $25 I would recommend to any fan of the Far Cry series. Ya know, while you're waiting for Far Cry 6.

TLDR: Buy it at the DLC price it should‚Äôve had all along. If you enjoyed the gunplay, treasure hunting and explosive action from FC5, you‚Äôll likely enjoy this too, even with the small RPG additions. There are even missions in this game that are better than most of what was in FC5. 

Hyperbolic hate aside, Far Cry: New Dawn is fun and the vitriolic non-players of this game have exaggerated the flaws. Most of the gripes I have with this game are holdovers from Far Cry 5, such as the A.I. on both sides being dumb and inconsistent, the boss fights being nothing but bullet sponges that have the potential to one shot you, and the writing being pretty terrible. 

FC5‚Äôs narrative already felt like someone trying to write about rural folk and religious fervor, when they themselves were probably some hipster prick from Massachusetts who spends more time in a coffee shop than on the job board...but New Dawn‚Äôs narrative kind of feels like someone saw Mad Max: Fury Road and tried to write a comedy around that. Any opportunity there is to make a scene grim or dark, they just pull away and try to steer clear of implications. The villains are the worst in the series so far, suffering from the same problem as the last three games by not being around, but also just being annoying teenagers that have little depth to them. They cry and bitch about how you‚Äôre such a pain in their butt and that‚Äôs it. No enforcer is sent to try and take you out, they just wait until you literally come to them and finish the job. (No disrespect to the voice actors, they did great with the meh material they were given.)
At least in FC5, the Seed siblings would kidnap you at a certain point (un-creatively as time went on, but still.) Even when I did kill them, I got no sense of relief because they were simply nothing as characters. I‚Äôd honestly rather murder the DJ that made that low-effort "We think this is what Millennials and Zoomers like" trash they kept blaring on the radios. At least it was funny to defeat them high on Bliss with a shovel. 

Now the combat...honestly hasn‚Äôt changed that much since 5. If you play like I do, explore the open world a lot, clearing outposts and hunting animals before even touching the main story, this honestly won‚Äôt feel all that different from other Far Cry games. The numbers are there and it might be annoying when you come up against enforcers (legendary-esque enemies with armor), but I never felt like I had to grind to have a leg up, especially when explosives and the overpowered Saw Launcher still got the job done. 

The only real complaint I have is with the lack of customization. New Dawn has a lot of crafting mechanics in it but it's shallow. This isn‚Äôt like Fallout 4 or Metro : Exodus where you get to build your guns and swap out parts. Works more like a store with incredibly specific currency; you‚Äôre just unlocking prefabbed weapons and can‚Äôt change anything about them. 

Halfway through the campaign, you get an rechargeable ability that simulates the syringes from prior games. While going berserk with a shovel through an enemy outpost is hilariously gratifying, it doesn‚Äôt feel like the game was built around this or the double jump mechanic at all. The only time the latter became useful was during the final boss fight. 

Final note is that optimization is good and the game looks gorgeous at times. Traversal is the same as before though, with less helicopters, so get used to hoofing it a fair amount of the time. Petty note is that whoever is doing the subtitles needs a pay drop cause I counted at least a dozen errors in some cutscenes and they don‚Äôt even line up with pacing of the scene itself 90% of the time.
Overall, get it on sale price cause the campaign is short and my 17 hours was only achieved through my adventures in dicking around and wanting to make my character look and feel like a badass. You know, one of those things this series is really good at.

New Dawn is an expansion to Far Cry 5 and is not a full game. The story in this game is very bland. I stopped caring after about 2 hours in. The gameplay is just Far Cry 5 but with a sad RPG like mechanic to it. I don't see any replay value unless you got a friend that wants to play. If you care about your friend do them a favor and don't make them buy it, instead get it for them when it's on sale. The grind is fine didn't have any issues with it although you do get to a point where certain materials become very hard to gather since things don't re-spawn like in 5. The world is nice I like the post apocalyptic setting and the exploration is fun, but it just makes no sense in the grand scope. I'm okay with Ubisoft not knowing how nuclear annihilation works but 17 years is just way to little time to let it be believable. Would I recommend this game? This is a great co-op game with graphics that can push most systems (but be turned down to get good performance, too). Co-op is drop in/drop-out, and the dropped in character seems to keep their gear from their own game. The co-op player can't advance the story or apply their resources to your game, but they can help you kick down doors and blast em. If you don't have a friend to play, you can recruit AI friends to play with you, but you can't do both at the same time.

You get to explode stuff and shoot a lot of bullets, all while driving around an otherworldly beautiful landscape (depicted well on the product page). The story is good, and you don't spend too much time in cutscenes. You don't need to have played Far Cry V to play this, and you could play this before Far Cry V, even though this is a sequel.

Checks all the boxes for what's important in an FPS multiplayer story game in my book.

I hated the slog through the game even though the gameplay was fine and found myself groaning through all the protracted, boring, badly written dialog.

I honestly don't blame the voice talent either, the acting was fine, it's just that literally every line in this game is a cliche, unfunny, boring and tedious.

Don't buy this game, and unless you're really invested in finding out what happens with Hurk and such in this iteration, don't play it even if it's free, you're completely safe to take a pass on this, just watch the cut scenes for five minutes on youtube and you'll realize exactly what I'm talking about, shut it off and never think of it again.

It's like Far Cry 4 and 5 but with the charismatic villains and interesting settings replaced with some annoying twins who blast terrible rap music everywhere they go to announce their presence. 

The weapons are scrap piles and can't be customised (like you could in EVERY other recent Far Cry) so you can't put different scopes or barrel attachments on/off guns as you want. Also for some reason enemies now have RPG healthbars ranging from level 1, which are standard grunts who die in a couple of shots, to level 5 elites, who require massive amounts of firepower to take out and have health bars the size of a planet. 

Also why is the recurve bow now a tier 5 weapon? The whole weapon tier system is irritating as heck... they now have RPG style damage values and levels from 1-5 too. Someone in the dev team REALLY wanted to shoehorn RPG elements into the combat and i don't understand why. The fancy recurve bow does 1200 damage but a 50 cal sniper does 1000? What?? 

Ultimately you're way better off just replaying 3, 4 and 5 which were really great (4 probably my favourite, i loved the arena challenges) and not bothering with this. I got it on a MASSIVE discount and still just don't really think it's worth it. They took out everything that made the games enjoyable (customizable weapons, simple standard combat instead of RPG bullet sponge scaling enemies, charismatic characters, cool locations) and replaced it with a bunch of stuff that i guess Gen Z might enjoy?? Really not sure who the game is aimed at tbh. Give it a miss unless it's very cheap on sale and you're just REALLY desperate for some "new" Far Cry after having 100%'d every other one several times over already. Otherwise, just go replay them instead.

Thanks to the negative reviews, I held off getting this for two years and still only got it because it came bundled with FC5 in a sale. 

Biggest mistake. 

This is basically FC5, but far better. The only thing really fleshed out with FC5 was its story, otherwise, New Dawn is an improvement in almost every conceivable way.

The top review says it deserved to be DLC instead.  Wrong. 
There's a whole new weapon system, UI upgrade, Outpost and Perk system, all new roster of GFH, aesthetic overhaul of the map, colour pallete, and more

That isn't a DLC. It's a sequel to FC5. Honestly, I prefer it over FC5 almost completely. The only thing I missed from FC5 was its music, map size and story.  If New Dawn had that, it would be absolutely spot on. I suppose the Devs kept that in mind when finalising the price.

Far Cry New Dawn gave me the conclusion I was looking for regarding the story line started in Far Cry 5.

Gameplay wise the game does not improve much however the game adds in RPG elements that I have really enjoyed for example enemies have health bars and you can actually see how much damage your weapon is chipping of which I found very satisfying.

Overall I found the enemies more fun to fight, armor actually maters as helmets for once can actually stop bullets and are not just for show which I found refreshing, the Guns for hire system was simplified in a good way as well, making it clear what your allies do and only being able to recruit one at a time no further complications added. Special mention to the fact that once they die you actually have to use resources to revive them, it made me pay more attention to them and I really enjoyed that feature.

The changes to Hope county were awesome to discover, especially after just finishing Far Cry 5. I enjoyed the vibrant colors of the world and revisiting past locations after the Collapse.

New characters are however quite weak, the twin villains were not as memorable as anyone of the seed family encountered in the previous installment of the series. They were not bad by all means but rather lacking, the new allies are also not among the best. I mostly enjoyed returning characters, to see what they have become.

Joseph Seed still remains the best character in my opinion, I was thrilled by him once more and loved how the story wrapped up. He really stole the showcase that the twins were supposed to have but truth be told if New Dawn was not a sequel to Far cry 5 I don't think I would have enjoyed it that much.

I was not the biggest fan of Far Cry 5 but knowing it's story, the world and characters it has introduced, seemed to be absolutely mandatory to get the fullest out of New Dawn. Every bland new character came under my radar because I kept getting blown away by the discovery of what had become of this world. I (for once in a game) was eager to find notes often recalling the past in which I lived my previous adventure.

This journey is far smaller and more approachable than the one you set on in Far cry 5. That game sometimes lost me because it threw too much at me but New Dawn was perfect and the fairly linear RPG progression was more up my alley. 

I would definitely recommend this game if you loved Far Cry 5's ending and want more however if you never played that game this one might be a tough sell despite technically being able to be enjoyed as a standalone experience.

Whatever the case may be, I would not recommend the experience at full price but on a sale why not, especially if you can snag this game bundled up with Far Cry 5 ‚ô•
