Far Cry New Dawn is the same as every other Far Cry game, but this time there's an enhanced emphasis placed on building your home town called 'Prosperity', and by grinding the open world you can upgrade various elements of the settlement, giving you the ability to craft higher tier weapons, cars, etc. I think the weakest part of this game is this whole RPG element of the game, and while it is not too grindy, it will take you a while to get the weapons you want and you may be stuck with weak weapons for a few hours. This is unlike Far Cry 5, which pretty much lets you get the guns you want in the game from the get-go. The story also is pretty good, but some of the missions felt a little bit disjointed at times, and it felt like I was doing random missions that do not really advance the story. A few of the story missions involve saving various characters which really have no effect on the game's story or the gameplay whatsoever. There are emotional moments in the game where characters die that you literally couldn't care less about because you only really even see them for about 15 minutes. The villains also fall flat. Without spoiling too much, just like in the other Far Cry games they leave you to die instead of actually killing you, which inevitably will make you feel like they must be genuinely stupid. This time, unlike in Far Cry 5, hunting animals will help you to craft some items, for example some weapons. In fact, you have to craft pretty much every weapon by grinding outposts and looting the environment, and this can get quite grindy if you are trying to level up or get better weapons. Admittedly, the game is not very long so you won't be grinding for too long. To pad out game time, you can complete each outpost multiple times (3 times) and you get rewards each time (Ethanol) which is necessary for upgrading your settlement. Taking outposts is relatively easy anyway, but it did not feel very satisfying as I would have preferred to use the weapons I want from the get-go such as silenced snipers to take down the outposts, and instead for the first third of the game I was stuck with terrible and weak weapons. Furthermore, enemies in this game are also bullet-spondges unless you use high level weapons. What is this, The Division 2? This whole system feels unnecessary and added in to increase the game's length, because if you avoid doing the outposts and crafting and what-not this game may take you even less time to complete. It took me about 10 hours to beat the story, do 4 expeditions, finish all outposts (except 2 of them) twice and two three times, and loot areas to find more resources. A part of the game you should not miss out on is Expeditions. They take you to new areas outside of the map where you go and find a package in the environment, and you are extracted out of the area by helicopter upon completion. The missions are extremely short, probably 10 minutes each and there's 7 expeditions you can do 3 times at higher levels, but they are fun and definitely worth playing. Expeditions are one of the best part about this game because they take you to areas which look unique and different from the largely samey open world that you might've already traversed in Far Cry 5. This game only has 1/3 of the map of FC5, so it does feel a lot smaller. Overall, though, the game was definitely worth playing and I would recommend you get it if you are a fan of the Far Cry series. Although the story has great moments, it isn't consistent in quality, but all moments which feature Joseph Seed and forms of spiritual/mystical experiences were fun to go through and felt good. This game is not as good as Far Cry 5, but it is still a great open world game with a very fun combat system and absolutely beautiful visuals. If I would give it a score, this would be about an 8/10.

I‚Äôll start by saying I played the game all the way through and had a good time because I am a BIG fan of the far cry formula. But I would not recommend this game to my friends over other Far Cry titles. Far Cry New Dawn delivers more of the chaotic open world FPS shenanigans that I have come to know and love, but lacks the style, substance, and quality mechanics of previous entries.

Far Cry New Dawn takes place in a ‚Äúpost-apocalyptic‚Äù Hope County, the setting of the previous installment, Far Cry 5. However, the map is significantly smaller than FC5‚Äôs map and has about half the outposts. The setting is New Dawn‚Äôs strongest card, but only if you take it with a grain of salt. The land is lush and fertile, which would make for a compelling story line about different factions completing for resources in this untouched paradise, but no, the story is much more of a goofy romp. Also, at the end of FC5, a nuke literally lands on the county, and its VERY hard to believe the land would look so lush only like 17 years after such an event. But, like I said, if you take it with a grain of salt, the setting is wonderful. Everything is overgrown and filled with flowers, mutated animals, and buried treasures. Far Cry has its own take on all the post-apocalyptic tropes and does them decently. 

The characters from the previous game show up, Hurk is there, and that‚Äôs the most interesting NPC you have. Your faction lacks the style of FC4‚Äôs Kyrati ‚ÄúGolden Path‚Äù or FC Primal‚Äôs Wenja tribespeople. Your faction‚Äôs NPC are just normal people. They lack style and their assets are recycled ad-nauseum. The same 4 or 5 people are in one million places. The enemies are also uninspired. They are... Rap listening-graffiti spraying-motocross bikers? They seem like the developers wanted a mad-max meets urban youth, and to me, the concept flops. 

Sound design is a mixed bag, the weapons and FX sound great. But the choice to make rap music the main track-list is certainly a questionable decision. Not gonna lie, I was jamming out to Hopsin, Die antwoord, Run The Jewels, etc. but it made the game feel gimmicky. Why do the bad guys listen to hip-hop and the good guys listen to oldies? 

The core gameplay that I know and love is back in New Dawn. Enemies chase you down on the roads, stealth is fun and engaging. The open world is chaotic and full of life. 

The gameplay mechanics took a step backwards. Everything rests on your ability to collect ethanol to upgrade the facilities of your main camp. To get the ethanol, you basically have to grind for it. In New Dawn, you can ‚Äúrecapture‚Äù an outpost, basically resetting it back to enemy hands, and beat it again with harder enemies, more alarms etc, which is kind of neat, but not an excuse to cut the number of outposts in half, basically making you recapture the same outposts over and over to get ethanol. Also animal skins do nothing and it removes the fun of hunting in the past games. 

The ethonol system is a drag, to be honest. Making an annoying grind out of unlocking all the content. I hope they don't carry that mechanic over to the next game. 

The one improvement to the gameplay were the ‚Äúexcursions‚Äù which took you to various places in order to raid them for supplies and were a welcome addition to the game in my opinion. 

Lack of multiplayer is a big negative. Far Cry 5 had great multi. The Far Cry brand of map creation is absent. 
Lack of achievements is lame. 

All in all, I enjoyed my time in New Dawn because I am a Far Cry fan boy.  I‚Äôve been playing since Instincts/Predator. But I would not recommend this game to my friends over higher quality Far Cry titles like 3,4, and perhaps even Primal.

And I have to say out of the just about 15 hours I played this game the only 5 enjoyable minutes to me was the side mission where you rescue and befriend Horatio a SUPER based boar that you can get as your follower. So I can't recommend this game cause if you don't find a man sized pig that crushes anyone foolish enough to stand against you as enjoyable as me I don't think there is much else going for it. The story, game play and even the followers felt worse than the 5th's in my opinion (with the exception of Horatio who filled the Cheeseburger shaped hole in my follower slot for the duration of my playthrough) and there is also a few things through the game I noticed that made it seem lazily put together. The main example being the fact that every single and I do mean EVERY side quest that you can get from talking to a member of your faction comes from 1 of 2 people either a white chick or a black hipster dude. So I would say it could be worth it if you can get it for under 15-20$ but defiantly not 40$ I would rather buy silicon tits for my anime body pillow with that money than use it to purchase this game at full price.

TLDR: Based boar was the best part of this game, not worth 40$.

It is a sort of sequel of the main game, slightly smaller in size yet packed with new features and small changes that make it interesting. A "Far Cry Primal" pairing of Far Cry 5 if you like, a jump into a post-apocalyptic future that reminds me a little of Fallout games, it is just much much more optimistic. Never give up hope and always grow better - that would be a short motto of it. Apart from the conclusion of the FC5 story line it brought some changes like enemy/animal/weapon levels that moved it towards some arcade-ish direction. Boss fights ring a bell for sure. All in all some well-spent gaming hours passed playing FC-New Dawn. If you have FC5 and liked it I'd absolutely recommend playing this one, too. New Dawn plus the helicopter missions that would make a complete DLC alone, the 3 main game DLCs and Far Cry5 itself - I think it is a very rich package for the fans of the franchise.

Far Cry 5 got some things right and others it didn't even bother trying to change or make better. Far Cry New Dawn tries to change things up, yet ends up shedding a lot of what made FC3 and FC4 good entries in the FC series. 

The game starts and introduces you to the main antagonists. And yeah, they're not great. The main villains are immediately comically evil a la Negan from The Walking Dead - evil for evil's sake. After a bit of an intro that shows you the world it opens up and you have to build up your base. Base-building can be fun if it's a main part of the game. For Far Cry New Dawn, however, that is not the case. All you do to build your base is collect resources... Which would be fine except...

Micro-transactions are abundant, with credits being pushed on every menu in the game. The game devolved into a collect-a-thon within the first 1.5 hours of play, with every item being crafted from random, arbitrary supplies that you have to meticulously collect. There's also a magical currency in the game - ethanol - that you have to collect from bad guy bases to build the base as mentioned above. The game play loop is lazy and uninspired but what else can you expect from an Ubisoft game?

Multiplayer takes a front seat in this game, and on more than one occasion I found myself getting into a vehicle with 2+ seats and accidentally getting into the passenger seat and wondering why the vehicle won't chase after the enemy I'm fighting. Menus pop up and tell you all about the multi player and won't leave you alone. The addition of dedicated companions seemed like a fun concept, but when my team mate went down and fell through the terrain they were on I was unable to revive and had to spend a lot of the resources I had gathered on getting them back up. The "downed" feature was also an interesting addition to the game, clearly due to the focus on multiplayer, and ultimately adds the tiniest bit more depth to the game. Unfortunately, it becomes a bore-fest with you having to worry about a dumb AI that runs directly at a bear.

The game looks superb, runs well, and the production value is clearly AAA. However, that doesn't negate the fact that the game is a cash-grab re-skin. If you like Far Cry 5 and never played FC3 or 4 you may enjoy this game. If you're looking for more of a FC3 and FC4 single player experience you may be better off replaying one of the aforementioned two games.

Far Cry: New Dawn manages to take the positives of Far Cry 5 and then reverse them by revisiting some of the series biggest shortcomings. Far Cry 5 has Joseph Seed, this has Mickey and Lou, character whose names literally took effort to remember while writing this. They are one note, simplified "bad for the sake of being bad" bandits. The game throws a few cursory background details about them to claim they came from a bad home,  but its just one of several lines tossed out without impact during scenes where the attention is elsewhere. When they die there's an entire monologue death scene that has more lines in one spot than either villain got in the game up to that point. It feels annoying and dragged out, as though we should "feel bad" this bandit with a custom NPC skin is dying. 
The game is filled with lots of fun "put all your nice gear in this bag" moments, or "tie yourself up or we'll kill your friend", all of which are immediately followed by the game killing an NPC or doing something nasty and laughing at you for being dumb enough to follow the un-avoidable button prompt. Really dumb writing.
A big character dies, but we barely know anything about them, so again... little impact.
And the final boss isn't even the villains on the cover, spoilers but seriously save your money.
The map is just the same map as farcry 5, but with less to do. The base upgrading system is very cool! But with so little time in the game, its over with pretty quick and all the upgrades are done.
The expeditions are great! But there's not many of them, and at t a certain point its just to get parts for more weapons.
But yeah, anything this game does Farcry 5 did better and more enjoyably. If its heavily discounted it'll get you a bit more fun out of Hope County, but wait for FarCry 6 or replay Farcry 5 otherwise. Ubisoft's writers definitely didn't survive this apocalypse.

[h1] BLOOD DRAGON IS DISAPPOINTED [/h1] 


[h1]===[ General Consensus ]===[/h1]


[h1]INTRODUCTION:[/h1]

After the explosive ending of Far Cry 5 (spoilers lol) where the apocalypse happens, exactly like Joseph Seed had predicted, you are taken by him to a shelter and the game ends on a cliff hanger.

This was one of the best but also the most infuriating endings ever. It really leaves you hanging without any answers...

[u]So naturally, Ubisoft pumping and milking out a sequel was as predictable as taxes at the end of the month.[/u]


[h1]PLOT:[/h1]

[b]Seventeen years after the nuclear explosions that devastated Hope County, life has returned to Hope County, Montana. 

Endless black rain and wind have given way to blue skies and blooming flora. Humans that survived the bombs now work to rebuild, forming communities across the county. One group of survivors formed in California is led by Thomas Rush. Rush's group dedicate themselves to engineering and bio-farming in order to assist communities across the country. 

Players assume the role of The Security Captain for Rush's group, and upon arriving in Hope County, they are swept up in a conflict between the Scavengers, the Highwaymen, ran by Mickey and Lou, the game's antagonists, and New Eden. [/b]

This story was empty. No emotions, no heart, no effort. Nothing. I felt nothing while playing this. No, wait, that‚Äôs a lie. I cringed a lot at the story and performances.

The game makes no real attempt to have an entertaining and engaging story. It‚Äôs just good old cliches and bad writing. Things we have all seen before, where two factions fight in the aftermath of the apocalypse and the bad guys are so bad that they kidnap and torture people for fun, while listening to bad guys music (in this game it‚Äôs rap and edgy music, just because it‚Äôs cool). It does nothing to distinguish itself from other games and to be honest, it really doesn‚Äôt want to.

The problem here is that we get a really unsatisfying conclusion to the, may I say, bold ending that we had in Far Cry 5. It just goes nowhere‚Ä¶ And shock, Joseph Seed is here, but he looks like he is already dead, if not, on Xanax overdoses.

The performances are also terrible. The evil twins are laughably bad with their line deliveries but they couldn't do much with a script like this. Same goes for the other characters, where they try to make them all "cool" but it just looks like a 70 yr old trying to write 15yr olds' messages on Instagram. It's that bad... No one is saved here.

[b]To summarize, this story is pointless, goes nowhere with it, it‚Äôs clich√© as hell. If you were going to play this for the story, you are better off just reading it on the wiki and saving your money. [/b]

[u]Terrible[/u]


[h1]GAMEPLAY AND LEVEL DESIGN:[/h1]

[u]It‚Äôs probably the only good part of the game, although it‚Äôs Ubisoft‚Äôs ‚Äúrecipe for success‚Äù copy and pasted all over it.[/u]

Far Cry New Dawn shares the same map with its antecessor, Far Cry 5 (much like Far Cry 3 and Blood Dragon), with a few cuts and texture changes. 

The world feels like Poison Ivy invaded Hope County and made Nature Great Again. It‚Äôs all pink and green and the colors are over exposed (almost had seizures with the game jk), but it‚Äôs very beautiful, non the less.

The gameplay is similar to Far Cry 5, being an FPS with skills to unlock and all kinds of weapons in your roaster, and it‚Äôs quite perfected here, having learned with the previous games. It feels very smooth and responsive and it‚Äôs very fun too, so if you played any of the other games, you know what to expect.

Like in other FC games, we have enemy outposts to take on, either stealthily or guns blazing, and after beating them, you can do it again, with harder enemies, to earn more supplies for your Base. Ah yes, I forgot to mention, now there is Home Base (Prosperity), where you can upgrade different things like crafting, fast travel, etc‚Ä¶

But not everything is pleasant. They decided to introduce an RPG like level system (tier-based combat), where you and your enemies have levels, and it‚Äôs increasingly hard to take on enemies with higher levels (Ubi‚Äôs Recipe for Success). And personally, I find it very annoying having all the enemy health bars and damage points system, it just visual noise and makes enemies even more bullet sponges.

Ubisoft made supplies harder to find and thus, unlocking new weapons is also harder and requires a lot of grinding. I didn't bother much with it, o, but this limits the gameplay variety and the fun you might have playing with different weapons. But wait, they said, [u]NOW YOU CAN BUY THE MATERIALS YOU NEED, CAUSE MICROTRANSACTIONS[/u]. [h1]Shame on you Ubisoft.[/h1]

Also, mid-campaign, you get these ridiculous super powers called Eden‚Äôs Gift, which just break the game and make you a literal super hero. They were fun to use, but at what expense‚Ä¶

[b]To conclude, the gameplay is fun just like the other ones, but I feel that FC5 is better and not ruined with this ridiculous level system and the superpowers. And don't even get me started with the microtransaction...[/b]


[h1]SOUND AND MUSIC:[/h1]

I can‚Äôt remember the music that well. I guess standard Hollywood music for the cutscenes. And for the cars you have two radio stations: Rap and Edgy songs and a 50‚Äôs radio station, because why not. I particularly did not enjoy the first one, it was really bad, so every time I drove a car, I picked the retro radio station which was quite pleasant.

[b]Meh just meh.[/b]


[h1]GRAPHICS:[/h1]

Like I said previously, the graphics are pretty and world design is good.
I played using Nvidia GeForce Now (streaming service) and got a lot of performance issues, with terrible FPS, but that was not on my end so I can't really say much.

[b]Overall it's good, but not groudbreaking.[/b]


[h1]CONCLUSION:[/h1]

[b]Far Cry 5 - Part 2[/b]

[u]If there was a mixed button for Steam, I would pick that. But as there isn't, I'm forced to make a choice.

And my answer is a No. I just can't recommend this game, even on sale.
It does nothing excellent to distract you from the god awful story and performances, it's a basic copy and paste from other Ubisoft titles, and the new additions to gameplay only seem to do more harm than good.[/u]

[h1]If you were pretending to see the conclusion to the cliff hanger of FC5, you are better off just watching it or reading the summary.[/h1]

[h1]6/10[/h1]

I may have massive amounts of bias due to this game being my first Far Cry game (yes, you may hate me for it), but I think this game's decent. I agree with most criticism for this. The world's too small, the enemy difficulty system just pads time, the story is... not good, and the villains suck. However, I thought the Highwaymen's graffiti art was really cool. This game has legitimate style to it. The weapons are also really cool too. The Saw Launcher might just be the best Far Cry weapon ever. I enjoyed my time with New Dawn, but don't go into the series with this.

It is really about gameplay, not storyline. You won't get enough details about the motivations of the villains until late in the game, when it doesn't much matter any more. For most of the game, you will be focused on improving your tactical implementation as you expand your repertoire of perks and equipment unlocks. The game has a slightly slower progression pacing to it than previous Far Cry installments but it does not feel (to me, anyhow) like a grind because the gameplay is sufficient reward unto itself.

I had a really hard time in deciding whether I wanted to give this game a thumbs up or thumbs down. The graphics are stunning, the guns are a blast to use, and the gameplay loop can be addicting. Despite those positive aspects though, I found it very hard to care about anything that was happening in the game world. All of the dialogue is cliche, all of the missions are essentially the same, and the game felt very grindy despite it being pretty short. I have spent the last 8 months of my life playing and reviewing every far cry game and I know that far cry has the capability to birth better games than this. If you are to buy this game, I'd get it on sale :0.

After playing through almost all of the far cry series (excluding the xbox games, wii game and arcade game), I can confidently say that this is weakest entry. Now its not terrible, the fun factor can often outweigh a lot of the negatives. But I don't think that's the case here. First of all, it's way too similar to Far Cry 5. Reuses the map, assets, characters and story, etc. The recycling along with the much lower amount of content makes Far Cry New Dawn feel like it should just be a $15 DLC. Next problem, a lot of the new content and game design choices are utterly moronic. The RPG-style of the combat completely take away all the fun and freedom from doing missions, and this in combination with the plot and setting even makes the game feel as though it is apeing off of other series like Fallout and Borderlands. Also, and I believe this may be a problem with modern Ubisoft games, the game requires you to do side content in order to progress. That isn't how an open world game should work. You should be able to do side content only if you want to, and then continue with the main story missions at your own pace. Not to mention the microtransactions, annoying side characters, and embarrassing villains. Basically, what I'm trying to say is, this game isn't very good. It is almost saved by the fun factor, as well as certain aspects of gameplay such as the gunplay and world exploration, but those are pretty much a given in a Far Cry game, and this game isn't special when it comes to those features. If you really want to play it that badly, I'd get it at least 80% off. Otherwise, I'd steer clear. Just go play one of the other Far Cries... Like 3, or 4, or 2, or 5, or Blood Dragon, or... Hell, even Primal was better than this.

The game feels very unbalanced and it still has a lot of bugs. Also not a fan of the tiered level system where enemies become indestructible because you dared use a tier 2 machine gun against a highwayman's tier 3 paintball mask...or god forbid a tier 2 .50 cal sniper rifle against an elite motorcycle helmet. The tiered leveling aspect of this game just feels like the developers added a bunch of grinding to compensate for the lack of depth in the story. Ultimately, the whole thing kind of feels like a sloppy correction for Far Cry 5's terrible ending to help give players closure to events. The best part of the game is probably the saw launcher, other than that, it feels like a lazy and unnecessary addition to the Far Cry franchise. Also, the music in this game is annoying as hell...if you were to molest a chipmunk with a chainsaw while blasting Dubstep in the background...that's what it sounds like.
This is a really decent expansion for the price.  Recommended

It should have been an Expansion (DLC). It is the perfect size for one.

As a stand alone game it is lacking in variety and depth. 

I will note it is very well optimized graphically. I can run it on max settings and get a reliable 60 FPS at 1440 with it hovering around the mid 70s when not in combat. In contrast, far cry 5 and 4 are much more taxing and don't look as good on my machine.

The two enemy protagonist kind of miss the mark. Their power is derived from simply having tough people around them. If they are placed 1 on 1 with the main character they suddenly become a lot less intimidating. That being said I found the ending underwhelming. 
 
Overall, I'd say wait for a sale or just pass on it. You are not missing anything in this title.

Aesthetically pleasing would be the one genuine compliment I have for New Dawn. It‚Äôs just so vibrant and colorful, almost everywhere you look is just visual eye candy. The rest, however, is 50/50 and if I could I‚Äôd give the game a neutral rating but since I can‚Äôt I‚Äôll give it a VERY cautious thumbs up.
                                                                        ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
The story is lackluster, shallow and plays out like a DLC rather than a standalone sequel. I found myself caring less about most if not all of the good guys. Many tend to go on long unfunny tangents, and you‚Äôre going to get the joke, but the joke just isn‚Äôt funny. Unfortunately, the writers thought they were hilarious, and you‚Äôll have to endure this with many of the side quests. Mickey and Lou, however, were entertaining, and their cutscenes were the only real saving grace to the story. Hell, I was rooting for them and if given the option would‚Äôve immediately sided with the bad guys. It‚Äôs a shame, because I believe if they had put the effort into doing a fully fleshed out story revolving around the twins it would‚Äôve been great. Instead, what we‚Äôre left with is two random villains who have no relation to the FC5 events, and anything relating to FC5 could‚Äôve been squeeze in or popped into a small DLC.

The selling point is online co-op, however, even that feels half-assed. There are multiple missions where you will need to escort an NPC in a vehicle, however, these vehicles are only designed for two people, which leaves your co-op buddy scrambling to find a ride to try and keep up because otherwise, the mission will fail for them ‚Äúabandoning the objective.‚Äù Another thing is progress, it only counts for the host which also means no Uplay achievements that are story related for your pal. Now we didn‚Äôt care about the achievements but progress being tied to the host only is pretty stupid. Also, this is just a nitpick, but photo mode should work in co-op as well, just sayin‚Äô!
                                                                        ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
I thought the outposts and grinding for all the outfits weas the best part of the game. It‚Äôs very rewarding, and it was nice to be able to approach it in whatever way we wanted. Expeditions weren‚Äôt half bad either, though that got stale a lot quicker than the outposts did. The gameplay itself is solid enough, bugs aside. When you‚Äôre going in loud it feels like old COD when you‚Äôre opting for stealth it works out smoothly and it can feel rewarding the first few times you do it successfully. I was pleasantly surprised taking out alarms with a silencer didn‚Äôt alert everyone in the area.

The setting itself and the world is another plus, I honestly love it. The idea of the world being destroyed then coming back so vibrant and beautiful is a refreshing take on the post-apocalyptic concept, I adore it. Coming from a Fallout fan, I almost wish more games took that route. Even the monstrous animals were amazing in my eyes. I just wish the story had been up to par.

P Ä·¥á·¥Ñ…™·¥è·¥ús ‚ô° 
A Screenshot of Far Cry New Dawn
By: Miraakles

Finally, be warned. Like most Ubisoft games, it‚Äôs buggy. Now, most bugs I can pass on, like the enemy AI reinforcements at outposts just standing still in the desert leaving their friends to die as they suddenly have a midlife crisis. But bugs that get me killed repeatedly or require me to restart the whole game? It‚Äôs just annoying. Twice after a loading screen, I got stuck in place and couldn‚Äôt move. The first time there was nothing around, I was just standing in place, trapped by open-air around me. The second time I spawned in a small ass tree, that a car can destroy but a gun can‚Äôt. Sometimes your character won‚Äôt vault through windows, other times they won‚Äôt climb up or down the ladder. Had to reload one part at least 4 times because of an infinite loading screen, and then once again getting stuck in place. NPCS love running directly in front of your car btw, thus forcing you to hit them and aggro-ing everyone in the area. Also, why the hell can we heal at full health? The amount of medkits I‚Äôve wasted by accidentally hitting the button and my character deciding to pop some pills is ridiculous.
                                                                        ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
I don‚Äôt believe the game was god awful, but I don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs amazing either. I enjoyed it because of my coop partner and the story missions involving the twins, but otherwise, I would‚Äôve refunded a long time ago. So, take that as you will. New Dawn is pretty as hell, but lackluster, shallow, and pretty pitiful for a sequel. My advice? Grab a friend you trust and who‚Äôs funny, don‚Äôt take it seriously, buy it 50% or lower, and enjoy the ride.

I completed Far Cry 5 in every way except for the challenges I enjoyed it so much. This game has some nice new takedown animations but the gameplay is dreadful. They simplified the skill tree down by probably 75% and completely gutted the multiplayer. There is no arcade mode and if your friend is across the pond you'll likely never get to play the open world mode with them whatsoever, and that's an implemented feature to ensure no laggy connections. The straw that finally broke the camels back for me was the situation of me looting a supply truck of ethanol from the highwaymen. I stopped the truck to kill the remaining highwaymen following me, and the truck disappeared because I made the mistake of not looking at it for more than 2 minutes. I was lucky to get this game on the steam sale for like $9.99 but I was unlucky to have had played it. The fact that this isn't a DLC is jaw dropping, its the same game as the superior Far Cry 5 but much, much worse. 

TL;DR Game is a downgrade from Far Cry 5, so go buy 5 instead.

Even though it's a sequel, I found FC: New Dawn to be much better than Far Cry 5.  Don't get me wrong, most of the gameplay in Far Cry 5 was excellent.  But FC5's story stinks on ice!   New Dawn, on the other hand, isn't perfect but was still much more enjoyable than FC5.
Anyhow, here are some thoughts on the game:

PROS:
-- The story here is relatively simple.  It's a 'The Postman' or 'Mad Max' sort of affair...ya know, what you expect in almost every post-apocalyptic sci-fi genre piece?  That still makes it an exponentially better story than the FC5, which squandered so much potential with its hokey, railroaded plot mechanics and laughably absurd villains.
-- No lame bliss kidnapping mechanic like in FC5.
-- And speaking of villains...yes, sometimes FC villains can be cheesy and over-the-top.  FC5 took the high-octane cheddar to a whole new level.  The villains in New Dawn aren't particularly deep characters, but their whole 'ruthless wasteland bandit' shtick fits in just fine with this post-apocalyptic setting and plot.
-- The ability to helicopter into different settings in various locations around the USA makes for some fun side missions and a nice, and varied, change of scenery from Montana.
-- Good guns...eventually (I'll explain what I mean in the 'Cons' below).  There is the ability to further upgrade guns.
-- A base village to upgrade.
-- Plenty of playtime bang for your buck, especially if you get it on sale and especially if you are a completionist like me who likes to do every mission and explore every nook and cranny.
-- Can re-play outposts at higher difficulty in exchange for more resource in the short term.
-- Far fewer bugs and glitches than FC5.
-- The ending was good.  FC3 and FC4 were a blast to play, but their endings were lacking.  FC3's endings were both rather feeble.  FC4 basically gave the player endings that were[spoiler] "Yup, you did all that work and all that fighting...and this place still sucks nuts.  Better luck next time, sucker!  Haha!"[/spoiler]  By contrast, my favorite FC installment, Primal, had a good ending, I thought.  In Primal, [spoiler] the player feels like they actually accomplished something.  New Dawn has an ending like that, so I found it satisfying. [/spoiler]
-- And the icing on the cake?  [spoiler] You finally get to plug that self-important moron, Joseph Seed!  Yay![/spoiler] 

CONS:
-- The guns are ridiculously nerfed at the very beginning; They are essentially BB guns and can't hit the broad side of a barn.  Just stick to melee takedowns and/or RPG the heck out of everything that moves until you unlock the first level of better guns, which doesn't take too long.  Once you progress and the better guns start to unlock, the weaponry turns out to be just fine.
-- Like in FC5, the enemy AI is still wonky at times.
-- Why the hell is everything painted hot pink?!?  It's like, "Hey, everyone, it's a post-apocalyptic wasteland where resources of all kinds are in short supply...except pink paint.  We're totally good on pink paint!"  Yeah, yeah, there are pink mutant flowers everywhere, and they could have made the dye from the flowers, right?  But in a world where you're struggling on a daily basis to find enough guns, fuel, and bullets just to stay alive, let alone run a multi-state bandit gang, who's got 40 hours of free time a week to run a massive pink paint factory and then go gallivanting around the countryside painting murals everywhere?  Minor rant, I know...but it bugged me.
-- The DLC appears worthless; It's just a bunch of cosmetic stuff.

really bad. i would not be surprised if this was some new ubisoft studio's first project.

this game is awful. this is a step back from Far Cry 5 in almost all aspects and frankly that is an achievement.

Features in Far Cry 5 that New Dawn does not have:
-weapon customization
-anywhere near as many weapons, opting instead for the same weapons split into 4 tiers with different paintjobs and attachments
-planes
-helicopters

The usual Ubisoft Story caveats apply. It's really bad this time but most cutscenes and dialog are skippable. Not that I skipped them. I need to stop doing this to myself.

There is one set of three missions that made me Alt-F4 after about 30 minutes of fruitless attempts at "puzzle" solving (it turns out i needed to hit an input that the game does not have listed in its binds and that apparently displays once and never again, as I had to be informed of its existence by my coop partner. We also had to restart the mission because the input would randomly not work in certain mission areas).

You get Super Jesus Superpowers at some point (double jump, a berserk powerup, some other shit I don't care about, probably stealth or hunting buffs) and those are pretty cool. I wish they'd backport those into FC5. 

Expeditions are great. Frankly, I wish every mission was an Expedition style combat scenario rather than what they are. I only played the first one (unfortunately FCND is just that intolerable for me) but it was the exact sort of content I wanted to see in FC5. 

The usual perk point bullshit from FC5 still applies. This game is not an RPG. This game is a looter shooter, except you craft all the loot yourself (once, and then it's free). Enemies are Borderlands-tier of bulletspongey once you start getting to the higher levels and god help you if you don't have a purple gun for a purple enemy or a gold gun for a gold enemy.

It turns out that even if you only make one game, you can still fuck it up royally. Thanks, Ubisoft.

I strongly do not recommend this to anyone to be honest. With friends it is a game that you will not enjoy from gameplay but more for the company of others. This game was more of a money grab then anything else because it was a true shame seeing micro transactions being more heavily pushed for a story mode game. Lastly. for the game that was supposed to be a DLC to Far Cry 5, they sure failed to make it great and fit in well, as for there could of been better executions with map designs as for some areas were off compared to Far Cry 5 where it is supposed to be the same map as New Dawn. Gameplay:

- Meh (Decent).
- Very Buggy at unique points, such as character getting stuck in the ground, AI freaking out, and the game as a whole just not functioning right when the characters are stopped in place and they bug out.

Description for Gameplay:

- Compared to all the other Far Cry's the weapons were unique in design due to apocalyptic theme, but besides that it lacks a lot of other features. 1. Lack of music in cars and in game when facing scenarios. 2. Lack of types of guns 3. Lack of customization of cars, characters, and weapons, they could of made more apocalyptic customization. (Compared to Far Cry 5 where they gave you more options). 4. Buggy/Crashing

Guns:

- Unique

Description for guns:

- They gave an apocalyptic vibe but they sure lack in the amount of weapons. You would expect to find more weapons or unique variants of the weapons from Far Cry 5 in New Dawn because it is supposed to be the same place as 5, but instead it is just not there. The recoil on weapons is just not there, which is a true shame because that adds more better feelings of actually controlling the weapons. Furthermore the weapons extremely had few customization. 

The Antagonist/Villains: (Spoiler under Joseph Seed if anyone has not viewed some details of this game) 

- Joseph Seed (Somewhat Villain but not really in this game more of a good guy) (Great but way more awesome in Far Cry 5 as the antagonist)
- The Sisters - Complete Jokes
- Multiple Villains is a great idea but poorly executed in here.

Description for Antagonist/Villains: 

-  The sisters put on a great boss battle on the hardest difficulty the game offered but besides that, they were complete awful when it came to dialogue, their reasoning for being villains, and their lack luster threats. The sisters provided many threats (like a villain does) but they sure did not stick to them (I would go into detail here but it would be more spoilers). The villains do not make that much appearances in missions or the whole game in general for "being villains" they are just more there in the first mission, disappear until one mission in the mid game, then you basically never see them again until the last two missions. A goal of the villain is to make the viewer/gamer fear them and find them menacing, instead they talk crap and do nothing basically while making horrible jokes. Continuing, the villains backstory for becoming evil is very weak as for they could of done better at building their character for creating a new game that is supposed to be a DLC where the villains could have been more evil and mentally sick, but instead it seemed like they were trying to be evil and mentally ill but instead they made themselves look more like jokes. The dialogue and interactions between the antagonist could of been more engaging as for it does not meet up to greatly and does not present the villains and sick in the head like Far Cry series is supposed to present for their villains. Every other Far Cry presented their evil and sickness in them to the audience (player) but instead this did not stick up to it, they were more like weak terrorist then anything. 

Graphics:

- You expect a game to get better in graphics because it is newer and using the same engine as Far Cry 5, instead it was rather a noticeable and big downgrade compared to Far Cry 5 even with HDR on. I do not mind graphics so much because games are not claimed as good for graphics they are claimed great for gameplay, build, and story. 

Characters:

- Descent

Description for characters:

- The characters stated above discuss some about them but as for the rest, they were typical Far Cry characters and it seemed normal. They could of built more story between them and 5 and how the event from 5 to New Dawn impacted them as a whole.

Customization for your character:

- Huge downgrade from Far Cry 5, other Far Cry's sure they do not have customization and that is fine, and character customization is nothing big to worry about at all, but it sure did not have much to choose from compared to 5. I like the idea of unlocking some new outfits after some missions being completed but it could have the potential to present more.

Ending:

- Anti climatic for the most part, but not so expecting.

Pricing:

- Maximum: $8.99 USD
- Minimum: Freemium or $5.00 USD

Overall:

- No matter what developer anyone is for a game, I give them a great job for building a game because that is something I know I cannot do. As a customer of their product, I expected better and it could of have more detailed but I give the team a great job for building a game and making a product in which I cannot make. The viewpoint as a customer, playing their game, it could of presented better and gets a negative review by me as for I see it as lazy and unfinished worked compared to their other products in the Far Cry Series. A developer should do more to listen to what the community wants and spend time to craft a masterpiece rather then having greed for money and pumping out constant garbage. It is amazing what time can do to a game and this is one of the game that could of used more time to work on.

Meh. Thats the best way I can sum the game up so far, hell I prefer Far Cry Primal to this. FC P being one of the most shit on games in the franchise still feels better than than this by a consumer stand point. Far Cry Primal was not a standard Far cry game and is more like a FC game mashed up with a low key survival vibe - in prehistoric times. It wouldn't have worked as a DLC because of how different it feels and how far it strays from FC3 or even Blood Dragon at the time.

New Dawn however feels like it could have easily been a 20-40$ DLC expansion rather than an 80$ stand alone game. It is very much a reskin with minor changes made, but its still Far Cry 5 at its core. Primal feels like a new game, New Dawn feels like a fan made mod like you would get for Skyrim. If anything consumers get screwed since FC5 was and still does feel like its missing content. Content that is in New dawn. Outposts have more use, more open map events and and upgradeable base. These should be a plus for New Dawn, but it just feels like they intentionally cut features from FC5 in order to crap out a "new" game a year later.

Its good enough to grab on sale, but if you buy it full price you will regret it. This is not a full game, its a large expansion. Far Cry 5 had me hooked and I sunk hours into it, continuously. 4 hours in to New Dawn and I want to go back to Primal or take a look at Rage 2.

I'll start off by saying this is a pretty fun game to me. I saw great potential in what was brought to the table, but am a bit disappointed in how it played out. This is one of those times when streamlining game mechanics too much hurt the overall package more than it helped. I give it a 7.5 / 10. 

( + Positive ) Far Cry New Dawn focuses more on game play than story with lots of collection and tasks you can do to check mark off a list. Between short story missions, hunting for pelts, upgrading a home base, and capturing temporary mini bases scattered across the open world. The game doesn't distinctively force you into doing any certain task which is nice, as you have the freedom to pursue what you'd like to do and at your own pace to keep it from becoming too repetitive. There is also coop and various followers you can team up with while sporting their own weapons, abilities, and play styles to supplement your own.

( + Positive ) The story isn't that deep, and that's fine to me after my great experience with games like Kane and Lynch 2 which only have minimal amounts of it to drive the game play forward. The story is mostly about rebuilding the base called Prosperity, which in turn incorporates itself into the game play by offering you better weapons, more health, more explosives, more vehicles and expeditions that award the materials to do these upgrades.

( + Positive ) For people who really enjoy collecting resources, you'll feel right at home. There are lots of materials to farm, perk point granting pick ups hidden off in hard to reach places that make you think to obtain them, costumes and character customization.

( - Negative ) While interesting at first, It didn't take me long to realize that the rpg mechanics feel rather slapped on than fully flushed out. Unlike Far Cry 5, weapon customization does not exist. There are a lot of weapons to choose from, but they are locked behind different tiers. Trying to use a lower tier weapon against a higher tier enemy will result in very un fun bullet sponges. Lack of customization really hurts as you'll be forced to use sights you don't want or stare at tape and a scissors bayonet. 

( - Negative ) Perks also seemed interesting at first, but majority of them turned out to just be simple stat boosters like carry more ammo instead of the insanely small amounts you start with. To a grappling hook which feels like it should of been something you find or are given early in the story. Instead it's just a perk. End game offers some interesting magic like abilities. While neat, I don't think magical really fits the game's aesthetic. 

( - Negative ) The game is a grind fest that actively encourages you to buy packs of resources or costumes so you don't have to farm them. You won't have to buy anything, but be prepared to farm like an MMORPG to get upgrades. With only a handful of base upgrades, it doesn't feel like you've accomplished much even after the boat loads of hours you've sunk to farm oil and parts. Expeditions helped break up the usual routine, but ultimately are all the same get in and grab something, get out. I wish more time was spent playing into the survival inspired aspects. It's almost like an extremely gutted Fallout.

Imagine if FarCry 5 had an eye-melting electric hot pink color theme, an  even goofier story line, and was far less entertaining. Or play New Dawn if you're struggling to imagine that. I should have trusted the review that said this should have been 5 DLC. Just replay 5, even though you know the whole story and you've probably run most or all of the missions, it'll still be better a second or third or seventeenth time than New Dawn.

This is more of a neutral rating.  The game itself is probably the best implementation of the "ubisoft world".  Unfortunately, the way you can interact with it is worse than farcry 5.  The weapons can >not< be customized or properly upgraded. "Upgraded" just adds a 5% damage bonus.  This is unfortunate, as it limits you to the top tier of weapons.  The "story" fails on every level. The characters are caricatures. I can't  bring myself to care about the heroes or the villains.  It fails to bring its shallow story to a satisfying conclusion. 

I sincerely hope farcry 6 will implement some of the things we see here. I enjoy the damage numbers. I LOVE the ammo types combined with enemy types.  I love being able to "surrender" settlements for more loots. 

I hope they stay AWAY from 4 classes of weapons.  Make all weapons more or less equal, and have them be upgrade-able to about the same potential.  This current system is too limiting. 

Final thoughts? Worth it for 10 bucks.  20 if you have friends to play with.  Not worth a penny if you want a plot based game.

[quote] [url=store.steampowered.com/curator/39449455][b]Truth[/b], [i]Doubt[/i] or [u]Lie[/u] - Steam Curator[/url] [/quote]

Story. Its mediocre at best. Very generic, not intriguing enough and dialogues & characters are bland. The Twins are okay villains but forgettable. As for the Joseph Seed from the Far Cry 5. I won't spoil anything, but you do get to finally resolve his story. Main story as I said is mediocre at best, however the side characters i.e. missions are all very enjoyable.

Game size. The whole game is about 2/3 the size of the original, both in map size, missions and outposts. However, you can do the same outpost three times with different difficulty. Also, the game size I described does not include the size of the expedition maps, which are larger than I was expecting and they add such a fresh air of game-play.

Performance. It runs brilliantly for me. I also didn't experience any significant bugs.

Game-play. In New Dawn there is a tiered enemy and weapon system (e.g. Silver, Blue, Purple and Yellow), but it does serve both to encourage new weapon usage, as well as slow the player improvement down a bit. It add a meaning to the grind. In FC5 you would do outposts just for the sake of it. In New Dawn, you must do Outpost in order to unlock better weapons, gadgets, vehicles and etc. Making the animals tiered also made them a much bigger threat than in FC5; I actually decided to carry a shotgun just because it worked so well on the animals. What I ended up liking the most though were some the smaller game-play additions. Like, there are now more randomized events in the world, like supply drops and looters, that make things feel more dynamic and make the open world more alive. Also, all enemies on the road now travel in packs of 2-3 vehicles, so no more picking off a lone supply truck. Plus, enemies have helmets that literally shatter when shot, meaning you have to headshot them twice to finish them off, unless you use AP rounds of course. Lastly, the game is also far more repayable, with all the outposts and expeditions being infinitely repayable and the world remaining populated with enemies after you beat the main story.

World design. Even though the map is essentially the same as FC5, it doesn't look even remotely similar. The world looks phenomenal. The overgrowth of vegetation really changes the look and feel of everything, especially in the regions that are now densely forested. But, it goes beyond that. The world is just incredibly pleasing to the eye, with its millions of flowers, aurora borealis both night and day, and turquoise water. It also has a ton of fine details integrated in, stuff like hummingbirds around collectible plants, dust clouds being kicked up by the wind, and multiple variations of the same animals. I think this sort of stuff really adds a lot of life to the world and, to be honest, I find the world of New Dawn to be one of the most pleasing just to be in of any game that I've played.

Final thoughts. I haven't talked about cooperation mode. I haven't yet played it, but if single-player is good as it is, the cooperation must be brilliantly fun. As for the downsides, you need 3rd party launcher (Ubisoft Connect), there are microtransactions, there are silly stupid costumes that don't belong in the game (IMHO) and I have found that wildlife is too much OP.

TL;DR. Don't use microtransactions to short the game-play, the whole fun in the game is the new improved progression system. Don't use companions, more of a challenge and fun while soloing. Don't buy it because of the story, its forgettable. Try not to use fast travels as often, the open-world is very much alive. Lastly, go into options menu and disable attention indicators, glowing indicators, damage indicators, tagging indicators, game icons and support icons and etc. plus play on hard difficulty - all of these will improve your experience guaranteed. You will have so much more fun.

progression system 9/10, gunplay 8/10, stealth mechanics 9/10, friendly AI 5/10, enemy AI 7/10, overall story 7/10, character writing 6/10, hunting 7/10, fishing 6/10, and how they balance everything together overall 8/10.

i really liked how you could choose to let the enemies retake an outpost, for more oil, it allows you to challenge yourself further while getting the reward of more materials to advance your weaponry and state unlocks for your health and camp utilities.

while not being a stealth game, i generally favor Far Cry stealth systems no matter what, it's of my favorite stealth systems, though not perfect. the AI is still kind of not great though, especially friendly AI. i often find the Guns-For-Hire a liability at times, and sometimes they will get stuck or confused when i need to be revived.

hunting was pretty decent, i liked the monstrous animals, otherwise nothing too fresh here. the fishing wasn't frustrating, but maybe too simplified compared to FC5. while ambivalent about FC5's fishing system, i liked the increase of dynamics and challenge that wasn't here in New Dawn.

i honestly wasn't feeling the character writing, the dialog was so-so, the Twins felt sloppily written, Ethan was fine but the setup wasn't strong enough i don't think, and well, i can't talk about a certain other person without spoiling a twist.

the game felt a bit too short, considering how much this game probably costed back in the day, but if you even find it bundled in or on sale, you should go for it. i personally had a lot of fun, and the gameplay was addicting enough that i got nearly everything unlocked except for the co-op challenges.

Too much dialogue, the playability is questionable and generally underwhelming. While I only paid $10 for it while it was on steam sale, still feel like I'm not going to get my moneys worth and that's pretty sad for a Ubisoft game.

A very much the weakest installment in the Far Cry series, this is keeping in mind that this is technically nothing but a glorified DLC of Far Cry 5.
The game has a few issues that stem out of the fact that things are very inconsistent, for example: your enemies either are the weakest thing and can be killed in one shot with the weakest gun in the game or a bullet sponge that you need to spray with an LMG to even chip.

The companions have two sides: Useless and Animal companions, Horatio and Timber (the pig and dog) actually help you in a fight properly and have useful functions while the human ones die before even shooting one shot cause they are useless in melee range (while your enemy is arguably at their strongest)

I am not even going to start about the vehicles and how shitty they are.
In the end 100% finished this game within 9 hours on the highest difficulty, died only once due to a bug of being hurt during a cutscene and i feel like it wasn't worth it, i just didn't want to feel like the few bucks i spend during the sale went to waste.

To summarize: The game lacks character, depth and most of all, fun!
You feel out of place for most of the game and feel like you are just shoehorned into the story.
I suggest skipping this one, if you want to have a unconventional Far Cry game, pick either Primal or one of the DLC's for Far Cry 5 as this one is not worth it.

Far Cry New Dawn is another game to the expanding series. This game is a story expansion within the realm of Far Cry 5 which I haven't played. The game comes without achievement, disappointing me who loves hunting them.

The gun play is fun and the styles for the guns great, but the combat is total trash. The tiers make enemies bullet sponges if they are a tier above your weapons. In theory that tier system would have provided a very satisfying feel when you get a higher tier weapon, but it doesn't feel right to implement the feature in the game.

The companion system is another great feature and I love the different character you can call to ally the player. Using Timber to find crafting materials and Nana to silently snipe enemies are some of my favorite options, and there are options to command them to shoot specific enemies. Unfortunately, there are some real jokes, and the only one I really had trouble with was the Judge since his fire rate and perhaps range was disgustingly awful.

Customization for the character is laughable and limited and there was no voice actor. A suggestion was to use a system similar to Saints Row 2 whereby you could choose a selection from voices or simply add one in.

The plot was pretty great and the characters were likable. I couldn't ask for a more deep and well written story but I could ask for a longer story as twenty-two missions felt a little short to me. The symbolism caught me off guard as well, and you'll see this in the cutscene just before the final boss. It was subtle, but exceeded my expectations from an American publisher.

The home base will be my final topic and I will be focusing mainly on expeditions. Most upgrades are somewhat respectable and not worth mentioning. Expeditions, are however a disgusting blight to the game. The concept behind them is fun, despite the GPS oversight. Seriously, what stops me from removing the GPS tracker from the package and taking the package. Expeditions fall under the tier system replayability like outposts and you have to play them about 3-4 times to fully complete them, thus artificially expanding playtime the most lazy way possible.

The rating of this game gets a total of 87,5% with points deducted from the tier system. The game play is solid and the story is great if you intend to play the game exactly how it's meant to be under the tier system limits but I recommend buying the Far Cry 5 bundle with this game and watch the other reviews.
Far Cry 5 had very little shortcomings, and this game managed to improve on things I didn't even know could have been. So worth every cent!

This game is an odd post-apocalyptics spin-off/continuation of the mainline Far Cry 5, which is cool. It contains the same map but with a different veneer placed on top of it and the locations remixed somewhat. Also, the gameplay differs in some ways and the story is a little more fantastical.
Gameplay wise this game brings in some more RPG and stat based progression. There are now clear cut tiers of enemies with different health bars and abilities, and the protagonist can also upgrade themselves and their equipment and companions in similar ways. Although I like this aspect of the game in some ways, and I suspect it's something Ubisoft is developing for use in Far Cry 6, the way that it's implemented in this game is admittedly pretty grindy. You have to grind through certain missions to acquire resources and use that to progress your character in order to handle the upgraded enemies at certain points in the game. I found the grindiness of the system annoying since I really felt like it could have been streamlined, and might have been to encourage micro-transactions, but ultimately I think the system could work if tweaked. I actually really like stuff like this, where you have a home base you can return to and manage aspects of your character as well as upgrade various game mechanics as you progress. I just wish it didn't feel like it was there as padding to make the relatively short story longer.
The game does handle enemy spawns more reasonably than Far Cry 5 but animals are still ridiculously powerful for some reason.
Because the game is a spin off there's not as much side content as Far Cry 5 but I'm ok with that since it felt overdone and pointless sometime in Far Cry 5. The Expeditions in particular are a cool idea. They're side missions that take place away from the game map so it's a special map specifically created for that mission which you don't see often in these games. However, after I did a couple of them I didn't see a reason to continue doing the Expeditions because it didn't gift me the one resource you actually need to upgrade things in the game.
Finally, the story. I actually kinda liked this more fantastical take on the game series. Some people hate it, but I liked the really colorful bright visuals of the post-apocalyptic Hope County. The game takes place 17 years after the events of the main game, which ended in a nuclear apocalypse and the game centers around you defending/building-up, a community in Hope County Montana that is under siege by this group of wasteland bandits called the Highwaymen, led by two women called "The Twins". The Twins don't have the same charisma as some other villains in the series and they don't really have any motivation other than just stealing your stuff. It's hard to take them serioiusly. However, the main antagonist from the previous game, Joseph Seed, also plays a pretty interesting role in this game, and I think it contrasts pretty well. It had a feeling sort of like some of the more mysterious/mystical elements that occasionally crop up in Fallout.
Overall, I did enjoy my time with the game, but if it wasn't for the grinding progression system it could have been a much tighter, yet shorter, experience.

As I watch the cutscenes, as I hear the dialogues, as I come close to the NPC's that are the same, my brain constantly goes:

THIS SHOULD'VE BEEN A DLC, THIS SHOULD'VE BEEN A DLC, THIS SHOULD'VE BEEN A DLC...

You can feel that everything's same. The animals are same with different skins, the buildings are same - just buried under some dirt. The guns are cheap reskins, already modified when you buy em. Just copy/paste from FC5 - add some screws and knives at the barrel to make em look post apocalyptic. Put some characters from the other game, reskin them as well. . Slap some ridiculous leveling system on them and voila, you got yourself a new AAA title. Oh - don't forget to paint every plant, wall and weapon pink.

I'd like to point out that I've enjoyed and finished every Far Cry game multiple times - up until now. With the exception of Primal - guess what, it was a reskinned FC4. FC5 was one of my fav games as well.

I really enjoy new games folks. New scenarios, new graphics, new gameplay. Small details, good acting, collectibles. I like 'em all. With the technology upgrading itself over time, we see more realistic, better looking and feeling, cinematic masterpieces more and more. Who knows what'll happen in 10 years. But this? This ain't it chief.

The feeling that makes you think: "Damn, they really reskinned a game, put a loose-a$$ scenario on it, slapped some new textures, brought in a 'couple' of new mechanics, and you paid a lot of money for it". This thinking never, NEVER went away during my entire playthrough! Every enemy I killed, every cutscene I watched, every new weapon I crafted, this thought NEVER, not FOR A SECOND left me. 

Companies are getting lazier and lazier. We, the consumers are getting more microtransactions (which exists in this game in a pretty annoying way as well - A SINGLE PLAYER game), more ridiculous skins that break the game's feeling / lore, more pay to win $hit, more useless, overpriced DLC's, exc... Meanwhile we get less and less good scenarios where you lose yourself, less interesting gameplays, less freshness. Generally less content for more money, if you catch my drift.

They don't give a $hit, because the community eats it up. Just like CoD and FIFA. Hell, I eat it up. Sure as $hit I'll buy FC6. Ubi, EA, Activision - it doesn't matter. They think and act like their customer base are complete fu*king idiots and are 10 yo kids. And they're right. If gaming community still supports these kinds of decisions, in some years we'll get less and less content, while they get more and more money for their sub-par products. 

Think about it folks.

FCND is great for its environment and gameplay and is very similar to most other Far Cry games. The exception would be its RPG/level based system which can be polarizing. I don't hate it but keep in mind that you can spend a ton of time farming resources for a weapon and upgrading it only to try another weapon and realize it has to be upgraded too for it to be viable as the enemies have scaled past it. It basically guarantees you'll only want to spend time on a few weapons and upgrades so make sure you figure out what you like the most, and quickly. I usually go with silenced weapons early since you wont be strong enough early game to take most outposts if they call in reinforcements.
The story was meh at best. The antagonists were super cringe but I actually liked the Joseph Seed angle and figuring out what happened to Hope County after the events of FC5. I definitely didnt see a few things coming that happened and it was very well done IMO. Most of your NPC guns for hire are useful when their AI isn't making them act like they just woke up from a coma at times. Sound effects are perfect; weapons feel meaty and have weight and the music is great too. The UI is terrible but that is just how Far Cry games have always been, at least from my experience. 

Overall this gets a solid 7.5/10

For what you actually get the price is absurd. I picked this up with a 75% discount and it seemed okay but full retail of $50? Hell no. The game is just Far cry 5 again set in the same location with basically the same weapons, vehicles, enemies and main characters. The only differences are cosmetic in that after the apocalypse stuff got brighter so weapon skins are more colourful as is the landscape and enemies. That's it the rest. The rest is Far cry 5 featuring the adventures of Joseph Manbun dullard and two vapid antagonists who are so bland and generic they make Mr Manbun himself look interesting.

The core gameplay is fine, exploring, shooting and taking outposts are the hightlights but everything story related just sucks. Don't even bother with the final six story missions because pretty much every single one of them begin with your moronic character giving up all their weapons just so the devs can shoe horn in some stupid melee combat or dull AF stealth sections.

If it's on sale (sub $15) then maybe give it a go if you like Far cry. Because that's all it is, Far cry 5 with a paintjob and an even dumber plot.

If you enjoyed Far Cry 5, then you will love New Dawn. It was enjoyable to explore the world and find  old locations and it still feels like you're exploring an entirely new map even though its reused. It also extends Far Cry 5's story, showing how people and places changed after the apocalypse. However, this game strays so far from the normal Far Cry formula, and this is where I have my gripes. This feels like they just made it because 5 was so popular, and just decided to add new things to experiment. Even if you are a big fan of Far Cry 5, this game can feel so much different than other games in the Far Cry series. The story was weak, the game is too grindy, bad villains, a weird enemy level system, uncustomizable guns, etc. It feels like they were throwing ideas and waiting to see which ones stick, although most of them didn't. So would I recommend it? That depends. If you Absolutely loved Far Cry 5, then yes. If you weren't a big fan, but still want to try it, wait and buy it when it is heavily discounted. I wish there was a mixed recommendation option, because this game is a weird limbo, in between good or bad. I am choosing yes because most of the people who are going to buy this game are fans of Far Cry 5, and if it weren't for being a sequel to 5, then I wouldn't recommend this game.

I enjoyed playing this the first time through, but only because I'm a massive fan of the Far Cry gameplay loop in general, I don't think I'll ever return to this game. 

Most of the blame for that is the RPG-ification of the gameplay, with enemies being turned into damage sponges if you aren't investing in higher levels of guns. It adds absolutely nothing good to the combat and is just a failed experiment to make the game more like a Borderlands type experience.

Also it's a continuation of the story of Far Cry 5, a rare example of a direct sequel in this series, but it's not really an interesting story at all. Unless you desperately want to know how a handful of the characters from FC5 are dealing with the aftermath of that games ending, this game being a follow-up is not at all a selling point. 

Hard pass, I really can't think of any good reason to get this game outside of you having played all the other games and being really desperate for more, and even then I'd say you're risking disappointment.

The worst part of the game (aside from the grinding for Ethanol and components) is the story. The final battle with the twins is so unenjoyable I didn't even bother finishing the game.

So to properly (and fairly) explain my thoughts about New Dawn, I'm going to have to break it into sections, so everybody buckle up and bear with me.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] So, it's FarCry 5, but in the post-apocalypse. If you liked the way FarCry 5 played, then you're going to get more of the same... mostly, and it's that "mostly" that I start having some issues with. I really don't understand the decision to give this game a Borderlands-esque tiered weapons and enemies system. It makes no sense in a FarCry game, and on top of that it makes the entire first 3 hours or so a nightmarish slog of gathering oodles of (s)crap and ethanol to upgrade your base enough, to unlock the ability to upgrade your equipment enough, to unlock the ability to actually kill enemies. Player skill is still important, don't get me wrong, but not near as important as it was in base FC5, and that can get... problematic. That being said, everything works and after you get used to the fairly drastic change in how the game works it's not bad. I will say that a hard negative for me is the removal of weapon customization, leaving you with weapons that either have the attachment you want or they don't, and if they don't then too bad for you. I'm seriously not a fan of that decision.

[b]Aesthetic:[/b] New Dawn is a VERY colorful game, and if you're referring to a Highwaymen encampment, you can change that to [i]obscenely[/i] colorful. The overgrown areas are very vibrant, everything really looks and feels like it's gone completely back to nature, albeit an altered nature. My only real complaints are with the weapons. I'm probably in a minority on that, but to me the weapon designs are so over-the-top goofy trying to look cobbled together (in the most cartoonish sense) that if you really don't enjoy them, it can get real obnoxious, real fast. There's a lot of things like that, though, by which I mean everything from world design to soundtrack choices is a collection of things that you're either going to love or hate, with not a lot of in-between. The things I didn't like didn't keep me from playing, so obviously it's not that big an issue, although I can see where it would be for some people.

[b]Story:[/b] I doubt anybody cares, but even so I can't talk about this without spoilers, mostly because I have a short rant about the Twins that requires talking about part of their story, so I'm going to put this section under the spoiler tag. For those that don't want to know, the short and spoiler-free version is that it's pretty typical FarCry, so don't expect anything beyond that.
[spoiler]Okay, so as I said above the story is pretty typical FarCry. You are Good Guy, the Twins are Bad Guys, you go stop Bad Guys. They try to do a couple little twists here and there, but none of it really works (like finding out Nick Rye is still alive despite Carmina and Kim Rye thinking he's dead... by seeing his icon on the freaking map. *slow clap* Good job, developers) and none of it is going to shock anyone. Rush getting (repeatedly) kidnapped, having to do a bunch of circuitous nonsense, pretty par for the course. Honestly the character with the most depth and the one that's by far the most sympathetic is, ironically enough, Joseph Seed. Now for the Twins. The Twins are the primary antagonists of New Dawn: Ruthless, murderous, remorseless raiders who, unlike Joseph Seed in FC5, are never given any sort of redeeming qualities. Yet, at the end, once you've finally given them what they richly deserve, it goes into this bulls**t Intermission cutscene showing how their father was a jerk and their mother wanted better and blablabla. It's a very hamfisted attempt to humanize two characters that, up to this point, have been treated as if they were irredeemable monsters. Now, I can think of reasons why they wouldn't want the Twins to just be villains with no asterisk, no excuses, but I'd rather leave politics out of it and just blame lazy writing for having spent hours making them out to be one thing and then really poorly attempting to reverse course at the literal last minute.[/spoiler]

Overall, I think if you liked FC5 you should give it a try, but try to get it on sale.

Game is amazing. Beautiful, vast open world to explore. Great Gun For Hire system (a choice of a single NPC sidekick from a pool of about 10 that you can unlock via gameplay). The sidekicks are upgradeable via number of kills they make. Just watch the AI though, occasionally they make dumb decisions. For example, the first sidekick to join you gains the ability to throw sticks of dynamite after she's killed so many bad guys. Problem is, she'll throw dynamte at an enemy you're meleeing, and can easily kill you by accident. After I died a few times, i stopped using her.

There is a huge range of vehicles and weapons, a decent selection of sidekicks (can only use 1 at a time) and your base is upgradeable. As you upgrade the base, you can upgrade the various services in it. ie: upgrade your helipad and you can summon more powerful helicopters. upgrade your training facility and your sidekicks are more powerful and skilled when summoned to help you. upgrade your medical facilities and your medkits will apply an increasingly longer heal-over-time on you in addition to the instant heal.

The graphics are beautiful and you can take time out to sight-see, go fishing or hunting (and trade the meat and skins for materials to upgrade your base or craft ammunition), go on treasure hunts, etc. Lots of stuff to do to take a break from the occsional story mode segment.

One caveat about the game!

Beware the Ubisoft scam of real-money purchases. If you buy stuff through their store, you will NOT get the purchased item in the Steam copy of the game. You have to buy currency or DLC via Steam. Twice now I've made a mistake of purchasing an item while tired, only to realize I'd bought it in the Ubisoft store instead of via Steam. About $10 stolen by Ubisoft so far. :(

I could talk about the worthless villains, the odd design choices, the boring cutscenes...but what really sinks this game is the story. Or rather, lack thereof. Every Far Cry game I've played up until this point had a direction, a purpose. Far Cry 3 was about the vicious cycle of violence, and what happens to those lost in it; Far Cry 4 discussed the futility of choice, and how we justify our actions; Far Cry 5 asked us, "what if you fought for a cause...and you were wrong?". Hell, even Far Cry: Blood Dragon gave us some inspiration about humanity and duty amidst the 80s-action parody. 

So what does Far Cry New Dawn talk about? Nothing, really. There are bad guys doing bad things, and you have to stop them. There's no subversive point, no deeper point. The game is empty. Play something else.
