This is where I wish steam had a meh button or a star/number system instead of yes or no. Ill give an in depth review because its not a bad game, but its not a great game either.  

I picked it up on that super sale at 9 bucks and thats still pushing it. If you're going to get new dawn, wait until sale and go into this game with the attitude that its a spinoff title like blood dragon and primal so it shoudnt be held to the same standards as 3 4 and 5 

The game is basically farcry 5 with borderland type mechanics. It takes place in the exact same map after the events of 5 but a majority of the map is blocked off (I believe the game takes place in john's corner). The map is pretty, game looks stunning on super low graphics no HD textures and the performance is more stable than 5

Gameplay wise, a lot of people take the piss out of the crafting but its whatever. If you constantly loot bodies like i do in every farcry game you will barley notice the difference and new dawn actually uses this new mechanic to encourage you to seize outposts. The gunplay in new dawn is probably the best in the series too and the game encourages different playstyles and got rid of the buzzer cheesing 

But thats where the positives end in new dawn gameplay wise. The final boss fight is basically "hope you survive bullet sponges with super powerful weapons." I had to quit the mission for the first time in any farcry game just so I could grind for a super busted weapon to quickly take them down...I HAD TO LOOK UP A TUTORIAL WHEN I WAS PLAYING ON EASY. Thats most of the game too, at a lesser extent of course. They reworked the weapon system and gave bad guys "tiers" so a lot of weapons dont work on the stronger units. They also reworked the perk system so its simple and smaller, personally I saw this as a positive thing because I only play farcry games for the story and gunplay but some people didnt like this fact.

The story is pretty bad. The only thing that saves it are the parts with New Eden returning (yes you probably should play 5 before this). The idea of mad max type enemy faction was actually pretty cool but their dialog is a little cringey. They (and all the characters tbh) talk like they are out of a borderlands game or some other game that tries too hard to be edgy and funny. Maybe thats your thing but everytime an enemy called me "chudwaffle" or similar names I rolled my eyes a little further back into my skull (dont even get me started on the more outragious character dialog). The worst characters were the main bad guys called "the twins." I cant really describe to you how annoying they are but what makes it worse is there's pretty much no story elaboration to them other than "we're assholes because our dad was an asshole." Its also kind of hard to feel anything for the good guys too because the game doesnt really elaborate on anything. 

Another small thing that really pisses me off is the lack of an interesting protagonist. I really hope in farcry 6 we get a real talking protagonist again. Just like in 5, you create this generic NPC looking character and do whatever others tell you to do. The only difference is I actually felt something for the other characters in 5. In new dawn, since the story doesnt have any interesting motives behind anyone you dont really feel immersed, which is a damn shame.

However, Its still a fun little game to play through if you treat it as a standalone DLC or a spinoff rather than a full farcry game. The gameplay mechanics feel much more improved over 5 and the missions, even though there are less than 5, are all super unique and mostly fun and its neat seeing New Eden at a different angle

If you enjoyed 5 youll probably enjoy new dawn. Just dont keep your standards too high and youll have fun, but do youself a favor and dont settle for getting it above 10 bucks. The positive rating is only for a super sale price. Dont bother outside of that.
Glad i waited till it was 8 bucks.  The Farcry franchise just gets worse and worse.

I wish there was a "middle ground" option for reviews. Far Cry: New Dawn is a game that excels in some areas and utterly fails in others. It addresses some of Far Cry 5's issues but creates new ones as well. It's very grindy and intent on making you use microtransactions to gain an edge against your enemies (I would strongly recommend not buying into them, though). At the core of this bizarre mashup of Borderlands, Fallout, and Far Cry is an entertaining open world FPS buried by questionable development choices.

Taking place 17 years after the..."conversation-starting" Resist Ending of Far Cry 5, Hope County has been reduced to a nuclear wasteland. You play as the security captain of a nationwide militia arriving to help with the rebuilding effort. However, your train is ambushed by the Highwaymen, an anarchist group dedicated to looting settlements for their own gain. Cut off from your team, your character allies with the citizens of Sanctuary and New Eden to drive out the Highwaymen once and for all.

The greatest strengths of Far Cry games are their charismatic villains and their engrossing environments. New Dawn lacks both of these. The main villains of ND have no defining philosophy beyond "we get to take your stuff," and the map is just recycled from Far Cry 5. Some characters from FC5 return, but they're either reduced to minor roles (Grace, Father Jerome, The Deputy) or limited to references in journal entries (Tracy, Nadine). Fan favorites like Jess Black aren't even referenced at any point. Even Joseph Seed is made underwhelming in this game! It's disappointing how Far Cry 5's compelling cast of varied characters got shafted in favor of an unimpressive new cast. As for the environments, expedition missions to cool areas like a beached frigate and an airplane crash in the woods add some variety, but they're fairly limited overall.

Combat in New Dawn takes on an RPG-like approach, where enemies have different levels and health values. Weapons have ranks that determine their damage and, more importantly, how resistant enemies are to them. Lower-level guns are made useless against high-level enemies, forcing you to grind for better equipment. You can't customize guns here, but New Dawn does a good job of making FC5's collection of weapons feel unique. New attachments like bayonets are equipped to some weapons. Existing attachments get a more improvised appearance, like oil cans taking the place of silencers. The weapons also look heavily maintained and feel fitting for a post-apocalyptic environment. 

There are also some fun and ridiculous abilities you get over the course of the game, like double-jumping and going into a berserker mode to deal more damage. Knife takedowns also make a grisly return, though they are much slower than they were in previous games. It's tough to chain takedowns when your character takes so much time performing a single knife execution. On the bright side, bayonet takedowns exist and go quicker than normal ones.

Getting new guns/vehicles and upgrading the installations at Sanctuary require you to find and scavenge resources. You can do this by hunting, raiding Highwayman supply drops, and replaying outpost missions with stronger opponents. This can require a LOT of grinding to get through. Naturally, Ubisoft hands you a small amount of microtransaction coins here and there to tempt you into buying your way to victory. The microtranscations here are more prevalent than they were in Far Cry 5 (which mostly purchased outfits and weapon reskins), and the way they're promoted feels sleazy.

Far Cry 5 had a fantastic soundtrack. so topping it would be a near-impossible task. New Dawn has some good tracks (like its main theme and the map menu music), but its soundtrack is mostly forgettable. It's nice that the Highwaymen have their own songs to set them apart from FC5's cult, at least.

Would I recommend Far Cry: New Dawn by itself? No. However, there are mods that remove the damage resistances and other grind-encouraging mechanics to make the game more enjoyable. I would personally recommend the Scavenger Mod and the Improved Weapons mod (bundled with the Unreleased Variety mod) to make lower-level guns viable and unlock content that wasn't made available. These mods bring it close to the fun, frantic action of Far Cry 5, and turn its RPG elements into less of a chore and more of an enhancement to the overall experience.

Overall, Far Cry: New Dawn feels like a wasted opportunity. We could have had a full-blown Vietnam War DLC instead of this half-baked continuation of Far Cry 5's story. Weak villains and greedy design choices bog down the fun gameplay of the franchise in this spin-off. If you still want to play it, I would wait until it is at least 50% off on sale, and I would install the previously mentioned mods to get around its less-than-fun enemy damage resistances.

I honestly liked it a lot, bought it a few days ago and now i just saw i almost have 24h in the game.

Imma be honest i'm a sucker for dogs in games so the existence of Timber was right up my alley.
The boar, Horatio, is so hilarious, charging and throwing enemies a few meters away.
Timber suprised me one time, I sent him to kill and enemy and he decided to troll the target and steal his weapon and bring it back to me. Good puppy.

The story itself is decent, there's some Bliss sections included but I honestly didn't find myself hating it.
The twins are quite the annoying villains, exactly because they have no philosophy and they just gun and steal everyone and everything, because they want to and they can. It's just a cold hard reality inspired situation, people don't need some deep "glorious" (for lack of a better word) reason to do bad things.
At this point, after almost 24h, i find myself almost done with the story, outposts, side missions. My base is lvl 3 and almost all of my facilities are lvl 3. 
I like it. I really like it. And I knew I'd like it since i saw the trailers before it came out.

It was a bold move by Ubisoft to sabotage their own game. Coming off the fantastic Far Cry 5 all they had to do was to... well, do the obvious thing. Far Cry 5 in the post apocalypse. And this is damned close. So tantalisingly close. The game contains a fatal flaw, however. Gun customisation is completely absent, instead replaced with a tier system, which in turn bleeds into the rest of the game. The feeling of freedom one would expect from a Far Cry title is taken away, in lieu of a progression system that fits neatly with microtransactions which are of course present. This is why I said Ubisoft sabotaged this game; and they did it because of greed. A disappointment.

Pros
+ Beautiful
+ Fun gameplay 
+ Some fun side missions
+ Even though its the same Far Cry 5 area they¬¥ve managed to make it feel different most of the time.

Not Pro or Con
* Story

Cons
- Bad optimization
- Stuttering.
- It takes long to kill or is impossible to kill enemies/animals if you have too low level weapons unlike in Far Cry 5.
- Shooting to body does more damage than to head on many enemies.
- Sometimes you have to do same outpost 5 times if you want complete outfit set.

Overall: 70/100 Decent game basically just worse version of Far cry 5

Personally, the story is kinda booty sauce bc it invalidates any decision or ending you worked for in the last game and forces you into the story after nukes destroy everything. The gameplay is fairly similar to the previous game, with exceptions to the customization of weapons. In Far Cry 5, players had the option to customize weapons with attachments. But to my knowledge i have not seen any form of this in New Dawn. Weapons are available to craft, but aside from that it is bland. If you do not care much for a story that makes sense, i say this game is for you. It can seem drawn out at times, but multiplayer can make for a much more fun experience. I would not recommend this game to those who like to replay games. This game can feel like a chore to play at times.

It's a fun game, and if you want to see what happens to Hope County after the events of Far Cry 5, you should definitely check out New Dawn.  

They decided to go with more of an RPG system with this game, in that you encounter different levels of enemies.  This requires you to get better and better equipment in order to do significant damage to them.  You also get to build up your home base to improve your character, equipment and companions.  Unfortunately, this means Ubisoft decided to become more heavyhanded with the pay-to-win currency, though I never needed to use any of it to get what I wanted.  I didn't have to grind everything too much either, so you can easily ignore this feature.  

In addition to the RPG mechanics, they have some new side tasks such as Expeditions.  These involve finding a package and carrying it to the extraction point, and they take place in various cool settings that aren't related to the main map.  I liked these quests quite a bit, and they were a great way to complete weapon and companion perk challenges. 

As for companions, they are mostly good.  Both of the animal companions are better compared to Far Cry 5, because Horatio the Boar is a lot sturdier than Cheeseburger and can wreak some serious havoc.  Timber has similar abilities to Boomer, though he can also get rid of guard dogs for you and he doesn't seem to die as easily.  Most of the human companions work well, especially Nana the sniper and Gina who kills everyone once she levels up a bit, though you also have duds like the Pastor who sets EVERYTHING on fire *ugh*.  

Like Blood Dragon, New Dawn is a "spinoff" from the main games so it gives you a smaller map and there aren't as many quests.  However, enemies still spawn after the game ends (unlike Far Cry 5) and you can retake Outposts which become more difficult each time you do so for more of a challenge.  In fact, it's essential that you do this at least a few times if you want to fully upgrade your home base.  

While I had a great time playing this game, the weakest part was its story.  The main villains weren't very threatening and are probably the least interesting that I've encountered in a Far Cry game. They get some back story at the last minute to affect what you decide to do at the end, but too little too late.  The final fights weren't that fun, either, since the bosses were bullet sponges even if you used elite weapons.  I did enjoy some parts, such my encounters with various people from 5, and it was nice to have some closure after what happened in that game.

Overall, I'd say this is worth playing if you've already finished 5 and want to see what happens next.  I wouldn't bother with it otherwise.

Far Cry New Dawn is a direct sequel to Far Cry 5, so make sure you check that game out first! Its the first game in the series to be a sequel to a previous instalment, adding a very special feeling to re-discovering areas of the map. The Story is actually pretty good, Graphics are great and Gameplay has received much love from the Devs at Ubisoft.
The Story starts you off as 'The Captain', again like in Far Cry 5 its an unnamed character who has no personality. Please don't make this a thing Ubisoft! Characters are given feelings and opinions when they have a voice and makes playing them a lot more interesting. Anyway, the antagonists are really good, almost as enjoyable as Vaas, as they are well built and their motives are clearly laid out in front of them. Throughout the story you meet characters met in Far Cry 5, who will help you on your quests. Very Enjoyable, probably the best since Far Cry 3.
Graphics are great, very similar to Far Cry 5 with addition to some minor upgrades that make the world feel brighter and alive.
This game has received a lot of Quality of Life changes I hope future games add as well. Health bars for enemies, enemy tiers, re-taking outposts for higher rewards, base upgrades, weapon upgrades, weapon tiers, improved buddy system, utilities crafting, medkit crafting and much, much more. All of which make the game a lot more enjoyable, and make you think how did you survive without this in previous games?
Overall, Far Cry New Dawn is a very enjoyable, well written and fun game to play. All the new features and improvements make it feel like the most comfortable game to play, with all the improvements hopefully carrying on to future games.
Far Cry New Dawn gets an 8/10. 

For more reviews check my Steam profile

Far Cry New Dawn is a post-apocalyptic game set in the world of Far Cry 5 post the nuclear attacks, and you‚Äôd think this would mean this game would take cues from other games with similar settings like Fallout, but no.
There are no apocalyptic wastelands here, the world is actually prettier than ever and the gameplay barely acknowledges the post-apocalyptic themes. Yes, you no longer have money and instead, you need to gather resources to craft things, and on paper that sounds good, but those resources become extremely abundant once you have good enough weapons and perks for easily clearing out outposts and completing expeditions. You don‚Äôt even need to hunt animals for upgrades like you had to in Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 4. My point is that this game is pretty much Far Cry 5 again, but with a new coat of paint, pink paint specifically. (Some aspects are actually worse than in that game, like how this time special takedowns are needlessly hard to execute because of their new and lengthier animations. (Well, at least they look pretty good)) Don‚Äôt get me wrong, that‚Äôs not inherently a bad thing, if you enjoyed Far Cry 5, you‚Äôll definitely enjoy this game too, but don‚Äôt expect much new from it. Even the level system that was added to this game because apparently, that‚Äôs something Ubisoft thinks every game absolutely must have now doesn‚Äôt change much. It just means some enemies will be bullet spongy until you unlock weapons that match their level, then they pretty much become average Far Cry enemies again. You might have noticed I haven‚Äôt mentioned anything about the story yet, that‚Äôs because there is not much to say about it. Most of it just feels like an excuse for you to shoot bad guys. Almost nothing about it is memorable, not even the main villains, which are usually the highlight of any Far Cry game.
Again, if you enjoy the gameplay loop of a post-FC3 Far Cry game, you‚Äôll probably enjoy this game too. Just don‚Äôt ever buy this game at full price. It is just not worth that given it feels more like a Far Cry 5 DLC than a proper new Far Cry game.

This Far Cry New Dawn felt very cheap 'n cheesy. The storyline was very cliche, as well as the villains, and it doesn't matter what choices you make in the game's story either.

The map is very small, there are only a handful of outposts. You can't even customize your weapons! There are also too many interlinked prerequisites for upgrading anything. Which means you are forced to upgrade one thing before you can upgrade what you actually wanted to upgrade. All this really limits your free choice.

I completed the game in 23 hours, but often the gameplay was very frustrating. Enemies knocking you to the ground when you try to hit them, 'Epic' creatures roaming around in nature which are almost impossible to kill UNLESS you have superb gear. And once you kill it, it just respawns as if nothing happened. And don't even get me started on the ridiculously frustrating and unrealistic 'boss' fights...

I really prefer the more 'realistic' gameplay of Far Cry 3 and 4, without the damn health bars and hitpoints that fly around as you hit things. I understand it's a game but now it looks like you're playing one of those MMORPGs. It just takes out the immersiveness. 

This whole game was clearly made with a small budget using the 'they will buy it anyway' philosophy.

Conclusion.. if you want to play it anyway, at least get it on a sale.

I don't think I can further emphasize how mediocre this game is. I would not say this game is worth $40, I got it on sale, and I have about 2 hours of game play per dollar I spent. I have 100% completed this game, challenges and all. Has some major flaws, but it's not a full game. Short review: 6.5/10, But not damnable. I recommend it b/c it is fun, It just missed the mark in a few areas. And, tbh, I would play through this game again with a friend or even for fun. It's simple FarCry fun. With that being said, If you like FarCry, buy this on sale, you won't regret it. Also, SPOILERS.

Things I liked:
-Has a "better" ending than FarCry 5. (Albeit debatable.)
-Concludes FarCry 5's story line. 
-Visually appealing 
-Tried something new. (Although most of these changes I would be happy if they NEVER came to light again.
-TIMBER. (And car rides with him.)

Things I had mixed feelings about:
-Antagonists: Mickie and Lou are very, very bland for FarCry villains. Honestly, they get a 6/10. 
-Joseph helps you, and doesn't act like he did in FarCry 5. Both in a good way and in a bad way.
-Leveling: Leveling is SUPER easy. Playing as I did will result in max stats and gear halfway through.
-Looting: There are two situations you run into regarding loot. A.) Ah shit... I have no materials. Or B.) Having 
  so much loot, you don't know what to do with it.
-Sheer grind for 100%: There are several things a "completion-ist" would want to do to feel like he/she 
  100%'ed the game. It's almost agonizing. 
-Hope county?: I understand that several nuclear bombs went off, but other than a few locations, it didn't 
  feel like Hope County. Might be just me.
- FUCKING PINK!: I'm sorry, but when does radiation = pink? I get it, its different and all that, but it feels off.
- Those who had a serious role in FarCry 5 are tossed aside, while side characters in FarCry 5 become main 
   characters in this game. (Not going to go into detail because spoilers... if you care.)
-Absent Characters. (Jess Black, Cheeseburger, Peaches, Adeline Drubman, etc.) Some characters are 
  revealed to be dead, but some are unexplained or flat-out missing in this game. 

Things I didn't like/hated:
-Guns: Crafting weapons is way, way, way to costly. 123 titanium for a pistol? That doesn't even 
  make any sense. Also, some weapons are vastly superior to others. Bows are better than .50 sniper riflers in 
  this game, due to the armor mechanics. 
-Armor: Your enemies have armor now. So, some can take a bullet/arrow to the face and still keep fighting. 
 Some helmets may save your life depending on the distance, caliber, etc; but a normal helmet shouldn't save 
  your life from a .50 Caliber BMG to the face from like 100yds away. Sorry... YOUR DEAD. Also, Bows are 
 somehow able to go through chest-plates with ease, but helmets only shatter from arrows. What gives?
-Enemy ranks/gear ranks: So, you have four ranks. Common, Uncommon, Legendary, and Elite. Self 
  Explanatory. But, elite enemies and to a certain degree, Legendary enemies, are perhaps a little too strong 
  in my opinion. Not saying they're too hard to kill, but an average person in motocross gear should normally 
  die from a few rounds from an MG42 at close range... Especially if some of those rounds fired are 
  headshots...  
-Guns/Fangs/Bows for Hire: My god. They FUCKED Guns for hire in this game... All of these characters have 
  three tiers, they all need 40 kills to reach the third tier. Also, sometimes they just stop moving or have fits 
  of confusion for no reason. My guess, their path-finding ability is all fucked up... Only three are worth using. 
  
  -Pastor Jerome has a shotgun, and throws Molotovs. In concept, this sounds good, but he shoots his 
    shotgun from too far away to do any real damage, and I've seen him kill himself with his own molotovs. 
    1/10. 
   -Carmina Rye has an Ar, and throws dynamite. She can't aim worth shit. She gets to throw three sticks of 
     dynamite at her third tier.  2/10. Only because I haven't seen her killing herself with her own dynamite.
     Wouldn't be surprised though... 
   -Gina is fucking awesome. She swings her MG42 like a baseball bat in stealth mode, and is accurate with 
     her LMG when detected. Also, she gets infinite ammo, and explosive ammo when she reaches third tier 
     Seriously, my third favorite Gun for Hire in this game. 9/10
   -Nana is the best human Gun for Hire in this game. She's quiet, and she's lethal. 2nd tier grants her the 
    ability to see through smoke. And her 3rd tier allows her shots to NEGATE COVER. THIS GRANNY GETS 
    WALL-HACKS BRO. 10/10
   -The Judge, is disappointing. He/She gets a bow. He/She has difficulty when detected or dealing with high
    ranking enemies. He/She gives immunity to wildlife in the 2nd tier. And Tri-shot in the 3rd tier. He/She is 
    limited in range, and sometimes only destroys armor, setting off alarms. EXTREMELY ANNOYING TO WORK 
    WITH AT TIMES. However, his/her tri-shot does allow him/her to kill higher ranking enemies. He/She is still 
    fucked if they're detected. 5/10.
   -Hurk: OH HURK... You actually made me laugh in this game, yet you're so shit... Hurk gets a MAC-10 and a 
    rocket Launcher. He can't aim worth shit, and he takes forever killing individual targets. He has no stealth 
    mode, just balls-to-the-wall loud. He gets faster reloads on his 2nd tier, and vehicle tracking on his 3rd tier. 
    Just as fucking useless and is as bad as Pastor Jerome. But, his only saving grace is vehicular 
    destruction. 4/10.
   -Timber is the best Guns/Fangs for Hire in this game. Not very good at killing, but TIMBER SEES
    EVERYTHING. Enemies, friendlies, loot, guns, materials, the list goes on. Also, he will take the 
    attention of animals when you're fighting them in the third tier. Super useful Albeit not very lethal. Timber 
    is a truly good boy. 10/10. Also he can sit in the car with you. THX UBISOFT. 
   -Lastly, Horatio. Horatio is the CHEAPEST Fangs for Hire/Guns for Hire character EVER CREATED. Horatio 
    can SELF REVIVE at his 2nd tier. Literally, just send him in a compound, and just wait, he'll get it done. And 
    his 3rd tier allows him to destroy anything in his way. Literally the god of destruction. However, Timber is 
    still better because Timber isn't an OP piece of shit unlike Horatio. 7/10, only for being so damn OP. 

-Silent Protagonist. 
-Forgettable Characters. 
-Short story. There are 22 missions total in this game. If I wanted to beat the game as fast as possible, I'd 
  imagine it'd take no more than 10 hours; 15 hours tops. 
-Expeditions: They only exist to pad the lack of content, get more resources, and make it ever so slightly 
  harder to 100% this game. I get the appeal, but I don't like it. 
-Upgradable perks: Some perks are able to be upgraded, stacking the effectiveness of the perk. But, this 
  could allow someone to max out a perk like ammo holding, which allows them to carry upwards of 
  thousands of rounds of ammo at once. 
-"God perks": Once you reach a certain point in the game, you get special powers such as a double jump, a 
  sneak ability, a rage ability, and a take-down that replenishes energy for the other abilities and replenishes 
  health. Making the game even MORE easier. 
-Not being able to modify/kit out you weapons: You can't choose attachments in this game, you're stuck 
  with what the game gives you. It's not bad, but its not great either. I enjoyed the freedom of customization. 
  (although some customizations in FarCry 5 were absurd. I.E. Suppressors on belt-fed machine guns.)



That's it, that's my in-depth analysis review of this game. I would say if you enjoy FarCry games, or you want to know how this story ends, get the game and play it. At least you'll get to see how it ends. Otherwise, I feel like this game was decent for its price. But nothing more than decent. I hope this will be helpful to someone.

The worst part of this game is the big bads, the two sisters - I never felt threatened by them at all and their story that unfolded just seemed a bit thin and underdeveloped - even the ending with them that to be fair had a decent amount of build up - felt like a wasted chance for the story to have a proper ending.

It is okay. It is a Far Cry game. This has some of the worst writing out of the series. The gun play is good. The map is not great. The enemy AI is a little retarded, but not below the acceptable level. The game isn't hard. A reasonably skilled player isn't going to be outmatched once you get used to things.

The co-op is the reason you'd get this over previous Far Cry titles. Some of the former ones were better games, but the multiplayer was significantly worst. You're still tethered to each other, but the distance isn't much of an inconvenience.

You're gonna experience a very annoying bug where either you or your co-op partner falls through the ground or gets stuck in the air or ground and can't move. Just fast travel somewhere else. It is super fucking annoying after a bit. It isn't impossible to deal with.

This review is written by someone who has owned and played every single Farcry game.

Usually, when I play a Farcry game, I enjoy the fact that my actions (the rare times where you can decide the fate of the game, usually by killing/sparing an enemy) actually mean something. 

I've played 3, 4, 5, then New Dawn in that order on Steam since I played 1, 2, and Primal on console. 

This was the first time that I've felt like my decisions were completely meaningless. For example, [spoiler]When you get to decide whether or not Mickey dies, it literally does not matter a single micron whether you kill her or not. She never comes back to either haunt/amend her ways. She doesn't sick her Highwaymen at you. Nothing. Only positive to killing her is you get to loot her body. WTF?[/spoiler]

In all the other games, ESPECIALLY 4, I loved how my decisions actually effected the world, and I believe this is one of the key ingredients in what makes Farcry, Farcry. I don't know about others, but this game truly did not feel like a Farcry game. 

If you love Farcry for solely the gameplay, wait for a sale. The weapon system is super fun imo, and unlike 5, hunting actually has somewhat of a significance again! Wait for a sale and then pick it up; TRUST ME. 

If you love Farcry for the story, I'd suggest just watching TheRadBrad or some other Youtuber on their channels. Even on sale, if you just want it for the story, I really don't think the game is worth it.

I was fortunate enough to get the $130 bundle of both 5 and New Dawn's deluxe editions for $20, and I think Farcry sales are quite common.

TLDR: There's A LOT of problems with this game.

It didn't take me long to realize this game is bad. There are a multitude of problems with the game that I will list; The characters aren't interesting, the antagonists and story line are both very stereotypical, all the car music sounds bad, the cult outposts don't have scenes when they are liberated, the amount of detail given is sometimes too much or too little in quests, the amount of guns and vehicles is depressingly low, the map size is tiny in comparison to Far Cry 5, you aren't allowed to do whatever you want (punching NPCs), the 'action' scenes are mediocre at best, the game doesn't work well with Co-Op, some missions are too direct and don't give player freedom, the characters are badly written and are hard to remember, there is a currency system that allows you to bypass playing the game to progress (like VBucks and the Battle Pass in Fortnite), there's a ranking system for items to stop people from progressing instead of adding natural progression, and the controls are sloppy.

Here are some good things: the graphics are nice, some of the guns and vehicles look cool, the environment feels great, the damage numbers and health bars are a good quality of life, and the crafting system is cool.
This game is the tiny corner of the shadow that Far Cry 5 makes. This game feels like a nostalgic money grab to me. I would not recommend this to ANYONE. I don't know if they're still updating this game, but, Ubisoft, this game is bad. Oh yeah, also the DLCs are bad.

2/10

IMPORTANT: If you still want to play this, I would recommend you wait for a sale because this game is overpriced.

Ok, so coming directly from FC5, this feels like a big improvement. AI is no longer dumb as a rock, companions are no longer completely useless, they can drive well, they can actually aim now and fight and save you from crappy situations, enemies finally seem to have brains and predators attack on sight, don't just pass by ignoring you. Graphically, it's beautiful and I haven't encountered bugs and glitches. I like the weapon crafting system and the guns. Main storyline finally blends in with the rest of the game, it's not only a bunch of cinematics and forced missions that felt completely out of place and cut from a different game like in FC5. Exploration is good, puzzles are fun, more RPG-like and I like how they made the perk and base building systems, although it's not really base building, it's more like a parallel perk system. Overall it's very fun

I'll split this into two parts, gameplay and performance, since performance is my fault.
Gameplay wise, I haven't had too much of an experience but what I have had I haven't had the best time with. Guns seem too weak, there is no option that I have found to customize weapons like 5, and the landscape just seems like an infinite forest with almost no buildings, while in 5, in the same county, albeit with a nuke or two to the face, had buildings everywhere, and nowhere just felt like an overly forested forest. Also, four hours in, I met a bug that erased my save and sent me back to the train. Then it happened again while I was getting ready to restart my progress. 
Now for performance. I have played through 5 with very few issues for a relatively poor quality computer, but with New Dawn the issues I had were multiplied tenfold. At random moments in the game, I received frame drops to sub-20 from around 50-60 fps. This is probably due to my computer being bad, but it ran 5 just fine with a couple drops for a minute or two. As mentioned before, a game-breaking bug set back all my progress from 4 hours of play twice, and I won't be playing this game again until I get a better computer.

TL;DR - it's nothing but a cash grab. Almost every other Far Cry game is way more enjoyable.

Don't buy this short, disappointing FC5 DLC cash grab at full price. It's so difficult to find what's good about the game, other than the fact that you get a half-a$$ed story continuation of FC5. Everything else is just an ugly trimmed reskin of FC5 with a wide variety of idiotic design decisions. The worst bit is the cringeworthy antagonists. Instead of having charisma and persuasion, the villains here are simple dumb insecure bandits who will start a brawl for no reason. If you compare them to their predecessors, these guys used to have some class, they used to interact with the player: Vaas in FC3 was all like "Jason, do you know the definition of insanity?", Pagan in FC4 - "Sorry Ajay, gotta pick up this call, we'll grant your mother's last wish afterwards", Joseph in FC5 - "You're my family now, we'll step into new Eden together". How do the girls in New Dawn behave? Along the lines of "Ya a problem-maker ya punk muvufuka ya're ma b1tch nao! Imma kill ya right here ya sucka! Howya like ma gun in ya face b1atch? We gon' destroy you, ya family and ya home fool". And all the while some experimental gangsta hip-hop is blasting through their trucks' speakers. Like what the hell is all this ghetto $#!t? They seriously want me to believe that these two little badmouthed children got the respect and utmost devotion of grown-a$$ people around Hope County by talking smack and are now leading a bandit gang? Get the f*ck outta here. If I wanted to deal with ghetto gangsters I'd play GTA, and they'd at least look a lot cooler and make more sense than the Highwaymen gang. Maybe it's time Ubisoft rethought their villain formula cause New Dawn feels like beating a dead horse.

The antagonist disaster aside, I really couldn't stand the pink/purple color scheme. The nature has taken back the land and flowers are growing everywhere, but it's completely unnatural and looks more like somebody's dream. You've probably seen some derelict places in your life overgrown with vegetation, so you know there might be a flower here and there, but not everywhere. Here though every inch of Hope County seems to have been covered by artificial-looking purple plants which don't lose their color even when you torch the whole flower field. Ugh.

Having been let down by the aforementioned design decisions I thought about what fun could be had here, and I always used to find outposts fun. Not anymore: enemies are segregated into toughness levels, as are cars, weapons, animals, etc. If you have a gun that's a level lower than the enemy you're facing, no dice - your gun is a total nerf gun and you're gonna get trampled. I needed FIFTEEN C4 explosives to take down a level 3 cougar. Fifteen. When the enemy is human, you could do a takedown but that again requires a different expensive perk to be unlocked for each toughness level, otherwise you'll creep up behind somebody only to be shown a prompt you can't perform a takedown on this enemy yet. So the stealth part is barely functional until you level up yourself and your gear. How do you level up your gear? By guzzling ethanol, lots and lots of it. Apparently ethanol is a great source for weapon, vehicle, gardening, settlement upgrades - an all-around miracle substance. I don't even... When you finally upgrade and get to craft new stuff, you'll find out that you can't customize anything. That means no extended mags, no silencer attachments, no car accessories, no nothing. You can only use presets which don't let you make the cool gear combinations you used to create in FC5.

I could go on and on about the drawbacks but what's the point.... I think the only fun thing to do might be exploration, because if you've played FC5 it could be pretty fun to see a place and realize you've been here, only 17 years ago, and look at how it's changed. But this again feels like a cheap cash grab which would have been better off as a DLC for FC5 than a new standalone game, and while a tiny bit of fun can be had, the majority of the game is a chore. Can't recommend it unless your expectations are low and you really really like purple flowers.

If you're new to the Far Cry series. Do yourself a favour and skip this one.

I've played Far Cry 3, 4, and 5 (All of which I really enjoyed). But this is hands down the worst Far Cry game in the series. This is nothing more than a half baked Far Cry 5 DLC that barely delivers on the Far Cry experience. The story sucks, the characters are bland and forgettable, and the game just straight up doesn't feel finished at all.
You see constantly recycled assets within 2 hours of play, It runs like shit (I have decent hardware but FPS fluctuates anywhere from 30-80fps, it's wildly inconsistent), and the game at times just feels completely unfair due to the new enemy level system that is just total garbage, legendary animals are effectively omnipotent and take literal tonnes of explosives or thousands of bullets to kill, and level 3 or higher enemies are just bullet sponges.
Having any companion besides the dog will make the game unstealthable due to bad pathing. 
But the icing on the cake is that the game requires you to be online to play it and they've introduced "Far Cry Coins" (You can probably guess what this means...), the coins are attainable in-game, but there is definitely a push for you to pay IRL money for more Far Cry Coins.
I've never raged at a game so much before, and it bothers me more for the fact that they had the perfect recipe with Far Cry, it may feel rinse repeat at times but it was still a fun experience, but they've ruined it with New Dawn, and if Far Cry 6 is anything like this, then I will absolutely not be playing it.

Amazing graphics, quality, gameplay, story, and everything else.

While I like that the game takes place in the same world as Far Cry 5, I do not like the new villians and gameplay mechanics.

First off the villians, in comparison to prior ones these two are pretty lame. At first they seem a great fit for what the world has become. However, later in the game you start feeling dissapointed at that all they seem to be is overly aggresive non-witty side characters. Following this there was a scene which bottered me quite a bit, but since it can be a spoiler I'll mark it below. [spoiler] The part of the game where they kidnapped one of your friends/squad mates. In this your go to a camp and clear it out after which they radio you to go to them since they are inside the house. They ask you to leave your weapons, which the MC does as the dumbass he is even though the outcome can be seen from a mile away. After that you go to them, of course get pinned down and watch your friend die...  then they kick you out. [/spoiler]

The bit above is a bit of a rant, however in comparison to prior games in which I liked the villian this is just something I am quite dissapointed by in this game.

The other part I do not want to see explorer in future instalments is the RPG mechcanics they included. While it might be new and refreshing in the beginning it will get old quite fast when you run into enemies for which you need to shoot a gun store worth of bullets to kill. Perhaps fine for the odd side game, but I can do without it in the mainline games.

In this game you also have a base improving mechanic. For this you would need resources which you can get in the open world. No all that exiting honestly, but it's fun to see your base grow so it's quite inoffensive.

As mentioned in the beginning I like how this game takes place in the prior Far Cry 5. There are even some spots in the game where you can see a more clear comparison between the two through old photo's. The current state of the world does give a mixed feel though, while it's still nice to look at it feels smaller then the prior installment which is a shame.

The gunplay feels solid like usual and it sports a nice selection of odd weapons which can spice up the gameplay. That being said, as mentioned with the RPG mechanics it suffers a bit because of the amount of shooting you need to do for some enemies just to down them which is a shame in my opinion.

To summarize, while the game does have it's good points I do not recommend it. Primarly because it's not the direction I want this franchise to go to. While it might work for some other games I do think this franchise has it's own strengths it should rather focus on.

If you generally like the far cry series, and have a good co-op partner this game is dumb fun.  Story was pretty short though, and opened up more plot points from the last entry that were never answered.  However, I was always quite inebriated playing this game so what do I know about the plot?

I really love Far Cry 5 so to have played this game was great. The story is pretty bad but at least it gives you a satisfying ending to FC5 when FC5 really only had bad endings. In terms of gameplay, they add a lot to the base FC5 gameplay with expeditions and tier-ed outposts which are welcome additions. The only gameplay hiccup would be some bullet sponge enemies and the removal of weapon customization, which even though was really just to add silencers to guns, seems like it would fit in this game much better than any other Far Cry game because of the theme. Speaking of the theme, the post-apocalypticness of the game is at a bare minimum and seems to just be there to sell scrap as micro-transactions. Just like with FC Primal and the ice age setting, the idea of a post apocalyptic theme isn't expanded upon and is just a cosmetic thing. I guess they do have you "building" weapons out of scrap you find in the world, but I never had to look for specific materials because I had plenty from just looting things as I went.

The additions of this game really add to the Far Cry formula and would love to see them expanded upon in FC6, like the base upgrading and expeditions, but the crappy story and lack of ambition keeps the game at an 8/10, which is what I gave FC5.

I had fun playing New Dawn.  If you loved Far Cry 5 and want more of the same, this is it.  I recommend getting it on a deep sale however.  It had plenty of problems.  The antagonists were cringe, the game crashes a lot, and there's a (completely avoidable) micro-transactions store. But ultimately, I enjoyed myself, so I'm giving a thumbs up.
After playing Far Cry 5 this has to be the biggest downgrade ever. Graphics, gameplay you name it. Rushed content and really let down.

If Farcry 5 were Highlander, New Dawn is Higlander 2: End Game. The game feels like they handed it to the B team who refaced old assets, character and mechanics and added a crappy South Side LA vibe to the whole thing. Oh yeah, let's toss more Joseph Seed in the mix as well as some sort of psycho spirit guide. Everything about this game is worse than the previous.

If you liked Far Cry 5, this may or may not be worth getting, when on sale ($10).  Not as deep and rich as 5, and has its own aggravations and nonsense, as 5 did,  but can be an interesting revisit of some 5 sites and geography. I was prepared to dislike it, but don't (correction... once I hit the Problem Solver incident taking the twins on directly, I took a dislike to it and uninstalled the game). I like the look of the new settlement buildings, but haven't figured out where they got all the plywood... or how the flat roofs don't leak like crazy   :-P

My guess is that to successfully take on the twins in Problem Solver incident, will first have to scavenge (cash out) and replay most of the incidents one or more times, in order to build up to their boss level strengths. Too tedious, not of interest.

Your mileage may vary.

Glad I only paid a tenner for this. Lazy copy paste gameplay from Far Cry 5 without any of the good writing or side quests / activities. Over way too quicky at under 20 hrs and thats including grinding a bit. Co-op was a laugh but the game didn't really do anything creative with the missions to take advantage of Co-Op. No side activities to do with friends. Expeditions were ok but the whole setting just felt lifeless. If youve never played the others you'll probably still enjoy it but if you've completed Far Cry 5 I wouldn't bother. The main villains are just so unthreatening and badly written and the number of times they "get away" during cutscenes is just a joke. Generally felt like a super lazy cash n grab from Ubisoft and after this and the spectacular fail of Watch Dogs Legion I doubt ill ever buy a full price Ubisoft game again.

[strike] Please don‚Äôt send me death treats, all I want is to explain what‚Äôs going in the game and share my experience and opinion. [/strike]

[h1]{Story and overview} [/h1]

[b] Far Cry New Dawn takes place 17-years after the events of Far Cry 5. (If you haven‚Äôt played Far Cry 5 please don‚Äôt reveal the next sentence, I don‚Äôt wanna spoil and ruin it for ya)  [spoiler] That means that this world has been through a global nuclear apocalypse. [/spoiler] Far Cry New Dawn picks up in a now post-apocalyptic version of Hope County, once controlled by the Seed family, led by ‚ÄúThe Father‚Äù, Joseph Seed. You have a choice at the start of the game, which is a personal choice and doesn‚Äôt effect the story, to be either a man or a woman, regardless of the character that you pick at the start of the game, you‚Äôll be fighting for the survivors of Prosperity.  Prosperity is the name of the encampment where the survivors have set-up their home base. However Joseph Seed is not the antagonist in the game, New Dawn‚Äôs villains are a pair of teens who run a gang called the Highwaymen, the twins Mickey and Lou, which are the main villians and just feel like nothing more than arrogant, foul-mouthed thugs who‚Äôve managed to murder their way up to the top of the food chain.
A lot of the new features of Far Cry 5 carry over into New Dawn, but there are also some new ones as well. With some returning faces from the previous game and some entirely new ones.  The Outpost system of clearing out enemy encampments as a major part of the game is still present but the way that these encounters function has been tweaked for the better.  There‚Äôs still a robust system of perks to unlock, items to craft, animals to hunt, and all the great progression and reasons that push you to explore the open world of Hope County that Far Cry 5 had. The new stuff you can expect in New Dawn are almost all changes for the better or additions to the formula. Crafting is expanded upon with rare materials that can only be found on Expeditions.  Outposts can now be recycled and escalated to tougher versions.  Each time you beat an outpost it will be outfitted with more powerful enemies, more alarms, and you‚Äôll get better rewards for completing it. While we are talking about outfitted, every time you beat a outpost you‚Äôll be rewarded with part of an outfit which can also be acquired with far cry credits(the premium in-game currency, which can be purchased[with real cash] or found in the world of Hope County) While enjoyable at first, most of these expeditions are nothing more than sneak into a location, steal package and escape which grew tiresome quickly. Expeditions can be played alone or in co-op, and I‚Äôd highly recommend the latter as it‚Äôs a far more enjoyable and rewarding experience. If there‚Äôs one downside to Far Cry New Dawn, it‚Äôs that it does feel a little on the short side when it comes to main campaign.  There are only around 20 main story missions and if that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre coming to the game for explicitly, the party could be over pretty quickly.  However, there really is a ton of other stuff to do in the game. There are 30 different outposts, 8 official side missions, 5 specialists to uncover, 10 treasure hunts to go on, and over a hundred challenges and collectibles to uncover. 
I‚Äôve seen a lot of people saying it should‚Äôve been a dlc, but i don‚Äôt see it like that , being a direct sequel to Far Cry 5, New Dawn ties up the loose ends of the story from the previous game and gives you a look at what happened to the world after the events of the last game.  It‚Äôs way too big to be considered an expansion and it‚Äôs too small to warrant a full-priced release. I recommend playing Far Cry 5, you obviously won‚Äôt know returning characters and there‚Äôs a major plot line that depends on you knowing what happened in Far Cry 5.  [/b]

[h1] {Duration} [/h1]
[b] Far Cry New Dawn will take between 15 and 30 hours to finish.The amount of time it'll take you to beat it depends on your playstyle and what you intend to do in the game. [/b]

[h1] {Age rating} [/h1]
[b] 14+

For the violence all blood can be turned off in settings, and for the bad language, most of it is on the radio, in songs, so as long as that is off its all good. [/b]

[h1] {My personal opinion} [/h1]
[b] Overall it‚Äôs a good game and I enjoyed playing it. I got the game for 11,24 euro, just to try it. I personally think it‚Äôs NOT worth the 45 dollars and you should buy at a sale. Playing it with a friend is really fun and I highly recommend it :) [/b]
